Eruvin



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If an alleyway is enclosed on three sides with courtyards opening into it from three sides, and the fourth side opens into a public domain, it is prohibited by rabbinic law to carry objects in it on Shabbat. However, carrying in an alleyway under those circumstances is permitted if a cross beam is placed horizontally over the entrance to the alleyway. The mishna teaches that if the cross beam spans the entrance to <b>an alleyway</b> at a <b>height above twenty cubits, one must diminish</b> the height of the cross beam so that it is less than twenty cubits. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He need not</b> diminish it, since the cross beam enables one to carry in the alleyway even at that height.
If the entrance to the alleyway is <b>wider than ten cubits, one must diminish</b> its width. <b>However, if</b> the entrance to the alleyway <b>has the form of a doorway,</b> i.e., two vertical posts on the two sides, and a horizontal beam spanning the space between them, <b>even if it is wider than ten cubits, he need not diminish</b> it, as it is then regarded as an entrance, rather than a breach, even if it is very wide.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there,</b> in tractate <i>Sukka</i>: <b>A <i>sukka</i> that is more than twenty cubits high is unfit, and Rabbi Yehuda deems it fit.</b> The <i>halakhot</i> are similar in substance but differ in formulation, and accordingly the Gemara asks: <b>What is the difference</b> that <b>with regard to a <i>sukka</i></b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that it is <b>unfit, whereas with regard to an alleyway, it teaches</b> the method of <b>rectification,</b> that one must diminish the height of the cross beam?
The Gemara answers: With regard to <b><i>sukka</i>,</b> since it is a mitzva <b>by Torah law,</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that it is <b>unfit,</b> as if it is not constructed in the proper manner, no mitzva is fulfilled. Whereas with regard to <b>an alleyway,</b> where the entire prohibition of carrying is only <b>by rabbinic law,</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> the method of <b>rectification,</b> as the cross beam comes only to rectify a rabbinic prohibition, but does not involve a mitzva by Torah law.
The Gemara suggests an alternative explanation: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>even</b> with regard to matters prohibited <b>by Torah law,</b> it would have been appropriate for the mishna to teach a method of <b>rectification. However,</b> with regard to <b><i>sukka</i>, whose matters are numerous, it categorically teaches</b> that it is <b>unfit.</b> Merely diminishing the height of a <i>sukka</i> is insufficient to render it fit; it must also satisfy requirements governing its size, its walls, and its roofing. Teaching the remedy for each disqualification would have required lengthy elaboration. With regard to <b>an alleyway,</b> however, <b>whose matters are not numerous,</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> the method of <b>rectification.</b> Once the height is diminished, it is permitted to carry in the alleyway.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: The Rabbis only derived</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that an opening more than twenty cubits high is not considered an entrance, <b>from the doorway of the Sanctuary,</b> the inner sanctum of the Temple. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda only derived</b> his opinion, that even an opening more than twenty cubits high is considered an entrance, <b>from the doorway of the Entrance Hall</b> leading into the Sanctuary.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The doorway of the Sanctuary is twenty cubits high and ten cubits wide, and that of the Entrance Hall is forty cubits high and twenty cubits wide.</b>
The Gemara explains the basis of this tannaitic dispute. <b>Both of them,</b> the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda, <b>interpreted the same verse homiletically:</b> “And he shall lay his hand upon the head of his offering <b>and slaughter it at the doorway of the Tent of Meeting,</b> and Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall sprinkle the blood on the altar round about” (Leviticus 3:2). <b>As the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>the sanctity of the Sanctuary is discrete and the sanctity of the Entrance Hall is discrete,</b> i.e., the Sanctuary and the Entrance Hall have distinct levels of sanctity. <b>And</b> since the essence of the Temple is the Sanctuary and not the Entrance Hall, and since the Sanctuary in the Temple parallels the Tent of Meeting in the Tabernacle, <b>when</b> the verse <b>speaks of the doorway of the Tent of Meeting, it is referring to</b> the doorway of <b>the Sanctuary.</b> Therefore, the term doorway applies to an opening similar to the doorway of the Sanctuary, which is twenty cubits high. There is no source indicating that an opening with larger dimensions is also considered a doorway.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>the Sanctuary and the Entrance Hall are one,</b> equal, <b>sanctity, and</b> therefore, <b>when it is written: “The doorway of the Tent of Meeting,” it is referring to both of them,</b> and accordingly, the term doorway applies to a larger entrance as well.
The Gemara suggests an alternative understanding of the dispute. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>even according to Rabbi Yehuda, the sanctity of the Sanctuary is discrete and the sanctity of the Entrance Hall is discrete. And here, this is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda:</b> By fusing together language from different verses, the result is <b>as it is written: To the doorway of the Entrance Hall of the House.</b> Therefore, even the doorway of the Entrance Hall is referred to in the Torah as a doorway, and the same is true of any opening with comparable dimensions.
<b>And the Rabbis</b> say: <b>Had</b> the verse <b>written: “To the doorway of the Entrance Hall,”</b> it would be interpreted <b>as you said.</b> However, <b>now that it is written: “To the doorway of the Entrance Hall of the House,”</b> it is to be understood: To the doorway of <b>the House that opens into the Entrance Hall,</b> i.e., the Sanctuary, and consequently, the definition of doorway is derived from the dimensions of the doorway of the Sanctuary.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with the very basis of this explanation: <b>But when this is written:</b> “The doorway of the Tent of Meeting,” <b>isn’t it written with regard to the Tabernacle</b> in the wilderness? How can the status in the permanent Sanctuary, i.e., the Temple in Jerusalem, be derived from matters stated with regard to the Tabernacle?
The Gemara answers: <b>We find that the Tabernacle is called Temple, and that the Temple is called Tabernacle;</b> therefore, the <i>halakhot</i> that govern one can be derived from the other. <b>As if you do not say so,</b> that the Tabernacle and the Temple are one with regard to their <i>halakhot</i>, <b>that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Peace-offerings that were slaughtered</b> in the Temple <b>prior to the opening of the doors of the Sanctuary</b> in the morning <b>are disqualified</b> would be difficult. That <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>as it is stated: “And he shall slaughter it at the doorway [<i>petaḥ</i>] of the Tent of Meeting,”</b> from which it is derived: <b>When</b> the doors to the Tent of Meeting <b>are open [<i>petuḥin</i>], and not when they are closed. But when this is written:</b> The doorway of the Tent of Meeting, <b>isn’t it written with regard to the Tabernacle? Rather,</b> for halakhic purposes, <b>we find the Temple called Tabernacle, and the Tabernacle called Temple.</b>
The Gemara questions its previous conclusion: <b>Granted, the Temple is called Tabernacle, as it is written: “And I will set My Tabernacle among you”</b> (Leviticus 26:11), and the reference is to the permanent Sanctuary, i.e., the Temple, as the verse is referring to that which will transpire after the Jewish people settle in their land. <b>However,</b> the fact that <b>the Tabernacle is called Temple, from where do we</b> derive it? The Gemara answers: <b>If you say</b> that it is derived <b>from that which is written: “And the Kehatites, the bearers of the Temple, set forward, that they may set up the Tabernacle before they came”</b> (Numbers 10:21),

Daf 2b

<b>that</b> instance of the term Temple <b>is</b> not written with regard to the Tabernacle; rather, it is <b>written with regard to the ark</b> and the other sacred objects in the Tabernacle, as the sons of Kehat carried only the sacred vessels and not the Tabernacle itself. <b>Rather,</b> it is derived <b>from here: “And let them make Me a Temple that I may dwell among them”</b> (Exodus 25:8), where the reference is to the Tabernacle.
The Gemara asks: <b>Both according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis and according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, let them derive</b> the maximum width of a doorway <b>from the doorway of the gate of the courtyard</b> of the Tabernacle. <b>As it is written: “The length of the courtyard shall be one hundred cubits and the breadth fifty everywhere, and the height five cubits”</b> (Exodus 27:18). <b>And it is written: “The hangings on one side of the gate shall be fifteen cubits;</b> their pillars three and their sockets three” (Exodus 27:14). <b>And it is written: “And for the other side of the court gate, on this hand and on that hand, were hangings of fifteen cubits;</b> their pillars three and their sockets three” (Exodus 38:15). If the hangings on both sides of the gate covered thirty of the courtyard’s total width of fifty cubits, apparently, the gate of the courtyard was twenty cubits wide and five cubits high. Therefore, <b>just as there,</b> with regard to the Tabernacle, an entrance <b>five</b> cubits high <b>by twenty</b> cubits <b>wide</b> is considered a doorway, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>eiruv</i>, an entrance <b>five</b> cubits high <b>by twenty</b> cubits <b>wide</b> should be considered a doorway.
The Gemara rejects this assertion: There is no proof from there, as that entrance <b>is called the doorway of the gate of the courtyard,</b> but <b>it is not called a doorway, unmodified.</b> Consequently, the dimensions of a doorway mentioned without qualification cannot be derived from that doorway.
The Gemara offers an alternative answer: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>when it is written: “The hangings on one side of the gate shall be fifteen cubits,”</b> it is referring <b>to the height</b> of the hangings. The width of the hangings, however, is not specified in the Torah at all, and therefore the width of the doorway of the gate of the courtyard is unknown.
The Gemara raises an objection: Could it be that the <b>height</b> of the hangings was fifteen cubits? <b>Isn’t it written</b> explicitly in the verse: <b>“And the height five cubits”?</b> The Gemara answers: The verse is stating that the height of the hangings was five cubits, measured <b>from the edge of the altar and above.</b> The altar itself was ten cubits high, while the hangings of the courtyard were fifteen cubits high, five cubits higher than the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rabbi Yehuda</b> actually <b>derive</b> his opinion <b>from the doorway of the Entrance Hall? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that if the entrance to an alleyway is <b>wider than ten cubits, one must diminish</b> its width? <b>And Rabbi Yehuda does not dispute</b> this ruling. Wasn’t the doorway of the Entrance Hall wider than ten cubits?
<b>Abaye said:</b> In fact, Rabbi Yehuda <b>disagrees</b> with the unattributed opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> <b>in a <i>baraita</i>. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the entrance to an alleyway is <b>wider than ten cubits, he must diminish</b> its width; <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> disagrees and <b>says: He need not diminish it.</b>
The Gemara asks further: If so, <b>let him disagree in the mishna.</b> Why is Rabbi Yehuda’s dispute cited only in the <i>baraita</i>, and not in the mishna? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda <b>disagrees</b> in the mishna <b>with regard to</b> an entrance’s <b>height, but the same applies to its width.</b> His statement: He need not reduce it, is referring both to the entrance’s height and to its width.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>And still,</b> is it possible that <b>Rabbi Yehuda derived</b> his opinion <b>from the doorway of the Entrance Hall? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a cross beam spanning the entrance to <b>an alleyway that is higher than twenty cubits, one must diminish</b> its height; <b>and Rabbi Yehuda deems it fit up to forty and fifty cubits. And</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>, <b>bar Kappara taught</b> the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda: It is fit <b>up to a hundred</b> cubits.
The Gemara clarifies its question: <b>Granted, according to bar Kappara,</b> the phrase: Up to a hundred, can be understood as <b>an exaggeration,</b> not as an exact number. All that Rabbi Yehuda meant to say is that it is permitted to carry in the alleyway even if the cross beam is significantly higher than twenty cubits. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda</b> in the name of Rav, <b>what exaggeration</b> is there? He certainly meant precisely what he said. <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>forty</b> cubits, <b>Rabbi Yehuda derived</b> it <b>from the doorway of the Entrance Hall. However,</b> with regard to <b>fifty</b> cubits, <b>from where does he derive</b> it? Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda did not derive the dimensions of an entrance from the doorway of the Entrance Hall. He derived them from a different source.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> It was <b>this <i>baraita</i></b> that <b>misled Rav</b> and led him to explain that Rabbi Yehuda derived the measurements of an entrance from the doorway of the Entrance Hall. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a cross beam spanning the entrance to <b>an alleyway that is higher than twenty cubits, higher than the doorway of the Sanctuary, one must diminish</b> its height. Rav <b>maintains: From</b> the fact <b>that the Rabbis derived</b> the dimensions of an entrance <b>from the doorway of the Sanctuary, Rabbi Yehuda</b> must have <b>derived</b> those dimensions <b>from the doorway of the Entrance Hall. But that is not so.</b> Rather, <b>Rabbi Yehuda derived</b> the dimensions of an entrance <b>from the entrance of kings,</b> whose regular practice was to erect their entrances exceedingly high and wide.
The Gemara asks: <b>And,</b> according to <b>the Rabbis, if they derived</b> their opinion <b>from the doorway of the Sanctuary, let them require doors</b> in order to render an alleyway fit for one to carry within it, <b>just as</b> there were doors in <b>the Sanctuary. Why</b> then <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna: With regard to the method of <b>rendering an alleyway fit</b> for carrying within it, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> Both <b>a side post</b> placed adjacent to one of the sides of the alleyway’s entrance <b>and a</b> cross <b>beam</b> over the entrance to the alleyway are required. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> Either <b>a side post or a</b> cross <b>beam</b> is sufficient. However, not even according to the more stringent opinion of Beit Shammai are doors required.
The Gemara answers: <b>The Sanctuary doors were made solely for</b> the purpose of <b>privacy,</b> but served no practical function. The doorway of the Sanctuary did not require doors to be considered an entrance. It was a full-fledged entrance even without them.
The Gemara raises another question: <b>But if so,</b> that the Rabbis derive their opinion from the entrance to the Sanctuary, <b>the form of a doorway,</b> i.e., two vertical posts on the two sides, with a horizontal cross beam spanning the space between them, <b>should not be effective</b> if the alleyway is more than ten cubits wide, <b>as the Sanctuary had the form of a doorway, and even so, it was</b> no more than <b>ten cubits wide. Why</b> then <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>If</b> the entrance <b>has the form of a doorway,</b> then <b>even if it is wider than ten cubits, he need not diminish</b> its width?
The Gemara answers: <b>As that is the reason only according to Rav,</b> who holds that the Rabbis derive their opinion from the doorway of the Sanctuary. <b>Didn’t Rav Yehuda teach</b> this mishna to <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav before Rav,</b> saying that if the entrance had the form of a doorway <b>he need not diminish it, and Rav said to him</b> to <b>teach</b> a different version: <b>He must diminish it.</b> Apparently, according to Rav himself, the form of a doorway does not render it permitted to carry within the alleyway if its entrance is wider than the doorway of the Sanctuary, and therefore the question about the form of a doorway poses no difficulty to his opinion.
The Gemara raises an additional difficulty: <b>However, if</b> that is <b>so,</b>

Daf 3a

<b>a</b> molded or protruding <b>cornice [<i>amaltera</i>]</b> crowning the entrance <b>should not be effective</b> in rendering an alleyway fit to carry within it if it is higher than twenty cubits, <b>as the Sanctuary had a cornice, and even so</b> it was <b>twenty cubits high,</b> and no more. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Over it were five oak cornices, one</b> protruding <b>above the other.</b>
The Gemara attempts to dismiss this difficulty: <b>And,</b> with regard to <b>that</b> mishna, <b>what is the refutation? Perhaps when that</b> mishna <b>with regard to cornices was taught, it was taught with regard to the Entrance Hall,</b> whose height was forty cubits, and not with regard to the Sanctuary.
The Gemara responds: <b>And what is the difficulty</b> with <b>that? Perhaps the design of the Sanctuary was like the design of the Entrance Hall.</b> Just as there were cornices in one doorway, there were cornices in the other.
The Gemara returns to its question with regard to a cornice: <b>Why</b> then <b>did Rabbi Ile’a say</b> that <b>Rav</b> himself <b>said:</b> If the <b>width</b> of a cross beam is <b>four</b> handbreadths, <b>even if it is not sturdy,</b> it renders the alleyway fit for carrying within it. <b>And if it has a cornice, even if it is higher than twenty cubits, one need not diminish</b> its height.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <b>cornice</b> was not actually stated by Rav, but rather it <b>is a <i>baraita</i>. Who,</b> in fact, <b>teaches</b> that <i>baraita</i>? Perhaps it is not an authoritative <i>baraita</i>, and Rav does not have to accept what it says.
<b>Abaye said: Isn’t it Ḥama, son of Rabba bar Avuh, who teaches it? And</b> therefore, even if the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <b>cornice will be a <i>baraita</i>, it</b> nevertheless <b>poses a difficulty to Rav.</b>
<b>Rav</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> Even if you <b>eliminate me</b> and my explanation <b>from</b> the discussion <b>here, don’t the</b> two <b><i>baraitot</i></b> themselves, the <i>baraita</i> that states that the Rabbis derive the dimensions of an entrance from the doorway of the Sanctuary and the <i>baraita</i> that states that in the case of a cornice, even if it is higher than twenty cubits, it need not be lowered, <b>contradict each other? Rather, what have you to say</b> to reconcile the contradiction? The matter is the subject of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>; so too, according to my</b> opinion, it <b>is</b> the subject of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Without Rav, the <i>baraitot</i> do not contradict each other,</b> as <b>according to the Rabbis, what is the reason</b> that <b>a</b> cross <b>beam</b> renders an alleyway fit for carrying? Because it serves <b>as a conspicuous marker</b> between the alleyway and the public domain. Ordinarily a cross beam more than twenty cubits high is not noticeable; however, a cornice attracts attention even at that height. <b>And that which is taught</b> in the other <i>baraita</i> with regard to the height of a beam at the entrance to an alleyway: <b>Greater than the entrance of the Sanctuary,</b> is <b>merely</b> a <b>mnemonic</b> device. No actual <i>halakhot</i> are derived from the entrance of the Sanctuary.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> that the explanation of <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak works out well if he does not hold this</b> opinion <b>of Rabba; however, if he holds this</b> opinion <b>of Rabba,</b> it is difficult. As <b>Rabba said</b> with regard to the fitness of a <i>sukka</i> whose roofing is higher than twenty cubits that <b>it is written: “In order that your generations should know that I made</b> the children of Israel <b>dwell in booths</b> when I brought them out of the land of Egypt; I am the Lord your God” (Leviticus 23:43). When the roofing of a <i>sukka</i> is <b>up to twenty cubits</b> high, <b>a person is aware that he is dwelling in a <i>sukka</i>;</b> however, when the roofing of the <i>sukka</i> is <b>above twenty cubits, a person is not aware</b> that he is dwelling in a <i>sukka</i>, <b>because the eye does not discern</b> the <i>sukka</i> roofing. One does not usually raise his head to look that high, and consequently, he sees the walls and does not notice the defining feature of the <i>sukka</i>, its roofing.
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>Apparently, with regard to <i>sukka</i> as well,</b> the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda <b>disagree</b> whether or not an item more than twenty cubits high is <b>conspicuous.</b> According to Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, <b>why do I</b> need them to <b>disagree</b> about the same point <b>in two cases,</b> that of <i>sukka</i> and that of an alleyway? That the dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda with regard to <i>sukka</i> revolves around this issue indicates that their dispute with regard to an alleyway revolves around a different point, as asserted by Rav.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to teach both disputes, <b>as had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> only <b>with regard to <i>sukka</i>,</b> one might have thought that only <b>in this</b> case does <b>Rabbi Yehuda say</b> that an object is conspicuous even above twenty cubits; <b>since</b> a <i>sukka</i> <b>is designed for</b> extended <b>dwelling, the eye</b> undoubtedly <b>discerns</b> the roofing at some point. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>an alleyway,</b> which <b>is designed for walking, say</b> that <b>he concedes to</b> the <b>Rabbis</b> that a person walking in an alleyway does not notice objects at so significant a height. <b>And had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> case of an alleyway, one might have thought that only <b>in that</b> case do <b>the Rabbis say</b> that people do not notice objects at so significant a height; <b>however, in that</b> case of <i>sukka</i>, <b>say</b> that <b>they concede to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> for the above-stated reason. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to teach both disputes.
The Gemara seeks to arrive at a precise definition of <i>amaltera</i>, translated above as cornice. <b>What</b> is <b>an <i>amaltera</i>? Rav Ḥama, son of Rabba bar Avuh, said:</b> It refers to decorative wood carvings in the shape of <b>birds’ nests. When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, it is referring to <b>cedar poles.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>The one who said</b> that <i>amaltera</i> refers to <b>cedar poles</b> would <b>all the more so</b> permit use of carvings of <b>birds’ nests,</b> as a cross beam engraved with images attracts attention and is noticeable even at a great height. However, <b>the one who said</b> that <i>amaltera</i> refers to carvings of <b>birds’ nests</b> would say that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a cornice applies only to them, <b>but not to cedar poles.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the opinion of <b>the one who said cedar poles. What is</b> the <b>reason</b> for his opinion? He holds that <b>since its length is great,</b> a cedar pole attracts attention. <b>But isn’t the length of a <i>sukka</i> great</b> as well, <b>and</b> nevertheless, <b>the Rabbis say that</b> a <i>sukka</i> higher than twenty cubits is <b>not</b> fit?
<b>Rather,</b> the reason is as follows: <b>Since</b> a cedar pole <b>is</b> of <b>significant</b> value, <b>it</b> generates <b>publicity.</b> People passing through an alleyway stop and stare at a cross beam of that kind, even when it is higher than twenty cubits, leading others to do so as well.
The Gemara raises a question: If <b>part of the</b> cross <b>beam</b> of an alleyway is <b>within twenty</b> cubits of the ground, <b>and part of the</b> cross <b>beam</b> is <b>above twenty</b> cubits, and similarly, if <b>part of the roofing</b> of a <i>sukka</i> is <b>within twenty</b> cubits, <b>and part of the roofing</b> is <b>above twenty</b> cubits, what is its legal status? <b>Rabba said: In</b> the case of <b>an alleyway, it is fit; in</b> the case of <b>a <i>sukka</i>, it is unfit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different in</b> the case of <b>an alleyway</b> that the ruling is <b>that it is fit?</b> It is because <b>we say: Thin</b> the part of the cross beam that is beyond twenty cubits, i.e., consider it as if it were not there. If so, in the case of <b><i>sukka</i> too, say: Thin</b> the roofing that is beyond twenty cubits.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you thin</b> the roofing beyond twenty cubits, <b>it will result in</b> a <i>sukka</i> <b>whose sun is more than its shade.</b> Were the section of the roofing above twenty cubits removed, the roofing that remained would not provide sufficient shade for the <i>sukka</i>.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a cross beam, <b>if you thin</b> the section above twenty cubits, <b>it would become a</b> weak and unstable cross <b>beam that is removed by the wind,</b> which does not render the alleyway fit for carrying within it. <b>Rather, perforce,</b> the status of the remaining parts of those cross beams <b>becomes like</b> that of <b>metal skewers [<i>shefudin</i>],</b> which, although they are thin, are not removed by the wind. <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a <i>sukka</i>, <b>perforce,</b> even after the upper roofing is removed, the status of the <i>sukka</i> <b>becomes like</b> that of a <i>sukka</i> <b>whose shade is more than its sun.</b>
The Gemara explains Rabba’s distinction differently. <b>Rava from Parzakya said: A <i>sukka</i>, which is</b> generally erected <b>for an individual,</b> if the portion of the roofing below twenty were removed and only the portion above twenty remained, <b>he</b> would <b>not be reminded</b> to lower the remaining roofing and would dwell in a <i>sukka</i> that is unfit. <b>An alleyway,</b> in contrast, <b>which is</b> used by <b>many</b> people, if the section of the cross beam below twenty cubits were removed, <b>they</b> would <b>remind each other</b> to remedy the situation.
<b>Ravina said</b> a different explanation: <b>With regard to a <i>sukka</i>,</b> since its mitzva <b>is by Torah law, the Sages were stringent.</b> However, <b>with regard to an alleyway,</b> since the entire requirement to place a cross beam across the entrance in order to permit carrying in an alleyway <b>is</b> only <b>by rabbinic law, the Sages were not stringent.</b>
The Gemara cites a different version of Rabba’s distinction: <b>Rav Adda bar Mattana taught this <i>halakha</i> of Rabba</b> in the <b>opposite</b> manner. <b>Rabba said: In</b> the case of <b>an alleyway, it is unfit; in</b> the case of <b>a <i>sukka</i>, it is fit.</b> As a result, all the previous explanations must be reversed.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different in</b> the case of <b>a <i>sukka</i></b> that <b>it is fit?</b> Because <b>we say: Thin</b> the roofing that is beyond twenty cubits. If so, then <b>in</b> the case of <b>a</b> cross <b>beam as well, let us say: Thin</b> the part of the cross beam that is beyond twenty cubits.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you thin</b> the part beyond twenty cubits, <b>it will become a</b> weak and unstable cross <b>beam that moves in the wind.</b> The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a <i>sukka</i>, <b>if you thin</b> the upper section of the roofing, <b>it would become</b> a <i>sukka</i> <b>whose sun is more than its shade. Rather, perforce,</b> even after the upper roofing is removed, the status of the <i>sukka</i> <b>becomes like</b> that of a <i>sukka</i> <b>whose shade is more than its sun; here too,</b> in the case of an alleyway, <b>perforce,</b> the status of the remaining parts of those cross beams <b>becomes like</b> that of <b>metal skewers,</b> which, although they are thin, do not move in the wind.
The Gemara offers a different explanation of Rabba’s distinction: <b>Rava from Parzakya said:</b> In the case of <b>a <i>sukka</i>, which is</b> generally erected <b>for an individual, he casts</b> responsibility <b>upon himself and is reminded</b> to make certain that the roofing is fit. In the case of <b>an alleyway, which is</b> used by <b>many</b> people, <b>they</b> are likely to <b>rely upon each other and are not reminded</b> to check the height of the cross beam. <b>As people say: A pot</b> belonging to <b>partners is neither hot nor cold.</b> When responsibility falls upon more than one person, each relies on the other, and ultimately the task is not completed.
<b>Ravina</b> offered a different explanation and <b>said:</b> The mitzva of <b><i>sukka</i>,</b> which <b>is by Torah law, does not require reinforcement</b> by the Sages, and consequently, they were lenient in that case. However, since the entire requirement to place a cross beam across the entrance to <b>an alleyway is by rabbinic law,</b> it <b>requires reinforcement,</b> and therefore the Sages were stringent.
Since there are two contradictory versions of Rabba’s statement, the Gemara inquires: <b>What</b> practical conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about this</b> problem, if part of the roofing of the <i>sukka</i> or the cross beam was above twenty cubits? <b>Rabba bar Rav Ulla said:</b> In that case, both <b>this,</b> an alleyway, <b>and that,</b> a <i>sukka</i>, <b>are unfit. Rava said:</b> Both <b>this and that are fit,</b>

Daf 3b

as that which <b>we learned</b> in the mishna, with regard to the unfitness of a <i>sukka</i> higher than twenty cubits, is referring to the interior <b>space of the <i>sukka</i>;</b> and that which <b>we learned</b> in the mishna, that a cross beam spanning an alleyway that is more than twenty cubits must be lowered, is referring to the <b>space</b> at the entrance <b>of the alleyway</b> beneath the cross beam.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Rava:</b> A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught that supports your</b> opinion: If the cross beam spanning the entrance of <b>an alleyway is higher than twenty cubits</b> off the ground, <b>greater than the entrance of the Sanctuary, one must diminish its</b> height. <b>And the space of the</b> entrance of the <b>Sanctuary itself was twenty</b> cubits high, and its roof was higher than twenty cubits. Apparently, the twenty cubits mentioned with regard to a <i>sukka</i> and an alleyway refers to the space beneath the roofing and the cross beam.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Rav Ashi raised an objection to Rav Pappa</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>How</b> precisely <b>would he do it? He places the</b> cross <b>beam from the edge of twenty</b> cubits <b>and below.</b> Apparently, the entire cross beam must be within twenty cubits of the ground, and if any part of it rises above twenty it is unfit.
Rav Pappa replied: Emend the <i>Tosefta</i> and <b>say:</b> From the edge of twenty cubits <b>and above.</b> Rav Shimi retorted: <b>But isn’t it taught:</b> And <b>below?</b> What justification is there to completely reverse the meaning of the <i>Tosefta</i>?
Rava explained that there is no need to emend the language of the <i>baraita</i>, but merely to reinterpret it. The <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching us the following:</b> The <i>halakha</i> <b>below is like</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>above. Just as above,</b> with regard to the maximum height of the cross beam, it is the <b>space</b> beneath the cross beam that may not be more than <b>twenty</b> cubits, <b>so</b> too <b>below,</b> with regard to the minimum height of the cross beam, it is the <b>space</b> beneath the cross beam that may not be less than <b>ten</b> handbreadths. However, a cross beam placed within ten handbreadths of the ground is unfit and does not render it permitted to carry within the alleyway.
The Gemara considers the measure of the cubit mentioned in the mishna and elsewhere. <b>Abaye said in the name of Rav Naḥman: The cubit</b> mentioned with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of <i>sukka</i> and the cubit</b> mentioned in connection with the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of an alleyway</b> is <b>a</b> small <b>cubit</b> consisting <b>of five</b> handbreadths. In contrast, <b>the cubit of</b> a forbidden mixture of <b>diverse kinds</b> of seeds is <b>a</b> large <b>cubit</b> consisting <b>of six</b> handbreadths. Apparently, Rav Naḥman rules stringently in all cases.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>The cubit of an alleyway is a cubit</b> consisting <b>of five</b> handbreadths. <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> does this ruling apply? It applies <b>to</b> the issue of the height of the cross beam spanning an alleyway that may not be more than twenty cubits high, <b>and to the breach of an alleyway</b> that may not be more than ten cubits wide.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>But isn’t there</b> also the issue of <b>the</b> minimal <b>length of an alleyway?</b> For carrying in an alleyway to be rendered permissible by means of a side post or a cross beam, it must be at least <b>four cubits</b> long. In that case, measuring the alleyway with small cubits will lead <b>to a leniency.</b>
The Gemara resolves this difficulty: Rav Naḥman holds <b>in accordance with the one who said</b> that the length of an alleyway need only be <b>four handbreadths.</b> However, a cubit mentioned in the context of an alleyway is always a small cubit, which is a stringency.
The Gemara proposes an alternative solution: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that actually Rav Naḥman holds in accordance with the opinion that the length of an alleyway must be <b>four cubits,</b> and in that case, the alleyway is measured with large cubits of six handbreadths as a stringency. When he is saying that the cubit of an alleyway is a cubit of five handbreadths, <b>he is speaking of most,</b> but not all, <b>cubits</b> mentioned in the context of an alleyway.
Rav Naḥman said that <b>the cubit of a <i>sukka</i></b> is <b>a</b> small <b>cubit</b> consisting <b>of five</b> handbreadths. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> does this ruling apply? It applies <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing <b>its height,</b> i.e., that a <i>sukka</i> may not be more than twenty cubits high, <b>and to the</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>a curved wall.</b> A <i>sukka</i> is considered valid if there are up to four cubits of invalid roofing, provided that this roofing is adjacent to one of the walls of the <i>sukka</i>. In that case, the invalid roofing is considered an extension of the wall, i.e., the wall is considered to be curved, and consequently, the entire <i>sukka</i> is valid. With regard to both <i>halakhot</i>, the ruling is stringent and distance is measured with small cubits.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> also the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the</b> minimal <b>length of a <i>sukka</i>,</b> which must be at least <b>four cubits</b> long? If it is measured with small cubits, <b>that</b> will lead <b>to a leniency. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I say, any <i>sukka</i> that does not</b> have <b>in it</b> an area of at least <b>four cubits by four cubits is invalid.</b>
The Gemara resolves this difficulty: Rav Naḥman holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say:</b> A <i>sukka</i> is valid <b>even if it holds only one’s head, most of his</b> body, <b>and his table.</b>
The Gemara suggests another solution: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> Rav Naḥman’s statement holds true even if <b>it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi that a <i>sukka</i> must be at least four cubits long. Indeed, the <i>sukka</i> is measured with large cubits consisting of six handbreadths, which is a stringency. <b>And</b> when he says that the cubit of a <i>sukka</i> is a cubit of five handbreadths, <b>he is speaking of most,</b> but not all, <b>cubits</b> mentioned with regard to <i>sukka</i>.
The Gemara continues: As stated above, Rav Naḥman said that <b>the cubit of a</b> forbidden mixture of <b>diverse kinds</b> of seeds <b>is a cubit</b> consisting <b>of six handbreadths.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> does this ruling apply? It applies <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a clearing in a vineyard and to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the perimeter of a vineyard.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Kilayim</i>: With regard to <b>a clearing in a vineyard, Beit Shammai say:</b> Its measure is <b>twenty-four cubits, and Beit Hillel say: Sixteen cubits.</b> With regard to <b>the perimeter of a vineyard, Beit Shammai say: Sixteen cubits, and Beit Hillel say: Twelve cubits.</b>
The mishna explains: <b>What is a clearing in a vineyard?</b> It is referring to <b>a vineyard whose middle</b> section <b>was laid bare</b> of vines. If <b>there are not sixteen cubits</b> across in the clearing, <b>one may not bring</b> foreign <b>seeds</b> and sow them <b>there,</b> due to the Torah prohibition against sowing other crops in a vineyard (Deuteronomy 22:9). If <b>there were sixteen cubits</b> across in the clearing, <b>one provides</b> the vineyard with <b>its</b> requisite <b>work area,</b> i.e., four cubits along either side of the vines are left unsown to facilitate cultivation of the vines, <b>and he sows the rest</b> of the cleared area with foreign crops.
The mishna continues: <b>What is the perimeter of a vineyard?</b> It is the vacant area <b>between the vineyard and the fence</b> surrounding it. If <b>there are not twelve cubits</b> in that area, <b>one may not bring</b> foreign <b>seeds</b> and sow them <b>there.</b> If <b>there were twelve cubits</b> in that area, <b>he provides</b> the vineyard, with <b>its</b> requisite <b>work area,</b> four cubits, <b>and he sows the rest.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t there</b> also the <i>halakha</i> of vines that planted <b>consecutively, within four cubits</b> of each other, with regard to <b>which</b> measuring the distance with large cubits would lead <b>to a leniency? As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a vineyard that was planted</b> in consecutive rows <b>with less than four cubits</b> between them, <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Since the rows are planted so closely together, <b>it is not</b> considered <b>a vineyard,</b> and if one plants other crops there he is not liable. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> It is <b>a vineyard, and one regards the middle</b> vines, those planted between two appropriately spaced rows, <b>as if they are not</b> there. One who plants other crops there is indeed liable. According to Rabbi Shimon’s opinion, measuring the distance between the rows with large cubits leads to leniency.
The Gemara resolves the difficulty: Rav Naḥman made his statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that a densely planted vineyard <b>is a vineyard. And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> Rav Naḥman’s statement holds true even if <b>it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> that a densely planted vineyard is not a vineyard, and the distance between the rows is measured with small cubits consisting of five handbreadths as a stringency. When he says that the cubit of diverse kinds of seeds is a cubit consisting of six handbreadths, <b>he is speaking of most,</b> but not all, <b>cubits</b> mentioned with regard to a forbidden mixture of diverse kinds of seeds.
The above was based on the ruling of Rav Naḥman according to Abaye. <b>But Rava said in the name of Rav Naḥman: All cubits</b> mentioned in measurements by the Sages consisted of a large <b>cubit of six</b> handbreadths. <b>However, these,</b> the cubits mentioned with regard to diverse kinds of seeds, <b>are</b> measured with <b>expansive</b> handbreadths, with the fingers spread apart, <b>whereas those,</b> the cubits mentioned with regard to an alleyway and a <i>sukka</i>, <b>are</b> measured with <b>compressed</b> handbreadths, with the fingers held together.
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All cubits that were mentioned by the Sages are cubits of six</b> handbreadths, <b>provided</b>

Daf 4a

<b>that they are not precisely</b> a cubit. <b>Granted, according to Rava,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>So that these,</b> the cubits of diverse kinds of seeds, <b>should be</b> measured with <b>expansive</b> handbreadths, <b>and those,</b> the cubits of <i>sukka</i>, should be measured with <b>depressed</b> handbreadths. <b>However, according to Abaye,</b> it is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Abaye</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> Emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say: The cubit of diverse kinds</b> of seeds mentioned by the Sages <b>is</b> measured <b>with a cubit of six</b> handbreadths, not the other cubits.
The Gemara raises a difficulty. <b>However, from</b> the fact <b>that it is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: All the cubits that the Sages mentioned with regard to diverse kinds</b> of seeds are measured <b>with cubits of six</b> handbreadths, <b>provided that they are not</b> measured with <b>exact</b> handbreadths? This proves <b>by inference</b> that <b>the</b> anonymous <b>first <i>tanna</i> is speaking of all cubits,</b> and not only those in the case of diverse kinds of seeds.
The Gemara answers that <b>Abaye</b> could have <b>said to you: Isn’t there Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who holds in accordance with my</b> opinion? <b>I stated</b> my opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>According to Abaye,</b> the issue of large and small cubits <b>is certainly</b> subject to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as his ruling can only be in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. <b>According to Rava,</b> however, <b>must it be said</b> that <b>this is</b> subject to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>?</b>
The Gemara answers: This is not necessarily the case, as <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> does not dispute the basic teaching of the anonymous first <i>tanna</i> that all the cubits mentioned by the Sages are cubits of six handbreadths. Rather, he <b>came to teach us this: One</b> should <b>not reduce the cubit of diverse kinds</b> of seeds, i.e., one should not measure it with depressed handbreadths.
The Gemara raises an objection. <b>And</b> if that is the case, <b>let him say: One must not reduce the cubit of diverse kinds</b> of seeds. <b>What does</b> the phrase: <b>A cubit</b> consisting <b>of six</b> handbreadths come <b>to exclude? Does it not</b> come <b>to exclude the cubit of a <i>sukka</i> and the cubit of an alleyway,</b> which are measured with cubits of five handbreadths?
The Gemara rejects this argument. <b>No,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s formulation comes <b>to exclude the cubit of the base</b> of the altar, which is the bottom level of the altar, one cubit high with a ledge one cubit wide, <b>and the cubit of the surrounding ledge</b> of the altar, which is five cubits above the base, six cubits above the ground, and one cubit wide. Everyone agrees that those cubits are small cubits of five handbreadths.
<b>As it is written: “And these are the measures of the altar by cubits; the cubit is a cubit and a handbreadth, the bottom shall be a cubit, and the breadth a cubit, and its border by its edge round about shall be a span: And this shall be the higher part of the altar”</b> (Ezekiel 43:13). And the Sages explained this verse as follows: <b>“The bottom shall be a cubit,” this is the base</b> of the altar; <b>“and the breadth a cubit,” this is the surrounding ledge</b> of the altar; <b>“and its border by its edge round about,” these are the horns</b> of the altar, i.e., extensions of the corners of the altar; <b>“and this shall be the higher part of the altar,”</b> this refers to <b>the golden altar</b> that stood inside the Sanctuary and was also measured by small cubits.
Since the Gemara discussed measurements, it proceeds to cite that which <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: The measures</b> relating to mitzvot in the Torah, and the <i>halakhot</i> governing <b>interpositions</b> that invalidate ritual immersions, and the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>partitions are</b> all <b><i>halakhot</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b> These <i>halakhot</i> have no basis in the Written Torah, but according to tradition they were orally transmitted by God to Moses together with the Written Torah.
The Gemara questions this assertion: Are <b>measures</b> a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai? <b>They are</b> written <b>in the Torah, as it is written: “A land of wheat, and barley,</b> and vines, and figs, and pomegranates, a land of olive oil and honey” (Deuteronomy 8:8), <b>and Rav Ḥanan said: This entire verse was stated for</b> the purpose of teaching <b>measures</b> with regard to different <i>halakhot</i> in the Torah.
<b>Wheat</b> was mentioned as the basis for calculating the time required for one to become ritually impure when entering a house afflicted with leprosy, <b>as that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One who enters a house afflicted with leprosy</b> of the house (see Leviticus 14), <b>and his clothes</b> are draped <b>over his shoulders, and his sandals and his rings are in his hands,</b> both <b>he and they,</b> the clothes, sandals, and rings, <b>immediately</b> become <b>ritually impure.</b> However, if <b>he was dressed in his clothes, and his sandals were on his feet, and his rings were on his fingers, he immediately</b> becomes <b>ritually impure, but they,</b> the clothes, sandals, and rings, <b>remain pure until he stays</b> in the house <b>long enough to eat half a loaf</b> of bread. This calculation is based on <b>wheat bread,</b> which takes less time to eat, <b>and not</b> on <b>barley bread,</b> and it relates to one who is <b>reclining and eating</b> it together <b>with relish,</b> which hastens the eating. This is a Torah measurement connected specifically to wheat.
<b>Barley</b> is also used as a basis for measurements, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A bone</b> from a corpse the size <b>of a</b> grain of <b>barley imparts</b> ritual <b>impurity through contact and by being carried,</b> but <b>it does not impart impurity</b> by means <b>of a tent,</b> i.e., if the bone was inside a house, it does not render all the articles in the house ritually impure.
The halakhic measure determined by a <b>vine is the quantity of a quarter-<i>log</i> of wine for a nazirite.</b> A nazirite, who is prohibited to drink wine, is liable to be flogged if he drinks that measure.

Daf 4b

<b>Fig</b> alludes to the measure of <b>a dried fig-bulk with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>carrying out</b> on <b>Shabbat.</b> One is liable for carrying food fit for human consumption on Shabbat, provided that he carries a dried fig-bulk of that food.
<b>Pomegranate</b> teaches the measure, <b>as that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All</b> ritually impure wooden <b>vessels belonging to</b> ordinary <b>homeowners</b> become pure through being broken, as broken vessels cannot contract or maintain ritual impurity, and they are considered broken if they have holes <b>the size of pomegranates.</b>
The Sages interpreted: <b>A land of olive oil and honey,</b> as: <b>A land, all of whose measures are olive-bulks.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that it is a land <b>all of whose measures</b> are olives-bulks? <b>Yet aren’t there those</b> measures <b>that we</b> just <b>mentioned</b> above, which are not olive-bulks? <b>Rather, say: A land, most of whose measures are olive-bulks,</b> as most measures, e.g., those relating to forbidden foods and to impurity imparted by a corpse in a tent and by contact with an animal carcass, are olive-bulks.
<b>Honey,</b> i.e., dates from which date honey is extracted, also determines a measure, as with regard <b>to</b> eating on <b>Yom Kippur,</b> one is liable only if he eats <b>a large date-bulk</b> of food. Clearly, the measurements pertaining to mitzvot are explicitly written in the Torah and were not transmitted to Moses from Sinai.
The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>And can you hold</b> that all these <b>measures are</b> explicitly <b>written</b> in the Torah with regard to each of the <i>halakhot</i> mentioned above? <b>Rather, they are <i>halakhot</i></b> that were transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and the Sages based them on verses</b> in the Torah.
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said above that Rav said that the laws governing <b>interpositions</b> that invalidate ritual immersion are <i>halakhot</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai. The Gemara challenges this assertion: These, too, <b>are</b> written <b>in the Torah, as it is written: “And he shall bathe all his flesh in the water”</b> (Leviticus 15:16), and the Sages derived <b>that nothing should intervene between his flesh and the water.</b> The definite article in the phrase <b>“in the water”</b> indicates that this bathing is performed in water mentioned elsewhere, i.e., specifically <b>in the water of a ritual bath,</b> and not in just any water. And the phrase <b>“all his flesh”</b> indicates that it must be in <b>water into which all of his body can enter,</b> i.e., in which a person can immerse his entire body at once. <b>And how much</b> water <b>is that?</b> It is <b>a cubit by a cubit by the height of three cubits. And the Sages calculated</b> the volume of a ritual bath of this size and determined that <b>the waters of a ritual bath</b> measure <b>forty <i>se’a</i>.</b> As this is derived from the Written Torah, what need is there for a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai?
The Gemara answers: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai <b>is needed</b> with regard <b>to his hair,</b> that it too must be accessible to the water without interposition. <b>And this is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna, as Rabba bar Rav Huna said: A single hair tied</b> in a knot <b>constitutes an interposition</b> and invalidates the immersion. <b>Three</b> hairs tied together in a knot <b>do not constitute an interposition,</b> because three hairs cannot be tied so tightly that water cannot penetrate them. With regard to <b>two</b> hairs tied together in a knot, <b>I do not know</b> the <i>halakha</i>. This <i>halakha</i> with regard to hair is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his hair is also</b> written <b>in the Torah, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And he shall bathe all [<i>et kol</i>] his flesh.</b> The superfluous word <i>et</i> comes to amplify and include <b>that which is subordinate to his flesh, and that is hair.</b>
The Gemara answers: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai <b>comes</b> to teach the details of interpositions on the body <b>with regard to its majority and its minority, and with regard to one who is particular and one who is not particular, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak.</b>
<b>As Rabbi Yitzḥak said: By Torah law,</b> if there is an interposition between a person and the water, and it covers <b>the majority</b> of <b>his</b> body, <b>and he is particular</b> and wants the interposing substance removed, only then <b>is it</b> considered <b>an interposition</b> that invalidates immersion in a ritual bath. <b>However, if he is not particular about</b> that substance, <b>it is not</b> considered <b>an interposition.</b> The Sages, however, <b>issued a decree</b> prohibiting substances covering <b>the majority</b> of <b>one’s</b> body with regard to which <b>he is not particular, due to</b> substances covering <b>the majority</b> of <b>one’s</b> body with regard to which <b>he is particular. And,</b> they issued a decree prohibiting substances covering <b>the minority</b> of <b>his</b> body with regard to which <b>one is particular, due to</b> substances covering <b>the majority</b> of <b>his</b> body with regard to which <b>one is particular.</b>
The Gemara raises a question: Then <b>let us also issue a decree</b> deeming substances covering <b>the minority</b> of <b>one’s</b> body with regard to which <b>he is not particular</b> an interposition <b>due to</b> substances covering <b>the minority</b> of <b>his</b> body with regard to which <b>one is particular, or alternatively, due to</b> substances covering <b>the majority</b> of <b>his</b> body with regard to which <b>he is not particular.</b>
The Gemara answers: We do not issue that decree, because the <i>halakha</i> that deems both an interposition covering the minority of his body about which one is particular and an interposition covering the majority of his body about which one is not particular <b>an interposition is itself a decree. Shall we</b> then <b>rise up and issue</b> one <b>decree to</b> prevent violation of another <b>decree?</b> In any case, these details with regard to interpositions are neither written nor alluded to in the Torah; rather, they are <i>halakhot</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai.
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said that Rav said that the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>partitions</b> were transmitted to Moses from Sinai. The Gemara challenges this assertion as well: <b>They are</b> written <b>in the Torah,</b> as the fundamental principle that a partition ten handbreadths high establishes a separate domain is derived from the Torah.
<b>As the Master said:</b> The Holy <b>Ark</b> in the Tabernacle was <b>nine</b> handbreadths high, as the verse states that its height was a cubit and a half. A cubit contains six handbreadths, so its height totaled nine handbreadths. <b>And the cover</b> atop the Ark was one <b>handbreadth, which</b> total <b>ten.</b> There is a tradition that the Divine Presence does not descend into the domain of this world, which is derived from the verse that states that the Divine Presence would reveal itself from above the cover of the Ark. Apparently, a partition of ten handbreadths creates a separate domain.
The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai <b>is necessary only</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said: The cubit</b> mentioned with regard to <b>the building</b> of the Tabernacle and the Temple <b>was a</b> large <b>cubit of six</b> handbreadths, whereas <b>the cubit</b> mentioned with regard to the sacred <b>vessels was a cubit of five</b> handbreadths. According to this opinion, the Ark, which was a cubit and a half, and its cover, which was a handbreadth, measured eight and a half handbreadths. Therefore, nothing can be derived with regard to a partition of ten handbreadths.
The Gemara poses a question. <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: All the cubits were medium</b> ones, regular cubits of six handbreadths; <b>what can be said?</b> Apparently, according to his opinion, the laws governing partitions are explicitly stated in the Torah.
The Gemara answers: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a partition of ten handbreadths is indeed written in the Torah. However, the <b><i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai <b>comes</b> to teach other <i>halakhot</i> concerning partitions, e.g., the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>extending</b> [<b><i>gode</i>],</b> according to which an existing partition is extended upward or downward to complete the requisite measure; <b>and</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>joining [<i>lavud</i>],</b> according to which two solid surfaces are joined if they are separated by a gap of less than three handbreadths; <b>and</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the curved wall</b> of a <i>sukka</i>. A <i>sukka</i> is valid even if there are up to four cubits of invalid roofing, provided that this roofing is adjacent to one of the walls of the <i>sukka</i>. In that case, the invalid roofing is considered a bent extension of the wall. These concepts are certainly not written in the Torah.
The Gemara returns to the laws of alleyways: If the cross beam spanning the entrance to an alleyway <b>was higher than twenty cubits</b> from the ground <b>and one comes to diminish its</b> height, <b>how much must he diminish</b> it? The Gemara is surprised by the question: <b>How much must he diminish</b> it? <b>The amount that he needs</b> in order to render its height less than twenty cubits.
<b>Rather,</b> the space between the cross beam and the ground must, of course, be reduced to twenty cubits. However, when one raises the alleyway, <b>how much</b> must <b>the width</b> of the raised section be in order to render the alleyway fit for carrying within it? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> One <b>handbreadth. Abaye said: Four</b> handbreadths.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that these <i>amora’im</i> <b>disagree about this: The one who said</b> one <b>handbreadth holds</b> that <b>one is permitted to utilize</b> the area <b>beneath the</b> cross <b>beam</b> spanning the entrance to the alleyway, as he maintains that the cross beam serves as a partition, and the alleyway is considered as if it were sealed by a partition descending from the outer edge of the cross beam that faces the public domain. Since the area beneath the cross beam is part of the alleyway and is less than twenty cubits, there is a conspicuous demarcation for one standing in the alleyway.

Daf 5a

<b>And the one who said four</b> handbreadths <b>holds</b> that the alleyway is considered as if it were sealed from the inside edge of the cross beam, and consequently it is prohibited <b>to utilize</b> the area <b>beneath the</b> cross <b>beam.</b> As the area beneath the cross beam is not part of the alleyway, a significant demarcation, i.e., one of four handbreadths, is required within the alleyway itself.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No, everyone agrees that it is permitted to utilize</b> the area <b>beneath the</b> cross <b>beam, and they disagree with regard to this:</b> This <b>Master,</b> Rav Yosef, <b>holds</b> that <b>a</b> cross <b>beam</b> functions in an alleyway <b>as a conspicuous marker</b> that demarcates the alleyway from the public domain, and consequently a mere handbreadth is sufficient, as even a handbreadth is sufficiently conspicuous. <b>And</b> this <b>Master,</b> Abaye, <b>holds</b> that <b>a</b> cross <b>beam</b> serves <b>as a partition,</b> and a partition is not effective for an area of less than four handbreadths. The principle that an outer edge descends and seals the alleyway does not apply if the beam is higher than twenty cubits. In order for it to be considered a partition, there must be at least four handbreadths that are less than twenty cubits beneath the cross beam.
The Gemara proposes an alternative explanation: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>a</b> cross <b>beam</b> serves <b>as a conspicuous marker, and here they disagree with regard to</b> the relationship between <b>a conspicuous marker below,</b> i.e., the raised area of the alleyway, <b>and a conspicuous marker above,</b> i.e., the cross beam. This <b>Master,</b> Rav Yosef, <b>holds</b> that <b>we say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that governs <b>the conspicuous marker below is like</b> the <i>halakha</i> that applies to <b>the conspicuous marker above,</b> and one handbreadth suffices. <b>And</b> this <b>Master,</b> Abaye, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that governs <b>the conspicuous marker below is like</b> the <i>halakha</i> that applies to <b>the conspicuous marker above.</b> The lower sign must be more prominent and extend four handbreadths.
The Gemara proposes yet another explanation of the amoraic dispute: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>we say</b> that fundamentally, the <i>halakha</i> that governs <b>the conspicuous marker below is like</b> the <i>halakha</i> that applies to the <b>conspicuous marker above,</b> and even a handbreadth should suffice. <b>But here they disagree whether</b> the Sages <b>decreed</b> that four handbreadths are necessary, <b>lest</b> people treading upon it will erode and <b>diminish</b> the raised area. Rav Yosef is not concerned that it will be diminished and therefore holds that a raised area of a handbreadth is sufficient, whereas Abaye is concerned that the raised area of a handbreadth will erode to less than a handbreadth, rendering it inconspicuous, and the alleyway will come to be utilized in a prohibited manner.
The Gemara considers a new case: If the cross beam spanning the entrance to an alleyway <b>was less than ten handbreadths</b> above the ground, <b>and one hollowed out</b> the ground under the cross beam in order <b>to complete</b> the distance from the ground to the cross beam <b>to ten, how much must he hollow out?</b> The Gemara is surprised by the question: <b>How much must he hollow out? However much is necessary for it</b> to increase the height to at least ten handbreadths. <b>Rather,</b> the question is as follows: <b>How far must</b> the hollowed-out area <b>extend</b> into the alleyway in order to render it permitted to carry throughout the alleyway? <b>Rav Yosef said: Four</b> handbreadths. <b>Abaye said: Four cubits.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that</b> these <i>amora’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> the ruling of <b>Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi. As it was stated</b> with regard to the following question: If <b>the side wall of an alleyway was breached toward its entrance,</b> i.e., close to where the alleyway opens into the public domain, what is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>It was stated in the name of Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi: If an</b> upright <b>board four</b> handbreadths wide remains of the original wall or is set up where the original wall had ended, the cross beam or side post at the entrance to the alleyway <b>renders it permitted</b> to carry in the alleyway even if there is <b>a breach</b> of <b>up to ten</b> cubits wide.
<b>And if</b> there is <b>no</b> upright board there, the following distinction applies: If the breach is <b>less than three</b> handbreadths, the cross beam or side post <b>renders it permitted</b> to carry in the alleyway, based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>. If the breach is <b>three</b> or more handbreadths, the cross beam or side post <b>does not render it permitted</b> to carry. The Gemara proposes that <b>Rav Yosef,</b> who says that the hollowed-out area need only extend four handbreadths, <b>adopts</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ami,</b> whereas <b>Abaye,</b> who requires a hollowed-out area of four cubits, <b>does not adopt</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ami.</b>
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Abaye</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that the two cases are not comparable: <b>There,</b> in Rav Ami’s case, we are dealing with <b>the final</b> stage <b>of an alleyway,</b> i.e., an alleyway that had at first been properly structured, and only later did it become breached. <b>Here,</b> we are dealing with <b>the initial</b> stage <b>of an alleyway,</b> i.e., an alleyway that from the very outset did not fulfill the necessary conditions. In this case: <b>If there are four cubits</b> in the hollowed-out area, <b>yes,</b> it is considered an alleyway, and <b>if not, no,</b> it is not considered an alleyway.
<b>Abaye said: From where do I say</b> that a length of at least four cubits is required? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An alleyway is permitted by means of a side post or</b> cross <b>beam only if it has</b> both <b>houses</b> opening into courtyards <b>and courtyards opening into it,</b> as only in that case can it be called an alleyway.
<b>And if</b> the entire length of the alleyway is only <b>four</b> handbreadths, as is indicated by Rav Yosef’s opinion, <b>how can you find this</b> case? Under what circumstances is it possible for such a short alleyway to have courtyards opening into it? Even if there are only two such courtyards, the entrance to each is at least four handbreadths wide.
<b>And if you say that</b> the alleyway <b>opens</b> into the courtyards <b>through</b> its <b>middle wall,</b> i.e., the alleyway is only four handbreadths long but is wide enough to have two entrances opening into two courtyards, this is difficult. <b>Didn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>we hold</b> on the authority of tradition: <b>Which is an alleyway that is permitted by a side post or a</b> cross <b>beam? Any</b> alleyway <b>whose length is greater than its width and has houses and courtyards opening into it.</b> Accordingly, if the alleyway is only four handbreadths long, its width must be even less than that. Consequently, argues Abaye, a length of at least four cubits is required.
<b>And Rav Yosef,</b> how would he respond to this? Rav Yosef explains that the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with a case <b>where</b> the courtyards <b>open</b> into the alleyway <b>at its corners.</b> In this way it is possible to have two openings, each of which is at least four handbreadths wide, although the length of the alleyway itself is no greater than four handbreadths, as the four handbreadths of the openings to the courtyards are divided between the width and the length of the alleyway.
<b>Abaye</b> further <b>said: From where do I say</b> that a length of at least four cubits is required? <b>As Rami bar Ḥama said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said:</b> With regard to <b>a side post that protrudes from the wall</b> on the side <b>of an alleyway</b> into the opening of the alleyway, if its protrusion was <b>less than four cubits, it is deemed a side post</b> that renders it permitted to carry in the alleyway, <b>and no other side post is required to render it permitted</b> to carry in it. However, if it protruded <b>four cubits,</b> that section <b>is deemed an alleyway,</b> as though there were an additional alleyway within an alleyway, <b>and another side post is required to render it permitted</b> to carry there. This shows that anything less than four cubits does not have the status of an alleyway, which supports the position of Abaye.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav Yosef,</b> how would he respond to this? Rav Yosef distinguishes between the cases: With regard <b>to removing its status as a side post,</b> this status remains <b>until there are four cubits</b> in the length of the side post. However, <b>in order to be</b> deemed <b>an</b> independent <b>alleyway, even with</b> a wall of <b>four handbreadths it is also</b> considered <b>an alleyway.</b>
The Gemara examines Rami bar Ḥama’s statement cited in the course of the previous discussion. As to the matter <b>itself: Rami bar Ḥama said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said:</b> With regard to <b>a side post that protrudes from the wall</b> on the side <b>of an alleyway</b> into the entrance of the alleyway,

Daf 5b

if its protrusion is <b>less than four cubits, it is deemed a side post</b> that renders it permitted to carry in the alleyway, <b>and no other side post is required to render it permitted.</b> However, if it protrudes <b>four cubits,</b> that section <b>is deemed an alleyway, and another side post is required to render it permitted to</b> carry in it.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>That side post,</b> which is added in order to permit carrying within the alleyway that was formed by the four-cubit side post, <b>where does one position it</b> such that one may carry within the alleyway? The Gemara clarifies its difficulty: <b>If one positions it alongside</b> the first side post as an addition to it, it looks as if <b>he is</b> merely <b>extending</b> the original side post, and it is not noticeable that an extra side post is present.
<b>Rav Pappa said: He should position it,</b> the extra side post, <b>on the other side</b> of the alleyway, near the opposite wall. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Even if you say that he positions it alongside</b> the first side post, it is valid, so long as <b>he adds to it or diminishes from it</b> in thickness or height, so that it will be noticeable that it is a side post of its own.
The Gemara limits the application of Rami bar Ḥama’s ruling: <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: We stated</b> this halakha with regard to a side post protruding four cubits into the alleyway <b>only in</b> the case of <b>an alleyway</b> that is at least <b>eight</b> cubits wide. <b>However, in</b> the case of <b>an alleyway</b> that is only <b>seven</b> cubits wide, it is <b>permitted</b> to carry within the alleyway without an additional side post, not because the original side post functions as a side post but rather because it sufficiently seals off the entrance to the alleyway such that the <b>standing</b> segment <b>is greater than the breached</b> segment. The alleyway is now closed off from all four sides, and the remaining opening to the public domain is regarded as an entrance, as most of that side is closed and only a small part of it is open.
<b>And</b> this is derived by means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from a courtyard: Just as</b> in <b>a courtyard, which is not</b> rendered a <b>permitted</b> domain <b>by</b> means of <b>a side post or a</b> cross <b>beam,</b> but actual partitions are required, it <b>is</b> nevertheless rendered a <b>permitted</b> domain even if there are gaps in the partitions, as long <b>as the standing</b> segment <b>is greater than the breached</b> segment in <b>an alleyway,</b> with regard to which the Sages were lenient, <b>as</b> it <b>is</b> rendered a <b>permitted</b> domain <b>by</b> means of <b>a side post or a</b> cross <b>beam, is it not right</b> that it <b>is</b> rendered a <b>permitted</b> domain <b>when the standing</b> segment of the partition is <b>greater than the breached</b> segment?
The Gemara refutes this <i>a fortiori</i> inference that was based on the fact that the legal status of a courtyard is more lenient than that of an alleyway, as it is in fact more stringent than that of an alleyway in at least one respect. With regard to <b>what</b> is true of <b>a courtyard, that</b> as long as <b>its breach is</b> less than <b>ten</b> cubits it remains a permitted domain, can <b>you say</b> the same <b>of an alleyway,</b> which is more stringent, as in a case where <b>its breach is</b> only <b>four</b> handbreadths it is not permitted to carry in the alleyway? Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> of an alleyway cannot be derived from the <i>halakha</i> of a courtyard.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, holds</b> that <b>the breach of an alleyway</b> is <b>also ten</b> cubits. The Gemara raises a difficulty: But <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>did we state</b> this <i>a fortiori</i> inference? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna. But doesn’t Rav Huna</b> himself <b>hold that the breach</b> of an alleyway is <b>four</b> handbreadths.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua,</b> did not come to explain Rav Huna’s position. Rather, he <b>stated his own view,</b> and he does not accept Rav Huna’s opinion with regard to the law of a breach in an alleyway.
<b>Rav Ashi</b> went further than Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, and <b>said: Even if you say</b> that the law with regard to a side post protruding four cubits into the alleyway applies <b>in</b> the case of <b>an alleyway</b> that is exactly <b>eight</b> cubits wide, in that it <b>too does not require an</b> additional <b>side post. Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, you are forced to arrive at this conclusion: <b>If</b> you say that the <b>standing</b> segment <b>is greater,</b> then the alleyway <b>is permitted,</b> because its <b>standing</b> segment <b>is greater than the breached</b> segment; <b>and if</b> you say that the <b>breached</b> segment <b>is greater,</b> then the protrusion is <b>deemed a side post,</b> as its width must be less than four cubits.
<b>What</b> might <b>you say</b> that would require an additional side post? Would you suggest that there is yet another possibility, <b>that the two are</b> exactly <b>equal,</b> the standing portion and the breach? <b>This is an uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>rabbinic law,</b> as carrying in an alleyway is forbidden only by rabbinic law, <b>and</b> the principle is that where there is <b>an uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>a rabbinic law,</b> one may assume the <b>lenient</b> position, as opposed to an uncertainty arising with respect to a Torah law, where one assumes the stringent position.
The Gemara considers a new case: <b>Rav Ḥanin bar Rava said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>an alleyway that was breached,</b>

Daf 6a

if it was breached <b>from its side,</b> the side wall of the alleyway, carrying within the alleyway is prohibited if the breach is <b>ten</b> cubits wide. But if it was breached <b>from its front,</b> the wall that faces the public domain, carrying within the alleyway is prohibited even if the breach is only <b>four</b> handbreadths wide.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>What is the difference</b> such that carrying is prohibited due to a breach <b>from the side</b> only if the breach is <b>ten</b> cubits? This is <b>because</b> you <b>say</b> that up to ten cubits <b>it is</b> deemed <b>an entrance.</b> If the breach is <b>in the front, let us also say it is an entrance,</b> and carrying should be permitted if the breach is less than ten cubits.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> We are dealing with <b>a case where the breach is in a corner.</b> Since <b>people do not make an entrance in a corner,</b> a breach of this kind cannot be viewed as an entrance, and if the breach is larger than four handbreadths it must be sealed.
<b>Rav Huna</b> disagreed with Rav Ḥanin bar Rava and <b>said:</b> There is no distinction between the side and the front, for in <b>both this</b> case <b>and that,</b> a breach of up to <b>four</b> handbreadths is allowed. <b>And so Rav Huna said to Rav Ḥanan bar Rava: Do not dispute me, as Rav</b> himself <b>arrived at</b> a place called <b>Damḥarya and performed an action,</b> i.e., issued a practical ruling, <b>in accordance with my</b> opinion. Rav Ḥanan bar Rava <b>said</b> in response <b>to him:</b> No proof can be brought from that incident, for in that case <b>Rav found an</b> unguarded <b>valley and fenced it in,</b> i.e., Rav saw the need to add a safeguard and was therefore stringent in this case. His ruling, however, was not generally applied.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Rav Huna’s opinion stands to reason, as it was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagree about the following issue: With regard to <b>a crooked,</b> L-shaped <b>alleyway</b> that opens onto the public domain at both ends, <b>Rav said: Its law is like</b> that of an alleyway that is <b>open</b> on two opposite sides, and it must be treated in a manner suitable for such an alleyway, i.e., an opening in the form of a doorway must be constructed at both ends, or else such an opening must be constructed at the point where the two arms of the alleyway meet and a side post or a cross beam must be placed at each end. <b>And Shmuel said: Its law is like</b> that of an alleyway that is <b>closed</b> on one side, and all that is necessary is a side post or a cross beam at each end.
The Gemara clarifies the particular circumstances of the case: <b>With what are we dealing? If you say</b> that the width of the alleyway at the point of the turn is <b>more than ten</b> cubits wide, <b>in this</b> case, <b>would Shmuel say that its law is like</b> that of an alleyway that is <b>closed</b> on one side? With an opening of that size, it must be considered like an alleyway that is open on both ends.
<b>Rather, are we not</b> dealing with a case where the width of the alleyway at the point of the turn is <b>ten</b> cubits or less, <b>and Rav</b> nonetheless <b>said</b> that <b>the law</b> of such an alleyway <b>is like that of</b> an alleyway that is <b>open</b> on both ends. <b>Apparently, a breach in the side</b> wall <b>of an alleyway</b> renders it prohibited to carry even if it is only <b>four</b> handbreadths wide, in accordance with the opinion of Rav Huna.
<b>And Rav Ḥanan bar Rava</b> argues that the cases cannot be compared: <b>It is different there,</b> in the case of the L-shaped alleyway, <b>for many people cross through</b> the opening from one arm to the other. Since in practice the alleyway is open to regular traffic, the ruling is stringent even with regard to a small breach.
The Gemara asks: Can it be <b>inferred</b> from this <b>that Rav Huna holds</b> that <b>even if many people</b> do <b>not cross through</b> the opening, a breach of four handbreadths still prohibits carrying? <b>What is the difference</b> between this case and the case of the ruling of <b>Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi</b> cited earlier, that an upright board of four handbreadths suffices in order to allow a breach of up to ten cubits?
The Gemara answers: <b>There, there are remnants of a wall</b> that render it difficult to pass through the breach, and therefore that breach does not annul the partitions. However, <b>here, there are no remnants of a wall.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does one render a public thoroughfare fit</b> for carrying <b>by</b> means of <b>an <i>eiruv</i>? He constructs an</b> opening in the <b>form of a doorway from here,</b> on one side of the thoroughfare, <b>and a side post or a</b> cross <b>beam from here,</b> on the other side. <b>Ḥananya</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> This is the subject of an early dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>, for <b>Beit Shammai say: He constructs a door from here,</b> on one side, <b>and a door from here,</b> on the other side, <b>and when he exits and enters, he must lock</b> the door. It is not sufficient to construct a symbolic door; rather, there must be a door that actually closes. And <b>Beit Hillel say: He constructs a door from here,</b> on one side, <b>and a side post or a</b> cross <b>beam from here,</b> on the other side.
The Gemara raises a fundamental question: <b>Can a public domain be rendered fit</b> for carrying <b>by</b> means of <b>an <i>eiruv</i>? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said:</b>

Daf 6b

<b>One who has two houses</b> opposite each other <b>on the two sides of the public domain,</b> and he wishes to carry from one house to the other on Shabbat via the public domain, <b>he may place a side post from here,</b> on one side of one of the houses, <b>and</b> an additional <b>side post from here,</b> on the other side. <b>Alternatively,</b> he may place <b>a</b> cross <b>beam from here,</b> from one end of one house, <b>and</b> an additional cross <b>beam from here,</b> from the other side of the house, <b>and</b> then <b>he may carry</b> objects <b>and place</b> them in the area <b>between</b> them, for in this manner he turns the middle area into a private domain.
