With regard to the resolution of this incident, <b>the Exilarch recited</b> the following <b>verse about</b> these Rabbis: <b>“They are wise to do evil, but to do good they have no knowledge”</b> (Jeremiah 4:22), as on Friday they ruined the arrangement that Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana had made to permit carrying from the house to the pavilion, and the next day all they could do was prove that they had acted improperly the day before and that it was prohibited to carry in the orchard.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Elai said: I heard from Rabbi Eliezer</b> that one is permitted to carry in a garden or <i>karpef</i>, <b>even</b> if the garden <b>is</b> the size of <b>a <i>beit kor</i>,</b> thirty times larger than a <i>beit se’a</i>. The Gemara notes that all agree that what the mishna taught was <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥananya says:</b> One is permitted to carry <b>even if it</b> is the size of <b>forty <i>beit se’a</i>, like the court of a king.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Both</b> Rabbi Elai and Ḥananya <b>derived</b> their opinion <b>from the same verse, as it is stated: “And it came to pass, before Isaiah was gone out into the middle courtyard,</b> that the word of the Lord came to him, saying” (ii Kings 20:4). In the biblical text, <b>it is written: “The city [<i>ha’ir</i>],” and we read</b> it as: “The middle <b>courtyard [<i>ḥatzer</i>],”</b> as there is a difference in this verse between the written word and how it is spoken. <b>From here</b> it is derived that <b>royal courts were</b> as large <b>as intermediate-</b>sized <b>cities.</b> Consequently, there is no contradiction, as the central courtyard of the royal palace was itself like a small town.
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Elai and Ḥananya <b>disagree?</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elai, <b>maintains: Intermediate-</b>sized <b>towns are</b> the size of a field that had an area of <b>a <i>beit kor</i>; and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Ḥananya, <b>maintains: They are</b> the size of <b>forty <i>se’a</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks about the Biblical narrative cited above: <b>What did Isaiah need</b> to do <b>there</b> in the middle court, i.e., why was he there? The Gemara answers: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This teaches that Hezekiah took ill, and Isaiah went and established a</b> Torah <b>academy at his door,</b> so that Torah scholars would sit and occupy themselves with Torah outside his room, the merit of which would help Hezekiah survive.
<b>Based on this,</b> it is derived, <b>with regard to a Torah scholar who took ill, that one establishes an academy at</b> the <b>entrance</b> to <b>his</b> home. The Gemara comments: <b>This,</b> however, <b>is not a</b> proper <b>course</b> of action, as <b>perhaps they will come to provoke Satan against him.</b> Challenging Satan might worsen the health of a sick person rather than improve it.
The mishna cites another statement made by Rabbi Elai in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: <b>And I also heard from him</b> another <i>halakha</i>: If <b>one of the residents of a courtyard forgot and did not join in an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the other residents, and on Shabbat he ceded ownership of his share in the courtyard to the other residents, it <b>is prohibited</b> for him, the one who forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, to bring in objects or take them out from <b>his house</b> to the courtyard; but it is permitted to the other residents to bring objects from their houses to that other person’s house via the courtyard, and vice versa.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: It <b>is prohibited</b> for the one who forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i> to bring in objects or take them out from <b>his house</b> to the courtyard, <b>and for</b> the other residents who did make an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>to take out</b> objects from the house to the courtyard <b>or to bring</b> them into the house from the courtyard.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is <b>not difficult.</b>

Daf 26b

<b>This,</b> the mishna here, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, while that,</b> the other mishna, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
Rav Sheshet adds: <b>When you examine</b> the matter closely, you will find that <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Eliezer, one who renounces</b> his <b>authority over his</b> share in the <b>courtyard</b> to the other residents of the courtyard also <b>renounces</b> his <b>authority over his</b> own <b>house.</b> However, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, one who renounces</b> his <b>authority over his</b> share in the <b>courtyard</b> to the other residents <b>does not renounce</b> his <b>authority over his</b> own <b>house</b> to them.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this comment: But it is <b>obvious</b> that this is the point over which the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree.
The Gemara answers: <b>Raḥava said:</b> Both <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana and I explained:</b> Rav Sheshet’s explanation <b>was necessary only with regard to</b> the case of <b>five</b> people <b>who lived in the same courtyard, one of whom forgot to join in an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the others.
<b>According to the statement of Rabbi Eliezer, when he renounces his authority, he need not renounce it to each and every one</b> of the residents, as we already know that Rabbi Eliezer holds that one who renounces authority does so in a generous manner, renouncing authority not only of his share in the courtyard, but also of his own house. Consequently, if he is required to renounce authority to many people, we assume that he does so even if this is not explicitly stated.
In contrast, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, when he renounces his authority,</b> it does not suffice that he renounces it in favor of one person; rather, <b>he must</b> explicitly <b>renounce it to each and every one,</b> as we cannot presume that he renounces authority in a generous manner.
The Gemara continues: <b>In accordance with which</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>is</b> the ruling <b>that was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>? If <b>five</b> people <b>lived in the same courtyard, and one of them forgot and did not join in an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the other residents, <b>when he renounces his authority, he need not renounce his authority to each and every one</b> of the residents. The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It is <b>in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer,</b> as explained above.
<b>Rav Kahana taught</b> the passage <b>this way,</b> as cited above, that it was Raḥava and Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana who applied Rav Sheshet’s explanation to the case of the five people living in the same courtyard. <b>Rav Tavyomei,</b> on the other hand, <b>taught</b> it <b>as follows,</b> that it was Rav Sheshet himself who applied it to that case: <b>In accordance with which</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>is</b> the ruling <b>that was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>? If <b>five</b> people <b>lived in the same courtyard, and one of them forgot and did not join in an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the other residents, <b>when he renounces his authority, he need not renounce his authority to each and every one</b> of the residents. This statement is <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion? <b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said: In accordance with whom? In accordance with Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> which presumes that one renounces his authority over his house as well, <b>if one</b> who forgot to join in an <i>eiruv</i> with the other residents of the courtyard explicitly <b>stated: I am not renouncing</b> authority of my house, <b>and</b> likewise, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, if he</b> explicitly <b>stated: I am renouncing</b> authority of my house, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in such cases?
The Gemara clarifies: Is <b>Rabbi Eliezer’s reason because he maintains</b> in general that <b>one who renounces authority over his</b> share in a courtyard to the other residents presumably also <b>renounces</b> to them <b>authority over his</b> own <b>house, but</b> that since <b>this</b> person explicitly <b>stated: I am not renouncing</b> authority of my house, he therefore maintains his authority?
<b>Or perhaps Rabbi Eliezer’s reason</b> is <b>because people do not</b> generally <b>live</b> in <b>a house without a courtyard,</b> and therefore anyone who renounces authority over his share in a courtyard automatically renounces authority over his own house regardless of what he says. Therefore, <b>when he says: I am not renouncing</b> authority over my house, it is <b>not in his power</b> to do so, <b>as even though he says: I</b> will continue <b>to live</b> in and retain authority over my house, <b>he has said nothing.</b>
<b>And</b> the question likewise arises <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. If one</b> explicitly <b>stated: I am renouncing</b> authority of my house as well, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is <b>the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>the Rabbis because they maintain</b> that <b>one who renounces authority over his</b> share in a <b>courtyard</b> to the other residents presumably <b>does not renounce authority over his</b> own <b>house</b> to them, <b>but</b> since <b>this</b> person explicitly <b>stated: I am renouncing</b> authority over my house, the other residents should be permitted to carry?
<b>Or perhaps the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> is <b>because one does not usually remove himself entirely from a house and courtyard, making himself like a guest among</b> his neighbors. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>when he states: I am renouncing</b> authority over my house, it is <b>not in his power</b> to do so, and his statement is disregarded.
Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa in answer to his question: <b>Both according to the Rabbis and according to Rabbi Eliezer, once one has revealed his wishes, he has revealed</b> them, and everything follows his express wishes.
The mishna records yet another teaching handed down by Rabbi Elai: <b>And I also heard from</b> Rabbi Eliezer another <i>halakha</i>, <b>that one may fulfill his obligation</b> to eat bitter herbs <b>on Passover with <i>arkablin</i>,</b> a certain bitter herb. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>arkablin</i>? Reish Lakish said:</b> It is <b><i>Atzvata ḥaruziyata</i>,</b> a type of fiber that wraps itself around a date palm.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may establish a joining</b> of houses in courtyards [<i>eiruv ḥatzerot</i>] in order to permit carrying on Shabbat in a courtyard shared by two or more houses, and one may establish a joining of Shabbat borders [<i>eiruv teḥumin</i>] in order to extend the distance one is permitted to walk on Shabbat; <b>and</b> similarly, <b>one may merge</b> courtyards in order to permit carrying in an alleyway shared by two or more courtyards. This may be done <b>with all</b> kinds of food <b>except for water and salt,</b> as they are not considered foods and therefore may not be used for these purposes.
The mishna continues with two similar principles: <b>All</b> types of food <b>may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money,</b> which must be taken to Jerusalem and used to purchase food (Deuteronomy 14:26), <b>except for water and salt.</b> Similarly, <b>one who vows that nourishment</b> is prohibited to him <b>is permitted</b> to eat <b>water and salt,</b> as they are not considered sources of nourishment.
It was further stated with regard to the laws of joining courtyards that <b>one may establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> <i>teḥumin</i> <b>for a nazirite with wine,</b> even though he is prohibited to drink it, because it is permitted to others. <b>And</b> similarly, one may establish an <i>eiruv teḥumin</i> <b>for an Israelite with <i>teruma</i>,</b> even though he may not eat it, because it is permitted to a priest. The food used for an <i>eiruv teḥumin</i> must be fit for human consumption, but it is not essential that it be fit for the consumption of the one for whom it is being used. <b>Summakhos,</b> however, <b>says:</b> One may only establish an <i>eiruv teḥumin</i> for an Israelite <b>with unconsecrated</b> food.
It was additionally stated that one may establish an <i>eiruv teḥumin</i> <b>for a priest in a <i>beit haperas</i>,</b> a field containing a grave that was plowed over. There is doubt as to the location of bone fragments in the entire area. A priest is prohibited to come into contact with a corpse, and therefore may not enter a <i>beit haperas</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> An <i>eiruv teḥumin</i> may be established for a priest <b>even between the graves</b> in a graveyard, an area which the priest may not enter by Torah law,

Daf 27a

<b>since he can interpose</b> between himself and the graves <b>and go and eat</b> the food that comprises the <i>eiruv</i> without contracting ritual impurity.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One may not learn from general statements,</b> i.e., when a general statement is made in a mishna using the word all, it is not to be understood as an all-inclusive, general statement without exceptions. This is true <b>even in a place where it says</b> the word <b>except.</b> Even in that case, there may be other exceptions to the rule that are not listed.
The Gemara notes: <b>From</b> the fact that Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said: Even in a place where it says except,</b> this proves <b>by inference that he was not relating to</b> the general statement made <b>here</b> in the mishna, which uses the word except. <b>To which</b> mishna, then, <b>was he relating</b> when he formulated his principle?
The Gemara answers: <b>He was relating</b> to a mishna found <b>there:</b> With regard to <b>all time-bound, positive commandments,</b> i.e., mitzvot that can only be performed at a certain time of the day, or during the day rather than at night, or on certain days of the year, <b>men are obligated</b> to perform them <b>and women are exempt.</b> But positive commandments <b>that are not time-bound, both women and men are obligated</b> to perform.
<b>Is it</b> a general <b>principle</b> that <b>women are exempt from all time-bound, positive commandments</b> without exception? But <b>there is</b> the commandment to eat <b><i>matza</i></b> on Passover, the commandment of <b>rejoicing</b> on a Festival, and the commandment of <b>assembly</b> in the Temple courtyard once every seven years during the festival of <i>Sukkot</i> following the Sabbatical Year, all of which <b>are time-bound, positive commandments, and</b> nevertheless, <b>women are obligated</b> to perform them.
Similarly, <b>are women obligated in all positive commandments that are not time-bound?</b> But <b>there is</b> the commandment of <b>Torah study,</b> the commandment to <b>be fruitful and multiply,</b> and the commandment of <b>redemption of the firstborn,</b> all of which are <b>positive commandments that are not time-bound, and</b> nevertheless, <b>women are exempt</b> from them. <b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One may not learn from general statements, even in a place where it says except,</b> because it is always possible that there other exceptions to the rule.
<b>Abaye said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yirmeya</b> who said: <b>We, too, have also learned</b> a proof for Rabbi Yoḥanan’s principle from a mishna: <b>They stated</b> yet <b>another</b> general <b>principle: Anything</b> that is <b>carried upon a <i>zav</i> is</b> ritually <b>impure. And anything on which a <i>zav</i> is carried is</b> ritually <b>pure, except for</b> an object <b>suitable for lying or sitting upon and a human being,</b> which become defiled if a <i>zav</i> is borne on them. The following objection may be raised: <b>And is there nothing else? But there is</b> an object upon which a person <b>rides</b> that becomes impure, as explained in the Torah itself.
The Gemara first asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of an object upon which <b>one rides? If he sat upon it, it is a seat.</b> If not, how does it become defiled? What is there that is suitable for riding upon but does not fall into the category of something upon which one lies or sits? The Gemara answers: <b>We say as follows: There is the upper part of a saddle,</b> which becomes ritually impure as a riding accessory and not as a regular seat. <b>As it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>A saddle</b> upon which a <i>zav</i> sat <b>is impure</b> as <b>a seat</b> of a <i>zav</i>, <b>and the pommel,</b> which is attached to the front of the saddle and used by the rider to maintain his position or to assist in mounting, <b>is impure</b> as <b>a riding</b> accessory. Therefore, we see that the general statement found in the mishna omits that which is suitable for riding upon. <b>Rather, conclude from this</b> that <b>one may not learn from general statements, even in a place where it says except.</b>
<b>Ravina said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Naḥman</b> who said: <b>We, too, have also learned</b> a proof for Rabbi Yoḥanan’s principle from the mishna, which states: <b>One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> and merge</b> alleyways <b>with all</b> kinds of food, <b>except for water and salt. And is there nothing else? But there are truffles and mushrooms,</b> which also may not be used for an <i>eiruv</i> because they are not regarded as food. <b>Rather, conclude from this</b> that <b>one may not learn from general statements, even in a place where it says except.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>All</b> types of food <b>may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money,</b> except for water and salt. <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina</b> both had the same tradition, but <b>one teaches</b> it <b>with regard to <i>eiruv</i>, and one teaches</b> it <b>with regard to</b> the second <b>tithe.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>One teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the issue of <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> as follows: <b>They only taught</b> that <b>one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> with water or salt in the case of <b>water by itself or salt by itself. But</b> with <b>water and salt</b> together, <b>one may</b> indeed <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<b>And</b> the other <b>one teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the issue of the second <b>tithe: They only taught</b> that water or salt <b>may not be bought</b> with second-tithe money in the case of <b>water by itself or salt by itself. But water and salt</b> mixed together <b>may</b> indeed <b>be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money.
The Gemara comments: <b>The one who teaches</b> this law <b>with regard to</b> the second <b>tithe, all the more so</b> would he apply it <b>to an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> i.e., he would certainly maintain that water and salt together are suitable to be used for an <i>eiruv</i>. However, according to <b>the one who teaches</b> this law <b>with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> it applies only to an <i>eiruv</i>; <b>but with regard to</b> the second tithe, <b>no,</b> it does not apply. <b>What is the reason</b> for this distinction? For the second tithe, <b>we require produce,</b> as stated in the Torah, and even when water and salt are mixed together they do not have the status of produce.
<b>When Rabbi Yitzḥak came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he taught</b> this law <b>with regard to</b> the second <b>tithe.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish testified before Rabbi Eliezer: In Father’s house they would buy</b> fish <b>brine with</b> second-<b>tithe money. He said to him: Perhaps you only heard</b> this in a case <b>where the fish’s innards were mixed with</b> the brine. Since this mixture contains a small portion of the fish, the brine becomes significant enough to be purchased with second-tithe money. <b>And even Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish only said</b> his statement <b>with regard to brine, which is the fat of produce,</b> i.e., because a certain amount of fish fat, which itself may be purchased with second-tithe money, is mixed in with the brine; <b>but</b> a mixture of <b>water and salt</b> alone may <b>not</b> be bought with it.
In response to this difficulty, <b>Rav Yosef said:</b>

Daf 27b

Rabbi Yitzḥak’s ruling that water and salt mixed together may be bought with second-tithe money <b>was only necessary</b> in a case <b>where one added oil to them.</b> But a mixture of water and salt alone may not be purchased with second-tithe money.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: If so, <b>let him derive</b> that the mixture may be bought with second-tithe money <b>because of the oil</b> alone. The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>No, it was necessary</b> for a case in which <b>one paid the value of the water and salt by including</b> it in the payment for the oil. Although ostensibly the money that he paid was for the oil, he added to the price of the oil in order to include payment for the water and salt that were mixed with it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if something may not be bought with second-tithe money, <b>is one permitted</b> to buy it <b>by including</b> it in the payment for something which may be bought with second-tithe money? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, and so it was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Ben Bag Bag says</b> in exposition of the verse: “And you shall bestow that money on all that your heart desires, on oxen, on sheep, on wine, on strong drink, on whatever your soul requests” (Deuteronomy 14:26): <b>“On oxen” teaches that one may buy an ox</b> and include in its price payment for <b>its hide.</b> Although the hide cannot be eaten, it may be bought together with the ox, and it does not acquire the sanctity of the second tithe. <b>“On sheep” teaches that one may buy a sheep</b> and include in its price payment for <b>its fleece,</b> which is used for purposes other than eating. <b>“On wine” teaches that one may buy wine</b> and include in its price payment for <b>its jug. “On strong drink” teaches that</b> one is permitted to buy not only actual wine, but <b>one may buy</b> even <b>mead,</b> water in which grape seeds are soaked, <b>once it has fermented</b> and acquired the flavor of wine.
Having cited ben Bag Bag’s exposition of the verse, the Gemara continues: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Whoever interprets</b> the words <b>“on oxen” for me in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Bag Bag, I will carry his clothes after him into the bathhouse,</b> i.e., I will honor him to such an extent that I will be prepared to treat him as a servant treats his master.
<b>What is the reason</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan’s difficulty? <b>All</b> parts of the verse cited above <b>are necessary, except for</b> the expression <b>“on oxen,” which is not necessary.</b> The Gemara clarifies: For <b>what</b> purpose are all the other words <b>necessary? As, if the Torah had written</b> only <b>“on oxen,” I might have said</b> that <b>it is</b> only an <b>ox that may be bought</b> together <b>with its hide</b> with second-tithe money <b>because</b> the hide <b>is</b> an inseparable part of <b>its body,</b> and therefore it is not considered an independent entity from its flesh. <b>But</b> as for buying a <b>sheep</b> together <b>with its fleece, which is not</b> an inseparable part of <b>its body</b> because the fleece can be removed from the sheep while it is alive, you might <b>say no,</b> second-tithe money may not be spent in this manner. It was therefore necessary to state “on sheep.”
<b>And if the Torah had</b> also <b>written “on sheep,”</b> teaching that one may buy even a sheep with second-tithe money together <b>with its fleece, I might have said</b> that it is only a sheep that may be bought together with its fleece <b>because</b> the fleece <b>is attached to it,</b> and therefore it is considered part of the animal. <b>But</b> as for buying <b>wine</b> together <b>with its jug,</b> you might <b>say no,</b> second-tithe money may not be spent this way. It was therefore necessary to state “on wine.”
<b>And if the Torah had</b> also <b>written “on wine,”</b> indicating that one may even buy wine together with its jug with second-tithe money, <b>I might</b> still <b>have said</b> that this is <b>because</b> the jug <b>is</b> needed for the wine’s <b>preservation,</b> as there is no way to carry wine without some sort of container. <b>But</b> as for <b>mead that has fermented, which is mere acidity,</b> you might <b>say no,</b> it should not be included among the items that may be bought with second-tithe money. Therefore, <b>the Torah wrote:</b> “On <b>strong drink.”</b>
The necessity of each word much be proven in the opposite order as well. <b>And if the Torah had</b> only <b>written “on strong drink,” I might have said: What is</b> meant by <b>strong drink? Dried figs from</b> the town of <b>Ke’ila, which are</b> choice and juicy figs that can have an intoxicating effect. They are therefore considered <b>produce</b> and not merely mead. <b>But</b> as for buying <b>wine</b> together <b>with its jug,</b> you might <b>say no,</b> this may not be done with second-tithe money, and therefore it was necessary to state “on wine.”
<b>And if the Torah had</b> also <b>written</b> “on wine,” indicating that one may buy even <b>wine</b> together <b>with its jug</b> with second-tithe money, I might have said that this is because the jug <b>is</b> needed for the wine’s <b>preservation. But</b> as for buying a <b>sheep</b> together <b>with its fleece,</b> you might <b>say no,</b> this may not be done with second-tithe money. Therefore, <b>the Torah stated</b> “on <b>sheep,”</b> to teach <b>that</b> a sheep may be bought with second-tithe money <b>even</b> together <b>with its fleece.</b>
If so, <b>why do I</b> need the words <b>“on oxen”?</b> If one may purchase a sheep together with its fleece with second-tithe money, it should certainly be permitted to buy an ox together with its hide. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>if the Torah had not written “on oxen,” I might have said</b> that <b>a sheep</b> together <b>with its hide, yes,</b> it may be bought with second-tithe money, but together <b>with its fleece, no,</b> it may not be bought; therefore, <b>the Torah wrote “on oxen,” to include its hide,</b> and so “on <b>sheep” remains</b> available for interpretation <b>to include its fleece,</b> i.e., that a sheep may be bought even together with its fleece. Therefore, the words “on oxen” are necessary, for without them I would have understood “on sheep” differently.
This argument can, however, be refuted: Even <b>if the Torah had not written “on oxen,” I would not have said</b> that a <b>sheep</b> together <b>with its hide, yes,</b> it may be bought with second-tithe money, but together <b>with its fleece, no,</b> it may not. For <b>if</b> it were <b>so, the Torah should have written</b> “on <b>oxen,” in which case</b> the words “on <b>sheep” would remain</b> available for interpretation. “On sheep” can be explained in two ways, both in reference to its hide as well as in reference to its fleece. Had the Torah wanted to teach only that an animal may be bought together with its hide but not with its fleece, it would have written “on oxen” only, which would have left no room for error, as oxen do not have fleece.
<b>And since the Torah writes</b> “on <b>sheep,”</b> teaching that a sheep may be bought with second-tithe money <b>even</b> together <b>with its fleece, why do I need</b> the words <b>“on oxen”?</b> These words are <b>now</b> entirely superfluous. If a <b>sheep may be bought</b> together <b>with its fleece, is it necessary</b> to state that an <b>ox</b> may be bought together <b>with its hide? This is what Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> meant when he <b>said: Whoever interprets</b> the words <b>“on oxen” for me in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Bag Bag, I will carry his clothes after him into the bathhouse.</b>
The Gemara now returns to the tannaitic disagreement pertaining to buying fish brine with second-tithe money: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish, and Rabbi Eliezer, and these <i>tanna’im</i></b> whose views will be cited <b>below, disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish and Rabbi Eliezer expound</b> the verse based on the principle of <b>amplifications and restrictions, and these <i>tanna’im</i> expound</b> it based on the principle of <b>generalizations and details,</b> which is a different approach to biblical exegesis.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish and Rabbi Eliezer expound</b> the verse based on the principle of <b>amplifications and restrictions.</b> When the verse states: <b>“And you shall bestow the money on all that your heart desires”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:26), <b>it has amplified.</b> When it then states: <b>“On oxen, on sheep, on wine, and on strong drink,” it has restricted</b> its discussion to certain specific items. When it concludes with the phrase: <b>“On whatever your soul requests,” it has</b> once <b>again amplified.</b> According to this exegetical approach, we conclude that since <b>it amplified and restricted and</b> once again <b>amplified, it has amplified</b> the general category to include <b>everything. What has it amplified</b> the category to include? <b>It has amplified</b> the category to include <b>everything. And what has it restricted</b> from inclusion in the category? Only one thing: <b>According to Rabbi Eliezer, it restricted brine</b> from inclusion because brine is not at all similar to the items listed in the verse; <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish, it restricted water and salt.</b>
<b>And these</b> other <b><i>tanna’im</i> expound</b> the verse according to the principle of <b>generalizations and details, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The phrase: <b>“And you shall bestow the money on all that your heart desires”</b> is <b>a generalization,</b> as no particular type of food is specified. The phrase: <b>“On cattle, on sheep, on wine, and on strong drink”</b> is <b>a detail,</b> as specific types of food are mentioned. When the verse concludes: <b>“On whatever your soul requests,” it has generalized again,</b> as no specific type of food is mentioned. Since the verse is formulated as <b>a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail. Just as</b> the items mentioned in <b>the detail</b> are clearly <b>defined as the produce of produce,</b> i.e., not only the produce itself but also things that come from it, such as the calf that comes from a cow or grapes from a seed, <b>and</b> they are also things <b>grown from the ground,</b> as all of these items grow from the ground or receive their main sustenance from it, <b>so</b> it includes <b>all</b> things that are <b>the produce of produce and are grown from the ground.</b>
<b>And it was taught in another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Just as</b> the items mentioned in <b>the detail</b> are clearly <b>defined as the offspring of the offspring of the earth,</b> i.e., things that come from items that came from the ground, <b>so</b> it includes <b>all</b> things that are <b>the offspring of the offspring of the earth.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> these two <i>baraitot</i>? <b>Abaye said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to <b>fish. According to the one who said</b> that we apply the law to that which is <b>the produce of produce and grown from the ground, fish are</b> regarded as having <b>grown from the ground.</b> However, <b>according to the one who said</b> we apply it to that which is <b>the offspring of the offspring of the earth, fish were created from water.</b> Therefore, they are not of the offspring of the earth, and consequently they are not included among the items that may be purchased with second-tithe money.
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Abaye say</b> that <b>fish are</b> regarded as having been <b>grown from the ground? Didn’t Abaye say the following?</b>

Daf 28a

If <b>one ate a <i>putita</i>,</b> a certain water insect, <b>he is given four</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> as he has transgressed four separate negative Torah commandments, two that relate to creeping animals in general and two that relate to water insects in particular. If he ate <b>an ant, he is given five</b> sets of <b>lashes</b> for violating the two general prohibitions and another three negative commandments stated with regard to insects that creep upon the earth. If he ate <b>a hornet, he is given six</b> sets of <b>lashes,</b> for in addition to the prohibitions applying to an ant, he has transgressed a prohibition stated with regard to flying insects. <b>And if it is</b> correct that something that lives in water is considered as growing from the ground, one who eats <b>a <i>putita</i> should also be given lashes for</b> violating the following prohibition: “And <b>every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth</b> is a detestable thing; it shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 11:41). Rather, fish must certainly not be considered as growing from the ground, and therefore this explanation is to be rejected.
<b>Rather, Ravina said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between</b> the two <i>baraitot</i> with regard to <b>fowl. According to the one who said</b> that one may use second-tithe money only to purchase food which is <b>the produce of produce and grown from the ground, these</b> fowl <b>are also</b> regarded as having <b>grown from the ground.</b> However, <b>according to the one who said</b> that we apply it to that which is <b>the offspring of the offspring of the earth, these fowl were created from mud</b> and not from the ground, and consequently they are not included among the items that may be bought with second-tithe money.
These two distinct opinions are both based upon the exegetical principle of a generalization and a detail. The Gemara now asks: <b>What is the reason of the one who includes fowl, and what is the reason of the one who excludes fowl?</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>The one who includes fowl holds</b> that when there is a generalization, a detail, and another generalization, <b>the latter generalization is primary.</b> Therefore, the rule is similar to that governing <b>a detail</b> followed by <b>a generalization,</b> which maintains that <b>the generalization is considered an addition to the detail, and all</b> other <b>items are included.</b> However, <b>the first generalization is effective in excluding anything that is not similar to</b> it <b>in two respects,</b> as it is nonetheless a case of a generalization, a detail, and a generalization. Therefore, he excludes anything that does not grow from the ground and is not the produce of produce.
<b>And the one who excludes fowl holds</b> that <b>the first generalization is primary.</b> Therefore, a generalization, detail, and generalization is similar to a single <b>generalization</b> that is followed by <b>a detail,</b> with regard to which we maintain that <b>the generalization only includes that which is</b> spelled out <b>in the detail.</b> Therefore, with regard to <b>these</b> items mentioned in the verse, <b>yes,</b> one may purchase them with second-tithe money. With regard to <b>something else, no,</b> one may not. However, <b>the latter generalization is effective to include anything that is similar to it in three respects,</b> namely, it is the produce of produce, grows from the ground, and is offspring of the offspring of the earth, to the exclusion of fowl.
<b>Rav Yehuda said in the name of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat,</b> who said <b>in the name</b> of <b>Rav: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> with cheap and unimportant produce such as <b>cress, purslane, and sweet clover, but</b> one may <b>not</b> establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with green grain or with unripe dates.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But may one establish an <i>eiruv</i> with sweet clover? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>sweet clover</b> that <b>those who have many children may eat</b> it, but <b>those without children may not eat</b> it, as it is harmful to one’s reproductive capacity; <b>and if it was hardened into seed,</b> i.e., if it became very hard and already fit to be planted, <b>even those who have many children may not eat</b> it? Therefore, we see that it is prohibited to eat sweet clover. How can it possibly be used to establish an <i>eiruv</i>?
The Gemara answers: <b>Interpret</b> Rav’s statement as referring to sweet clover <b>that was not</b> yet <b>hardened into seed, and</b> its use for establishing an <i>eiruv</i> is limited to <b>those who have many children</b> and are therefore permitted to eat it.
<b>And if you wish,</b> you can <b>say</b> instead that <b>actually,</b> sweet clover is fit for an <i>eiruv</i> even <b>for those without children because it is fit</b> to be eaten by <b>those who have many children.</b> The food used for an <i>eiruv</i> must be edible, but it does not need to be edible for the particular person using it as his <i>eiruv</i>. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for a nazirite with wine, and for an Israelite with <i>teruma</i>? Apparently,</b> these items may be used as an <i>eiruv</i> <b>even though</b> they <b>are not fit for this</b> person, because they are <b>fit for that</b> other person. <b>Here too, even though</b> the sweet clover <b>is not fit for this</b> person, it may be used because <b>it is fit for that</b> other person.
<b>And if you wish,</b> you can <b>say</b> instead: <b>When Rav said</b> that sweet clover may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, he was referring to <b>Median clover,</b> which is of superior quality and is not harmful.
The Gemara considers the continuation of Rav’s statement: <b>And</b> may one <b>not</b> establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with green grain? Didn’t Rav Yehuda say that Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>dodder and green grain, one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with them; and</b> when eating <b>them one recites the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground?</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> first statement, according to which green grain may not be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, was made <b>before Rav came to Babylonia. That</b> second statement was made <b>after Rav came to Babylonia</b> and saw that people there ate green grain, at which point he ruled that it is fit to be used for an <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is Babylonia the majority of the world?</b> Laws are established according to the custom prevalent in most of the world. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>beans, barley, and fenugreek that</b> one <b>planted</b> in order to use <b>as an herb,</b> e.g., as animal fodder, <b>his opinion is rendered irrelevant by the opinions of all other people?</b> Since most people do not act this way, we do not consider this particular person’s intention to be significant. <b>Therefore, one is obligated</b> to tithe <b>their seeds, and their herbs are exempt.</b> When one harvests these plants in their green state, before their seeds have matured, they are regarded as not having fully ripened. However, in the case of <b>cress and arugula,</b> which are commonly eaten both in their green state and as seeds, if <b>one planted them</b> in order to use them <b>as herbs, they are tithed</b> both <b>as herbs and as seeds;</b> if <b>one planted them for</b> their <b>seeds, they are tithed as seeds and as herbs,</b> no matter how they are eaten. In any case, the first part of the <i>baraita</i> teaches that the law is determined in accordance with the common custom of most of the world and not with the practice in one particular place.
The Gemara answers: <b>When Rav said</b> that green grain may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>,

Daf 28b

he was referring <b>to the garden variety,</b> which is commonly eaten.
Having mentioned <b>arugula seeds,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>For what are they suitable?</b> Generally, only the plant’s leaves are eaten. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The earlier</b> generations, <b>who had no pepper, would crush</b> these seeds <b>and dip</b> their <b>roasted meat in them.</b> Therefore, arugula seeds are also eaten, even though this is not their typical use.
The Gemara relates that <b>when Rabbi Zeira was exhausted from his studies, he would go and sit at the entrance</b> to the academy <b>of Rav Yehuda bar Ami,</b> and <b>say: When the Sages go in and out, I shall stand up before them and receive reward for</b> honoring <b>them,</b> as it is a mitzva to honor Torah scholars. Too tired to engage in actual Torah study, he sought a way to rest while fulfilling a different mitzva at the same time.
Once, a young <b>school child was leaving</b> the study hall. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: What did your teacher teach you</b> today? <b>He said to him:</b> The proper blessing for <b>dodder</b> is: <b>Who creates the fruit of the ground;</b> the proper blessing for <b>green grain</b> is: <b>By Whose word all things came to be.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: On the contrary, the opposite is</b> more <b>reasonable,</b> as <b>this,</b> the green grain, <b>derives nourishment from the ground, whereas that,</b> the dodder, <b>derives nourishment from the air,</b> and it is fitting to recite a blessing over each item in accordance with its source of nourishment.
The Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the</b> young <b>school child. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>This,</b> the dodder, is <b>fully ripened produce, and that,</b> green grain, is <b>not fully ripened produce.</b> If produce is not fully ripened one can only recite the blessing: By Whose word all things came to be. <b>And that which you said: This,</b> the green grain, <b>derives nourishment from the ground, whereas that,</b> the dodder, <b>derives nourishment from the air, this is not so. Dodder also derives nourishment from the ground, for we see that when the</b> prickly <b>shrub is cut off, the dodder</b> attached to it <b>dies.</b> This shows that dodder also derives its nourishment from the ground, albeit indirectly.
The Gemara now considers the next part of Rav’s statement: <b>And</b> is it correct that <b>one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with unripe dates? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Heart of palm,</b> the soft, edible inner core of a palm tree, <b>may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money; but it does not contract the</b> ritual <b>impurity of foods,</b> as it is not actually a food, but rather a part of the tree itself. <b>And unripe dates may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money, and</b> they even <b>contract the</b> ritual <b>impurity of foods.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> this somewhat differently: <b>Heart of palm is like a tree in all its</b> legal <b>aspects, except that it may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money,</b> as it is edible. <b>And unripe dates are like fruit in all regards,</b> as they are actual fruit, <b>except</b> with respect to one characteristic, which is <b>that they are exempt from tithes</b> because they are not yet fully ripened.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the <b>fruit</b> of palms that <b>never</b> fully <b>ripen</b>. They are therefore regarded as full-fledged fruit even in their unripe state. Rav, however, was referring to the fruit of palms, which eventually ripen. Their unripe state is merely a transitional stage in their development.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, would Rabbi Yehuda say with regard to this</b> that <b>they are exempt from tithes? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: The unripe figs of</b> the place called <b>Beityoni were only mentioned with regard to tithes,</b> as it was stated: In the case of <b>the unripe figs of Beityoni, and the unripe dates of</b> the place called <b>Tuvina, one is obligated to tithe them</b> even though they never ripen, since they are considered full-fledged fruit in all respects?
<b>Rather,</b> say as follows: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is not referring to</b> the <b>fruit</b> of palms that <b>never</b> fully <b>ripen,</b> but rather to the fruit of palms that eventually ripen. However, the <i>halakha</i> <b>pertaining to the</b> ritual <b>impurity of foods is different,</b> and an item’s status as a food with regard to the impurity of foods cannot be brought as proof of its status as a food with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>. <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> elsewhere: <b>Since they are fit to be sweetened through</b> cooking with <b>fire,</b> they are regarded as food for the purpose of tithes; <b>here too,</b> we can say: <b>Since they are fit to be sweetened through</b> cooking with <b>fire,</b> unripe dates are fit to contract the impurity of foods. However, with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>, we require food that is ready for consumption, and something that can be prepared to become food is not sufficient.
The Gemara asks: <b>Where was</b> this comment of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> originally <b>stated?</b> The Gemara answers: It was stated <b>on this</b> ruling, <b>which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One is <b>obligated</b> to tithe <b>bitter almonds</b> while they are still <b>small</b> and green, as they are fit to be eaten while still undeveloped. When they are <b>large,</b> however, one is <b>exempt</b> from tithing them, as they are no longer edible. One is <b>obligated to</b> tithe <b>sweet, large</b> almonds, whereas one is <b>exempt from</b> tithing <b>small ones,</b> as they have not yet fully ripened. <b>Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yosei, said in the name of his father:</b> One is <b>exempt from</b> tithing <b>both this and that,</b> large and small bitter almonds. <b>And some say</b> that he said in the name of his father: One is <b>obligated to</b> tithe <b>both this and that. Rabbi Ila said: Rabbi Ḥanina ruled in Tzippori in accordance with the one who said:</b> One is <b>exempt from</b> tithing <b>both this and that.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>According to</b> the view of <b>the one who said</b> one is <b>obligated to</b> tithe <b>both this and that, for what are</b> large, bitter almonds <b>suitable? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Since</b> these almonds <b>are fit to be sweetened</b> and made edible <b>through</b> cooking with <b>fire,</b> they are regarded as food for the purpose of tithes.
The Gemara further examines the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier. <b>The Master said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Heart of palm is like a tree in all its</b> legal <b>aspects, except that it may be bought with</b> second-<b>tithe money.</b> The Gemara asks: Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion <b>is</b> identical to that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>.</b>
<b>Abaye said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case where <b>one boiled or fried</b> the heart of palm. According to Rabbi Yehuda, it does not contract the ritual impurity of foods even if it was boiled or fried, whereas the first <i>tanna</i> holds that in that case it does contract impurity.
<b>Rava strongly objects to this: Is there</b> really <b>anyone who said</b> that even if <b>one boiled or fried it,</b> it does <b>not</b> contract the ritual impurity of foods? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The hide and the placenta</b> of an animal, which people do not typically eat, <b>do not contract the</b> ritual <b>impurity of foods;</b> however, <b>a hide that one boiled</b> until it became edible <b>and a placenta that one intended</b> to eat <b>do contract the impurity of foods?</b> This indicates that even something not originally fit to be eaten contracts the impurity of foods once it has been boiled or fried, and the same should apply to heart of palm according to all opinions.
<b>Rather, Rava said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to <b>the blessing</b> that must be recited prior to eating, <b>for it was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about the blessing recited over heart of palm: <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> the appropriate blessing is: <b>Who creates the fruit of the ground. And Shmuel said</b> the appropriate blessing is: <b>By Whose word all things came to be.</b>
The Gemara explains the two opinions: <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> the appropriate blessing is: <b>Who creates the fruit of the ground, as it is food.</b> Since heart of palm is edible it is called a fruit, and we recite a blessing over it in the manner of all fruits. <b>And Shmuel said</b> the appropriate blessing is: <b>By Whose word all things came to be. Since it will eventually harden</b> and become like an inedible tree, <b>we do not recite over it the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground,</b> as it will eventually lose the status of a fruit.
<b>Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: <i>Shinnana</i>, your opinion is reasonable, as a radish will eventually harden, and</b> yet <b>we recite over it the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>But it is not so,</b> because <b>people plant radish with the intention</b> of eating it while it is <b>soft; but people do not plant palm trees with the intention</b> of eating <b>heart of palm.</b> Therefore, heart of palm is not considered the fruit of the palm, but rather food extracted from it, over which only the following blessing should be recited: By Whose word all things came to be. <b>And</b> the Gemara concludes: <b>Even though Shmuel praised Rav Yehuda, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b>
The Gemara now examines <b>the matter itself</b> cited in the previous discussion in the name of Rav. <b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said</b> with regard to <b>dodder and green grain: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with them, and</b> when eating <b>them one recites the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How much dodder</b> must be used to establish an <i>eiruv</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>As Rav Yeḥiel said</b> with regard to a similar issue: <b>A handful. Here, too,</b> the measure is <b>a handful.</b>
Similarly, <b>how much green grain</b> is needed to establish an <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Rabba bar Toviya bar Yitzḥak said that Rav said: A full farmers’ bundle.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥilkiya bar Toviya said: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with glasswort.</b> The Gemara expresses astonishment: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with glasswort?</b> People do not eat glasswort. <b>Rather,</b> one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with the herb from</b> whose ashes <b>glasswort</b> is prepared, as it is fit for human consumption before it is burnt. <b>And how much</b> of it is needed to establish an <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Rav Yeḥiel said: A handful.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya</b> once <b>went out to</b> visit certain <b>villages,</b> and the villagers <b>asked him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to establishing an <i>eiruv</i> with moist beans? He did not have</b> an answer for them. <b>When he came to the study hall, they said to him: This is what Rabbi Yannai said: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with moist beans. And how much</b> is needed for that purpose? <b>Rav Yeḥiel said: A handful.</b>
<b>Rav Hamnuna said: One may</b> also <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with raw beets.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Ḥisda say: Raw beet kills a healthy person,</b> which indicates that beets are unhealthy and should therefore be unfit for establishing an <i>eiruv</i>?

Daf 29a

The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> is referring <b>to</b> a beet <b>that was</b> only <b>partially cooked,</b> which is dangerous.
<b>There are</b> some <b>who say</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna said: One may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with raw beets,</b> as <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Raw beet kills a healthy person.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Don’t we see</b> people <b>eating it and they do not die?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> it is referring <b>to</b> a beet <b>that was</b> only <b>partially cooked,</b> which is dangerous.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: A cooked dish of beets is beneficial for the heart, good for the eyes, and all the more so</b> beneficial <b>for the intestines. Abaye said: That is</b> specifically when the dish <b>sits on the stove and makes a <i>tukh tukh</i></b> sound, i.e., it is cooked thoroughly enough to produce a boiling sound.
<b>Rava</b> once <b>said</b> when he was in an especially good mood: <b>Behold, I am like</b> the intellectually sharp <b>ben Azzai,</b> who would regularly expound <b>in the markets of Tiberias.</b> I, too, am ready to answer any question posed to me. <b>One of the Sages said to Rava: How many apples</b> are needed to establish an <i>eiruv</i>? Rava <b>said to him: Does one establish an <i>eiruv</i> with apples?</b>
The other Sage responded: <b>And</b> is it <b>not</b> permissible to establish an <i>eiruv</i> with them? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>All foods combine to disqualify the body</b> of a priest who eats <b>half of a half-loaf</b> of ritually impure food, <b>and</b> to complete the measure of <b>food</b> required for <b>two meals for</b> the purpose of <b>an <i>eiruv</i>, and</b> to complete the measure of <b>an egg-bulk</b> required for a food to be able <b>to contract the</b> ritual <b>impurity of foods?</b> An apple is a kind of food, so it should be included in the items that may be used to establish an <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the refutation? If you say</b> it is <b>because it was taught</b> using the term <b>all foods, and these</b> apples <b>are fit for eating,</b> how can an objection be raised from such a general term? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> already <b>say: One may not learn from general statements</b> using the word all, <b>even in a place where it says except,</b> since no rule exhausts all cases?
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>because it taught: And</b> all foods combine to complete the measure of <b>food</b> required for <b>two meals for</b> the purpose of <b>an <i>eiruv</i>, and</b> to complete the measure of <b>an egg-bulk to contract the</b> ritual <b>impurity of foods; and these</b> apples <b>are also susceptible to the</b> ritual <b>impurity of foods.</b> Therefore, there is clear proof that the mishna is referring to apples as well.
Having established that an <i>eiruv</i> may be established with apples, the Gemara returns to the question raised above: <b>How many</b> apples are needed to establish an <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The minimum measure of <b>apples</b> that must be used for an <i>eiruv</i> is <b>a <i>kav</i>.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> When distributing poor man’s tithe, one must give each individual poor person at least <b>an <i>ukla</i>,</b> an eighth of a <i>log</i>, <b>of spices, a liter of vegetables, ten nuts, five peaches, two pomegranates,</b> or <b>one citron,</b> as these are worthy amounts for distribution. <b>And Gursak bar Darei said in the name of Rav Menashya bar Sheguvlei,</b> who said <b>in the name of Rav: And similarly,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> Now, it can be asked: <b>These</b> apples <b>should also be like peaches,</b> as they are similar in size, and it should be enough to use five apples for an <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara answers that there is a distinction between them: <b>These</b> peaches <b>are important,</b> and therefore five of them are a significant amount, <b>but these</b> apples <b>are not important,</b> and therefore one must use the larger measure of a <i>kav</i>.
<b>Rav Yosef said: May his Master,</b> God, <b>forgive Rav Menashya bar Sheguvlei,</b> for he erred and caused others to err. <b>I stated before him</b> a ruling in the name of Rav <b>concerning a mishna, and he stated it concerning the <i>baraita</i>,</b> which led to the error. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One may not give a pauper</b> receiving poor man’s tithe <b>at the threshing floor less than half a <i>kav</i> of wheat or</b> less than <b>a <i>kav</i> of barley. Rabbi Meir says:</b> He must be given at least <b>half a <i>kav</i> of barley.</b> Similarly, he must be given no less than <b>a <i>kav</i> and a half of spelt, a <i>kav</i> of dried figs, or a <i>maneh</i> of pressed figs. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Not a <i>maneh</i>, but <b>half</b> a <i>maneh</i>. He must be given at least <b>half a <i>log</i> of wine. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Half that amount, <b>a quarter</b> <i>log</i>. <b>And</b> similarly, he must be given <b>a quarter</b> <i>log</i> <b>of oil. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Half that amount, <b>an eighth</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all other fruit, Abba Shaul said:</b> He must be given <b>enough to sell them and buy food</b> that suffices <b>for two meals with</b> the proceeds of <b>their</b> sale. <b>And</b> with regard to this mishna, <b>Rav said: And similarly,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara poses a question with regard to Rav Yosef’s harsh reaction to Rav Menashya bar Sheguvlei’s statement: <b>What is the strength of this over that?</b> The mishna and <i>baraita</i> seem to share the same content, so why should Rav’s ruling be more applicable to one than the other? <b>If you say</b> it is <b>because</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>spices was</b> also <b>taught in this</b> <i>baraita</i>, <b>and spices are not fit for eating</b> on their own but only when added as a flavoring to other foods, and therefore Rav could not have been referring to the <i>baraita</i> when he said that the same law applies to an <i>eiruv</i>; <b>wasn’t</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>wheat and barley taught here</b> in the mishna, <b>and they</b> too <b>are not</b> immediately <b>fit for eating</b> until they are processed further.
<b>Rather, it is because it was taught</b> in the mishna that one must give <b>half a <i>log</i> of wine. And Rav said: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with two-quarters</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>of wine,</b> which is equal to half a <i>log</i>. <b>Since we require so much</b> wine, <b>learn from here</b> that <b>when Rav said: And similarly,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>, he said it about this mishna</b> and the measures mentioned therein. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from this</b> that this is the proper understanding of Rav’s statement.
The Gemara further examines the mishna cited earlier. <b>The Master said: And</b> all foods combine to complete the measure of <b>food</b> required <b>for two meals for</b> the purpose of <b>an <i>eiruv</i>. Rav Yosef thought to say</b> that an <i>eiruv</i> may not be established <b>unless there is</b> a complete <b>meal of this</b> kind of food <b>and</b> a complete <b>meal of that</b> kind of food, meaning that an <i>eiruv</i> may only be established if each meal consists of a single type of food. <b>Rabba said to him:</b> An <i>eiruv</i> may be established with the amount of food required for two meals <b>even</b> if each type of food made up only <b>half, a third, or a quarter</b> of a meal.
The Gemara now examines Rav’s statement <b>itself,</b> which was cited in the course of the previous discussion. <b>Rav said: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with two-quarters</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>of wine.</b> The following question may be raised: <b>Do we</b> really <b>need so much? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> The minimal amount of <b>wine</b> required for an <i>eiruv</i> is <b>enough to eat</b> bread <b>with it,</b> i.e., enough to soak the bread in to enable one to eat it? Additionally, the minimal amount of <b>vinegar</b> that may be used to establish an <i>eiruv</i> is <b>enough to dip</b> the food <b>in it,</b> and the minimal amount of <b>olives and onions</b> is <b>enough to eat them</b> together with the bread. All of these quantities are calculated on the basis of <b>two meals.</b> This <i>baraita</i> clearly indicates that an <i>eiruv</i> may be established with much less than two-quarters of a <i>log</i> of wine.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to cooked wine,</b> which is very strong, and therefore even a small amount suffices.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that the minimal amount of <b>vinegar</b> that may be used for an <i>eiruv</i> <b>is enough to dip</b> food <b>in it. Rav Giddel said that Rav said: Enough to dip in it the food of two meals</b> consisting <b>of vegetables. Some say</b> that <b>Rav Giddel said that Rav said:</b> Enough to dip in it the <b>vegetables that are eaten in two</b> ordinary <b>meals,</b> which is less than the amount consumed in two meals consisting entirely of vegetables.
<b>The Master</b> also <b>said</b> that the minimum measure of <b>olives and onions</b> that may be used for an <i>eiruv</i> is enough <b>to eat them</b> with <b>the food of two meals.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>May one establish an <i>eiruv</i> with onions? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Rabbi Meir once spent Shabbat in</b> the town of <b>Ardiska, and a certain person came before him</b> and <b>said to him: Rabbi, I made an <i>eiruv</i></b> of Shabbat borders [<i>eiruv teḥumin</i>] <b>with onions,</b> so that I might walk to the town of <b>Tiv’in.</b> Ardiska was located between the man’s <i>eiruv</i> and his destination of Tiv’in, which was beyond his Shabbat limit as measured from his hometown. <b>And Rabbi Meir made him remain within his four cubits.</b> He forbade him to leave his four cubits, as he held that an <i>eiruv</i> made with onions is not an <i>eiruv</i>, and therefore the person had left his Shabbat limit without an <i>eiruv teḥumin</i>.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> ruling, which states that onions may not be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, is referring <b>to</b> onion <b>leaves,</b> which are harmful; whereas <b>that</b> ruling, which states that onions may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, is referring <b>to</b> onion <b>bulbs,</b> which are edible. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>ate an onion and died early</b> the next morning, <b>we need not ask from what he died,</b> as his death was certainly caused by the onion. <b>And Shmuel said: They only taught</b> this <b>with regard to the leaves; but with regard to</b> onion <b>bulbs, we have no</b> problem <b>with it. And even with regard to the leaves, we only stated</b> this concern

Daf 29b

in a case where the bulb <b>has not grown</b> to the size of <b>a span,</b> the distance between the thumb and the little finger of a hand that is spread apart, because at that stage the leaves are very toxic; <b>however, if it has grown</b> to the size of <b>a span, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said: We only stated</b> this concern about eating onion leaves in a case where <b>one did not drink beer</b> afterward; <b>however, if he drank beer</b> afterward, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person should not eat onion because of</b> the <b>toxins in it. There was an incident with Rabbi Ḥanina, who ate half an onion and half of its toxins, and he fell deathly ill, and his colleagues prayed for mercy for him, and he survived.</b> He was rescued only <b>because the time needed him,</b> as his generation was in need of his teaching, but otherwise he would not have recovered.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said that Shmuel said: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with beer, and it invalidates a ritual bath with</b> a measure of <b>three <i>log</i>,</b> similar to drawn water. <b>Rav Kahana strongly objects to this:</b> This is <b>obvious, for what is the difference between this and dye-water? As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Dye-water invalidates a ritual bath with</b> a measure of <b>three <i>log</i>,</b> like regular drawn water. <b>They said:</b> There is a difference between the two cases, as <b>there,</b> the liquid <b>is called dye-water; here, it is called beer.</b> Therefore, it might have been possible to argue that beer is not considered like water at all, in which case it would only invalidate a ritual bath if it changed the color of the water, and so Shmuel’s novel teaching was necessary.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> beer is needed to <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i>? Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Yosef, thought to say before Rav Yosef</b> as follows: <b>Two-quarters</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>of beer.</b> Rav Aḥa’s reasoning is now spelled out in detail. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: If <b>one carries out wine</b> on Shabbat from a private domain to a public domain, he is liable if he carries out <b>enough</b> wine <b>for diluting a cup,</b> i.e., enough undiluted wine to fill a cup after it has been diluted with water. <b>And</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught about</b> this mishna: <b>Enough</b> wine <b>for diluting a fine cup.</b> They inquired: <b>What</b> is meant by <b>a fine cup?</b> They answered: <b>A cup of blessing. And Rav Naḥman said that Rabba bar Avuh said: A cup of blessing must contain a quarter of a quarter-</b><i>log</i> of wine, <b>so that</b> after one <b>dilutes</b> the wine with water, <b>it amounts to a</b> full <b>quarter-</b><i>log</i>. <b>And</b> this measure is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rava</b> with regard to the strength of wine, <b>as Rava said: Any wine that is not</b> strong enough to require that it be <b>diluted</b> with <b>three</b> parts <b>water to one</b> part wine <b>is not</b> proper <b>wine.</b>
<b>And we learned in the latter clause</b> of the aforementioned mishna: <b>And</b> one is liable for carrying out <b>all other liquids, and</b> similarly <b>all waste water,</b> in the measure of <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i>. Now, Rav Aḥa argues as follows: <b>Since there,</b> with respect to liability for carrying on Shabbat, the ratio is <b>one to four,</b> as one is liable for carrying out a quarter of a quarter-<i>log</i> of wine, and one is only liable for carrying out other liquids if one carries out a quarter-<i>log</i>; <b>here, too,</b> with respect to making an <i>eiruv</i>, the ratio of <b>one to four</b> should be maintained. Therefore, since Rav said that two-quarters of a <i>log</i> of wine are required for an <i>eiruv</i>, the minimum amount of beer one may use should be two full <i>log</i>.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>And this is not so. There,</b> with regard to carrying on Shabbat, we require four times as much beer as wine because <b>less than that</b> amount, i.e., less than a quarter-<i>log</i> of beer, <b>is insignificant. However, here,</b> with regard to establishing an <i>eiruv</i>, this is <b>not</b> relevant, <b>as it is common for people to drink a cup</b> of beer <b>in the morning and a cup</b> of beer <b>in the evening, and they rely on them</b> as their meals, as beer is satisfying even in such quantities. Therefore, we should require only two-quarters of a <i>log</i> of beer for an <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>How many dates</b> are needed to establish an <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> The minimal amount of <b>dates</b> one may use is <b>a <i>kav</i>. Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one inadvertently <b>ate dried figs</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and paid dates</b> in compensation, <b>may a blessing come upon him.</b>
The Gemara proceeds to clarify this ruling: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If you say</b> that one paid <b>according to the value</b> of the figs he ate, e.g., <b>he ate a <i>zuz</i></b> worth of figs <b>and he paid a <i>zuz</i></b> worth of dates, <b>what is</b> the reason it says: <b>May a blessing come upon him? He ate a <i>zuz</i> and paid a <i>zuz</i>. Rather, is it not</b> that he paid <b>in accordance with the measure</b> of the figs eaten, e.g., that <b>he ate a <i>se’a</i> of dried figs worth one <i>zuz</i>, and he paid a <i>se’a</i> of dates worth four</b> <i>zuz</i>. <b>And it says: May a blessing come upon him. Apparently, dates are superior</b> to dried figs. Accordingly, since we learned above that one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with a <i>kav</i> of dried figs, a <i>kav</i> of dates should certainly suffice for the purpose of an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: No proof can be brought from here. It can be argued that <b>he actually ate a <i>zuz</i></b> worth of figs <b>and he paid a <i>zuz</i></b> worth of dates. <b>And what</b> is the reason it says: <b>May a blessing come upon him? For he ate something that buyers are not eager</b> to buy, <b>and he paid him something that buyers are eager</b> to buy. Even though they are equal in value, the priest benefits, for it is easier for him to sell dates than to sell dried figs.
With regard to <b><i>shetita</i>,</b> a dish made of roasted flour and honey, <b>Rav Aḥa bar Pineḥas said: Two large spoonfuls</b> are needed for an <i>eiruv</i>. With regard to <b><i>kisanei</i>,</b> a type of roasted grain, <b>Abaye said: Two Pumbeditan <i>bunei</i>,</b> the name of a particular of measurement.
Having mentioned roasted grain, the Gemara tangentially relates that <b>Abaye said: Mother,</b> actually his foster mother, <b>told me: These roasted grains are good for the heart and drive away</b> worrisome <b>thoughts.</b>
<b>And Abaye said: Mother told me</b> about another remedy. <b>One who suffers from weakness of the heart should</b> go and <b>bring the meat of the right thigh of a ram, and</b> also <b>bring the dung of grazing cattle from</b> the month of <b>Nisan, and if there is no cattle dung he should bring willow twigs, and</b> then <b>roast</b> the meat on a fire made with the dung or twigs, <b>and eat</b> it, <b>and drink afterward</b> some <b>diluted wine.</b> This will improve his condition.
Returning to the matter of quantities of food required for an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The minimum quantity for <b>anything that serves as a relish</b> is <b>enough to eat</b> two meals <b>with it,</b> i.e., enough to serve as a relish for the bread eaten in two meals. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>anything that is not a relish,</b> but rather is a food in its own right, one must use <b>enough to eat</b> two meals <b>of it.</b> The minimum quantity of <b>raw meat</b> is <b>enough to eat</b> two meals <b>of it. Roasted meat</b> is the subject of a dispute: <b>Rabba said: Enough to eat</b> the bread of two meals <b>with it.</b> That is to say, roasted meat is not a food in itself, but rather it serves as relish for other foods. <b>And Rav Yosef said: Enough to eat</b> two meals <b>of it,</b> as it is a food in its own right.
<b>Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>For these Persians eat pieces of</b> roasted <b>meat [<i>tabahakki</i>] without bread,</b> which shows that meat itself is a food. <b>Abaye said to him: But are the Persians a majority of the world?</b> The <i>halakha</i> follows the customary practice of most of the world and not that of particular locales. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> the following in a <i>baraita</i>? <b>Clothing of the poor,</b> i.e., pieces of cloth measuring three by three fingerbreadths, contracts impurity when in the possession of any <b>poor people</b> because poor people attach importance even to scraps of cloth of such small size. <b>Clothing of the wealthy</b> measuring at least three by three handbreadths contracts impurity in all cases, whether or not it is owned by <b>the wealthy.</b>

Daf 30a

<b>But the clothing of the wealthy</b> does <b>not</b> need to be three by three handbreadths in order to become ritually impure <b>for the poor</b> because even smaller pieces of cloth are significant for the poor. Therefore, the law with regard to the poor is not determined by the customary practice of the rich. So too, the law of <i>eiruv</i> pertaining to the rest of the world should not be determined by the customary practice of the Persians to eat roasted meat as a food in itself.
<b>And if you say:</b> Both <b>here</b> the ruling is <b>stringent,</b> and <b>there</b> the ruling is <b>stringent,</b> i.e., with regard to ritual impurity the <i>halakha</i> is stringent with respect to the poor and declares scraps of cloth that are only three by three fingerbreadths impure, but with regard to <i>eiruv</i> the <i>halakha</i> requires enough roasted meat to suffice for two meals as a food in its own right, in accordance with the practice of the Persians, then there is a difficulty: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for an ill or elderly</b> person <b>with</b> an amount of <b>food that is enough for him</b> for two meals, and if he eats less than the average person due to his sickness or age, a smaller amount of food is required in order to establish an <i>eiruv</i> on his behalf; <b>however, for a glutton,</b> we do not require food in an amount that would satisfy him but merely enough food for two meals measured according to <b>an average meal for the typical person?</b> This indicates that the <i>halakha</i> with respect to an <i>eiruv</i> is lenient and not stringent. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: <b>Did Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> really <b>say this? Wasn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> pertaining to the laws of ritual impurity that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Og, king of the Bashan,</b> or any similar giant, requires an <b>opening as</b> big as <b>his full size?</b> If a person dies in a house and it is not clear how his corpse will be removed, all of the openings in the house are considered ritually impure, as the corpse might be carried out through any one of them. If the corpse can fit through some of the openings but not through others, only the larger openings are ritually impure. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says that in the case of a giant the size of Og, king of the Bashan, one opening can only prevent the others from contracting impurity if it is large enough for Og’s corpse to fit through. This indicates that the law is determined by the measure of each particular person and not by some general measure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>Abaye</b> say? How does he reconcile his position with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>, which maintains that we follow the customary practice of most of the world and not that of particular locales, with Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar’s ruling with regard to the corpse of a giant? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of a giant, <b>what should we do? Should we cut</b> the corpse <b>into pieces and carry it out?</b> We have no choice but to carry it out through an opening large enough for the corpse to pass through. However, in the case of the food for the two meals of an <i>eiruv</i>, there is no such logistical constraint, and the law should be determined in accordance with the usual practice.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, or not? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that which <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Og, king of the Bashan,</b> requires <b>an opening of four</b> handbreadths in order to save the other openings in the house from becoming ritually impure. This indicates that the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>There,</b> we are dealing with a case <b>where there are many small openings, and there is</b> only <b>one that is four</b> handbreadths wide. Therefore, it may be assumed <b>with certainty that when one widens</b> one of the openings in order to remove the corpse from the house, <b>he will widen that</b> opening. Consequently, that opening is ritually impure while the others are not. However, if all the openings in the house are equal in size, they are all ritually impure, as we cannot know through which opening the corpse will be carried out.
Returning to the laws of <i>eiruv</i>, <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Rav Ashi said that Rav said: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with raw meat</b> because it can be eaten when necessary, even though it is not ordinarily regarded as food. <b>Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya said: One may</b> also <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with raw eggs.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How many</b> eggs are required for an <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: One. Sinai,</b> a nickname of Rav Yosef, <b>said: Two.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>One who vows that nourishment</b> is prohibited to him <b>is permitted</b> to eat <b>water</b> and salt. The Gemara infers from this: <b>It is</b> only <b>salt and water</b> that <b>are not considered nourishment, but all</b> other food <b>items are considered nourishment. Let us say</b> that <b>this is a refutation of</b> the position of <b>Rav and Shmuel. As it was Rav and Shmuel who both said: One only recites the blessing: Who creates</b> the various <b>kinds of nourishment, over the five species</b> of grain <b>alone,</b> but not over other types of food.
The Gemara asks a question: <b>Did we not</b> already <b>refute</b> their position <b>on one occasion</b> from a different source? The Gemara answers: Indeed, we already refuted their view, but <b>let us say</b> that <b>there is a refutation of their</b> position <b>from here as well.</b>
<b>Rav Huna said:</b> We can resolve the difficulty from the mishna by saying that it is referring to someone who vows and <b>says: Anything that nourishes</b> is prohibited <b>to me.</b> In that case, <b>it is water and salt</b> that are permitted to him, <b>as they do not nourish, but all</b> other food <b>items</b> are prohibited, as they <b>do nourish.</b> This inclusive formulation includes anything that provides even a small degree of nourishment; but the particular term <i>mazon</i>, nourishment or sustenance, used in the blessing over food, is reserved only for the five species of grain.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say: When we were following Rabbi Yoḥanan to eat of the fruits of Genosar,</b> very sweet fruits that grow in the region of the Sea of Galilee, <b>when we were</b> a group <b>of a hundred</b> people, <b>each and every</b> person <b>would take ten</b> fruits; and <b>when we were</b> a group <b>of ten, each and every</b> person <b>would take a hundred</b> fruits for him. <b>And each hundred of these</b> fruits <b>could not fit into a three-<i>se’a</i> basket. And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>would eat them all and</b> then <b>say: I swear that I have not</b> yet <b>tasted something that nourishes.</b> Didn’t we say that only water and salt are excluded from the category of things that nourish? The Gemara corrects the rendition of the story: <b>Say</b> that he said as follows: I have not tasted <b>sustaining food,</b> but fruit is certainly considered something that nourishes.
<b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If one said: <b>I swear that I shall not eat this loaf, one may</b> nonetheless <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it</b> because the food used for an <i>eiruv</i> does not have to be edible for the particular individual the <i>eiruv</i> services.
