However, if one said: <b>This loaf</b> shall be forbidden <b>to me, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it,</b> as this formulation indicates that he is prohibiting himself to use or benefit from the loaf in any manner.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based upon the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who vows</b> not to benefit <b>from a loaf, one may</b> nonetheless <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it. What, is it not</b> referring to one <b>who said:</b> This loaf shall be forbidden <b>to me?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is only is referring to a case <b>where he said:</b> I swear that I shall not eat <b>this</b> loaf.
The Gemara comments: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to understand the <i>baraita</i> in this fashion, <b>as it was taught in the latter clause: When</b> do we apply this <i>halakha</i>? Only <b>when one said: I swear that I shall not taste it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if <b>he said:</b> This loaf shall be forbidden <b>to me, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>So too, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it.</b> But <b>if so,</b> there is a difficulty. <b>Instead of teaching</b> in the continuation of the <i>baraita</i> that if one said: <b>This loaf is consecrated</b> property, <b>one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it, as one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with consecrated</b> objects, <b>let him make</b> an internal <b>distinction in the case</b> of a non-sacred loaf <b>itself</b> and state: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> Only where <b>one said:</b> I swear that I shall not eat <b>this</b> loaf. <b>But if one said:</b> This loaf shall be forbidden <b>to me, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it.</b> This indicates that Rav Huna’s understanding of the <i>baraita</i> is incorrect.
<b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: Rather, what</b> would you say, that <b>wherever</b> one <b>said:</b> This loaf shall be forbidden <b>to me, one may establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for him with it? If so, there is <b>a difficulty</b> from the <b>first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, which states: When do we say this? Only when one said: I swear that I shall not taste it. That indicates that if one said: This loaf shall be forbidden to me, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it.
The Gemara answers that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete, and it teaches the following:</b> With regard to <b>one who vows</b> not to benefit <b>from a loaf, one may</b> nonetheless <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it. And even if one said:</b> This loaf shall be forbidden <b>to me, it is as though he said: I swear that I shall not taste it.</b> Therefore, the loaf itself is only forbidden to him as food, but he can use it for the purpose of an <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara comments: <b>Nevertheless,</b> the <b>difficulty</b> remains <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He stated</b> his view <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer; as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If one said: <b>I swear that I shall not eat this loaf, one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it;</b> but if he said: <b>This loaf</b> shall be forbidden <b>to me, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rabbi Eliezer</b> really <b>say this? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This is the principle:</b> With regard to <b>a person</b> who <b>prohibits himself from</b> eating a particular <b>food,</b> e.g., if one said: I swear that I shall not eat this loaf, <b>one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with</b> that loaf. However, if the <b>food was prohibited to a person,</b> e.g., if he said: This loaf shall be forbidden to me, <b>one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If he said: <b>This loaf</b> shall be forbidden <b>to me, one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it.</b> However, if he said: <b>This loaf is consecrated</b> property, <b>one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with it, as one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for him with consecrated</b> objects. Therefore, Rabbi Eliezer does not distinguish between the two differently worded types of vows, but between a vow and consecration.
The Gemara answers: It must be explained that these are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i></b> who both held <b>according to Rabbi Eliezer.</b> Two later <i>tanna’im</i> disagreed with each other in reporting Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for a nazirite with wine</b> and for an Israelite with <i>teruma</i>, even though they themselves may not partake of these foods. The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna</b> was <b>not</b> taught <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Beit Shammai say: One may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for a nazirite with wine and for an Israelite with <i>teruma</i>. Beit Hillel</b> disagree and <b>say: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for a nazirite with wine and for an Israelite with <i>teruma</i>. Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: Do you not concede</b>

Daf 30b

<b>that one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for an adult</b> even <b>on Yom Kippur,</b> despite the fact that he may not eat on Yom Kippur? It must be because eating is permitted to a minor.
Beit Shammai <b>said to them: Indeed [<i>aval</i>],</b> it is so. Beit Hillel <b>said to them: Just as one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for an adult on Yom Kippur, so</b> too, <b>one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for a nazirite with wine and for an Israelite with <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>And</b> how do <b>Beit Shammai</b> explain the difference between these cases? The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> with regard to Yom Kippur, <b>there is</b> at least <b>a meal that was fit</b> to be eaten by that person <b>while it was still day,</b> on the eve of Yom Kippur. <b>Here,</b> in the cases of wine for a nazirite and <i>teruma</i> for an Israelite, <b>there is no meal that was fit</b> to be eaten by them <b>while it was still day,</b> on Friday.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion was that entire <i>baraita</i> stated? It was <b>not</b> taught <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya, as it was taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥananya says: The whole</b> view <b>of Beit Shammai,</b> i.e., their fundamental position, was that <b>they did not concede to</b> the very possibility of <b>joining</b> Shabbat borders [<i>eiruv teḥumin</i>] by simply placing food in a particular location. Rather, they hold that one’s Shabbat residence remains the same <b>until</b> he literally moves his residence, such as if <b>he carries out his bed and his utensils to there,</b> to a new location.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is</b> the ruling <b>that was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one established an <i>eiruv</i> in black</b> clothing, and Shabbat commenced while he was still dressed those clothes, <b>he may not go out in white</b> clothing. If one established the <i>eiruv</i> while dressed <b>in white, he may not go out in black. According to whose</b> opinion is this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya, and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya,</b> is it <b>with black</b> clothing that <b>he may not go out, but in white</b> clothing <b>he may go out? Didn’t</b> Ḥananya <b>say</b> that according to Beit Shammai an <i>eiruv</i> is not effective at all <b>until one carries out his bed and his utensils</b> to the place he wishes to establish as his residence? The Gemara answers: The wording of the <i>baraita</i> must be emended and <b>this is what it said:</b> If <b>one established an <i>eiruv</i></b> while dressed <b>in white</b> clothing, <b>and he needed black</b> clothing but did not have it with him, <b>he may not go out even in white</b> clothing. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion was this <i>baraita</i> taught? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya, and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>Summakhos</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> One may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for an Israelite with <i>teruma</i>, but only <b>with</b> regular, <b>non-sacred</b> food items. The Gemara notes: <b>But</b> with regard to the mishna’s ruling that an <i>eiruv</i> may be established for <b>a nazirite with wine,</b> Summakhos <b>does not</b> appear to <b>disagree. What is the reason</b> for the distinction? The Gemara explains: A nazirite <b>can ask</b> a Sage to annul his vow and release him from <b>his nazirite status,</b> and then he himself will be able to drink the wine.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> in the case of <b><i>teruma</i> as well, one can ask</b> a Sage to annul <b>its</b> status. <i>Teruma</i> is consecrated through a verbal declaration by the one separating it, and that declaration, like other consecrations and vows, can be nullified by a Sage. The Gemara answers: Such a course of action would not help. <b>If one asks</b> a Sage to annul his declaration that turned the produce into <i>teruma</i>, the produce <b>will return to</b> its status as <b><i>tevel</i>,</b> produce from which the requisite dues and tithes were not separated, and he will still be prohibited to consume it.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let him separate</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>for</b> that produce <b>from</b> produce located <b>somewhere else</b> and thus permit it to be eaten. The Gemara answers: <b><i>Ḥaverim</i>,</b> members of a group dedicated to the precise observance of mitzvot, <b>are not suspected of separating</b> <i>teruma</i> from produce that is <b>not</b> situated <b>near</b> the produce it comes to exempt, as this is prohibited <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let him separate</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>from</b> the produce used for the <i>eiruv</i> <b>itself</b> and consequently permit the rest of the produce to be eaten. The Gemara answers: We are dealing with a case <b>where,</b> after removing <i>teruma</i>, <b>it would not contain the amount</b> required for an <i>eiruv</i>, i.e., one would be left with less than the quantity of food sufficient for two meals.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> makes it <b>necessary</b> to say that the mishna is referring to this very unique case? <b>Rather,</b> we must retract all that was stated above and say as follows: <b>Summakhos agrees with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say: Anything that is</b> prohibited on Shabbat <b>due to a rabbinic decree [<i>shevut</i>],</b> the Sages <b>issued the decree</b> to apply even <b>during twilight.</b> Even though this period is of questionable status with regard to whether it is day or night, the Shabbat restrictions instituted by the Sages apply then as they do on Shabbat itself. Consequently, since it is prohibited to separate <i>teruma</i> on Shabbat, it is prohibited during the twilight period as well. Therefore, during twilight, when the <i>eiruv</i> would go into effect, it is impossible to cause it to become permitted to an Israelite.
The Gemara now asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is</b> the ruling <b>that we learned</b> in the following mishna: <b>There are</b> <i>halakhot</i> with regard to which <b>they stated</b> that measures <b>are all in accordance with the</b> particular <b>person</b> involved, e.g., <b>the handful of</b> flour that a priest scoops out from <b>a meal-offering, and the handfuls of incense</b> the High Priest would offer on Yom Kippur, <b>and one who drinks a cheekful on Yom Kippur, and with regard to the</b> measure of <b>two meals’</b> worth of <b>nourishment for an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> All these measures are determined by the particular individual involved. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rabbi Zeira said: It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Summakhos, who said: We require that which is fit for him,</b> the particular individual, and we do not follow a standard measure.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the aforementioned mishna <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for an ill or elderly</b> person <b>with</b> an amount of <b>food that is enough for him</b> for two meals; and if he eats less than the average amount due to his sickness or age, a smaller amount of food is sufficient. <b>But for a glutton</b> we do not require food in an amount that would satisfy him; we measure on the basis of <b>an average meal for the typical person.</b>
The Gemara answers: When the mishna says that the measure of food for two meals is determined by the particular person involved, <b>interpret</b> that as referring to <b>an ill or elderly</b> person. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a glutton,</b> we do not determine the measure of food by his standard for a different reason, namely because <b>his opinion is rendered irrelevant by the opinions of all other people.</b> Therefore, there is no reason to be stringent with him and determine the measure according to his particular needs.
We learned in the mishna: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>for a priest in a <i>beit haperas</i>,</b> an area in which there is doubt concerning the location of a grave or a corpse. The Gemara explains that the reason for this is as <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In a time of need <b>a person may blow</b> on the dust in a <b><i>beit haperas</i></b> before taking each step, so that if there is a bone beneath the dust he will expose it and avoid it, <b>and</b> he may thus <b>walk</b> across the area. Similarly, <b>Rabbi Yehuda bar Ami said in the name of Rav Yehuda: A <i>beit haperas</i> that has been trodden</b> underfoot, creating a path, <b>is pure,</b> as we assume that it no longer contains any bones as large as a kernel of barley. Both of these statements indicate that the ritual impurity of a <i>beit haperas</i> is a stringency decreed by the Sages. Therefore, since there is a way to avoid becoming ritually impure there, even a priest may place his <i>eiruv</i> in a <i>beit haperas</i>.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> An <i>eiruv</i> may be established for a priest <b>even</b> in <b>a cemetery,</b> an area which the priest may not enter by Torah law. <b>It was taught:</b> This is permitted <b>because</b> the priest <b>can interpose and walk</b> between the graves inside <b>a carriage, a crate, or a cupboard.</b> These containers do not contract impurity because of their large size, and anything found inside of them remains pure. From here we see that <b>he holds</b> the following: <b>A moving tent is called a tent,</b> and therefore the carriage, box, or cupboard are also considered tents. They shield a person carried in them from the impurity imparted by the graves in a cemetery.
The Gemara notes that this matter is the subject of <b>a dispute between the following <i>tanna’im</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who enters the land of the nations,</b> i.e., any territory outside Eretz Yisrael, not on foot, but <b>in a carriage, a crate, or a cupboard, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>renders</b> him ritually <b>impure. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, renders</b> him <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <b>a moving tent is not called a tent.</b> The principle is that only something fixed can shield against ritual impurity, but if one is situated inside a portable vessel, the vessel contracts impurity and he becomes impure along with it. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>a moving tent is called a tent,</b> and it shields the person inside from contracting ritual impurity.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b>

Daf 31a

<b>One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for a priest who is</b> ritually <b>pure with <i>teruma</i> that is</b> ritually <b>pure</b> and resting <b>on a grave,</b> even though the location is impure and he cannot reach it. <b>How does he go</b> there? <b>In a carriage, crate, or cupboard,</b> which shield him from the ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> it true that <b>once</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>was placed</b> directly on the grave, the <i>teruma</i> <b>became defiled,</b> and ritually impure <i>teruma</i> is not fit to be eaten by anyone? The Gemara answers: We are dealing here with a case <b>where</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>had not yet been rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, as it had not yet come into contact with a liquid. Produce that has yet to come into contact with a liquid does not contract impurity. <b>Or</b> we are dealing with bread <b>that was kneaded with fruit juice,</b> which is not one of the seven liquids that render a food susceptible to ritual impurity.
The Gemara now asks: <b>How can he bring it</b> from where it is resting on the grave in order to eat it? The Gemara answers: <b>With flat wooden utensils</b> that are not shaped as receptacles and therefore <b>do not contract</b> ritual <b>impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Doesn’t</b> the utensil <b>cover</b> the grave? The Sages decreed that anyone who holds a utensil that is a handbreadth wide over a corpse or grave is ritually impure. The Gemara answers: <b>He may bring it on the edge</b> of the utensil while holding the utensil sideways so that it does not form a cover that is a handbreadth wide over the grave.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> that is <b>so,</b> and there is a way for the <i>teruma</i> to remain ritually pure and for the priest to access it, <b>what is the reason</b> the Sages disagreed with Rabbi Yehuda and did not allow an <i>eiruv</i> to be established for a priest on a grave? The Gemara answers: <b>They hold</b> that <b>it is prohibited to acquire a home with items from which benefit is prohibited.</b> It is prohibited to derive benefit from a grave. Since one acquires a place of residence for Shabbat by means of the <i>eiruv</i>, it would be as if the priest acquired a home for himself with something from which he may not derive benefit.
The Gemara asks: If so, does this prove <b>by inference that Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>it is permitted</b> to acquire a home with items from which benefit is prohibited? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda <b>holds</b> that <b>mitzvot were not given for benefit.</b> The fulfillment of a mitzva is not in itself considered a benefit. Since the acquisition of a place of residence by means of an <i>eiruv</i> is a mitzva, as one may establish an <i>eiruv teḥumin</i> only for the sake of a mitzva, it is even permitted to establish one’s <i>eiruv</i> in a place from which it is prohibited to benefit.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> if so, with regard to <b>that which Rava said: Mitzvot were not given for benefit, let us say</b> that <b>he stated his <i>halakha</i></b> only <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of one side in a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you: If they hold that one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> only for the sake of a mitzva, all would agree</b> that the <i>eiruv</i> may be placed on a grave because <b>mitzvot were not given for benefit.</b> However, the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Sages centers on a different aspect of the issue. <b>Here, they disagree with regard to this: One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> only for the sake of a mitzva.</b> Since mitzvot do not constitute forbidden benefit, it is therefore permitted to make use of the grave. <b>And one Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> even for a voluntary matter.</b> Establishing a Shabbat residence on the site of a grave by means of an <i>eiruv</i> made for a voluntary matter is regarded as forbidden benefit, and therefore it is prohibited.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> if so, with regard to <b>that which Rav Yosef said</b> as a general principle: <b>One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> only for the sake of a mitzva, let us say</b> that <b>he stated his <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> one side in a dispute between the <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Yosef</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> In fact, <b>all agree</b> that <b>one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> only for the sake of a mitzva, and all agree</b> that <b>mitzvot were not given for benefit, and they disagree with regard to this: One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds: Once</b> he <b>acquired his</b> Shabbat residence at twilight by means of the <b><i>eiruv</i>, he is indifferent to its safeguarding,</b> as his main goal has already been achieved. He has no further need for the food used for the <i>eiruv</i>, and therefore, he receives no benefit from its placement on the grave. <b>And one Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds: It is pleasing to him that</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>is safeguarded, for if he needs</b> it the next day, <b>he can eat it.</b> According to this opinion, he would be making prohibited use of the grave to preserve his meal for the following day, and therefore the Sages prohibited placing an <i>eiruv</i> on a grave.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with <i>demai</i>,</b> produce purchased from one who may not have separated the required tithes, <b>and</b> similarly, one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with</b> the <b>first tithe whose <i>teruma</i> has been taken</b> in order to be given to a priest, <b>and with</b> the <b>second tithe and consecrated articles that have been redeemed; and priests</b> may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the portion of dough that must be given to a priest.
<b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with <i>tevel</i>,</b> produce from which the priestly dues [<i>teruma</i>] and other tithes have not been separated, <b>nor with first tithe whose <i>teruma</i>,</b> which must be given to a priest, <b>has not been taken, nor with</b> the <b>second tithe or consecrated articles that have not been redeemed.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: How can one establish an <i>eiruv</i> with <b><i>demai</i>? Isn’t it unfit for him?</b> Since it is prohibited to eat <i>demai</i>, how can it be used as an <i>eiruv</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Since if he wants, he could declare his property ownerless, and he would be a poor</b> person, <b>and</b> the <i>demai</i> would then <b>be fit for him,</b> as a poor person is permitted to eat <i>demai</i>, <b>now too,</b> even though he has not renounced ownership of his property, <b>it is</b> considered <b>fit for him</b> to use as an <i>eiruv</i>. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One may feed the poor <i>demai</i>,</b>

Daf 31b

<b>and</b> one may also feed <b>soldiers <i>demai</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Huna said: It was taught</b> that <b>Beit Shammai say: One may not feed the impoverished <i>demai</i>. And Beit Hillel say: One may feed the impoverished <i>demai</i>.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel.
We learned in the mishna: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with first tithe</b> whose <i>teruma</i> <b>has been taken.</b> The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>It is obvious</b> that if the <i>teruma</i> was already taken there is no problem. Why is it necessary to state it may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>It is only necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in a case where the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest while the grain was still <b>on the stalks,</b> i.e., the Levite took his tithe before the grain was threshed and before the priest took the <i>teruma</i>; <b>and the <i>teruma</i> of the tithes was taken from it</b> but <b><i>teruma gedola</i> was not taken from it.</b> Therefore, since the <i>teruma</i> is generally separated first, a portion of the first tithe that the Levite took should have been separated as <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion that <b>Rabbi Abbahu</b> said that <b>Reish Lakish said, as Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish said: First tithe,</b> in a case <b>where</b> the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest while the grain was still <b>on the stalks, is exempt from <i>teruma gedola</i>, as it is stated: “And you shall set apart from it a gift for the Lord, even a tenth part of the tithe”</b> (Numbers 18:26), from which the following inference is made: <b>A tenth part of the tithe,</b> i.e., the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <b>I told you,</b> the Levite, to separate. <b>And</b> I did <b>not</b> tell you to separate <b><i>teruma gedola</i> and the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe.</b>
With regard to this matter, <b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: If so, even</b> if the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest after the kernels of grain were removed from the stalks and placed <b>in a pile,</b> the Levite should still not have to separate <i>teruma gedola</i>. Abaye <b>said to him: With regard to your</b> claim, <b>the verse states: “From all that is given to you, you shall set apart that which is the Lord’s <i>teruma</i>”</b> (Numbers 18:29). The inclusive phrase “from all” indicates that <i>teruma gedola</i> must be separated even from the first tithe in the case where the Levite precedes the priest after the grain has been collected in a pile.
Rav Pappa asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you to expound one verse as exempting the Levite from separating <i>teruma gedola</i> from first tithe that has been separated while the grain was on the stalks, and to expound another verse as requiring <i>teruma gedola</i> to be separated when the Levite took his first tithe after the grain was collected in a pile? Abaye answers: <b>This</b> produce, which has been threshed and placed into piles, is completely processed and <b>has become grain, and that</b> produce, which remained on the stalks, <b>did not</b> yet <b>become grain.</b> The wording of the biblical verses indicates that the requirement to separate <i>teruma</i> applies only to grain, whereas the produce is not considered grain until it has been threshed.
The mishna also stated that one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with</b> the <b>second tithe and consecrated</b> food <b>that have been redeemed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>It is obvious</b> that these foods may be used to establish an <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara answers: This ruling <b>was only needed</b> for a case <b>where one</b> redeemed the second tithe or consecrated food and <b>paid the principle but did not pay the</b> additional <b>fifth</b> of their value, which must be paid when they are redeemed. <b>And</b> the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the failure to pay <b>the</b> additional <b>fifth does not invalidate</b> the redemption. Once the principle is paid, even if payment of the additional fifth is still outstanding, the article is regarded as redeemed and may be used for mundane purposes.
The mishna further states: <b>But</b> one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with <i>tevel</i>,</b> produce from which the priestly dues and other tithes have not been separated. The Gemara asks: This too is <b>obvious,</b> as it is prohibited to eat or derive any benefit from <i>tevel</i>. The Gemara answers: This ruling <b>is only needed with regard to <i>tevel</i> that is considered <i>tevel</i> by rabbinic decree.</b> What is included in this category? <b>For example, if one planted</b> seeds <b>in an imperforated container,</b> one is exempt by Torah law from separating <i>teruma</i> and tithes from the resulting produce because Torah law does not consider produce grown in such a container to have grown from the ground.
The mishna stated that one may <b>not</b> establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with first tithe whose <i>teruma</i> has not been taken.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>It is obvious,</b> as such produce is <i>tevel</i>. The Gemara answers: This ruling <b>is only needed</b> for a case where the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest and took first tithe from <b>the pile, and</b> only <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe was taken from it,</b> but <b><i>teruma gedola</i> was not taken from it,</b> and the produce is therefore still <i>tevel</i>.
<b>Lest you say</b> the <i>halakha</i> in that case is <b>as Rav Pappa said to Abaye,</b> and the Levite is exempt from separating <i>teruma gedola</i>, and therefore the food may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, the mishna <b>teaches us as</b> Abaye <b>responded to</b> Rav Pappa: If the Levite takes grain after it had been gathered in a pile, he must separate <i>teruma gedola</i>. Until he does so the produce may not be eaten.
We also learned in the mishna that one may <b>not</b> establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with</b> the <b>second tithe or consecrated</b> food <b>that have not been redeemed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>It is obvious</b> that these items may not be used.
The Gemara answers: This ruling <b>is only needed</b> for a case <b>where he redeemed them,</b> but <b>did not redeem them properly,</b> e.g., in the case of <b>second tithe that was redeemed with an unminted coin [<i>asimon</i>]. And the Torah says</b> with regard to the redemption of the second tithe: <b>And bind up [<i>vetzarta</i>] the money</b> in your hand” (Deuteronomy 14:25). This is expounded to mean that the second tithe may only be redeemed with <b>money that has a form [<i>tzura</i>]</b> engraved <b>upon it;</b> however, unminted coins are not considered money for the purpose of redeeming the second tithe.
With regard to <b>consecrated property,</b> the reference is to a case <b>where one redeemed it</b> by exchanging it <b>for land</b> instead of money, <b>as the Torah states: “He will give the money and it shall become his.”</b> Since the verse speaks of giving money, it may be inferred that consecrated property cannot be redeemed by giving the Temple treasury land of equivalent value.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one sends his <i>eiruv</i> in the hands of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor,</b> all of whom are regarded as legally incompetent, <b>or in the hands of one who does not accept</b> the principle of <b><i>eiruv</i>, it is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> But <b>if one told another</b> person <b>to receive it from him</b> at a specific location and set it down in that spot, <b>it is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> The critical point in the establishment of an <i>eiruv</i> is that it must be deposited in the proper location by a competent person; but it is immaterial how the <i>eiruv</i> arrives there.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Is a minor not</b> fit to set down an <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Didn’t Rav Huna say: A minor may collect the</b> food for an <b><i>eiruv</i></b> from the residents of a courtyard and establish an <i>eiruv</i> on their behalf even <i>ab initio</i>? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>here,</b> where the mishna invalidates an <i>eiruv</i> placed by a minor, it is referring <b>to an <i>eiruv</i> of</b> Shabbat <b>borders.</b> These laws are relatively stringent, as they require that one establish a new place of residence, which a minor cannot do. <b>There,</b> where Rav Huna said that a minor may collect the food for an <i>eiruv</i>, he was referring <b>to an <i>eiruv</i> of courtyards.</b> This type of <i>eiruv</i> is more lenient and may be established even by a minor, as all that is necessary is to join together domains that already exist.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Or</b> if one sends his <i>eiruv</i> <b>in the hands of one who does not accept</b> the principle of <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is this? <b>Rav Ḥisda said: A Samaritan [<i>Kuti</i>],</b> who does not accept the laws of the Sages with regard to <i>eiruv</i>.
The mishna also states: <b>And if he told another</b> person <b>to receive</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>from him, it is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara challenges this statement: <b>Let us be concerned that perhaps</b> the minor or other incompetent person will <b>not bring</b> the <i>eiruv</i> to the other person. The Gemara responds: This may be answered <b>as Rav Ḥisda said</b> with regard to a different statement, that it was referring to a case <b>where he stands and watches him. Here, too,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the person sending the <i>eiruv</i> <b>stands and watches him</b> from afar until the <i>eiruv</i> reaches the person designated to receive it.
The Gemara asks: But nonetheless, <b>let us be concerned that perhaps</b> the other person will <b>not take</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>from</b> the deaf-mute, imbecile, or minor and deposit it in the designated place. From a distance, one cannot see exactly what is happening. He only saw that the messenger arrived at his destination. The Gemara answers this question <b>as</b> follows: <b>Rav Yeḥiel said</b> in a different context that there is a legal <b>presumption</b> that <b>an agent fulfills his agency. Here, too,</b> there is a legal <b>presumption</b> that the <b>agent</b> appointed to accept the <i>eiruv</i> <b>fulfills his agency.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Where were</b> these principles of <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rav Yeḥiel stated?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They were stated with regard to</b> the following, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one gave</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>to</b> a trained <b>elephant, and it brought it</b> to the place where he wanted the <i>eiruv</i> deposited, or if he gave it <b>to a monkey, and it brought it</b> to the proper location, <b>it is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>. But if he told another</b> person <b>to receive it from</b> the animal, <b>it is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> the animal <b>will not bring</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>to</b> the person appointed to receive it? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a case <b>where</b> the person sending the <i>eiruv</i> <b>stands and watches it</b> from afar until it reaches the person designated to receive the <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara asks further: But <b>perhaps</b> the person appointed to receive the <i>eiruv</i> <b>will not accept it from</b> the elephant or monkey. <b>Rav Yeḥiel said:</b> There is a legal <b>presumption</b> that <b>an agent fulfills his agency.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said: With regard to Torah</b> laws, we do <b>not</b> rely on the <b>presumption that an agent fulfills his agency;</b> rather, one must actually see the agent performing his mission.

Daf 32a

However, <b>with regard to rabbinic</b> laws, we do rely on the <b>presumption</b> that <b>an agent fulfills his agency. And Rav Sheshet</b> disagreed and <b>said:</b> With regard to <b>both this,</b> Torah law, <b>and that,</b> rabbinic law, we rely on the <b>presumption</b> that <b>an agent fulfills his agency.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet said: From where do I say this? As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Once the <i>omer</i> has been offered,</b> the grain from <b>the new crop is immediately permitted.</b> The Torah prohibits eating from the new crop of grain until the <i>omer</i> sacrifice is offered on the second day of Passover (Leviticus 23:14); once the <i>omer</i> is offered, it is immediately permitted to partake of the new grain.
<b>And those far</b> from Jerusalem, who do not know whether or not the <i>omer</i> has already been offered, <b>are permitted</b> to eat from the new crop <b>from midday and on,</b> as the <i>omer</i> must surely have been offered by this time. <b>Isn’t</b> the prohibition to eat from <b>the new</b> crop <b>a Torah law? And</b> nevertheless, <b>it was taught: And those far</b> from Jerusalem <b>are permitted</b> to eat from the new crop <b>from midday and on. Is this not because</b> we may rely on the <b>presumption</b> that <b>an agent fulfills his agency?</b> The priests in the Temple serve as the agents of the entire Jewish people, and it may be assumed that they have performed the mission entrusted to them.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rav Naḥman,</b> who holds that with respect to Torah laws we may not rely on the presumption that an agent fulfills his agency, refute this proof? He can respond as follows: <b>There,</b> the agents may be trusted for <b>the reason that was</b> explicitly <b>taught: Because we know that the court will not be indolent</b> in offering the <i>omer</i> sacrifice; however, the same cannot be said of ordinary agents.
<b>And some say</b> a different version of this response: <b>Rav Naḥman said: From where do I say this</b> principle? <b>As it was taught</b> that <b>the reason</b> is <b>because we know that the court will not be indolent</b> in offering the <i>omer</i> past midday. From this we may infer: <b>It is the court</b> that <b>will not be indolent</b> with regard to missions entrusted to it, <b>but</b> an ordinary <b>agent may</b> indeed <b>be indolent</b> with regard to his mission. Therefore, we cannot rely upon an ordinary agent.
<b>And Rav Sheshet</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that this is not the correct inference; rather, we should infer as follows: It is only <b>the court</b> that is presumed to have executed its mission <b>by midday,</b> even though the mitzva to bring the <i>omer</i> offering lasts all day. However, an ordinary <b>agent,</b> who is not as diligent, is only presumed to have completed his mission by the end of <b>the entire day.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet said: From where do I say</b> my opinion? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woman who is responsible</b> to offer sacrifices following <b>childbirth or</b> after experiencing <b><i>ziva</i></b> (Leviticus 12, 15) <b>brings money and puts it in</b> the appropriate collection <b>box</b> in the Temple, <b>immerses</b> in a ritual bath, <b>and</b> she may then <b>eat sacrificial food at nightfall. What is the reason</b> that she is permitted to eat immediately at nightfall? <b>Is it not because we say</b> that there is a <b>presumption</b> that <b>an agent fulfills his agency,</b> and the priests certainly purchased the appropriate sacrifices with her money and offered them during the day?
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rav Naḥman</b> counter this proof? <b>There,</b> in the case of a woman who put money in the box, the reason she may rely on agency is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Shemaya, as Rav Shemaya said:</b> There is a legal <b>presumption</b> that <b>the court of priests would not leave</b> the Temple <b>until all the money in the</b> collection <b>box has been spent</b> on the purchase of sacrifices. We may rely only on the special court appointed to carry out this task, as it can be trusted. However, no proof may be brought from here with regard to an ordinary agent.
<b>Rav Sheshet said</b> another proof: <b>From where do I say this? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who says to another</b> person: <b>Go and gather for yourself figs from my fig tree,</b> if he does not specify the amount that he should take, the gatherer <b>may eat casually from them</b> even without separating tithes. However, if one wishes to eat the figs as a regular, set meal, <b>he must</b> first <b>tithe them</b> as fruit that is known <b>with certainty</b> not to previously be tithed. In this case, it may be assumed that the owner of the fig tree did not separate tithes to exempt these figs, as he did not know how many the gatherer would take. However, if the owner of the fig tree said to him: <b>Fill this basket for yourself with figs from my fig tree, he may eat from them casually</b> without tithing, <b>and</b> before eating them as a regular meal, <b>he must tithe them</b> as <b><i>demai</i>,</b> produce with regard to which we are unsure if the appropriate tithes have been separated. Since the owner of the tree knows how many figs the gatherer will take, it is possible that he has already separated tithes for these figs.
<b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> Where the owner of the fig tree is <b>an <i>am ha’aretz</i>. But</b> if he is <b>a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> the gatherer <b>may eat</b> the figs, <b>and he need not tithe</b> them even as <i>demai</i>, as the owner certainly separated tithes for them from other produce; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. His father, <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, says</b> the opposite: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> Where the owner of the fig tree is an <b><i>am ha’aretz</i>. But</b> if he is <b>a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> the gatherer <b>may not eat</b> the fruit <b>until he tithes</b> them <b>because <i>ḥaverim</i>,</b> who are meticulous in their observance of <i>halakha</i>, <b>are not suspected of separating <i>teruma</i></b> and tithes <b>from</b> produce that is <b>not adjacent</b> to the produce they seek to exempt. Since the figs that have been picked are not adjacent to the owner’s other figs, he has certainly not separated <i>teruma</i> and tithes on their account.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: My statement appears</b> to be more correct <b>than Father’s statement: It is better that <i>ḥaverim</i> should be suspected of separating</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>from</b> produce that is <b>not adjacent</b> to the produce they seek to exempt, <b>and they should not feed <i>amei ha’aretz</i></b> produce that is <b><i>tevel</i>.</b>
The Gemara infers: The <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagreed only</b> with regard to the following point: <b>That one Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <i>ḥaverim</i> <b>are suspected</b> of tithing with produce that is not adjacent to the produce it comes to exempt, <b>and one Sage,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>holds</b> that <b>they are not suspected</b> of that. <b>But all</b> agree that we may rely on the <b>presumption</b> that <b>an agent fulfills his agency,</b> i.e., that the owner, who is regarded as an agent to tithe his produce so that no one will eat <i>tevel</i> on his account, can be relied upon to separate the tithes.
<b>And Rav Naḥman</b> can respond as follows: <b>There,</b> the owner can be trusted, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Ḥanina Ḥoza’a, as Rav Ḥanina Ḥoza’a said: There is</b> a legal <b>presumption with regard to a <i>ḥaver</i> that he does not release anything that is not tithed from his possession.</b> Therefore, we are not relying on a general presumption with regard to agents but on a presumption with regard to <i>ḥaverim</i>.
The previous <i>baraita</i> contained several puzzling elements. Now that the Gemara has completed its primary discussion, namely the presumption that an agent carries out his mission, it turns to a discussion of the <i>baraita</i> itself. <b>The Master said:</b> If one said to his fellow: Go and gather for yourself figs, <b>in what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is in a case where the owner of the fig tree is <b>an <i>am ha’aretz</i>. However,</b> if he is <b>a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> the gatherer <b>may eat</b> the figs, <b>and he need not tithe</b> them; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara asks: <b>This <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> who addressed his fellow man, <b>to whom did he speak? If you say that he spoke to his fellow <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> if so, how are we to understand the statement that follows: <b>He must tithe them as <i>demai</i>? Would</b> an <i>am ha’aretz</i> <b>comply</b> with the admonition of the Sages to suspect that the produce of his fellow <i>am ha’aretz</i> may not have been tithed? <b>Rather,</b> this must be referring <b>to an <i>am ha’aretz</i> who told a <i>ḥaver</i></b> to gather figs from his fig tree, and the <i>ḥaver</i> will certainly tithe them. However, <b>say</b> that <b>the latter clause</b> of this <i>baraita</i>: <b>My statement appears</b> to be more correct <b>than Father’s statement,</b> means the following: <b>It is better that <i>ḥaverim</i> should be suspected of separating</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>from</b> produce that is <b>not adjacent</b> to the produce they seek to exempt, <b>and they should not feed <i>amei ha’aretz</i></b> produce that is <b><i>tevel</i>. What is the relevance of <i>amei ha’aretz</i> there?</b> According to that explanation, the situation is the opposite. The person eating the figs is a <i>ḥaver</i>, and the owner of the fig tree is an <i>am ha’aretz</i>.
<b>Ravina said: The first clause</b> is referring <b>to an <i>am ha’aretz</i> who spoke to a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> while <b>the latter clause</b> is referring <b>to a <i>ḥaver</i> who spoke to an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, and a different <i>ḥaver</i> heard him</b> speak, and the discussion relates not to the one gathering the figs but to whether the second <i>ḥaver</i> may partake of the figs if they are offered to him. The Gemara explains the disagreement according to this understanding: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi

Daf 32b

<b>holds: That <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> who heard the first <i>ḥaver</i> speaking to the <i>am ha’aretz</i>, <b>may</b> immediately <b>eat</b> from the basket, <b>and he is not required to tithe</b> the produce, <b>as the first <i>ḥaver</i> certainly separated tithes for</b> the person who picked the figs, as he would not have caused an <i>am ha’aretz</i> to eat <i>tevel</i>. <b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> That <i>ḥaver</i> <b>may not eat</b> of the fruit <b>until he has tithed</b> them, <b>for <i>ḥaverim</i> are not suspected of separating</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>from</b> produce that is <b>not adjacent</b> to the produce they seek to exempt. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: It is better that <i>ḥaverim</i> should be suspected of separating</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>from</b> produce that is <b>not adjacent</b> to the produce they seek to exempt, <b>and they should not feed <i>amei ha’aretz</i></b> produce that is <b><i>tevel</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds: It is preferable to a <i>ḥaver</i> that he commit a minor transgression,</b> namely separating tithes from produce that is not adjacent to the produce they seek to exempt, so that <b>an <i>am ha’aretz</i> will not commit</b> the <b>major transgression</b> of eating <i>tevel</i> on his account. <b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds: It is preferable to a <i>ḥaver</i> that an <i>am ha’aretz</i> commit a major transgression, and that he</b> himself <b>not commit even a minor transgression.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one placed</b> his <i>eiruv</i> <b>in a tree above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>;</b> if it is <b>below ten handbreadths, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> If <b>he placed</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>in a pit, even</b> if <b>it was a hundred cubits deep, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba sat, and</b> with him sat <b>Rabbi Asi and Rava bar Natan, and Rav Naḥman sat beside them, and they sat and said: This tree</b> mentioned in the mishna, <b>where does it stand? If you say it stands in the private domain, what</b> is the difference <b>to me</b> whether the <i>eiruv</i> is placed <b>above</b> ten handbreadths or <b>below</b> ten handbreadths? <b>The private domain ascends to the sky,</b> and there is no difference whether an object is above or below ten handbreadths.
<b>Rather,</b> say <b>that</b> the tree <b>stands in the public domain;</b> but in that case the question arises: <b>Where</b> did the person <b>intend to establish his Shabbat residence? If you say that</b> he <b>intended to</b> establish his <b>Shabbat residence</b> in the tree <b>above, he and his <i>eiruv</i> are in one place.</b> Consequently, the <i>eiruv</i> should be valid, even if is at a height of more than ten handbreadths. <b>Rather,</b> say that he <b>intended to establish his Shabbat residence</b> on the ground <b>below;</b> but <b>isn’t he making use of the tree</b> if he accesses his <i>eiruv</i>? It is prohibited to make use of a tree on Shabbat, and therefore his <i>eiruv</i> should invalid even if it is less than ten handbreadths above the ground because it is inaccessible to him.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> we can accept the latter assumption <b>that</b> the tree <b>stands in the public domain, and that he intended to establish his Shabbat residence</b> on the ground <b>below,</b> in the public domain. <b>And</b> with regard to the prohibition against making use of a tree, this mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said: Anything that is</b> prohibited on Shabbat not by Torah law, but rather <b>due to a rabbinic decree [<i>shevut</i>],</b> the Sages <b>did not issue the decree</b> to apply <b>during twilight,</b> which is neither definitively day nor definitively night. Since using a tree is only prohibited due to a <i>shevut</i>, it is permitted to make use of the tree and remove one’s <i>eiruv</i> from it during the twilight period, which is when the <i>eiruv</i> establishes the person’s Shabbat residence. Therefore, the <i>eiruv</i> is valid, provided that it is below ten handbreadths. If, however, the <i>eiruv</i> is above ten handbreadths, it is invalid. At that height, removing the <i>eiruv</i> from the tree entails violation of the Torah prohibition of carrying from a private domain to a public domain, which is prohibited even during twilight.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to them: Well</b> said, <b>and Shmuel said similarly</b> with regard to this issue. <b>They said to him: Have you,</b> the Sages of Babylonia, <b>gone so far in your explanation</b> of the mishna? The Gemara asks: Why were the Sages of Eretz Yisrael so surprised? <b>They, too, explained</b> the mishna <b>in this</b> manner. <b>Rather, this is what they said to</b> Rav Naḥman: <b>Have you established this</b> explanation <b>as part of your</b> regular <b>study</b> of the mishna? <b>He said to them: Yes.</b> Indeed, <b>it was also</b> explicitly <b>stated</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Here, we are dealing with a tree standing in the public domain,</b> and the tree is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide.</b> It thereby constitutes a private domain, <b>and</b> one <b>intended to establish his Shabbat residence below</b> in the public domain. <b>And</b> the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said: Anything that is</b> prohibited on Shabbat not by Torah law, but rather <b>due to a rabbinic decree,</b> the Sages <b>did not issue the decree</b> to apply <b>during twilight.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> in continuation of this discussion: <b>They only taught</b> this law <b>with regard to a tree that stands beyond the outskirts of the city,</b> i.e., outside a radius of seventy and two-thirds cubits around the city. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a tree that stands within the outskirts of the city, even</b> if the <i>eiruv</i> was placed <b>above ten</b> handbreadths, <b>it is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>, as the city is considered as though it were filled in</b> with earth, so that anything located at any height within the town itself or its outskirts is regarded as being in the same domain. Even though the person intended to establish his Shabbat residence below the tree in the public domain, we view the ground as raised to the height of the <i>eiruv</i>, and his <i>eiruv</i> is therefore valid even though he cannot actually remove it from the tree during the twilight period.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if the tree stood <b>beyond the outskirts of the town,</b> there should <b>also</b> be no difference whether the <i>eiruv</i> is above or below the height of ten handbreadths. <b>Since Rava</b> himself <b>said: One who places his <i>eiruv</i></b> in a particular location <b>has four cubits</b> surrounding him that are considered as a private domain, here too, the area should be considered <b>a private domain; and a private domain rises to the sky.</b> Since the tree stands within this area, all parts of the tree should be regarded as a private domain regardless of their height.
<b>Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Mesharshiya, said: Here, we are dealing with a tree that leans out</b> horizontally <b>beyond four cubits</b> from its trunk, and one placed the <i>eiruv</i> on a section that is beyond four cubits,

Daf 33a

<b>and he intended to establish his Shabbat residence at its base. And what</b> is the meaning of the terms <b>above and below,</b> as we said that this tree extends horizontally to the side, which indicates that it remains at a uniform height? After the tree leans horizontally beyond four cubits from the place of its roots, <b>it</b> rises once <b>again in an upright</b> position, and therefore the terms above and below are applicable.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> it true that even if the <i>eiruv</i> is above ten handbreadths, <b>if one wants, he can</b> remove it from where it was deposited and <b>bring it by way of</b> the tree’s <b>leaves,</b> i.e., its branches that are above ten handbreadths, to within four cubits of the place where he intended to establish his Shabbat residence? Therefore, the <i>eiruv</i> should be valid even though it is above ten handbreadths.
The Gemara answers: We are dealing with a unique situation <b>where</b> the horizontal section of the tree is used by <b>the masses</b> to <b>shoulder</b> their burdens <b>on it,</b> i.e., to temporarily rest their loads on it, so that they can adjust them and easily lift them up again; <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> in that case <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla, as Ulla said:</b> With regard to <b>a pillar</b> that is <b>nine</b> handbreadths high and situated <b>in the public domain, and the masses</b> use it to <b>shoulder</b> their loads upon it, <b>and someone threw</b> an object from a private domain <b>and it came to rest upon it, he is liable,</b> as this pillar has the status of a public domain. Consequently, in the case of the tree, one may not bring the <i>eiruv</i> by way of the tree’s branches, as the horizontal section of the tree has the status of a public domain, and one may not carry from one private domain to another via a public domain.
The Gemara previously cited the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi that anything that is prohibited on Shabbat due to rabbinic decree is not prohibited during the twilight period. The Gemara now attempts to clarify the matter: <b>What is</b> the source that originally cites <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion, <b>and what is</b> the source which cites the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b>
The Gemara cites the source of the disagreement: <b>As it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>If one placed</b> his <i>eiruv</i> <b>in a tree above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> If he placed it <b>below ten handbreadths, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>, but he is prohibited to take it</b> on Shabbat in order to eat it because it is prohibited to use the tree on Shabbat. However, if the <i>eiruv</i> is <b>within three</b> handbreadths of the ground, <b>he is permitted to take it</b> because it is considered as though it were on the ground and not in a tree. If <b>one placed</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>in a basket and hung it on a tree, even above ten handbreadths, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis</b> disagree and <b>say:</b> In <b>any</b> situation in which the <i>eiruv</i> was placed in <b>a location where it is prohibited to take</b> it, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: With regard <b>to which</b> statement did <b>the Rabbis state</b> their opinion? <b>If you say</b> they were referring <b>to the latter clause</b> with respect to the basket hanging from the tree, <b>let us say that the Rabbis hold</b> that using even <b>the sides</b> of a tree <b>is prohibited,</b> as making use of the basket is considered using the sides of a tree. <b>Rather,</b> the Rabbis’ statement must refer <b>to the first clause,</b> in which Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says that if one put the <i>eiruv</i> below ten handbreadths, his <i>eiruv</i> is valid, but he is prohibited to move it.
The Gemara clarifies further: <b>This tree, what are its circumstances? If it is not four</b> by four handbreadths wide, <b>it is an exempt domain,</b> i.e., a neutral place with respect to the laws of carrying on Shabbat, from which an object may be carried into any other Shabbat domain. In that case, the <i>eiruv</i> should be valid even if it was placed higher than ten handbreadths in the tree. <b>And if it is four</b> by four handbreadths wide, <b>when one places it in a basket, what of it?</b> What difference does it make? In any event it is in a private domain.
<b>Ravina said: The first clause</b> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the tree <b>is four</b> by four handbreadths wide. The <i>eiruv</i> is not valid if it was placed above ten handbreadths because the tree at that height constitutes a private domain, and the <i>eiruv</i> cannot be brought to the public domain below, where one wishes to establish his Shabbat residence. <b>The latter clause,</b> however, is referring to a case <b>where</b> the tree <b>is not four</b> by four handbreadths wide, <b>and the basket completes</b> the width of the tree at that spot <b>to four.</b>

Daf 33b

<b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and he</b> also <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> the following in the case of an arched gateway in which the lower, straight-walled section is three handbreadths high, and the entire arch is ten handbreadths high: Even if, at the height of ten handbreadths, the arch is less than four handbreadths wide, one considers it as if he <b>carves out</b> the space <b>to complete</b> it, i.e., the arch has the legal status as though it were actually enlarged to a width of four handbreadths. Similarly, in our case the basket is taken into account and enlarges the tree to a width of four handbreadths.
<b>And he</b> also <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said: We require</b> that the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> rest <b>on a place</b> that is <b>four</b> by four handbreadths wide, <b>and</b> here <b>there is not</b> a width of four handbreadths without taking the basket into account.
The Gemara now asks: <b>What is</b> the source of the ruling of <b>Rabbi Yehuda? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If one stuck a</b> cross <b>beam</b> into the ground <b>in the public domain and placed his <i>eiruv</i> upon it,</b> if the cross beam is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide,</b> so that it has the status of a private domain, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>; but if not, his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>On the contrary,</b> if the cross beam is not ten handbreadths high, why shouldn’t his <i>eiruv</i> be valid? <b>He and his <i>eiruv</i> are in the same place,</b> i.e., in the public domain. <b>Rather, this is what he said:</b> If the cross beam is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high, it is necessary that its top be four</b> handbreadths wide, so that it can be considered its own domain; but if it is <b>not ten</b> handbreadths <b>high, it is not necessary that its top be four</b> handbreadths wide because it is considered part of the public domain.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Ravina offer his explanation, which maintains that we are dealing with a basket that completes the dimension of the tree to four handbreadths and yet it is not treated as a private domain? <b>It is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> If <b>one stuck a reed</b> into the ground <b>in the public domain, and placed a basket [<i>teraskal</i>]</b> four by four handbreadths wide <b>on top of it, and threw</b> an object from the public domain, <b>and it landed upon it, he is liable</b> for carrying from a public domain to a private domain. According to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, if a surface of four by four handbreadths rests at a height of ten handbreadths from the ground, this is sufficient for it to be considered a private domain. Ravina’s explanation of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s position, however, does not appear to accept this assumption.
The Gemara refutes this and claims that this proof is not conclusive: <b>Even if you say</b> that Ravina’s explanation is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> a distinction can be made: <b>There,</b> in the case of the basket resting on a reed, the sides of the basket constitute <b>partitions</b> that <b>surround</b> the reed on all sides, and we can invoke the principle of: Lower the partition, according to which the partitions are viewed as extending down to the ground. Consequently, a kind of private domain is created within the public domain. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the basket hanging from the tree, the <b>partitions</b> of the basket <b>do not surround</b> the tree, and so they do not suffice to create a private domain.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi in the <i>Tosefta</i> can be explained in an entirely different manner: <b>A basket is different, since one can tilt it and</b> in that way <b>bring it to within ten</b> handbreadths of the ground. Without moving the entire basket, one can tilt it and thereby remove the <i>eiruv</i> in order to eat it, without carrying it from one domain to another.
<b>Rav Pappa sat and recited this <i>halakha</i>. Rav bar Shabba raised an objection to Rav Pappa</b> from the following mishna: <b>What does one do</b> if a Festival occurs on Friday, and he wishes to establish an <i>eiruv</i> that will be valid for both the Festival and Shabbat? <b>He brings</b> the <i>eiruv</i> to the location that he wishes to establish as his residence <b>on</b> the eve of the <b>first</b> day, i.e., the eve of the Festival, <b>and stays</b> there <b>with it until nightfall,</b> the time when the <i>eiruv</i> establishes that location as his residence, <b>and</b> then <b>he takes it</b> with him <b>and goes away,</b> so that it does not become lost before Shabbat begins, in which case he would not have an <i>eiruv</i> for Shabbat. <b>On</b> the eve of the <b>second</b> day, i.e., on Friday afternoon, he takes it back to the same place as the day before, and <b>stays</b> there <b>with it until nightfall,</b> thereby establishing his Shabbat residence; and then he may then <b>eat</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>and go away,</b> if he so desires.

Daf 34a

<b>Why</b> must one actually bring the <i>eiruv</i> to the place where he wishes to establish his residence? <b>Let us say: Since if he wished to bring</b> the <i>eiruv</i> there <b>he could bring it, even though he did not bring it, it is considered as though he did bring it</b> there. This follows the same reasoning proposed by Rav Yirmeya in the case of the basket: Since one can tilt it. The fact that this reasoning is not employed here indicates that the potential to do something is insufficient; rather, the deed must actually be done.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The fact that one must bring his <i>eiruv</i> the day before to the spot that he wishes to establish as his place of residence, and the potential to bring it there does not suffice, is <b>a decree due to a Festival that occurs after Shabbat.</b> In that case, the <i>eiruv</i> is valid for the Festival only if it was brought there before Shabbat, for it cannot be carried there on Shabbat. Since one cannot actually bring the <i>eiruv</i> there, it cannot be said: It is considered as though he did bring it there because had he wished to bring the <i>eiruv</i> he could have. Consequently, the Sages decreed that in all cases, the <i>eiruv</i> is only valid if it was actually brought to the designated spot, lest one come to think that even on a Festival that occurs after Shabbat it need not be brought there.
Rav bar Shabba <b>raised</b> another <b>objection</b> from a different <i>baraita</i>: With regard to one who <b>intended to establish his Shabbat residence in the public domain and placed his <i>eiruv</i> in a wall</b> that is more than four cubits away from that location; if he placed the <i>eiruv</i> <b>below</b> a height of <b>ten handbreadths</b> above the ground, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>;</b> but if he placed it <b>above ten handbreadths, his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i></b> because he is in a public domain while his <i>eiruv</i> is in a private domain. If <b>one intended to establish his Shabbat residence on top of a dovecote or on top of</b> a large <b>cupboard,</b> if he placed the <i>eiruv</i> in the dovecote or cupboard <b>above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i></b> because both he and his <i>eiruv</i> are in a private domain; but if he placed it <b>below ten handbreadths,</b> the area in which he placed his <i>eiruv</i> is considered a <i>karmelit</i>, and <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i></b> because he cannot transport his <i>eiruv</i> from there to his own domain on Shabbat.
<b>Why</b> should this be so? <b>Here too, let us say</b> that his <i>eiruv</i> should be valid even if it was placed below ten handbreadths, <b>since one can tilt</b> the cupboard <b>and bring it to within ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, in which case he and his <i>eiruv</i> would be in the same domain. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: Here, we are dealing with a cupboard that is nailed</b> to the wall so that it cannot be tilted.
<b>Rava said: Even if you say</b> that it is referring to <b>a cupboard that is not nailed</b> to the wall, <b>here, we are dealing with</b> a very <b>tall cupboard,</b> such <b>that were one to tilt it a little</b> in order to bring the top of the cupboard within ten handbreadths from the ground, the top of the cupboard <b>would project beyond</b> the <b>four cubits</b> that constitute one’s Shabbat residence.
The Gemara asks: <b>What,</b> exactly, <b>are the circumstances? If</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the cupboard <b>has a window, and</b> one has <b>a rope</b> at hand, <b>let him bring it by means of the window and rope.</b> In other words, let him lower the rope through the cupboard’s window and bring the <i>eiruv</i> with it, and he will not have to move the entire cupboard. The Gemara answers: Here we are dealing with a case <b>where it does not have a window, and</b> he does not have <b>a rope</b> at hand.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If one placed</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>in a pit, even</b> if <b>it is a hundred cubits deep,</b> his <i>eiruv</i> is a valid <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>This pit, where is it situated? If you say that it is situated in the private domain,</b>

Daf 34b

<b>it is obvious,</b> for <b>the private domain ascends to the sky, and just as it ascends upward, so</b> too, <b>it descends downward</b> to the bottom of the pit, even if it is more than ten handbreadths deep. <b>Rather,</b> we must say <b>that</b> the pit <b>is situated in the public domain.</b>
The Gemara now clarifies: <b>Where</b> did one <b>intend to establish his Shabbat residence? If</b> he intended to establish his residence <b>above</b> the pit in the public domain, this is a case where <b>he is in one place and his <i>eiruv</i> is in another place,</b> i.e., in a private domain, and therefore his <i>eiruv</i> is not valid. Alternatively, <b>if</b> one intended to establish his Shabbat residence <b>below,</b> in the pit, <b>it is</b> also <b>obvious,</b> as <b>he and his <i>eiruv</i> are in one place.</b>
The Gemara answers: This ruling <b>is necessary only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the pit <b>is situated in a <i>karmelit</i>, and he intended to establish his Shabbat residence above</b> the pit in the <i>karmelit</i>. <b>And</b> with regard to the question of how this <i>eiruv</i> can be valid, as one cannot bring the <i>eiruv</i> from the pit to the <i>karmelit</i>, the answer is that the mishna was taught in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said:</b> With regard to <b>anything that is</b> prohibited on Shabbat <b>due to rabbinic decree [<i>shevut</i>], they did not issue the decree</b> to apply <b>during twilight.</b> Since carrying from the pit to the <i>karmelit</i> is only prohibited as a <i>shevut</i>, a person may carry from the pit to the <i>karmelit</i> during twilight, the time when the <i>eiruv</i> establishes one’s Shabbat residence.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one placed</b> his <i>eiruv</i> <b>on top of a reed or on top of a pole [<i>kundas</i>], when</b> the reed or pole <b>is detached</b> from its original place <b>and stuck</b> into the ground, <b>even</b> if it is <b>a hundred cubits high, it is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> as one can remove the reed or pole from the ground and take his <i>eiruv</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Adda bar Mattana raised a contradiction before Rava</b> concerning two tannaitic rulings: The mishna states that if the reed <b>was detached</b> from its place of growth <b>and</b> then <b>stuck</b> into the ground, <b>yes,</b> the <i>eiruv</i> is valid. That indicates that if it <b>was not detached and</b> then <b>stuck</b> back into the ground, <b>no,</b> the <i>eiruv</i> is not valid. In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say: Anything that is</b> prohibited on Shabbat <b>due to rabbinic decree [<i>shevut</i>],</b> such as using a tree on Shabbat, <b>they issued the decree</b> to apply even <b>during twilight.</b> Therefore, if the <i>eiruv</i> was on top of a reed that was still attached to the ground in its original place of growth, since it is prohibited by rabbinic decree to make use of trees on Shabbat, one cannot remove the <i>eiruv</i> from its place at the time that he must establish his Shabbat residence, and therefore his <i>eiruv</i> is invalid. But <b>didn’t you say</b> that <b>the first clause,</b> i.e., the previous mishna, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? How can you say that <b>the first clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and the latter clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b>
Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Adda: <b>Rami bar Ḥama already raised this contradiction before Rav Ḥisda, and</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>answered him:</b> Indeed, <b>the first clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and the latter clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis.
<b>Ravina said:</b> You can, in fact, say that <b>it is all Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and the latter clause,</b> i.e., the mishna that insists that the reed be detached and inserted, is not based upon the prohibition of utilizing trees on Shabbat. Rather, in that case there is a unique <b>decree lest he break</b> it <b>off</b> from the ground if the reed is relatively soft. Therefore, the mishna requires one to use something that has already been detached from the ground and reinserted. However, the previous mishna is referring to someone who placed his <i>eiruv</i> in a tree, where this concern is not relevant.
The Gemara relates <b>that</b> a certain <b>army [<i>pulmosa</i>]</b> once <b>came to Neharde’a</b> and took quarters in the study hall, so that there was not enough room for the students. <b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> the students: <b>Go out and create</b> seats by <b>compressing</b> reeds <b>in the marshes, and tomorrow,</b> on Shabbat, <b>we will go and sit on them</b> and study there.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised an objection to Rav Naḥman, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Ukva bar Abba</b> who raised the objection <b>to Rav Naḥman,</b> from the mishna that states that if the reed <b>was detached and</b> then <b>stuck</b> into the ground, <b>yes;</b> but if it <b>was not detached and not stuck</b> into the ground, <b>no.</b> This shows that it is not enough to compress the reeds, and they must actually be detached from the ground before they may be used on Shabbat.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: There,</b> in the mishna, we are dealing with <b>hard</b> reeds, which may not be bent and used on Shabbat, unlike soft reeds. He adds: <b>And from where do you say that we distinguish between hard</b> reeds <b>and</b> reeds <b>that are not hard? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Reeds, boxthorn, and thistles are species of trees, and</b> therefore they <b>are not</b> included in the prohibition of <b>food crops in a vineyard,</b> which applies only to herbs planted among vines. <b>And it was taught in another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Reeds, cassia, and bulrushes are species of herbs, and</b> therefore <b>they are</b> included in the prohibition of <b>food crops in a vineyard.</b> These two <i>baraitot</i> <b>contradict one another,</b> as one states that reeds are trees, while the other says that they are considered herbs.
<b>Rather, conclude from this</b> that we must distinguish between them as follows: <b>Here,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, it is referring <b>to hard</b> reeds, which are like trees; whereas <b>there,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, it is referring <b>to</b> reeds <b>that are not hard.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from this</b> that our resolution of the contradiction is correct.
The Gemara raises a question with regard to the previously cited <i>baraita</i>: <b>Is cassia a type of herb? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>One may not graft rue to white cassia, as this</b> involves the grafting of <b>herbs to a tree?</b> This proves that white cassia is a tree. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> There is no difficulty, as <b>cassia is distinct</b> and is considered a type of herb, <b>and white cassia is distinct</b> and is considered a type of tree.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>If one put</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>in a cupboard</b> and locked it, <b>and the key was lost,</b> so that he is now unable to open the cupboard and access the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>it is</b> nonetheless a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>. Rabbi Eliezer says: If he does not know that the key is in its place, it is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> should the <i>eiruv</i> be valid if the key was lost? <b>He is in one place and his <i>eiruv</i> is in a different place,</b> since he cannot access the <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>It was Rav and Shmuel who both said: Here, we are dealing with a cupboard</b> made <b>of bricks, and</b> the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: One may create a breach</b> in a brick wall on Shabbat <b><i>ab initio</i>, and take</b> produce from the other side. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: If <b>a house filled with produce</b> had been <b>sealed and was</b> then <b>breached, one may take out</b> produce <b>from the place of the breach. Rabbi Meir</b> disagrees and <b>says: One may</b> even <b>create a breach</b> in the wall of the house <b>and take</b> produce <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> Consequently, according to Rabbi Meir it is permissible to make a hole in the cupboard in order to remove the produce found inside.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rav Naḥman bar Adda say that Shmuel said</b> that that very mishna cited as a proof is referring <b>to</b> a structure built from <b>layers of bricks</b> piled one atop the other without cement or mortar between them, in which case making a hole cannot be considered dismantling a bona fide structure? The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> we are dealing with a cupboard made from <b>layers of bricks.</b>
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Zeira say:</b> The Sages in the aforementioned mishna, who discussed the breaching of a wall, <b>spoke</b> only <b>with regard to a Festival, but not with regard to Shabbat?</b> Therefore, it cannot be derived from that mishna that it is permitted to breach the cupboard on Shabbat in order to access the food inside. The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to</b> a case where the person needed an <i>eiruv</i> for <b>a Festival</b> but not for Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that the mishna is referring only to a Festival, there is a difficulty with <b>that which was taught about it</b> in the following <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: If</b> the key <b>was lost in a city, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>; and if it was lost in a field, his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> for within a city it is possible to carry the key by way of courtyards that have joined together in an <i>eiruv</i> or the like, but in a field it is impossible to carry it, as the field has the status of a <i>karmelit</i>. <b>And if</b> the mishna is referring <b>to a Festival, what</b> is the difference <b>to me</b> whether the key was lost in a <b>city</b> or a <b>field?</b> On a Festival there is no prohibition against carrying from a private to a public domain, and therefore if the key was lost even in a field, the <i>eiruv</i> should still be valid.

Daf 35a

The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is incomplete and it teaches the following:</b> If <b>one placed</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>in a cupboard and locked it, and the key is lost, it is</b> nonetheless a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? On a Festival; however, on Shabbat, his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> If <b>the key is found, whether in a city or in a field, his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>. Rabbi Eliezer</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> If it is found <b>in a city, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>;</b> but if it is found <b>in a field, his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara now explains the difference: If the key is found <b>in a city, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said: Roofs, courtyards, and enclosed fields [<i>karpeifot</i>] are all one domain</b> with regard <b>to utensils that began Shabbat in them.</b> Accordingly, a utensil that was left on a roof at the beginning of Shabbat may be carried into a courtyard or a <i>karpef</i>. It is possible to transfer anything located in a city from one place to another in a similar manner. If, however, the key is found <b>in a field, his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> due to the prohibition to carry in a <i>karmelit</i>. Although carrying there is merely a <i>shevut</i>, the <i>eiruv</i> is not valid.
