The discussion above constitutes one understanding of the mishna. <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef,</b> however, <b>both said: Here, we are dealing with a wooden cupboard,</b> and the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree with regard to the following point: <b>The</b> first, anonymous <b>Sage,</b> who rules that the <i>eiruv</i> is valid, <b>holds</b> that the cupboard <b>is a utensil, and</b> that <b>there is no</b> prohibited labor of <b>building utensils, and</b> similarly, <b>there is no dismantling of utensils.</b> Since dismantling a utensil is not included in the prohibited labor of dismantling, one may make a hole in the cupboard in order to access the food used for the <i>eiruv</i>. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, who invalidates the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>holds</b> that the cupboard <b>is a tent.</b> A wooden implement of such a large size is no longer classified as a utensil; rather, it is considered a building, and therefore it is subject to the prohibitions against building and dismantling on Shabbat.
<b>And</b> their dispute is parallel to <b>the dispute between these <i>tanna’im</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna with regard to the ritual impurity of a <i>zav</i>: One of the unique laws of a <i>zav</i> is that he imparts impurity to an object simply by moving it, even if he does not touch it directly. If a <i>zav</i> <b>knocked on a carriage, crate, or cupboard,</b> even if he did not actually come into direct contact with them, <b>they are</b> nonetheless ritually <b>impure</b> because he caused them to move when he struck them. <b>Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Shimon</b> disagree and <b>render</b> them <b>pure.</b>
<b>What, are they not disagreeing about this</b> point: <b>The</b> first <b>Sage holds</b> that a carriage, crate, or cupboard <b>is</b> categorized as <b>a utensil,</b> and therefore it contracts ritual impurity when a <i>zav</i> causes it to move; <b>and the</b> other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>it is a tent,</b> and a building does not contract ritual impurity in any way from a <i>zav</i>?
<b>Abaye said</b> in refutation of this proof: <b>And</b> do <b>you think</b> that this is a reasonable explanation of the mishna? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a <i>zav</i> shook a real <b>tent, and it moved, it is</b> ritually <b>impure;</b> and if he shook <b>a utensil and it did not move, it is</b> ritually <b>pure?</b> This indicates that the critical factor is not whether the article is classified as a tent or as a utensil but whether or not it actually moves when shaken. Furthermore, <b>it was taught in the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i>: <b>And if they moved, they are</b> ritually <b>impure,</b> and <b>this is the principle:</b> If a utensil or a tent <b>moved due to the</b> direct <b>force</b> of the <i>zav</i>, <b>it is</b> ritually <b>impure.</b> But if it moved <b>due to vibrations,</b> e.g., if the <i>zav</i> knocked on the floor or on the platform upon which the object is located, and the vibrations of the floor or the platform caused the object to move, <b>it is</b> ritually <b>pure,</b> as it was not moved by the direct force of the <i>zav</i>. Once again, the determining factor is not the object’s classification as a tent or a utensil but whether it was actually moved by the <i>zav</i>.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> that the dispute between the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Shimon should be understood as follows: <b>All</b> agree that <b>movement due to</b> the direct <b>force</b> of the <i>zav</i> causes the object to become ritually <b>impure,</b> whether it is a tent or a utensil. Conversely, if the movement was <b>due to vibrations</b> of the floor or base, <b>it is</b> ritually <b>pure. And here, we are dealing with</b> a case where the object <b>vibrated because of</b> the direct <b>force</b> of the <i>zav</i>, i.e., where he banged upon the object itself, causing it to vibrate but not to move. <b>And</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to the following</b> point: <b>The</b> first <b>Sage holds</b> that this, too, <b>is</b> considered <b>movement; and the</b> other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that vibration <b>is not</b> considered <b>movement.</b> Therefore, Abaye rejects Rabba and Rav Yosef’s proof for their explanation of the mishna.
The Gemara therefore proceeds to ask: If so, <b>how is the mishna</b> with regard to <i>eiruv</i> <b>to be interpreted?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Abaye and Rava both said: We are dealing</b> here <b>with a lock</b> that is <b>tied with a leather strap, and a knife is required to cut it</b> if there is no key.
<b>The</b> anonymous <b>first <i>tanna</i> holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who said: All utensils may be moved on Shabbat, except for a large saw and the blade of a plow.</b> Consequently, one may take a knife, cut the strap, and remove his <i>eiruv</i> from the cupboard.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, who said: Even a cloak,</b> and <b>even a spoon,</b> which are certainly used only for activities permitted on Shabbat, <b>may be moved</b> on Shabbat <b>only for the purpose of their</b> ordinary <b>use.</b> The same applies to a knife, which may be moved only in order to cut food, but not for any other purpose. Consequently, one cannot cut the strap around the lock of the cupboard, and therefore his <i>eiruv</i> is invalid unless the key is located in town and he can transport it via courtyards.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one’s <i>eiruv</i> <b>rolled beyond the</b> Shabbat <b>limit,</b> and he no longer has access to his <i>eiruv</i> since he may not go beyond his limit, or if <b>a pile</b> of stones <b>fell on it, or</b> if <b>it was burnt,</b> or if the <i>eiruv</i> was <b><i>teruma</i> and it became</b> ritually <b>impure;</b> if any of these occurrences took place <b>while it was still day,</b> prior to the onset of Shabbat, <b>it is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> since one did not have an <i>eiruv</i> at twilight, which is the time one’s Shabbat residence is established. However, if any of these occurred <b>after dark,</b> when it was already Shabbat, <b>it is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> as it was intact and accessible at the time one’s Shabbat residence is determined.
<b>If</b> the matter is <b>in doubt,</b> i.e., if he does not know when one of the aforementioned incidents occurred, <b>Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda say: This</b> person <b>is</b> in the position of both <b>a donkey driver,</b> who must prod the animal from behind, <b>and a camel driver,</b> who must lead the animal from the front, i.e., he is a person who is pulled in two opposite directions. Due to the uncertainty concerning his Shabbat border, he must act stringently, as though his resting place were both in his town and at the location where he placed the <i>eiruv</i>. He must restrict his Shabbat movement to those areas that are within two thousand cubits of both locations.
<b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon</b> disagree and <b>say: An <i>eiruv</i></b> whose validity is <b>in doubt is</b> nevertheless <b>valid. Rav Yosei said:</b> The Sage <b>Avtolemos testified in the name of five Elders that an <i>eiruv</i></b> whose validity is <b>in doubt is valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna: If one’s <i>eiruv</i> <b>rolled beyond the</b> Shabbat <b>limit</b> prior to the onset of Shabbat, it is not a valid <i>eiruv</i>. <b>Rava said: They only taught</b> this in a case <b>where</b> one established his <i>eiruv</i> at the edge of his town’s Shabbat limit and the <i>eiruv</i> <b>rolled more than four cubits</b> outside that limit; <b>however,</b> if it remained <b>within four cubits</b> of the Shabbat limit, it is a valid <i>eiruv</i>. The principle is that <b>one who places his <i>eiruv</i></b> in a particular location <b>has four cubits</b> around it, since he has established his Shabbat residence there.
The mishna continues: If <b>a pile</b> of stones <b>fell on</b> the <i>eiruv</i> prior to the onset of Shabbat, it is not a valid <i>eiruv</i>. <b>It</b> might <b>enter your mind</b> to say that the mishna is referring to a case <b>where if one wanted he could take</b> the <i>eiruv</i>, i.e., where it is physically possible to clear the stones and remove the <i>eiruv</i> from underneath them. The only reason he cannot do so is because of the rabbinic prohibition to handle items that are set-aside, such as stones, on Shabbat.
If so, <b>let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As, if</b> you say that <b>it is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, there is a difficulty: <b>Didn’t he say</b> that with regard to <b>anything prohibited due to rabbinic decree, they did not issue the decree to apply during twilight?</b> The prohibition to handle items that are set-aside is also a rabbinic decree, and therefore, according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, since the <i>eiruv</i> was accessible at twilight, it should be valid.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Even if you say</b> that the mishna <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, we can say that this ruling <b>was necessary only</b> in a case <b>where a hoe or a spade would be required</b> in order to remove the <i>eiruv</i> from under the stones, i.e., one would have to dig, which is a Shabbat labor prohibited by Torah law, not only by rabbinic decree.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> both rulings, the ruling concerning an <i>eiruv</i> that rolled beyond the Shabbat limit and the ruling concerning an <i>eiruv</i> that became buried under a pile of rocks, <b>are necessary. As, if</b> the mishna had only <b>taught</b> the case of the <i>eiruv</i> that <b>rolled</b> away, we might have said that the <i>eiruv</i> is invalid <b>because it is not near him, but</b> if <b>a pile</b> of rocks <b>fell on</b> the <i>eiruv</i>, since <b>it is near him,</b> you might <b>say that it should be</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> as one does not actually have to eat the <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the mishna had only <b>taught</b> the case where <b>a pile</b> of rocks <b>fell on</b> the <i>eiruv</i>, we might have said that the <i>eiruv</i> is invalid <b>because it is covered, but</b> in the case where it <b>rolled</b> away, since <b>sometimes a wind comes and brings it</b> back, <b>you might say that it should be a</b> valid <i>eiruv</i>. Therefore, it was necessary to teach both cases.
The mishna further states: <b>Or</b> if the <i>eiruv</i> <b>was burnt,</b> or if the <i>eiruv</i> was <b><i>teruma</i> that became</b> ritually <b>impure</b> before Shabbat, it is not a valid <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need</b> to teach these two cases? The essential point of both cases is the same: The <i>eiruv</i> is no longer fit to be eaten. The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>taught</b> the case where the <i>eiruv</i> <b>was burnt</b>

Daf 35b

<b>to convey the far-reaching nature of Rabbi Yosei’s</b> statement, as he is lenient in a case of uncertainty whether the <i>eiruv</i> was burnt the previous day or only after nightfall, even though the <i>eiruv</i> is now entirely destroyed. Additionally, the mishna <b>taught</b> the case of <b><i>teruma</i> that became</b> ritually <b>impure to convey the far-reaching nature of Rabbi Meir’s</b> statement, as he is stringent even though the <i>teruma</i> itself is still present, and there is only an uncertainty about when it became impure.
The Gemara questions the mishna’s ruling itself: <b>Does Rabbi Meir</b> really <b>hold</b> that in cases of <b>doubt</b> one must be <b>stringent? Didn’t we learn</b> the following in a mishna: If a ritually <b>impure</b> person <b>descended to immerse</b> in a ritual bath, and there is <b>doubt</b> whether he actually <b>immersed or he did not immerse; and even if he</b> certainly <b>immersed,</b> there is <b>doubt</b> whether he <b>immersed in</b> a ritual bath containing <b>forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water, the minimal amount of water necessary for the ritual bath to be valid, <b>or he did not immerse in forty <i>se’a</i>; and similarly,</b> if there are <b>two</b> adjacent <b>ritual baths, one</b> of which <b>has forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water <b>in it</b> and is therefore valid, <b>and one</b> of which <b>does not have forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water <b>in it, and he immersed in one of them, but he does not know in which of them he immersed;</b> in each of these cases, owing to <b>one’s doubt, he</b> remains ritually <b>impure?</b>
<b>In what case is this statement,</b> which maintains that in cases of doubt one is considered impure, <b>said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to severe</b> forms of ritual <b>impurity,</b> i.e., those imparted by a primary source of ritual impurity.
<b>However, with regard to lenient</b> forms of ritual <b>impurity</b> imposed only by rabbinic decree, <b>such as one who ate</b> half a half-loaf of <b>impure foods; and</b> similarly, <b>one who drank impure liquids; and one whose head and most of his body came under drawn water,</b> as opposed to spring water or rainwater, in which case the Sages decreed that person to be ritually impure; <b>or if three <i>log</i> of drawn water fell on one’s head and most of his body,</b> in which case the Sages also decreed that person to be impure; <b>and</b> if in any of these cases <b>one descended to immerse</b> himself in a ritual bath to purify himself of the rabbinically decreed impurity, and there is <b>doubt</b> whether he actually <b>immersed or he did not immerse; and even if he</b> certainly <b>immersed,</b> there is <b>doubt</b> whether he <b>immersed in forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water <b>or he did not immerse in forty <i>se’a</i>; and similarly,</b> if there were <b>two ritual baths, one</b> of which <b>has forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water <b>in it and one</b> of which <b>does not have forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water <b>in it, and he immersed in one of them, but he does not know in which of them he immersed;</b> in all of these cases, owing to <b>his doubt, he is</b> ritually <b>pure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei</b> disagrees and <b>renders him</b> ritually <b>impure.</b> In any event, it is clear that, according to the unattributed mishna, which is generally presumed to reflect the opinion of Rabbi Meir, the <i>halakha</i> is lenient in cases of doubt relating to ritual impurity that is due to rabbinic decree. Why, then, doesn’t Rabbi Meir agree that we should be lenient in cases of doubt relating to an <i>eiruv</i>, which is also of rabbinic origin?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that the prohibitions relating to Shabbat <b>limits are</b> prohibited <b>by Torah law,</b> and therefore the uncertainties in the mishna involve a Torah prohibition, with regard to which one may not be lenient.
The Gemara asks: <b>Does Rabbi Meir</b> really <b>hold</b> that the prohibitions of Shabbat <b>limits are</b> prohibited <b>by Torah law? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: When taking measurements related to Shabbat boundaries, if a fifty-cubit rope is held at either end by two people, the distance between them is deemed to be fifty cubits, even if the distance on the ground is greater, owing to inclines and depressions? If there is a hill or incline between them that <b>cannot be swallowed</b> by the fifty-cubit measuring rope, so that the usual mode of measurement cannot be used, <b>in this</b> situation, <b>Rabbi Dostai said in the name of Rabbi Meir: I heard that we pierce mountains,</b> i.e., we measure the distance as if there were a hole from one side of the hill to the other, so that in effect we measure only the horizontal distance and ignore the differences in elevation.
<b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to say that the prohibitions relating to Shabbat <b>limits are</b> prohibited <b>by Torah law, would</b> it be permitted to <b>pierce the mountains? Didn’t Rav Naḥman say that Rabba bar Avuh said: We may not pierce</b> mountains <b>when</b> measuring the boundaries of <b>cities of refuge nor</b> when measuring which city is closest to a corpse and is therefore obligated to perform the rite of the <b>heifer whose neck is broken, because those</b> laws <b>are from the Torah;</b> therefore, a more stringent policy is used to measure the distances precisely?
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as there is no contradiction between the two statements. <b>This</b> statement, according to which Shabbat limits are by Torah law, <b>is his; that</b> statement, in which he is lenient, <b>is his teacher’s.</b> The language of the mishna <b>is also precise</b> according to this explanation, <b>as we learned: In this</b> case, <b>Rabbi Dostai bar Yannai said in the name of Rabbi Meir: I have heard that we pierce mountains.</b> This formulation indicates that Rabbi Meir did not state his own opinion. Rather, he transmitted a ruling that he had heard from his teacher, even though he did not agree with it himself. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from this</b> that this resolution is correct.
The Gemara continues: There is still room <b>to raise a contradiction</b> between one ruling with regard to <b>Torah law and</b> another ruling with regard to <b>Torah law, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: If one <b>touched one</b> other person <b>at night, and he does not know whether</b> the person he touched was <b>alive or dead, and the following day he arose and found him dead,</b> and he is in doubt as to whether or not he contracted ritual impurity as a result of having come into contact with a corpse, <b>Rabbi Meir renders him</b> ritually <b>pure.</b> It is assumed that the deceased was still alive until the point that it is known with certainty that he is dead. <b>And the Rabbis render him</b> ritually <b>impure because</b> it is assumed that <b>all</b> ritually <b>impure</b> items had already been in the same state as they were <b>at the time they were discovered.</b> Just as the deceased was found dead in the morning, so too, it may be presumed that he was dead when he was touched in the middle of the night. Therefore, Rabbi Meir is lenient even with respect to an uncertainty relating to a Torah law, and he holds that a person is presumed to be alive until it is known with certainty that he died. Why, then, is he stringent concerning doubt as to whether the <i>eiruv</i> had already become impure on the previous day or only after nightfall? Here too, one should assume that the <i>eiruv</i> is ritually pure until he knows with certainty that it became defiled, and so the <i>eiruv</i> should be valid, even if Shabbat limits are considered Torah law.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: The mishna</b> is referring to a case <b>where a creeping animal</b> that imparts ritual impurity <b>was on</b> the <i>teruma</i> that was used to establish the <i>eiruv</i> <b>for the entire twilight</b> period. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, in that case, would Rabbi Yosei say</b> that <b>an <i>eiruv</i></b> whose validity is <b>in doubt is valid?</b> There is no uncertainty in this case.
It was <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef who both said:</b> The doubt here does not result from the facts of the case themselves, but from conflicting testimonies and an inability to decide between them. <b>Here, we are dealing with two sets of witnesses, one</b> of which <b>says:</b> The <i>teruma</i> <b>became impure while it was still day,</b> before the onset of Shabbat; <b>and one</b> of which <b>says:</b> The <i>teruma</i> became impure only <b>after nightfall.</b>

Daf 36a

<b>Rava said:</b> That is not the way to resolve the apparent contradiction between the two rulings; rather, there is a difference between the cases with regard to the ritual impurity itself: <b>There,</b> with regard to touching a person who was later found dead, there are <b>two presumptions</b> supporting <b>leniency,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> with respect to the <i>teruma</i> being used for an <i>eiruv</i>, there is only <b>one presumption</b> supporting <b>leniency.</b> How so? With regard to one who touched another person who was later found to be dead, there are two presumptions of purity: Firstly, the person who was found dead was previously alive, and the presumption is that he remained in that state until we know with certainty that he was dead. Secondly, the one who touched that person was previously pure, and he remains in that presumptive state until we know with certainty that he became impure. Therefore, Rabbi Meir had adequate reason to be lenient. However, with regard to <i>teruma</i>, only one presumption exists, that the <i>teruma</i> was previously pure and presumably remained in that state until proven otherwise. Since there is no additional presumption, Rabbi Meir ruled stringently.
All the difficulties raised above are based on the seemingly conflicting statements of Rabbi Meir. Yet it would appear that there is also <b>a contradiction between</b> one statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei and</b> another statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> for he was stringent with regard to the doubts involving ritual baths but lenient with regard to doubts involving <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana said:</b> The law with regard to ritual <b>impurity is different, since it has a basis in the Torah.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Yosei was stringent even with respect to immersion performed in order to remove impurity that is only of rabbinic origin. The Gemara asks: The prohibitions of <b>Shabbat</b> limits <b>are also</b> prohibited <b>by Torah law;</b> why isn’t Rabbi Yosei stringent about them as well? The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yosei holds:</b> The laws of Shabbat <b>limits</b> are by <b>rabbinic</b> law, not by Torah law.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>This</b> stringent ruling <b>is his; that</b> lenient ruling with regard to an <i>eiruv</i> <b>is his teacher’s.</b> The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise</b> according to this explanation, <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei said:</b> The Sage <b>Avtolemos testified in the name of five Elders that an <i>eiruv</i></b> whose validity is <b>in doubt is valid.</b> This formulation indicates that Rabbi Yosei was merely reporting a ruling that he had heard from his teacher, although he may not have accepted it. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from this</b> that this resolution of the contradiction is correct.
<b>Rava said</b> that a different resolution of the contradiction may be suggested: <b>There,</b> with regard to ritual baths, <b>this is the reason</b> for <b>Rabbi Yosei’s</b> opinion: <b>Keep the impure</b> person <b>in his presumptive state</b> of ritual impurity, <b>and say</b> that <b>he did not</b> properly <b>immerse</b> himself.
The Gemara responds: <b>On the contrary, keep the ritual bath in its presumptive state</b> of validity <b>and say that</b> the ritual bath <b>was not lacking</b> the requisite measure of water. The Gemara answers: We are dealing here with <b>a ritual bath that had not been</b> previously <b>measured</b> to determine whether it contained forty <i>se’a</i>, and therefore it had no prior presumption of validity.
<b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>In what case did Rabbi Yosei say that an <i>eiruv</i></b> whose validity is <b>in doubt is</b> nevertheless <b>valid?</b> For example, if <b>one established an <i>eiruv</i> with <i>teruma</i></b> that had been ritually pure but later became impure, and there is <b>doubt whether it became impure while it was still day,</b> before the onset of Shabbat, or <b>whether it became impure</b> only <b>after nightfall, and similarly,</b> if one made an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with</b> untithed <b>produce</b> that was later tithed and thereby became permissible for eating, and there is <b>doubt whether it was rendered fit while it was still day,</b> before the onset of Shabbat, or <b>whether it was rendered fit</b> only <b>after nightfall, this is an <i>eiruv</i></b> whose validity is <b>in doubt</b> which Rabbi Yosei said <b>is valid.</b>
<b>However, if one established an <i>eiruv</i> with <i>teruma</i></b> about which <b>there was doubt whether it was</b> ritually <b>pure or</b> ritually <b>impure</b> from the outset; <b>and similarly,</b> if one established an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with produce</b> about which <b>there was doubt</b> from the outset <b>whether it had been</b> tithed and thereby <b>rendered fit</b> or <b>whether it had not been</b> tithed and thereby <b>rendered fit, this is not</b> a case of <b>an <i>eiruv</i></b> whose validity is <b>in doubt</b> that Rabbi Yosei said <b>is valid.</b>
The Gemara raises a question in order to clarify the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>What is different</b> about <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> with regard to <b>which</b> we <b>say: Keep the <i>teruma</i> in its presumptive state</b> of ritual purity, <b>and say</b> that <b>it was</b> still <b>pure</b> at the onset of Shabbat, since it had been previously pure and it is not known when it became impure? According to that reasoning, with regard to untithed <b>produce [<i>tevel</i>]</b> it should <b>also</b> be said: <b>Keep the untithed produce in its presumptive state,</b> as the produce had certainly been untithed originally, <b>and say that it was not</b> tithed and thereby <b>rendered fit</b> prior to the onset of Shabbat.
Rather, emend the wording of the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Do not say:</b> There is <b>doubt whether it was rendered fit while it was still day,</b> before the onset of Shabbat. <b>Rather, say:</b> There is <b>doubt whether</b> regular produce <b>became mixed</b> with untithed produce <b>while it was still day,</b> or <b>whether it became mixed</b> only <b>after nightfall.</b> In other words, one used regular food to establish his <i>eiruv</i>, but then <i>tevel</i> was mixed with that food, prohibiting the entire mixture from being consumed until tithes are separated for the <i>tevel</i>. However, there is doubt whether the produce became mixed with the <i>tevel</i> while it was still day, in which case the <i>eiruv</i> is invalid, or whether it became mixed only after nightfall, in which case the <i>eiruv</i> is valid. In that case, we say: Keep the produce in its presumptive state and say that it was not mixed with <i>tevel</i> during the day, and therefore the <i>eiruv</i> is valid.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak raised a dilemma to Rav Huna:</b> If <b>there were two loaves of</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>before</b> someone, <b>one</b> that was ritually <b>impure and one</b> that was ritually <b>pure,</b> and he did not know which one was pure; <b>and he said: Establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> <i>teḥumin</i> <b>for me with the pure</b> loaf, <b>wherever it is,</b> i.e., even though I do not know which it is, I wish to establish my Shabbat residence at the location of the pure loaf, and those present placed both loaves in the same place, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is this a valid <i>eiruv</i> or not?
The Gemara clarifies: The question may <b>be asked according to</b> the stringent opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> and it may <b>be asked according to</b> the lenient opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> The question may <b>be asked according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> in the following manner: Perhaps <b>Rabbi Meir only stated</b> his stringent opinion with regard to a questionable <i>eiruv</i> <b>there, where there is no</b> <i>teruma</i> that is definitely <b>pure</b> present, but only <i>teruma</i> whose purity is in doubt. <b>Here,</b> however, <b>there</b> definitely <b>is a pure</b> loaf, and therefore even Rabbi Meir may agree to rule leniently. <b>Or perhaps</b> it may be argued that <b>even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, he only said</b> that we are lenient with regard to an <i>eiruv</i> whose validity is in doubt in the case dealt with <b>there,</b> where, <b>if indeed</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>is pure, he knows</b> where <b>it</b> is; <b>but here, he does not know</b> how to identify <b>it.</b>
Rav Huna <b>said to</b> Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak: <b>According to both</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei and</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, we require</b> that an <i>eiruv</i> consist of <b>a meal that is fit</b> to be eaten <b>while it is still day,</b> prior to the onset of Shabbat, <b>and</b> in this case <b>there is none.</b> Due to the uncertainty as to which loaf is pure and which is impure, neither of the two loaves may be eaten, and an <i>eiruv</i> made with food that may not be eaten while it is still day is not a valid <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rava raised</b> another <b>dilemma to Rav Naḥman:</b> If one said: <b>This loaf</b> shall remain <b>unconsecrated today, and tomorrow</b> it shall be <b>consecrated, and he</b> then <b>said: Establish an <i>eiruv</i> for me with this</b> loaf, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do we say that since the twilight period’s status as part of the previous day or part of the day that follows is questionable, the consecration of the loaf may take effect before the <i>eiruv</i> establishes one’s Shabbat residence, and since an <i>eiruv</i> cannot be made with a consecrated object, the <i>eiruv</i> is not valid? Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rava: In that case, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
Rava then asked about one who made the opposite statement: This loaf shall be <b>consecrated today, and tomorrow</b> it shall be <b>unconsecrated,</b> i.e., it shall be redeemed with money that I have in my house, <b>and he</b> then <b>said: Establish an <i>eiruv</i> for me with this</b> loaf, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: His <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> Rava asked him: <b>What is different</b> between the two cases? If we are lenient with regard to the twilight period, we should be lenient in both cases.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rava in jest: <b>After you eat a <i>kor</i> of salt over it,</b> and analyze the matter at length, you will be able to understand the difference. The difference is obvious: When one says that <b>today</b> the loaf shall remain <b>unconsecrated, and tomorrow</b> it shall be <b>consecrated,</b> we do <b>not</b> assume <b>out of doubt</b> that <b>sanctity has descended upon</b> the loaf. Therefore, the loaf remains in its presumptive state of being unconsecrated during the twilight period, and the <i>eiruv</i> is valid. With regard to the opposite case, however, when one says that <b>today</b> the loaf shall be <b>consecrated, and tomorrow</b> it shall be <b>unconsecrated,</b> we do <b>not</b> assume <b>out of doubt</b> that the loaf’s <b>sanctity has departed from it.</b> The loaf remains in its presumptive state of consecration for the duration of the twilight period, and therefore the <i>eiruv</i> is invalid.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there:</b> If <b>one filled a flask that was immersed during the day [<i>tevul yom</i>]</b> but does not become fully ritually pure until night <b>from a barrel of tithe</b> that was still <b><i>tevel</i>,</b> meaning that the produce inside was first tithe from which <i>teruma</i> of the tithe had not yet been separated, <b>and he said: Let</b> the contents of <b>this</b> flask <b>be <i>teruma</i> of the tithe</b> for the contents of the barrel <b>when night falls, his statement takes effect.</b> If he were to say that the designated portion should immediately become <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe would be defiled by the flask that is still a <i>tevul yom</i>. Once night falls, however, the flask is absolutely pure, and if the designation of the flask’s contents as <i>teruma</i> of the tithe takes effect at that time, the produce remains pure. The mishna teaches that <i>teruma</i> of the tithe can be separated in this manner.
The mishna continues: <b>And if he said: Establish an <i>eiruv</i> for me with</b> the contents of <b>this</b> flask, <b>he has not said anything,</b> as the contents of the flask are still <i>tevel</i>. <b>Rava said: That is to say</b> that <b>the end of the day</b> is when <b>the <i>eiruv</i> acquires</b> one’s Shabbat residence. The critical time with respect to an <i>eiruv</i> is the last moment of Shabbat eve, rather than the first moment of Shabbat.

Daf 36b

<b>As, if it should enter your mind</b> that <b>an <i>eiruv</i> acquires</b> one’s Shabbat residence at <b>the beginning of the day</b> of Shabbat, then <b>if he said: Establish an <i>eiruv</i> for me with</b> the produce in <b>this</b> flask, <b>why hasn’t he said anything?</b> After nightfall, when Shabbat begins, the flask is already pure, and therefore the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe inside it is also pure and is suitable for an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This is no proof; <b>even if you say</b> that <b>an <i>eiruv</i> acquires</b> one’s Shabbat residence at <b>the beginning of the day</b> of Shabbat, nonetheless, <b>we require a meal that is fit</b> to be eaten <b>while it is still day,</b> prior to the onset of Shabbat, in order for the <i>eiruv</i> to be valid, <b>and there is none</b> in this case. While it was still day, it was certainly prohibited to consume the contents of the flask, which were still <i>tevel</i>, and therefore it could not be used as an <i>eiruv</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person may make a condition with regard to his <i>eiruv</i></b> of Shabbat borders. In other words, he need not decide in advance in which direction his <i>eiruv</i> should take effect. For example, he may deposit an <i>eiruv</i> on each of two opposite sides of his town, <b>and say: If gentiles come from the east, my <i>eiruv</i> is in the west,</b> so that I can escape in that direction; and if they come <b>from the west, my <i>eiruv</i> is in the east. If they come from here and from there,</b> i.e., from both directions, <b>I will go wherever I wish,</b> and my <i>eiruv</i> will retroactively take effect in that direction; and <b>if they do not come</b> at all, <b>neither from here nor from there, I will be like</b> the rest of <b>the inhabitants of my town</b> and give up both <i>eiruvin</i> that I deposited, leaving me with two thousand cubits in all directions from the town.
Similarly, one may say: <b>If a Sage comes from the east</b> and he is spending Shabbat beyond the boundaries of my town, <b>my <i>eiruv</i> is in the east,</b> so that I may go out to greet him there; and if he comes <b>from the west, my <i>eiruv</i> is in the west.</b> If one Sage <b>comes from here, and</b> another Sage comes <b>from there, I will go wherever I wish; and</b> if no Sage comes, <b>neither from here nor from there, I will be like</b> the rest of <b>the inhabitants of my town. Rabbi Yehuda says: If one of</b> the Sages coming from opposite directions <b>was his teacher, he may go</b> only <b>to his teacher,</b> as it is assumed that was his original intention. <b>And if they were both his teachers,</b> so that there is no reason to suppose that he preferred one over the other, <b>he may go wherever he wishes.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara relates that <b>when Rabbi Yitzḥak came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he taught all</b> of the laws in <b>the mishna in the opposite</b> manner. That is to say, according to him, if the gentiles came from the east, his <i>eiruv</i> would be to the east, and, conversely, if the Sage came from the east, his <i>eiruv</i> would be to the west. This is <b>difficult</b> because if this is correct, there is a contradiction <b>between</b> the ruling concerning <b>gentiles</b> in the mishna and the ruling concerning <b>gentiles</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and</b> similarly there is a contradiction <b>between</b> the ruling concerning <b>a Sage</b> in the mishna <b>and</b> the ruling concerning <b>a Sage</b> in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction <b>between</b> the ruling concerning <b>gentiles</b> in the mishna <b>and</b> the ruling concerning <b>gentiles</b> in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>not difficult: This</b> case in the mishna is referring to <b>a tax collector [<i>parhagabena</i>],</b> from whom one wishes to flee; whereas <b>that</b> case in the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>the lord of the town,</b> with whom he wishes to speak. Therefore, there are times that one wants to go out toward the gentile, while at other times one wants to flee from him.
Similarly, the apparent contradiction <b>between</b> the ruling concerning <b>a Sage</b> in the mishna <b>and</b> the ruling concerning <b>a Sage</b> in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>not difficult: This</b> case in the mishna is referring to a scholar <b>who sits</b> and delivers public Torah <b>lectures,</b> and one wishes to come and learn Torah from him; whereas <b>that</b> case in the <i>baraita</i> is referring to one <b>who teaches</b> children how to <b>recite</b> the <b><i>Shema</i>,</b> i.e., one who teaches young children how to pray, of whom he has no need. The <i>baraita</i> teaches that if a scholar came from one direction to deliver a public lecture and the school teacher came from the opposite direction, his <i>eiruv</i> is in the direction of the scholar.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If one of</b> the Sages <b>was</b> his teacher, he may go only to his teacher, as we can assume that this was his original intention. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is the reason that <b>the Rabbis</b> do not accept this straightforward argument? The Gemara answers: The Rabbis maintain that <b>sometimes</b> one <b>prefers</b> to meet the Sage who is <b>his colleague rather than</b> the Sage who is <b>his teacher,</b> as sometimes one learns more from his peers than from his teachers.
<b>Rav said:</b> This version of <b>the mishna</b> should <b>not</b> be accepted <b>because of what</b> the Sage <b>Ayo taught</b> to the opposite effect, <b>as Ayo taught</b> the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: A person cannot make conditions about two things at once,</b> i.e., he cannot say that if one Sage comes from one direction and another Sage comes from the other direction, he will go wherever he wishes. <b>Rather,</b> he may say that <b>if a Sage came from the east, his <i>eiruv</i> is in the east, and if a Sage came from the west, his <i>eiruv</i> is in the west. But</b> he may <b>not</b> say that if one Sage came <b>from here, and</b> another Sage came <b>from there,</b> he will go wherever he wishes.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about a case in which one stipulated that if Sages came <b>from here and from there</b> he may go to whichever side he chooses, such <b>that</b> his <i>eiruv</i> <b>is not</b> effective? Apparently, this is due to the principle that <b>there is no retroactive designation,</b> meaning that a doubtful state of affairs cannot be clarified retroactively. However, according to this principle, when one established an <i>eiruv</i> <b>to the east</b> and <b>to the west</b> in order to be able to travel in the direction of one Sage who comes toward the town in a case where one does not know in advance from which direction he will come, we should <b>also</b> invoke the principle that <b>there is no retroactive designation.</b> Therefore, even if one deposited an <i>eiruv</i> at both ends of his town for the sake of one Sage who might come from either side, he should not be able to rely on what becomes clarified afterward and decide retroactively which <i>eiruv</i> he is interested in.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is not a true case of retroactive designation, as <b>the Sage had already come</b> by twilight but the person who established the <i>eiruv</i> did not yet know which side of the town the Sage had come toward. Therefore, at the time the <i>eiruv</i> establishes his Shabbat residence it is clear which <i>eiruv</i> the person wants, even though he himself will only become aware of that later.
The Gemara poses a question with regard to Rav’s statement cited above: Why should we reject the mishna because of the <i>baraita</i>? <b>On the contrary,</b> let us say that the ruling of <b>Ayo</b> should <b>not</b> be accepted <b>because of the mishna.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It should not enter your mind</b> to uphold the mishna’s ruling because it contradicts other sources, <b>as we have</b> already <b>heard that Rabbi Yehuda does not</b> accept the principle of <b>retroactive designation. As it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who buys wine from among the Samaritans [<i>Kutim</i>],</b> who do not tithe their produce properly,

Daf 37a

<b>may say: Two <i>log</i></b> of the hundred <i>log</i> present here, <b>which I will separate in the future,</b> when I have finished drinking, <b>shall be</b> the great <b><i>teruma</i></b> given to a priest; <b>ten</b> <i>log</i> shall be <b>first tithe;</b> and <b>nine</b> <i>log</i>, which are a tenth of the remaining ninety <i>log</i>, shall be <b>second tithe. He</b> then <b>redeems</b> the second-tithe with money because in its sanctified state second tithe may only be consumed in Jerusalem, <b>and he may</b> then <b>immediately drink</b> the wine, and the wine remaining at the end will be <i>teruma</i> and tithes. One may rely on the principle of retroactive designation and say that when he is finished drinking, the wine that is left becomes retroactively designated as <i>teruma</i> and tithes, such that the wine he drank was permitted for consumption. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Shimon prohibit</b> drinking the wine in this manner. Therefore, it would appear that Rabbi Yehuda rejects the principle of retroactive designation, contrary to the ruling of the mishna and in accordance with the opinion of Ayo.
<b>Ulla</b> also took note of this contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Yehuda, but he <b>said</b> the opposite: The statement of <b>Ayo</b> should <b>not</b> be accepted <b>because</b> it contradicts what is stated in <b>the mishna.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But that which was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Shimon prohibit</b> drinking the wine in this manner, indicates, as was demonstrated above, that Rabbi Yehuda rejects the principle of retroactive designation.
<b>Ulla taught</b> the names of the authorities mentioned in the <i>Tosefta</i> dealing with wine <b>in pairs,</b> as follows: The allowance mentioned in the <i>Tosefta</i> is according to <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda,</b> whereas <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon prohibit</b> drinking the wine in this manner. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda agrees with Rabbi Meir and accepts the principle of retroactive designation, in accordance with the mishna.
To this point, it has been accepted that Rabbi Yosei clearly prohibits the procedure described in the <i>Tosefta</i>. Therefore, he apparently rejects the principle of retroactive designation. With regard to this point, the Gemara asks: <b>Does Rabbi Yosei</b> really <b>hold that there is no retroactive designation? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna elsewhere that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> If <b>two women took their birds’ nests,</b> pairs of turtledoves or pigeons as purification offerings following childbirth, <b>jointly</b> and without specifying which pair of birds was for which woman, <b>or</b> if <b>they gave their birds’ nests to a priest</b> but did not inform him which birds were consecrated as sin-offerings and which as burnt-offerings, <b>whichever the priest wishes he may offer as a burnt-offering, and whichever he wishes he may offer as a sin-offering.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Yosei must accept the principle of retroactive designation, such that when the priest offers any of the birds as a sacrifice, it is retroactively clarified that the bird had been selected for that woman and as that sacrifice.
<b>Rabba said:</b> There is no proof from there, with regard to retroactive designation, as the mishna <b>there</b> deals with a special case, <b>where</b> the women <b>stipulated</b> from the outset that the priest would decide which bird would be offered for which woman and as what sacrifice.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> need was there for the mishna <b>to say</b> anything? If they made an explicit stipulation to that effect, then the priest certainly has the power to fulfill their condition. The Gemara answers: The mishna nonetheless <b>teaches us</b> that the law is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda, as Rav Ḥisda said: Birds’ nests become designated</b> as burnt-offerings or sin-offerings <b>only</b>

Daf 37b

<b>when they are purchased by their owner,</b> if the owner explicitly consecrated it as a burnt-offering or sin-offering when he purchased it, <b>or through the actions of the priest</b> when he offers the birds as sacrifices. Therefore, even if the women did not verbalize their intentions, it is considered as if they had made a stipulation from the outset. Therefore, this case is not an instance of retroactive designation.
<b>And still</b> the question may be raised: Does <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> really <b>hold</b> that <b>there is no retroactive designation? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>an <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> who is not known to be scrupulous in separating tithes, <b>said to a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> one known to be meticulous in his observance of <i>halakha</i> and especially the laws of <i>teruma</i> and tithes, before the <i>ḥaver</i> went to the market to buy himself vegetables from another <i>am ha’aretz</i>: <b>Buy for me</b> as well <b>a bundle of vegetables or a cake [<i>geluska</i>],</b> the <i>ḥaver</i> <b>does not need to tithe</b> the food that he gives to the <i>am ha’aretz</i>. The only reason the food needs to be tithed is because it is <i>demai</i>, and an <i>am ha’aretz</i> is not particular about that issue. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei.</b> It can be deduced from this ruling that Rabbi Yosei accepts the principle of retroactive designation, as the <i>ḥaver</i> purchased bundles of vegetables without specifying which was for himself and which was for the <i>am ha’aretz</i>, and when he gave one to the <i>am ha’aretz</i>, it became retroactively clear that he had purchased that bundle for the <i>am ha’aretz</i> from the start, and therefore he does not need to separate tithes from it as <i>demai</i>.
<b>And the Rabbis say: He must tithe</b> it. Since we do not accept the principle of retroactive designation, everything that the <i>ḥaver</i> bought was bought for himself, and the fact that he later gave part of it to the <i>am ha’aretz</i> does not exempt him from his original obligation to separate tithes from the <i>demai</i>. In any case, it seems that Rabbi Yosei’s opinion in this <i>baraita</i> contradicts his opinion in the <i>Tosefta</i> cited above with regard to wine. The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the opinions in the <i>baraita</i> and say that according to Rabbi Yosei he must tithe the produce he gives to the <i>am ha’aretz</i>, while the Rabbis permit him to proceed without tithing.
The Gemara attempts to bring another proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a different <i>Tosefta</i>: In the case of <b>one who says:</b> The second <b>tithe that I have in my house shall be redeemed upon the <i>sela</i></b> coin <b>that will</b> happen to <b>come up in my hand</b> when I remove it <b>from the pouch,</b> i.e., he did not have a particular coin in mind, <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The second tithe <b>is redeemed.</b> When the coin is removed from the pouch, it is retroactively clarified that this is the coin that he had in his mind from the outset. This indicates that Rabbi Yosei accepts the principle of retroactive designation.
The Gemara answers again: <b>Reverse</b> the attributions, and <b>say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: He has not redeemed</b> the second tithe. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>What did you see that you reversed two</b> sources <b>because of one,</b> and made the two <i>baraitot</i> conform to the mishna, which indicates that Rabbi Yosei holds that there is no retroactive designation? Perhaps <b>I should reverse one</b> source, i.e., the mishna, <b>because of</b> the <b>two</b> <i>baraitot</i> and say that in fact Rabbi Yosei accepts the principle of retroactive designation, and it is the lone source that indicates otherwise that must be revised.
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> <i>Tosefta</i> was <b>certainly taught in reverse,</b> as <b>the latter clause states: And Rabbi Yosei concedes with regard to one who says: The</b> second <b>tithe that I have in my house shall be redeemed with the new <i>sela</i></b> coin <b>that will</b> happen to <b>come up in my hand</b> when I remove it <b>from the pouch, that he has redeemed</b> the second tithe. The Gemara makes the following inference: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it said here that he has redeemed</b> the second tithe, it can be proven <b>by inference that there,</b> in the first clause of the <i>Tosefta</i>, <b>he did not redeem</b> the second tithe. Therefore, the wording found in the earlier part of the <i>baraita</i> is clearly incorrect and must be reversed.
The Gemara raises a question with regard to the <i>halakha</i> cited in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>This new <i>sela</i>, what are its circumstances? If</b> it is referring to a situation <b>where there are two</b> or <b>three</b> coins in his pouch, so that it is not clear which coin he is referring to, <b>and there is</b> the possibility of <b>retroactive designation, this is</b> exactly the same as <b>the first</b> case. Why does he rule here, as opposed to the earlier case, that there is retroactive designation? <b>Rather,</b> it must refer to a situation <b>where he has only one</b> coin in his pouch. But if so, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the expression: <b>Will</b> happen to <b>come up?</b>
The Gemara answers: In fact, it is referring to a case where one has only one coin in his pouch, and the wording of the latter clause is imprecise. <b>Since the first clause taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> using this expression: <b>Will</b> happen to <b>come up, the latter clause also taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> using this same expression: <b>Will</b> happen to <b>come up,</b> even though he was referring to the only new coin that he has in his pouch.
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: Who is this <i>tanna</i></b> who <b>does not accept</b> the principle of <b>retroactive designation even concerning rabbinic decrees? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one person <b>said to five</b> people: <b>I am hereby establishing an <i>eiruv</i> for whichever one of you I will choose,</b> so that the person <b>I have chosen will</b> be able to <b>walk</b> two thousand cubits from the spot of the <i>eiruv</i>, whereas whomever <b>I have not chosen will not</b> be able to <b>walk</b> two thousand cubits from the location of the <i>eiruv</i>, the following distinction applies: If <b>he chose</b> the person for whom he was making the <i>eiruv</i> before Shabbat, <b>while it was still day, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>;</b> but if he only chose him <b>after nightfall, his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> The <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> apparently rejects the principle of retroactive designation, even with regard to rabbinic enactments, as if that were not the case, the <i>eiruv</i> should be valid even if he only chose the person for whom he was making the <i>eiruv</i> after nightfall.
Rav Naḥman <b>was silent and did not say anything to</b> Rava. The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> Rav Naḥman <b>say to him</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is the opinion of a Sage <b>of the school of Ayo,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, which maintains that even with regard to an <i>eiruv</i> there is no retroactive designation. The Gemara answers: <b>He did not accept</b> Ayo’s version of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion and considered it incorrect.
<b>Rav Yosef said,</b> in his unique style: Have <b>you removed the <i>tanna’im</i> from the world?</b> Is there no <i>tanna</i> who holds this position? The possibility of retroactive designation with regard to rabbinic enactments <b>is</b> a dispute among <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One said: <b>I am hereby establishing an <i>eiruv</i> for the <i>Shabbatot</i> of the entire year,</b> so that <b>if I want</b> to make use of it, <b>I will</b> be able to <b>walk</b> two thousand cubits from the <i>eiruv</i>, and <b>if I do not want</b> to do so, <b>I will not walk. If he wanted</b> to make use of the <i>eiruv</i> for a particular Shabbat <b>while it was still day, his <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i></b> for that Shabbat. However, if he only decided <b>after nightfall</b> that he wanted the <i>eiruv</i> to be in effect, the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: His <i>eiruv</i> is</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>; and the Rabbis say: His <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> a valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> This indicates that according to the Rabbis there is no retroactive designation, even with regard to <i>eiruvin</i>, while Rabbi Shimon holds that his <i>eiruv</i> is in effect because of the principle of retroactive designation.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t we hear that Rabbi Shimon does not accept</b> the principle of <b>retroactive designation</b> in the case of wine from <i>Kutim</i>? The contradiction between one ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon and</b> another ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> himself <b>is difficult.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, reverse</b> the opinions and say that it is Rabbi Shimon who holds that his <i>eiruv</i> is not valid, and therefore he can be identified as the <i>tanna</i> who holds that there is no retroactive designation at all, even with regard to rabbinic decrees.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the difficulty</b> here? <b>Perhaps it is with regard to Torah law that Rabbi Shimon does not accept</b> the principle of <b>retroactive designation, but with regard to rabbinic</b> decrees, <b>he does accept</b> the principle of retroactive designation. Therefore, it is not necessary to reverse the opinions.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Yosef holds</b> that <b>one who accepts</b> the principle of <b>retroactive designation accepts it</b> in all cases; <b>there is no difference</b> between <b>Torah law and rabbinic</b> decrees. <b>And one who does not accept</b> the principle of <b>retroactive designation does not accept it</b> at all; <b>there is no difference</b> between <b>Torah law and rabbinic</b> decrees.
<b>Rava said:</b> The distinction between the case of the wine and the other cases is not related to the principle of retroactive designation. Rather, <b>there,</b> the case of the wine of a <i>Kuti</i>, <b>is different, as we require</b> that the <i>teruma</i> be <b>the first</b> of your produce, <b>whose remnants are recognizable.</b> Since <i>teruma</i> is called the first, if it is not clear which portion was separated and which portion is left over, the designation of part of the wine as <i>teruma</i> is not effective, despite the fact that Rabbi Shimon accepts the principle of retroactive designation.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> Do you really think that this ruling is correct? <b>But if that is so,</b> if <b>there were two pomegranates</b> that were <b><i>tevel</i> before him, and he said: If rain falls today, this</b> pomegranate <b>shall be <i>teruma</i> for that</b> other pomegranate, <b>and if rain does not fall today, that</b> second pomegranate <b>shall be <i>teruma</i> for this</b> first one, <b>so too, whether</b> rain <b>fell or did not fall, there is no</b> significance to <b>his statement</b> because the remnants that are not <i>teruma</i> are not immediately recognizable.
<b>And if you say</b> that indeed, it <b>is so,</b> there is a difficulty. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that if one says: <b>The <i>teruma</i> of this pile</b> of produce <b>and its tithes shall be inside it,</b> without specifying the location of the produce that he is designating for these purposes, <b>and</b> similarly, if one says about a pile of first-tithe produce: <b>The <i>teruma</i> of this tithe shall be inside it,</b> without specifying the location, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: He has given it a name,</b> i.e., the designation of the <i>teruma</i> and tithes take effect, even though it is impossible to distinguish between them and the permitted portion of the produce? Therefore, it is not necessary for the remnants of the act of separation to be recognizable.
Rava refutes this argument: <b>There,</b> with regard to a pile of produce, <b>it is different because there are</b> recognizable remnants <b>around it.</b> He specified that the <i>teruma</i> should be inside the heap, which indicates that it is in the middle of the pile, and therefore the produce on the perimeter of the pile is certainly not <i>teruma</i>, and some of the remnants of the act of separation are recognizable.
<b>And if you wish,</b> you can reconcile the difference between the case of separating <i>teruma</i> from wine and the other cases and <b>say in accordance with the reason that was taught</b> in the case of the wine: The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Meir: Don’t you concede</b> that <b>perhaps the</b> leather <b>flask will burst</b> before he manages to separate the <i>teruma</i>, <b>and retroactively this</b> person would have been <b>drinking <i>tevel</i>?</b> Since he never ended up separating <i>teruma</i>, the wine remained <i>tevel</i> all along. Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: When it bursts,</b> I will consider the matter, but presently I am not concerned that the bottle might burst. Therefore, we see that these <i>tanna’im</i> do not disagree about the principle of retroactive designation but over the likelihood that the flask will burst.
The Gemara now asks: <b>And according to what initially entered our minds,</b> which is <b>that we require</b> <i>teruma</i> that is <b>the first, whose remnants are recognizable what did</b> the Rabbis <b>say to</b> Rabbi Meir about that? That is the objection they should have raised against him.
The Gemara answers: <b>This is what they said to him: According to our</b> own opinion, <b>we require</b> <i>teruma</i> that is <b>the first, whose remnants are recognizable; according to your</b> opinion,

Daf 38a

<b>don’t you</b> at least <b>concede</b> that we must be concerned that <b>perhaps the</b> leather <b>flask will burst, and retroactively this</b> person would have been <b>drinking <i>tevel</i>?</b> Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: When it bursts,</b> I will consider the matter, but now I am not concerned about this possibility.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>a Festival adjacent to Shabbat, whether before it,</b> on a Friday, <b>or after it,</b> on a Sunday, <b>a person</b> may <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i></b> of Shabbat borders [<i>teḥumin</i>] <b>and say</b> as follows: <b>My <i>eiruv</i> on the first</b> day shall be <b>to the east, and on the second</b> day <b>to the west.</b> Alternatively, one may say: <b>On the first</b> day it shall be <b>to the west and on the second</b> day <b>to the east.</b> Similarly, one may say: <b>My <i>eiruv</i></b> shall apply <b>on the first</b> day, <b>but on the second</b> day I shall be <b>like</b> the rest of <b>the inhabitants of my town,</b> or: <b>My <i>eiruv</i></b> shall apply <b>on the second</b> day, <b>but on the first</b> day I shall be <b>like</b> the rest of <b>the inhabitants of my town.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis</b> disagree and <b>say</b> that such a split is impossible. Rather, <b>he either establishes an <i>eiruv</i> in one direction</b> for both days, <b>or he establishes no <i>eiruv</i> at all; either he establishes an <i>eiruv</i> for</b> the <b>two days, or he establishes no <i>eiruv</i> at all.</b>
<b>What does one do</b> to establish an <i>eiruv</i> that will be valid for both the Festival and Shabbat? <b>He</b> or his agent <b>brings</b> the <i>eiruv</i> to the location that he wishes to establish as his residence <b>on</b> the eve of <b>the first</b> day, <b>and he stays</b> there <b>with it until nightfall,</b> the time when the <i>eiruv</i> establishes that location as his residence for the Festival, <b>and</b> then <b>he takes it</b> with him <b>and goes away,</b> so that it will not become lost before the following evening, in which case he would not have an <i>eiruv</i> for the second day. <b>On</b> the eve of the <b>second</b> day, he takes it back to the same place as the day before, and <b>he stays</b> there <b>with it until nightfall,</b> thereby establishing his residence for Shabbat, and then he may <b>eat</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>and go away,</b> if he so desires. <b>Consequently, he benefits</b> in that he is permitted to <b>walk</b> in the direction that he desires, <b>and he benefits</b> in that he is permitted to eat <b>his <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
However, if the <i>eiruv</i> <b>was eaten on</b> the <b>first</b> day, <b>his <i>eiruv</i></b> is effective <b>for</b> the <b>first</b> day, <b>and his <i>eiruv</i> is not</b> effective <b>for the second</b> day.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to them:</b> If so, <b>you agree with me that</b> Shabbat and a Festival <b>constitute two</b> distinct <b>sanctities,</b> as if not, the <i>eiruv</i> that went into effect during the twilight period on the eve of the first day should have remained in effect for both days, even if it was eaten during the first day. This being the case, you should also agree with me that one can make two separate <i>eiruvin</i> for the two days in two different directions.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to the wording employed by the Rabbis: First, the Rabbis state that one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>in one direction. What does this</b> mean? He must establish an <i>eiruv</i> in that direction <b>for two days.</b> Then they state that he may establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>for two days. What does this</b> mean? He must establish an <i>eiruv</i> for the two days <b>in one direction.</b> If so, <b>this is</b> exactly the same as <b>the first</b> clause.
The Gemara explains: <b>This is what the Rabbis said to Rabbi Eliezer: Don’t you concede that</b> in the case of <b>one day, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for half</b> the day <b>to the north and</b> for <b>half of it to the south?</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them: Indeed,</b> I agree. They then said to him: <b>Just as one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for one day, half</b> the day <b>to the north and half</b> the day <b>to the south, so too, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for two</b> consecutive <b>days</b> of sanctity, <b>one day to the east and one day to the west.</b>
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> respond? He holds as follows: <b>There,</b> one day constitutes <b>one sanctity,</b> and it is impossible to impossible to divide the day such that the <i>eiruv</i> applies to one direction for one half of the day and to another direction for the other half of the day. <b>Here,</b> where Shabbat and a Festival fall out on consecutive days, they are <b>two</b> separate <b>sanctities,</b> and therefore one can establish separate <i>eiruvin</i> for the two days.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>Don’t you concede that if one established an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet</b> by actually going to the place where he desires to establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>on</b> the eve of <b>the first day</b> and remaining there during the twilight period, as opposed to depositing food there beforehand, he nonetheless must <b>establish</b> another <b><i>eiruv</i> with his feet on</b> the eve of <b>the second day,</b> and one <i>eiruv</i> does not suffice; similarly, if <b>his <i>eiruv</i> was eaten on the first day, he may not</b> rely <b>on it</b> and <b>go out</b> beyond the limit permitted to the rest of the inhabitants of his town <b>on the second day?</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to him: Indeed,</b> that is correct. Rabbi Eliezer then <b>said to them:</b> Then <b>isn’t it</b> correct that <b>they are two</b> distinct <b>sanctities,</b> and therefore one should be permitted to establish two separate <i>eiruvin</i> for the two days? <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond? <b>They are in doubt</b> about this issue, <b>and</b> therefore their ruling <b>here is stringent</b> and prohibits establishing separate <i>eiruvin</i> for the two days in different directions, in case the two days are considered a single sanctity; <b>and</b> their ruling <b>here is stringent</b> and they require a separate <i>eiruv</i> for each day, in case the two days are considered distinct sanctities.
The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Eliezer: Don’t you concede that one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> initially on a Festival for Shabbat,</b> i.e., if a Festival occurs on a Friday and one forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i> on the eve of the Festival, he may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for Shabbat on the Festival itself? Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them: Indeed,</b> that is correct. They said to him: Then <b>isn’t it</b> correct that the two days constitute <b>one sanctity?</b>
The Gemara responds that <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> holds that <b>there,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is so not because the two days constitute a single sanctity, but <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b>preparation</b> on a Festival for Shabbat, which includes establishing an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one established an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet</b> by going to the place he wished to establish as his residence <b>on</b> the eve of <b>the first day</b> and remaining there during the twilight period, <b>he must</b> nevertheless <b>establish</b> another <b><i>eiruv</i> with his feet on</b> the eve of <b>the second day.</b> Similarly, if he had established an <i>eiruv</i> by depositing food in the place he wished to establish as his residence, and <b>his <i>eiruv</i> was eaten on the first day, he may not</b> rely <b>on it</b> and <b>go out</b> beyond the limit permitted to the rest of the inhabitants of the town <b>on the second day.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b>

Daf 38b

<b>This</b> person <b>is</b> in the position of both <b>a donkey driver,</b> who must prod the animal from behind, <b>and a camel driver,</b> who must lead the animal from the front, i.e., he is pulled in two opposing directions. Since we are unsure whether the two days constitute one sanctity or two, he must act stringently as though the <i>eiruv</i> established for the first day is both effective and not effective for the second day, i.e., he must restrict his Shabbat movement to those areas where he would be permitted to go in both cases.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, say:</b> If <b>he established an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet on</b> the eve of <b>the first</b> day, <b>he</b> need <b>not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet on</b> the eve of <b>the second</b> day, as his <i>eiruv</i> remains effective for the second day as well. Similarly, if he had made an <i>eiruv</i> by depositing food in the place where he wished to establish his residence, and <b>his <i>eiruv</i> was eaten on the first day, he may</b> still rely <b>on it</b> and <b>go out</b> beyond the limit permitted to the rest of the inhabitants of the town <b>on the second</b> day, as the two days constitute one sanctity; from the outset, the <i>eiruv</i> acquired his place of rest for both days.
<b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>these four Elders and in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said:</b> When Shabbat and a Festival occur on consecutive days, <b>they</b> constitute <b>two</b> distinct <b>sanctities. And these are the four Elders: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel; Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka; Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon; and Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda, the</b> one whose opinions were often recorded as <b>unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i>. <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say: One of them is Rabbi Elazar, and remove</b> from the list <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda, the</b> one whose statements were often recorded as <b>unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Didn’t we hear that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka,</b> maintain <b>the opposite</b> opinion in the <i>baraita</i> cited above, namely that the two days constitute a single sanctity? The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the attributions in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, this is</b> exactly what <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi said. What is their dispute? The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that there is no disagreement between them, and the <i>baraita</i> should read as follows: <b>And so too, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said</b> that he agrees with what was stated above.
The Gemara now asks: <b>Let us also count Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi among these Elders, as he too holds that the two days are distinct sanctities. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught this</b> opinion, <b>and</b> he himself <b>did not hold it</b> to be correct. He transmitted a ruling that he received from his teachers, but his own opinion was otherwise.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, let us also say that <b>the Rabbis,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and Rabbi Yishmael <b>also taught</b> this law, <b>and</b> they themselves <b>did not hold it</b> to be correct. What proof is there that this represents their own opinions? The Gemara answers: <b>Rav</b> did not rely on the wording of these sources; rather, he <b>learned by</b> way of a definite <b>tradition</b> that these four Elders maintained this position.
The Gemara relates that <b>when Rav Huna,</b> Rav’s preeminent student, <b>passed away, Rav Ḥisda entered</b> the study hall <b>to raise a contradiction between</b> one statement of <b>Rav and</b> another statement of <b>Rav: Did Rav</b> actually <b>say:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the four Elders and in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> that when Shabbat and a Festival fall out on consecutive days, <b>they</b> constitute <b>two</b> distinct <b>sanctities?</b>
<b>Wasn’t it stated</b> that with regard to a case where <b>Shabbat and a Festival</b> occur on consecutive days, <b>Rav said:</b> An egg that <b>was laid on one is prohibited on the other,</b> just as an egg that was laid on a Festival day is prohibited on that same day? This statement indicates that the two days constitute a single sanctity. How, then, can he say here that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion that they are two distinct sanctities?
<b>Rabba said</b> that a distinction may be drawn between the cases: <b>There,</b> the egg is prohibited on the second day not because the two days constitute a single sanctity but <b>because of</b> the prohibition against <b>preparation,</b> i.e., because it is prohibited to prepare things on a Festival for Shabbat or on Shabbat for a Festival.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse that states: <b>“And it shall come to pass, on the sixth day, when they shall prepare</b> that which they bring in” (Exodus 16:5), indicates as follows: On an ordinary <b>weekday one may prepare</b> what is needed <b>for Shabbat, and</b> similarly, on an ordinary <b>weekday one may prepare</b> what is needed <b>for a Festival.</b> However, on <b>a Festival one may not prepare for Shabbat, and</b> on <b>Shabbat one may not prepare for a Festival.</b> Therefore, an egg that was laid on a Festival is prohibited on Shabbat not because they constitute a single sanctity, but because it is prohibited to prepare on one sanctified day for another.
<b>Abaye said to him: But</b> what about <b>that which we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>What does he do</b> if a Festival occurs on Friday, and he wishes to establish an <i>eiruv</i> that will be valid for the Festival and Shabbat? <b>He</b> or his agent <b>takes</b> the <i>eiruv</i> to the spot that he wishes to establish as his residence <b>on</b> the eve of <b>the first</b> day, <b>and he stays</b> there <b>with it until nightfall, and</b> then <b>he takes it</b> with him <b>and goes away. On the</b> eve of the <b>second</b> day, i.e., on Friday afternoon, he or his agent takes the <i>eiruv</i> back to the same place <b>and stays</b> there <b>with it until nightfall, and</b> then he may <b>eat</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>and go away,</b> if he so desires. <b>Isn’t he preparing on a Festival for Shabbat?</b> According to Rabba, this should be considered a prohibited act of preparation.
<b>Rabba said to him: Do you think that the <i>eiruv</i> acquires</b> one’s residence <b>at the end of the day,</b> i.e., at the last moment of Shabbat eve, which in this case is a Festival, so that this would involve prohibited preparation? <b>The <i>eiruv</i> acquires</b> his residence <b>at the beginning of the day,</b> i.e., at the first moment of Shabbat, which means that no preparations were made for Shabbat on the Festival, <b>and</b> on <b>Shabbat</b> one may <b>prepare for</b> Shabbat <b>itself.</b>
Abaye asked: <b>But if that is so, one should</b> be able to <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with flasks</b> of wine that were filled from a barrel of first-tithe that was still <i>tevel</i> with respect to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, and with regard to which one said: Let this wine in the flask be <i>teruma</i> of the tithe for the wine in the barrel only after nightfall. If you say that an <i>eiruv</i> acquires one’s residence at the beginning of the day, why was it determined that one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with such wine?
The Gemara answers: In that case the <i>eiruv</i> is not valid for a different reason: <b>We require a meal that is fit</b> to be eaten <b>while it is still day, and there is none,</b> as the wine in the flask remains <i>tevel</i> and therefore unfit for drinking until nightfall.
Abaye asked further: <b>But</b> what about <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If <b>a Festival is adjacent to Shabbat, whether before it or after it, a person may establish two <i>eiruvin</i>.</b> Why are these <i>eiruvin</i> valid? <b>Don’t we require a meal that is fit</b> to be eaten <b>while it is still day, and there is none?</b> Since one established his <i>eiruv</i> in one direction for the first day, he can only travel within a two-thousand-cubit radius of that location. Therefore, if he established his <i>eiruv</i> for the second day in the opposite direction, he cannot access that <i>eiruv</i> during the first day.
The Gemara responds: <b>Do you think that</b> we are dealing with a case where <b>he placed</b> one <i>eiruv</i> in the furthest possible spot <b>at the end of two thousand cubits in this</b> direction, <b>and</b> he placed the other <i>eiruv</i> in the furthest possible spot <b>at the end of two thousand cubits in that</b> direction, and he is therefore unable to go from one to the other on one day? <b>No,</b> the case is <b>that he placed</b> one <i>eiruv</i> <b>at the end of one thousand cubits in the this direction, and</b> he placed the other <i>eiruv</i> <b>at the end of one thousand cubits in that</b> direction, so that even after acquiring his residence on one side of the town by means of the first <i>eiruv</i>, he can still go to the spot where he left the other <i>eiruv</i> for the second day.
Abaye raised yet another difficulty: <b>But</b> what about <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> If <b>one established an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet</b> for the <b>first day, he may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet</b> for the <b>second day;</b> and if <b>he established an <i>eiruv</i> with bread on</b> the <b>first day, he may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with bread on</b> the <b>second day? Isn’t he preparing from a Festival to Shabbat?</b>
Rabba <b>said to him: Do you think that one must go and say something</b> at the site of the <i>eiruv</i>, therefore performing an act of preparation? <b>He goes, and is silent, and sits</b> there, and he automatically acquires his residence without having to say or do anything. This does not fall into the category of prohibited preparation.
Abaye asked: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion do you say that nothing must be said when establishing an <i>eiruv teḥumin</i>? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, who said:</b> A sleeping person acquires a Shabbat residence in the spot where he is sleeping. Even though he is comparable to ownerless property, <b>ownerless property</b> itself <b>acquires a Shabbat residence</b> and has its own Shabbat boundary, and there is no need for a person to establish a residence for it in a particular spot.
Rabba replied: <b>Even if you say</b> that my statement is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri only with regard to a sleeping person, who cannot say</b> anything, as he is asleep. Consequently, he cannot acquire a Shabbat residence. <b>However, with regard to</b> one who is <b>awake,</b> since <b>if he wanted to speak he could speak, even though he did not say</b> that he is acquiring his Shabbat residence, <b>he is considered as one who did say</b> that statement.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Ḥanin said to Abaye: If the Master,</b> Rabba, <b>had heard that which was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person may not walk to the end of his field</b> on Shabbat <b>to determine what</b> work and repair <b>it requires,</b> which will be done after Shabbat. <b>Similarly,</b>

Daf 39a

<b>a person may not stroll at the entrance to the city</b> toward the end of Shabbat or a Festival <b>in order to enter a bathhouse immediately</b> upon the conclusion of Shabbat, then Rabba would have <b>retracted his</b> statement with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>. This <i>baraita</i> indicates that even walking on Shabbat for something one needs after Shabbat falls into the category of prohibited preparation.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>And this is not</b> correct. Rabba <b>heard this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>but did not retract</b> his ruling, as a distinction can be drawn between the cases. <b>There,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> pertaining to one who walks to the end of his field, or one who strolls at the entrance to the city, <b>it is clear</b> to all observers that he is doing so in order to determine what work the field needs after Shabbat, or to enter the bathhouse immediately after Shabbat, respectively. Whereas <b>here,</b> with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>it is not clear</b> to others that one’s actions are for the purpose of establishing an <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara explains: <b>If he is a Torah scholar [<i>tzurva merabbanan</i>], we,</b> the observers, would <b>say:</b> Perhaps <b>his study pulled him,</b> i.e., he was engrossed in his study and was not paying attention to where he was going. <b>And if he is an ignoramus, we</b> would <b>say:</b> Perhaps <b>he lost</b> his <b>donkey</b> and went to look for it. His actions give no indication that he is going to establish an <i>eiruv</i> for the following day, as establishing an <i>eiruv</i> does not require any recognizable action.
