The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion was this statement made? <b>If you say</b> that it was made <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> it is <b>obvious. Now,</b> if <b>unclaimed objects, which do not have owners, do not acquire residence, is it necessary</b> to say that <b>a gentile’s objects, which have an owner,</b> do not acquire residence?
<b>Rather,</b> this statement must have been made <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, and</b> Shmuel <b>is teaching us</b> that when we <b>say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said</b> that objects <b>acquire residence, this applies only</b> to <b>unclaimed objects, which have no owners; but</b> it does <b>not</b> apply to <b>objects</b> belonging <b>to a gentile, which have owners.</b>
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> With regard to a Jew <b>who borrowed a utensil from a gentile on a Festival, and similarly</b> with regard to a Jew <b>who lent a utensil to a gentile on the eve of a Festival and</b> the gentile <b>returned it to him on the Festival, and</b> likewise <b>utensils or bins that acquired residence within the</b> city’s Shabbat <b>limit,</b> in all these cases the utensils <b>have,</b> i.e., can be moved, <b>two thousand cubits in each direction. But if a gentile brought</b> the Jew <b>produce from outside</b> the Shabbat <b>limit,</b> the Jew <b>may not move it from its place.</b>
<b>Granted if you say that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri holds</b> that <b>objects that belong to a gentile acquire residence,</b> one can say that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion? <b>It</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> that even a gentile’s objects acquire residence.
<b>However, if you say that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri holds</b> that <b>objects belonging to a gentile do not acquire residence,</b> in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>? It is <b>neither</b> in accordance with that of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri nor</b> that of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> say that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri holds</b> that <b>a gentile’s objects acquire residence,</b> and that <b>Shmuel,</b> who said that they do not acquire residence, <b>spoke in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. And</b> with regard to <b>that which you said,</b> that <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that a gentile’s objects do not acquire residence, so this ruling need not have been stated at all. The Gemara answers: That is incorrect, as <b>you might have said</b> that the Sages should issue a <b>decree</b> in the case of <b>gentile owners</b> that his objects acquire residence in his location and that they may not be carried beyond two thousand cubits from that spot, lest people carry objects belonging to <b>a Jewish owners</b> beyond their two-thousand-cubit limit. Therefore, it <b>is teaching us</b> that no decree was issued.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin,</b> however, <b>said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Objects that belong to a gentile</b> indeed <b>acquire residence,</b> due to the aforementioned <b>decree</b> issued in the case of <b>gentile owners due to</b> the case of <b>Jewish owners.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>certain rams were brought to</b> the town of <b>Mavrakhta</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rava permitted the residents of Meḥoza to purchase them</b> and take them home, although Mavrakhta was outside the Shabbat limit of Meḥoza and could be reached by the residents of Meḥoza only by way of an <i>eiruv</i> of Shabbat limits.
<b>Ravina said to Rava: What is your reasoning</b> in permitting these rams? You must rely upon that which <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Objects belonging to a gentile do not acquire residence,</b> and so they are permitted even if they were brought to Meḥoza from outside the Shabbat limit.
<b>Isn’t</b> the principle, in disputes between <b>Shmuel and Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan? And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin</b> already <b>said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Objects that belong to a gentile acquire residence,</b> based on <b>a decree</b> in the case of <b>a gentile owner, due to</b> the case of <b>a Jewish owner.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion.
<b>Rava reconsidered and said: Let</b> the rams <b>be sold</b> only <b>to the residents of Mavrakhta.</b> Although the rams acquired residence, and may be moved only four cubits as they were taken beyond their Shabbat limit, the legal status of <b>all Mavrakhta is like four cubits for them.</b> However, they may not be sold to the residents of Meḥoza, as the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A water-filled ditch [<i>ḥerem</i>] that</b> lies <b>between</b> two <b>Shabbat limits requires</b>

Daf 48a

<b>an iron partition to divide it</b> into two separate areas, so that the residents of both places may draw water from it. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> would <b>laugh at this</b> teaching, as he deemed it unnecessary.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why did</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>laugh? If you say</b> that it is <b>because</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>taught</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>stringently, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> saying that ownerless objects acquire a place of residence, <b>and</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina <b>holds leniently, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> and says that those objects do not acquire residence, this is difficult. Just <b>because he holds leniently, does he laugh at one who teaches stringently?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> he must have laughed for a different reason, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Flowing rivers and streaming springs are like the feet of all people,</b> as the water did not acquire residence in any particular spot. Consequently, one who draws water from rivers and springs may carry it wherever he is permitted to walk, even if it had previously been located outside his Shabbat limit. According to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, the same <i>halakha</i> should apply to the water in the ditch.
The Gemara rejects this argument: No proof can be brought from this ruling concerning rivers and springs, as <b>perhaps</b> we are dealing here with a ditch of still, <b>collected</b> water that belongs exclusively to the residents of that particular place.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, must have laughed for a different reason, <b>because</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>taught</b> in his <i>baraita</i> that the ditch <b>requires an iron partition to divide it</b> into two separate sections. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, argued: <b>Why is</b> a partition of <b>reeds different, that</b> we should say it is <b>not</b> effective in that case? Apparently, it is <b>because water enters it</b> and passes from one limit to the other. But this is difficult, as <b>even</b> in the case of a partition <b>of iron, water enters it</b> and passes from one limit to another, as it cannot be hermetically sealed. If so, what does the iron accomplish that the reeds do not accomplish?
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying</b> as follows: A water-filled ditch that lies between two Shabbat limits <b>requires</b> an iron partition to divide it into two separate sections. <b>But there is no remedy,</b> because it is impossible to hermetically seal a partition of that kind, and therefore its water may not be used.
<b>Rather,</b> you must say that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, laughed at Rabbi Ḥiyya’s teaching for a different reason, <b>because the Sages were lenient with regard to water.</b> The Rabbis said that a minimal partition suffices in the case of water. Consequently, there should be no need for an iron partition.
This is <b>similar to</b> the case involving <b>Rabbi Tavla, as Rabbi Tavla asked of Rav: Does a suspended partition,</b> i.e., a partition that is suspended and does not reach the ground, <b>permit</b> carrying <b>in a ruin?</b> Do we say that the remnants of the walls that are suspended in the air are considered as though they descend to the ground and close off the area, so that it is regarded as a private domain?
Rav <b>said to him: A suspended partition</b> of this kind <b>permits</b> carrying <b>only</b> in the case of <b>water,</b> as <b>the Sages were lenient with regard to water.</b> Just as the Sages were lenient about water with respect to a suspended partition, so too they should be lenient here and not require an iron partition; rather, a minimal partition should suffice, even one made of reeds.
The mishna taught: <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that if a person is sleeping at the onset of Shabbat and has no intention of acquiring residence in his location, <b>he has only four cubits,</b> whereas Rabbi Yehuda says he can walk four cubits in any direction he chooses. The Gemara asks: What is the dispute? The opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda is</b> the same as that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., the Rabbis.
<b>Rava said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them,</b> as the Rabbis permit him to carry in an area of <b>eight by eight</b> cubits. Rabbi Yehuda maintains that he has only four cubits, in the direction of his choosing, whereas according to the Rabbis he has four cubits in every direction, which totals an area of eight by eight cubits. <b>That was also taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>He has eight by eight</b> cubits; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> which is the opinion of the Rabbis of the mishna.
<b>And Rava</b> further <b>stated:</b> This <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda relates only <b>to walking, but as for carrying</b> objects, <b>all agree</b> that to carry them <b>four cubits</b> is <b>indeed</b> permitted; but to carry them <b>more</b> than that is <b>not.</b>
The Gemara inquires about the basis of this law: <b>These four cubits</b> within which a person is always permitted to walk on Shabbat, <b>where are they written</b> in the Torah?
The Gemara answers: <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse <b>“Remain every man in his place;</b> let no man go out of his place on the seventh day” (Exodus 16:29), means one must restrict his movement to an area <b>equal to his place. And how much is</b> the area of <b>his place?</b> A person’s <b>body</b> typically measures <b>three cubits, and an</b> additional <b>cubit</b> is needed <b>in order</b> to allow him <b>to spread out his hands and feet,</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> A person’s <b>body</b> measures <b>three cubits, and an</b> additional <b>cubit</b> is needed <b>in order</b> to allow him <b>to pick up an object from under his feet and place it under his head,</b> meaning, to give him room to maneuver.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between them?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in that Rabbi Yehuda provides him with <b>exactly four cubits</b> but no more; whereas Rabbi Meir maintains that we do not restrict him in this manner, but rather he is provided with expansive cubits, i.e., enough room to spread out his hands and feet, which measures slightly more than four cubits.
<b>Rav Mesharshiya said to his son: When you come before Rav Pappa, inquire of him</b> as follows: The <b>four cubits [<i>ammot</i>]</b> mentioned here, <b>do we grant</b> them to each person measured <b>according to his own forearm [<i>amma</i>],</b> i.e., the distance from his elbow to the tip of his index finger, <b>or do we grant</b> them measured <b>according to the cubit [<i>amma</i>] used for consecrated</b> property, i.e., a standard cubit of six medium handbreadths for everyone?
<b>If he said to you</b> that <b>we provide him</b> four cubits measured <b>according to the</b> standard <b>cubit used for consecrated</b> property, <b>what will be with regard to Og, king of the Bashan,</b> who is much larger than this? <b>And if he said to you</b> that <b>we provide him</b> four cubits measured <b>according to his own forearm, say to him: Why was</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>not taught together with</b> the other matters whose measures are determined by the specific measure of the person involved, in the mishna that teaches: <b>These are</b> matters <b>with regard to which they stated</b> measures <b>all in accordance with the</b> specific measure of the <b>person</b> involved. This means that the measures are not fixed, but rather change in accordance with the person in question. If the four cubits are measured according to each person’s forearm, this law should have been included in the mishna.
<b>When</b> Rav Mesharshiya’s son <b>came before Rav Pappa,</b> the latter <b>said to him: Were we to be so precise, we would not</b> be able <b>to learn</b> anything <b>at all,</b> as we would be too busy answering such questions.
<b>In fact, we grant him</b> four cubits measured <b>according to his own forearm. And as for that which was difficult for you, why was</b> this law <b>not taught</b> in the mishna that teaches: <b>These are</b> matters <b>with regard to which they stated</b> measures all in accordance with the specific measure of the person involved? It is because this law <b>is not</b> absolutely <b>clear-cut.</b> It occasionally must be adjusted, <b>since there may be</b> a person <b>whose limbs are small</b> in relation to his body. With regard to such a person, we do not measure four cubits according to the size of his own forearm, but rather by the standard cubits used for consecrated property.
The mishna taught: <b>If there were two</b> people positioned in a way that <b>part of the</b> four <b>cubits of the one</b> were subsumed within the four cubits of the other, they each may bring food and eat together in the shared area in the middle. Rabbi Shimon likened this case to that of three courtyards that open one into another, where the two outer courtyards established an <i>eiruv</i> with the middle one. The Gemara asks: <b>Why does</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>need to</b> offer an analogy and <b>say: To what may this be likened,</b> and thus connect our case to a different issue?
The Gemara explains: <b>This is what Rabbi Shimon said to the Rabbis: After all, to what is this similar? To three courtyards that open into one another, and that</b> also <b>open into a public domain. What is different there that you disagree</b> with me and say that it is prohibited to carry from any one courtyard to any other, <b>and what is different here that you do not disagree</b> with me?
<b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> reply? <b>There</b> the <b>residents</b> of the courtyards <b>are numerous,</b> and some might come to carry objects in a place where it is prohibited to do so; whereas <b>here</b> the <b>residents are not numerous,</b> and a mere three people can warn each other against Shabbat desecration.
The mishna taught: If the residents of the two outer courtyards established an <i>eiruv</i> with the middle one, it is permitted to carry from the middle one to the two outer ones, and it is permitted to carry from the two outer ones to the middle one. <b>And</b> it is prohibited to carry from one of <b>the two outer</b> courtyards to the other, as they did not establish a joint <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is it prohibited? <b>Since</b> the residents of the <b>outer</b> courtyards <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> with</b> the <b>middle one, they are</b> as <b>one,</b> and consequently, they should all be permitted with one another.
<b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case where the two outer courtyards did not place their <i>eiruv</i> in the middle courtyard; rather, to a case <b>where the</b> residents of the <b>middle</b> courtyard <b>placed its</b> first <b><i>eiruv</i> in this</b> courtyard <b>and its</b> second <b><i>eiruv</i> in that</b> courtyard, so that the <i>eiruv</i> of each of the other courtyards is not in the middle courtyard.
<b>And Rav Sheshet said: Even if you say that</b> the residents of each of the outer courtyards <b>placed their <i>eiruv</i> in the middle</b> courtyard, they are still not considered a single courtyard, as we are dealing <b>with a case where they placed</b> each <i>eiruv</i>

Daf 48b

<b>in two</b> separate <b>houses,</b> and consequently the two outer courtyards do not join together and become as one.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Rav Sheshet state that an <i>eiruv</i> placed in two houses, even within the same courtyard, does not join the houses together? He must have said this in accordance <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>five</b> people who <b>collected their <i>eiruv</i> and placed it in two</b> separate <b>utensils,</b> even in a single house, <b>Beit Shammai say: Their <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> as the two parts of the <i>eiruv</i> have not been deposited in the same place, <b>and Beit Hillel say: Their <i>eiruv</i> is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i></b> as long as the entire <i>eiruv</i> was deposited in a single domain.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Even if you say</b> that this is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Beit Hillel, Beit Hillel</b> may have <b>stated</b> their opinion <b>only there, with regard to two utensils</b> that are located <b>in one house</b> and consequently, they join together. <b>However,</b> if the two utensils are located <b>in two</b> separate <b>houses,</b> even Beit Hillel agree that the <i>eiruv</i> is <b>not</b> valid.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi:</b> The explanation <b>of Rav Yehuda is difficult</b> and the explanation <b>of Rav Sheshet is difficult.</b> The explanation of <b>Rav Yehuda is difficult, as he said</b> that it is speaking <b>about a case where the middle</b> courtyard <b>put its</b> first <b><i>eiruv</i> in the one</b> courtyard <b>and its</b> second <b><i>eiruv</i> in the other</b> courtyard. <b>However, once the middle</b> courtyard <b>establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with</b> one of the <b>outer ones, they are</b> regarded <b>as one,</b> so that <b>when it later establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with the other</b> outer courtyard, <b>it acts</b> also <b>on behalf</b> of the first outer courtyard, as both of them are treated like a single courtyard.
<b>And</b> the explanation <b>of Rav Sheshet is difficult.</b> Since the two outer courtyards placed their respective <i>eiruvin</i> in the middle courtyard, all are regarded as residents of the middle courtyard. And since each of the outer courtyards placed its <i>eiruv</i> in a different house, the case <b>should be</b> treated <b>like</b> that of <b>five</b> people <b>who lived in the same courtyard, one of whom forgot and did not join the <i>eiruv</i>, where they</b> all <b>prohibit one another</b> to carry in the courtyard. Similarly in this case, all should be prohibited to carry in the middle courtyard, the residents of the middle courtyard as well as the residents of the outer courtyards.
<b>Rav Ashi said to him: It is not difficult</b> according to the explanation <b>of Rav Yehuda and it is not difficult</b> according to the explanation of <b>Rav Sheshet. It is not difficult</b> according to the explanation of <b>Rav Yehuda, since the</b> residents of the <b>middle</b> courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> with</b> each of <b>the</b> two <b>outer</b> courtyards, <b>and the</b> residents of the <b>two outer</b> courtyards <b>did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with one another.</b> The residents of each of the outer courtyards <b>indicated that it desired</b> to join <b>with</b> the middle courtyard, <b>but did not desire</b> to join <b>with</b> the other outer courtyard. Since the residents of the outer courtyards demonstrated that that they did not want to join together and form a common <i>eiruv</i>, they cannot be forced to do so.
<b>And it is not difficult</b> according to the explanation <b>of Rav Sheshet. If they said</b> that the people living in the outer courtyards are considered as <b>residents</b> of the middle courtyard <b>as a leniency,</b> so that they should be permitted to carry in the middle courtyard, does this mean that <b>they will say</b> that they are considered <b>residents</b> of the middle courtyard also <b>as a stringency,</b> so that they should be prohibited from carrying in the middle courtyard as if they live there?
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: This</b> statement in the mishna, that objects may be carried from either of the outer courtyards into the middle courtyard and also from the middle courtyard into either of the outer courtyards, <b>is the statement of,</b> i.e., in accordance with the opinion of, <b>Rabbi Shimon. But the Rabbis say: One domain serves two domains.</b> That is to say, it is permitted to carry objects from either of the outer courtyards into the inner one, as no prohibition is imposed upon the outer courtyards, given that both established an <i>eiruv</i> with the middle courtyard. <b>But two domains do not serve one domain,</b> meaning that it is prohibited to carry objects from the middle courtyard into either of the two outer courtyards. The utensils of the middle courtyard are drawn after the other two, meaning that were he to bring them into one of the outer courtyards, he would be regarded as having removed them from the other.
Rav Yehuda relates: <b>When I recited</b> this teaching <b>before Shmuel, he said to me:</b>

Daf 49a

<b>This</b> teaching, that carrying objects from either of the outer courtyards into the middle courtyard is permitted, is <b>also the statement of,</b> i.e., in accordance with, the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. But the Rabbis say: All three</b> courtyards <b>are prohibited,</b> that is to say, carrying is prohibited from any of the courtyards to any of the others.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel. Rabbi Shimon said: To what is this comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to three courtyards that open into one another, and that</b> also <b>open into a public domain. If the two</b> outer courtyards <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> with the middle</b> one, a resident of one of the outer courtyards <b>may bring</b> food <b>from a house</b> in that courtyard <b>and eat</b> it in the middle courtyard, <b>and</b> likewise a resident of the other courtyard <b>may bring</b> food <b>from a house</b> in that courtyard <b>and eat</b> it in the middle courtyard. And similarly, <b>this</b> resident <b>may bring leftovers</b> from the house where he ate <b>back into</b> the <b>house</b> in that courtyard, <b>and that resident may bring leftovers</b> from the house where he ate <b>back into</b> the <b>house</b> in this courtyard.
<b>However, the Rabbis say: All three</b> courtyards <b>are prohibited.</b> Since the residents of the outer courtyards are prohibited to carry from one outer courtyard to the other, this results in a place where carrying is prohibited, and such a place prohibits carrying in all three courtyards.
The Gemara notes that <b>Shmuel follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> that he used elsewhere, as <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>a courtyard that is between two alleyways,</b> if that courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> with both</b> alleyways, <b>it is prohibited with both of them.</b> Since the residents of the two alleyways are prohibited to carry from one to the other and the <i>eiruv</i> enables the residents of the two alleyways to carry in the courtyard, it is prohibited to carry from the courtyard into the alleyways, so that the residents of the alleyways do not transfer objects from one alleyway to the other via the courtyard.
If the courtyard <b>did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with either</b> alleyway, <b>it prohibits</b> one to carry in <b>both of them.</b> Since the residents of the courtyard were accustomed to utilizing both alleyways and did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with either alleyway, the result is that each alleyway has a courtyard that did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, which prohibits carrying from the courtyard into either alleyway.
If, however, the residents of the courtyard were <b>accustomed to utilizing</b> only <b>one</b> alleyway, while <b>they</b> are <b>not accustomed to utilizing one</b> alleyway, then with regard to the alleyway <b>which</b> they are <b>accustomed to utilizing,</b> it <b>is prohibited</b> to carry there, as the residents of the courtyard did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with it. <b>But</b> with regard to the alleyway <b>which</b> they are <b>not accustomed to utilizing,</b> it <b>is permitted</b> to carry there, as the residents of the courtyard are not considered residents of that alleyway.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said:</b> With regard to residents of a courtyard who <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> with</b> the alleyway <b>which</b> they <b>were not accustomed to utilizing,</b> the alleyway <b>which</b> they <b>were accustomed to utilizing is permitted</b> to establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>on its own</b> without the courtyard. The residents of the courtyard have demonstrated their intention to use the other alleyway, despite their not being accustomed to doing so.
<b>And Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: If</b> the alleyway <b>which</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>were accustomed to utilizing established an <i>eiruv</i> on its own</b> without the courtyard, <b>while</b> the alleyway <b>which</b> they <b>were not accustomed to utilizing did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, and</b> also the courtyard <b>itself did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> with either alleyway, <b>we divert</b> the residents of the courtyard to use the alleyway <b>which</b> they are <b>not accustomed to utilizing.</b> This is because there is one alleyway in which it is prohibited to carry due to the lack of an <i>eiruv</i>, and a second alleyway in which it is permitted to carry; while it is prohibited for the residents of the courtyard to carry. As explained above, were they to utilize the alleyway which they are accustomed to utilizing, the other residents of the alleyway would also be prohibited to carry from their courtyards into the alleyway, despite having established an <i>eiruv</i> for their own alleyway. However, if they use the other alleyway, the residents of that alleyway will not lose anything; since they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, it is prohibited for them to carry in that alleyway regardless.
<b>In a case such as this, one compels</b> another to refrain from behavior <b>characteristic of Sodom.</b> We force a person to waive his legal rights in order to prevent him from acting in a manner characteristic of the wicked city of Sodom. If one denies another use of his possessions, even though he would incur no loss or damage by granting use of his property, his conduct is considered to be characteristic of Sodom. The courts may sometimes compel such a person to waive his legal rights.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>one who is particular about his <i>eiruv</i>,</b> i.e., that the other people should not eat of the food he contributed, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> After all, <b>what is its name? Joining [<i>eiruv</i>] is its name,</b> indicating that it must be jointly owned [<i>me’urav</i>] by all the participants in the <i>eiruv</i>. If one person does not allow the other participants to eat of it, it does not belong to all of them and cannot be called an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> Even in that case, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>, however,</b> that person <b>is called</b> one <b>of the men of Vardina.</b> The men of Vardina were renowned misers, meaning that he is considered to be like them.
<b>Rav Yehuda</b> also <b>said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>one who divides his <i>eiruv</i></b> into two parts, his <i>eiruv</i> <b>is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> This is for the aforementioned reason that, by definition, an <i>eiruv</i> needs to be indicative of joining, and this <i>eiruv</i> is separated into different parts.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Shmuel state this teaching? Could it be <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>five</b> people who <b>collected their <i>eiruv</i> and placed it in two</b> separate <b>utensils, Beit Shammai say: This is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>, whereas Beit Hillel say: This is an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> It does not stand to reason that Shmuel would follow Beit Shammai, whose opinion is not accepted as normative law.
The Gemara answers: <b>Even if you say</b> that Shmuel stated his opinion in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel, Beit Hillel stated</b> their opinion <b>only there, where the</b> first <b>utensil was filled and there was</b> still some food <b>left over,</b> and therefore, some of the leftover food had to be placed in a second utensil. <b>But where they divided it</b> from the outset, even Beit Hillel agree that the <i>eiruv</i> is <b>not</b> valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need two</b> rulings that are based on the same principle, i.e., that an <i>eiruv</i> must demonstrate joining? The Gemara answers: Both rulings were <b>necessary. As, had</b> the Gemara <b>taught us</b> the ruling only <b>there,</b> with regard to one who is particular about his <i>eiruv</i>, one might have said that the <i>eiruv</i> is not valid <b>because</b> the person <b>is particular</b> and expressly does not desire that his <i>eiruv</i> be eaten by others. <b>However here,</b> with regard to one who divides the <i>eiruv</i> into different parts, one might <b>say</b> that his portion should <b>not</b> be considered as separated from the rest.
<b>And had</b> the Gemara <b>taught us</b> the ruling only <b>here,</b> with regard to one who divides his <i>eiruv</i>, one might have said that the <i>eiruv</i> is not valid <b>because he divided it up,</b> thereby physically separating himself from the others. <b>However there,</b> with regard to one who is particular about his <i>eiruv</i>, one might <b>say</b> that his portion should <b>not</b> be considered as separated from the rest, since no act of separation was performed. Consequently, both rulings were <b>necessary.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba said to Rav Yehuda in the olive press in Rav Zakkai’s house: Did Shmuel</b> actually <b>say</b> that in the case of <b>one who divides his <i>eiruv</i>, it is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>? Didn’t Shmuel say</b> elsewhere: <b>The house in which the <i>eiruv</i> is placed need not contribute bread</b> for the <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this ruling? <b>Is it not because</b> Shmuel <b>maintains</b> that <b>since</b> there is bread <b>lying in a basket</b> somewhere in the house, <b>it is</b> regarded <b>as if it were placed here</b> with the rest of the <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Here too,</b> one should say that <b>since</b> the bread <b>is placed in a basket,</b> i.e., in one of the two utensils containing the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>it is</b> regarded <b>as if it were placed here</b> with the rest of the <i>eiruv</i>.
Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: There</b> Shmuel validates the <i>eiruv</i> <b>although there is no bread</b> in the house in which the <i>eiruv</i> is deposited. And <b>what is the reason</b> for his ruling? It is <b>because</b> by placing food in a particular house, <b>all</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>are</b> regarded <b>as living here.</b> Therefore, those living in that house need not contribute bread for the <i>eiruv</i>, as they are certainly residents of the house.
<b>Shmuel said: An <i>eiruv</i></b> that is deposited in a house is effective <b>due to</b> the principle of <b>acquisition,</b> as each person who contributes a portion of food acquires the right to a certain use of the residence and is considered one of its residents.
<b>And if you say: Why</b> then <b>can one not acquire</b> this right <b>through</b> payment of a coin such as <b>a <i>ma’a</i>,</b> but rather only through bread? It is <b>because</b> a <i>ma’a</i> <b>is not</b> always <b>available on Shabbat eve,</b> as many people spend all of their available money for the necessities of Shabbat, and it is difficult to find money available at that hour.
The Gemara asks: If so, according to Shmuel’s opinion, in a case <b>where he established an <i>eiruv</i></b> with money, <b>it should nonetheless acquire,</b> i.e., be valid. According to his opinion, there is no fundamental reason to invalidate the acquisition of rights in the residence through the payment of money, yet there is no indication that this position is valid.
The Gemara answers: Even Shmuel did not permit one to establish an <i>eiruv</i> with money, due to <b>a decree lest</b> people <b>say that a <i>ma’a</i> is essential, and sometimes a <i>ma’a</i> will not be available, and they will not come</b> to prepare <b>an <i>eiruv</i> with bread, and</b> the halakhic category of <b><i>eiruv</i> will be forgotten.</b>
<b>Rabba</b> disagreed with Shmuel and <b>said: An <i>eiruv</i></b> is effective <b>due to</b> the principle of <b>residence.</b> Each person who contributes a portion of food is considered as if he resides, for that Shabbat, in the residence in which the food is deposited.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical, halakhic difference <b>between these</b> two understandings? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to the question of whether an <i>eiruv</i> may be established with <b>a utensil.</b> If an <i>eiruv</i> is effective based on the principle of acquisition, in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel, then one should be able to establish an <i>eiruv</i> with a utensil; whereas, this would not constitute a valid <i>eiruv</i>, according to the opinion of Rabba.
<b>And</b> another practical difference between them is with regard to whether an <i>eiruv</i> may be established with food that is <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>.</b> According to Shmuel’s opinion, this would not be a valid <i>eiruv</i>, as there is no acquisition with something less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>; whereas according to Rabba’s opinion, since an <i>eiruv</i> is effective by establishing a person’s residence, this can be done even with an amount of food worth less than a <i>peruta</i>.

Daf 49b

<b>And</b> there is another practical difference between them with regard to the question whether <b>a minor</b> may collect the <i>eiruv</i> from the residents of the courtyard and deposit it in one of the houses. According to Shmuel’s opinion, this would not be a valid <i>eiruv</i>, for a minor cannot serve as an agent to effect acquisition, whereas according to Rabba’s opinion, the <i>eiruv</i> is valid, as the food itself establishes the common residence for all the residents.
<b>Abaye said to Rabba: It is difficult according to your</b> opinion that an <i>eiruv</i> is effective based on the principle of residence, <b>and it is difficult according to</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel</b> that it is effective based on the principle of acquisition. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>five</b> people <b>who collected their <i>eiruv</i>, when they take their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere,</b> in order to establish an <i>eiruv</i> together with another courtyard, <b>one</b> person may <b>take it</b> there <b>for all of them.</b> This indicates that <b>it is</b> only <b>that person who acquires</b> rights, <b>and nobody else,</b> and <b>it is</b> only <b>that person who gains residence, and nobody else.</b> In that case, how can the others rely on this <i>eiruv</i>?
Rabba said <b>to him:</b> It is <b>neither difficult according to my</b> opinion, <b>nor</b> is it <b>difficult according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> as, the person who takes the <i>eiruv</i> <b>acts as an agent,</b> effecting acquisition or determining residence <b>on behalf of all of them.</b>
With regard to the case of the three courtyards addressed above, <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> that it is permitted to carry from the middle courtyard into either of the two outer ones; and vice versa, however, it is prohibited to carry from one outer courtyard to the other.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who was coming along the way</b> on Shabbat eve, <b>and it grew dark</b> while <b>he</b> was traveling, <b>and he was familiar</b> with <b>a tree or a fence</b> located two thousand cubits from his current location, and two thousand cubits from his house, <b>and he said: My residence is beneath</b> that tree, rather than in his present location, <b>he has not said anything,</b> as he did not establish a fixed location as his residence.
If, however, he said: <b>My residence is at</b> the tree’s <b>trunk,</b> he acquired residence there, and he <b>may</b> therefore <b>walk from the place he is standing to the trunk</b> of the tree <b>two thousand cubits</b> away, <b>and from the trunk</b> of the tree <b>to his house,</b> an additional <b>two thousand cubits. Consequently, he walks after nightfall</b> a total of <b>four thousand cubits.</b>
<b>If one is not familiar</b> with a tree or any other noticeable landmark, <b>or if he is not an expert in the <i>halakha</i>,</b> unaware that residence can be established from a distance, <b>and he said: My residence is at my</b> current <b>location,</b> then his presence at <b>his</b> current <b>location acquires for him</b> the right to walk <b>two thousand cubits in each direction.</b>
The manner in which the two thousand cubits are measured is the subject of a tannaitic dispute. These cubits are measured <b>circularly,</b> i.e., as a circle with a radius of two thousand cubits; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigenos. And the Rabbis say:</b> These are measured <b>squarely,</b> i.e., <b>as a square tablet,</b> with each side measuring four thousand cubits, <b>so that he gains the corners.</b> He is permitted to walk from the middle to the corners of the square as well, a distance of approximately 2,800 cubits.
<b>And this is</b> the meaning of that <b>which</b> the Sages <b>said: The pauper establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet,</b> i.e., one who does not have the bread required to establish an <i>eiruv</i> may walk anywhere within his Shabbat limit and declare: This is my residence, and his Shabbat limit is measured from that location. <b>Rabbi Meir said: We have</b> this leniency in effect <b>only</b> for <b>a pauper,</b> who does not have food for two meals. However, one who has bread may only establish residence with bread. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> This leniency is in effect for <b>both a pauper and a wealthy person.</b> The Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with bread only</b> in order <b>to be lenient with the wealthy</b> person, <b>so that he</b> need <b>not</b> exert himself and <b>go out and establish an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet.</b> Instead, he can appoint an agent to place bread for him in that location. This, however, does not negate the option of personally going to that location in order to establish residence without bread.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that one who declares his intention to establish residence beneath a tree, without specifying the precise location, has not said anything. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the precise meaning of <b>he has not said anything?</b>
<b>Rav said: He has not said anything at all,</b> and has failed to establish residence anywhere, and <b>he may not even go to</b> the place <b>beneath</b> that <b>tree.</b> His failure to specify a particular location prevents him from establishing residence beneath the tree. The fact that he sought to establish residence someplace other than his present location prevents him from establishing residence at his present location. Accordingly, he may walk no more than four cubits from the place that he is standing.
<b>And Shmuel said: He has not said anything</b> with regard to going <b>to his home,</b> if it is two thousand cubits past the tree; <b>however,</b> with regard to the area <b>beneath the tree,</b> if its bough is entirely within two thousand cubits of his present location <b>he may</b> indeed <b>go</b> there.
<b>And</b> when we learned in the mishna that he did not establish residence, it means that the legal status of the area <b>beneath the tree becomes</b> comparable to both <b>a donkey driver,</b> who walks behind the animal and prods it, <b>and a camel driver,</b> who walks before the animal and leads it in the sense that the tree is pulling him in both directions. Since he did not specify a particular location as his residence, any part of the area beneath the tree could be the place where he established residence.
Therefore, if <b>he comes to measure</b> two thousand cubits <b>from the north</b> of the tree in order to ascertain whether or not he may go to his home, because of the uncertainty with regard to the precise location where he established residence, <b>one measures</b> the distance <b>for him</b> stringently <b>from the south.</b> And likewise, if <b>he comes to measure</b> the distance to his home <b>from the south, one measures</b> the distance <b>for him from the north.</b>

Daf 50a

<b>Rabba said: What is the reason for Rav’s</b> statement that one who declares his intention to establish residence beneath a tree has said nothing at all? It is <b>because the place</b> he designated <b>is not</b> precisely <b>defined.</b> Since he did not establish his residence in one particular location, he did not establish it at all.
<b>And some say</b> an alternative version of Rabba’s statement. <b>Rabba said: What is the reason</b> for the statement of <b>Rav?</b> It is <b>Because he maintains: Anything that cannot</b> be accomplished <b>sequentially,</b> due to halakhic or practical considerations, <b>even simultaneously, cannot</b> be accomplished, as one negates the other. In this case, since one cannot establish residence in an area of four cubits on one side of a tree and proceed to establish residence in an area of four cubits on the other side of the tree, neither can he simultaneously establish residence beneath a tree greater than four cubits.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between these</b> two versions of Rabba’s statement? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to a case <b>where he said: Let</b> residence be <b>acquired for me</b> in <b>four cubits of the eight</b> or more cubits beneath that tree.
According to <b>the one who said</b> that it is <b>because the place</b> he designated <b>is not</b> precisely <b>defined,</b> here too, <b>the place</b> he designated <b>is not</b> precisely <b>defined,</b> as he failed to specify the precise location of the four cubits in which to establish his residence.
<b>And</b> according to <b>the one who said</b> it is <b>because anything that cannot</b> be accomplished <b>sequentially even simultaneously</b> it <b>cannot</b> be accomplished, <b>this is</b> considered <b>as</b> if he established his residence in <b>four cubits, as here he stated</b> that he is designated only <b>four cubits</b> as his place of residence.
The Gemara proceeds to analyze <b>the matter</b> of Rabba’s statement <b>itself. Rabba said: Anything that cannot</b> be accomplished <b>sequentially even simultaneously</b> it <b>cannot</b> be accomplished. <b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba</b> based on the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who increases tithes,</b> i.e., he tithes two-tenths instead of one-tenth, the remainder of <b>his produce is rendered</b> fit for consumption, as he properly tithed it; <b>however, his tithes are ruined,</b> as the additional tenth is neither a tithe nor is it tithed produce. It is not a tithe because tithe status applies only to one tenth, and neither is it tithed produce as it was not tithed. Since it is unclear which of the two-tenths is the actual tithe and which is not, this produce may neither be treated as a tithe nor as tithed produce.
According to Rabba’s opinion, the question arises: <b>Why</b> should the produce be rendered fit for consumption? <b>Let us say</b> and apply his principle: <b>Anything that cannot</b> be accomplished <b>sequentially; even simultaneously</b> it <b>cannot</b> be accomplished. Since one may not designate two tenths sequentially, one tenth followed by a second tenth, likewise, he should be precluded from simultaneously designating two tenths of his produce as a tithe. Accordingly, it should be considered as though he had not designated any tithe at all, and therefore his produce should not be regarded as tithed.
Gemara answers: The case of <b>a tithe is different, as</b> tithe status <b>takes effect partially,</b> i.e., on less than a unit of produce. <b>As if one said: Let half of each</b> grain of <b>wheat be designated</b> as tithed, <b>it is designated.</b> Just as one can designate an entire grain of wheat as a tithe, he can likewise designate half a grain. In this case too, when one tithes two tenths of the produce, the ruling is not that one tenth is actual tithe and the other tenth is untithed produce mixed with the tithe. Instead, half of each grain of the set-aside portion is designated as a tithe, while the other half of each grain is not. Accordingly, the remainder of the produce is tithed, as one tenth of the total has been designated as first tithe. However, the portion designated as the tithe is ruined, because it is impossible to identify which part of each grain is designated.
Another objection was raised against Rabba’s opinion: Yet there is the case of the <b>animal tithe, which does take effect partially,</b> as one cannot consecrate half an animal for his tithe. Three times a year, the owner of a herd of kosher animals would gather all the animals born during the preceding period into an enclosure and let them out one by one. Every tenth animal would be marked with red paint to indicate that it was sacred. Only an entire animal could be consecrated as animal tithe, not a part of an animal.
<b>And Rabba said:</b> If <b>two</b> animals <b>emerged</b> from the enclosure together <b>as the tenth, and he designated them</b> both as the <b>tenth, the tenth and eleventh</b> animals <b>are intermingled with each other.</b> One is sacred with the sanctity of the animal tithe, while the other remains a peace-offering, but there is no way to determine which is which. The question arises: If the principle that anything which cannot be accomplished sequentially; even simultaneously it cannot be accomplished applies, neither animal is consecrated, as one cannot designate both the tenth and the eleventh animals as the animal tithe, one after the other.
The Gemara answers: The <b>animal tithe is different, as</b> two animals can indeed be designated as animal tithe <b>one after the other in</b> the case of <b>an error.</b> Although one cannot designate the tenth and eleventh animals as the animal tithe <i>ab initio</i>, if he did so in error they are both consecrated.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: If <b>one</b> erred and <b>designated the ninth</b> animal <b>as the tenth,</b> and erred again and designated <b>the tenth as the ninth and the eleventh as the tenth,</b> all <b>three</b> animals <b>are consecrated.</b> The first is consecrated because it was designated as the tenth, the second because it actually is the tenth, while the third is also consecrated because it was designated as the tenth. Apparently, more than one animal can be consecrated as the animal tithe, if designated in error. Here too, a modicum of sanctity applies to the two animals that emerged together and were together designated as the tenth.
The Gemara raises another objection to Rabba’s principle. <b>But there is</b> the case of the forty loaves that accompany a <b>thanks-offering, which are not</b> consecrated if they were designated <b>in error, and</b> likewise <b>are not</b> consecrated if two sets of loaves were designated for the same offering <b>one after the other. And</b> yet <b>it is stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to <b>a thanks-offering that was slaughtered</b> accompanied <b>by eighty loaves,</b> twice the required amount. <b>Ḥizkiya said: Forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated,</b> even though their identity cannot be determined; <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Not</b> even <b>forty of</b> the <b>eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated.</b> It would appear that these <i>amora’im</i> disagree whether or not sanctity that cannot take effect in sequence can take effect simultaneously.
The Gemara rejects this contention. <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to</b> this dispute that <b>Rabbi Zeira said: Everyone,</b> both Ḥizkiya and Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>concedes</b> that in a case <b>where</b> the donor <b>said: Let forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>be consecrated, that</b> the forty <b>are consecrated;</b> and in a case where he said: <b>Let forty</b> loaves <b>only be consecrated if</b> all <b>eighty are consecrated, everyone agrees that they are not consecrated.</b> This is in accordance with Rabba’s opinion.
<b>When</b> Ḥizkiya and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disagree</b> is with regard a case where the donor designated eighty loaves <b>without stipulation</b> how many he wants consecrated. <b>One Sage,</b> Ḥizkiya, <b>maintains:</b> Although he designated eighty loaves, he seeks to consecrate only forty, and when he sets aside eighty loaves, <b>he</b> merely <b>intends to ensure</b> that he will have forty, <b>and he</b> therefore <b>brought</b> the extra loaves <b>on condition</b> that if the first forty loaves are lost or become ritually impure, the second forty will be consecrated in their place. Consequently, the first forty loaves are consecrated.

Daf 50b

<b>And the other Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>maintains:</b> He <b>intends</b> to bring <b>a large offering</b> of eighty loaves, and therefore none of the loaves are consecrated.
<b>Abaye said: They only taught</b> Rav’s ruling that one cannot establish residence beneath a tree without precisely defining a particular location, <b>with regard to a tree beneath which there are</b> at least <b>twelve cubits. However, with regard to a tree</b> beneath <b>which there are not twelve cubits,</b> he can establish residence there, <b>as</b> at least <b>part of his residence is conspicuous.</b> In that case, there is a partial overlap between the middle four cubits beneath the tree and the four cubits nearest him and the four cubits farthest from him, and consequently each necessarily contains at least part of his residence.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, strongly objects to this: From where</b> is it ascertained <b>that he designates</b> his residence <b>in the four middle</b> cubits, so that there is a partial overlap with both the nearest and the farthest cubits; <b>perhaps he designates</b> it in <b>the four</b> cubits <b>on this side or</b> in <b>the four</b> cubits <b>on the other side?</b> Since he does not know which location he designated as his residence, he did not establish residence anywhere beneath the tree.
<b>Rather, Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> Abaye’s statement must be emended. <b>They taught</b> this <b>only with regard to a tree that</b> has at least <b>eight cubits beneath it. However, with regard to a tree that</b> has only <b>seven cubits beneath it,</b> even if one did not establish a particular location, he acquires residence, <b>as</b> at least <b>part of his residence is conspicuous,</b> as any four cubits must include at least one cubit of his residence.
With regard to the dispute between Rav and Shmuel, the Gemara notes that one <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> and another <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b>
The Gemara elaborates. A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav:</b> With regard to <b>one who was coming along the way</b> on Shabbat eve, <b>and it grew dark</b> while <b>he</b> was traveling, <b>and he was familiar</b> with <b>a tree or a fence</b> within two thousand cubits of his current location, <b>and he said: My residence is beneath</b> that tree, <b>he has not said anything</b> of legal consequence. <b>However, if he said: My residence is in such-and-such place, he walks until he reaches that place.</b> Once <b>he reached that place</b> that he established as his residence, <b>he walks</b> through <b>all of it and</b> another <b>two thousand cubits beyond it.</b>
<b>In what</b> case <b>are these matters,</b> that he establishes four cubits as his residence, and another two thousand cubits in each direction, <b>stated?</b> In a case where he selected <b>a</b> well-<b>defined,</b> clearly demarcated <b>place,</b> i.e., a case <b>where he established</b> residence <b>on a mound ten handbreadths high, and its</b> area ranges <b>from</b> a minimum of <b>four cubits to</b> a maximum of <b>two <i>beit se’a</i>.</b>
<b>And, likewise,</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> when he establishes residence on <b>a plain ten</b> handbreadths <b>deeper</b> than the surrounding area, <b>and its</b> area ranges <b>from</b> a minimum of <b>four cubits to</b> a maximum of <b>two <i>beit se’a</i>. However,</b> if he selected <b>a place that is not defined,</b> e.g., in the middle of a plain, he does not establish residence, and accordingly <b>he has only four cubits</b> in which to move.
<b>If two</b> people <b>were</b> walking together, <b>one</b> of whom is <b>familiar</b> with a particular location in the distance, <b>and one</b> of whom is <b>not familiar</b> with it, <b>the one who</b> is <b>not familiar</b> with it <b>entrusts</b> his right to designate <b>his</b> residence <b>to the one</b> who is <b>familiar</b> with it, <b>and the one who</b> is <b>familiar</b> with it <b>says: My residence is in such-and-such place.</b>
<b>In what</b> case <b>are these matters,</b> that he acquires four cubits as his residence and another two thousand cubits in each direction, <b>stated?</b> In a case <b>where he defined</b> the <b>four cubits that he</b> seeks to <b>establish</b> as his residence. <b>However,</b> if <b>he did not define</b> the <b>four cubits that he</b> seeks to <b>establish</b> as his residence, <b>he may not move from his</b> current <b>place,</b> as neither did he seek to establish residence there, nor did he acquire it in the location he sought to establish residence. This <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rav that one who fails to designate the four cubits he seeks to establish as residence has no residence at all.
Gemara poses a question: <b>Let us say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is a <b>conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel?</b> The Gemara answers: There is no difficulty, as <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with a</b> special <b>case, where from the place he is standing to the trunk</b> of the tree <b>there is</b> a distance of <b>two thousand and four cubits, so that if you were to establish</b> residence <b>on the other side of the tree, it would be situated outside</b> his Shabbat limit.
Consequently, <b>if he designated</b> his <b>four cubits</b> on the near side of the tree <b>he may go</b> there; <b>and if not, he may not go</b> from the place he is standing. In other words, since he did not establish residence in a particular location, the concern is that he sought to establish it beyond his two thousand cubit limit.
A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel. If one erred and established an <i>eiruv</i> in two directions</b> at once, for example, if in his ignorance <b>he imagined that</b> it is permitted to <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> in two directions,</b> that he may extend the distance that he may walk on Shabbat in two opposite directions, <b>or if he said to his servants: Go out and establish an <i>eiruv</i> for me,</b> without specifying the direction, and <b>one established an <i>eiruv</i> for him to the north, and one established an <i>eiruv</i> for him to the south, he may walk to the north as</b> far as he is permitted go based on <b>his <i>eiruv</i> to the south,</b> and he may walk <b>to the south as</b> far as he is permitted go based on <b>his <i>eiruv</i> to the north.</b> In other words, the assumption is that he established residence in both directions based on the <i>eiruv</i> in each direction, and he must therefore take both into consideration before moving.
<b>And</b> consequently, <b>if</b> each <i>eiruv</i> was placed two thousand cubits in opposite directions <b>placing him in the middle of the limit, he may not move from his</b> current <b>location,</b> as it is prohibited to venture beyond either limit. Apparently, even if one did not establish residence in a particular location, as in this case he has acquired residence in both places, nonetheless, the <i>halakha</i> is that residence has been established in his current location, in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>Let us say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is a <b>conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav?</b> The Gemara answers: This <i>baraita</i> indeed differs with Rav’s ruling. Nevertheless, his opinion is not disqualified, as <b>Rav himself</b> had <b><i>tanna</i></b> status and therefore, unlike later <i>amora’im</i>, could <b>disagree </b>with opinions of <i>tanna’im</i>.
We learned in the mishna that if, however, <b>he said: My residence is at</b> the <b>trunk</b> of the tree, he established residence there, and he <b>may walk from the place that he is standing to the trunk</b> of the tree, up to <b>two thousand cubits, and from the trunk</b> of the tree <b>to his house</b> another <b>two thousand cubits. Ultimately, he may walk after nightfall</b> a total distance of <b>four thousand cubits.</b>

Daf 51a

<b>Rava said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies <b>only</b> in a case <b>where, were he to run to the trunk</b> of the tree <b>he could reach it</b> before the onset of Shabbat. <b>Abaye said to him: But doesn’t</b> the mishna <b>state: And it grew dark</b> while <b>he</b> was traveling, indicating that he is farther away than that?
The Gemara answers: The mishna means that <b>it grew dark</b> while he was traveling so that he can no longer return <b>to his house</b> before nightfall; <b>however, he is able</b> to <b>go to the trunk</b> of the tree before Shabbat. <b>Some state</b> a different version of the previous statement. <b>Rava said:</b> The mishna means that <b>it grew dark</b> while <b>he</b> was traveling, so that <b>were he to walk very slowly</b> he could not reach his house; <b>however, if he runs, he can</b> still <b>arrive</b> before Shabbat.
<b>Rabba and Rav Yosef were going</b> together <b>along the way. Rabba said to Rav Yosef: Our residence will be beneath the palm that carries its brother,</b> the one with another palm tree leaning on it. <b>And some say</b> he said to him: Our residence will be <b>beneath the palm that spared its owner from the land tax [<i>karga</i>],</b> the palm which yielded enough dates for its owner to pay his entire land tax.
Rabba asked: <b>Does the Master know</b> of that tree? Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> No, <b>I do not know</b> of it. <b>He said to him:</b> Then <b>rely on me, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: If two</b> people <b>were</b> walking together, <b>one</b> of whom is <b>familiar</b> with a particular location in the distance, <b>and one</b> is <b>not familiar</b> with it, <b>the one who</b> is <b>not familiar</b> with it <b>entrusts</b> his right to designate <b>his</b> residence <b>to the one who</b> is <b>familiar</b> with it, <b>and the one who</b> is <b>familiar</b> with it <b>says: My residence is in such-and-such place.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>But it is not</b> so; that is not the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. Rabba <b>only taught it</b> as if it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei so that</b> Rav Yosef <b>would accept it from him, due to</b> the fact that <b>Rabbi Yosei’s reasoning</b> accompanies <b>his</b> rulings, Since the <i>halakha</i> is usually in accordance with Rav Yosei’s opinion, Rav Yosef would be less likely to raise doubts with regard to the ruling.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If one is not familiar</b> with a tree or any other noticeable landmark, <b>or if he is not an expert</b> in the <i>halakha</i>, unaware that residence can be established from a distance, and he said: My residence is at my current location, his presence at his current location acquires for him the right to walk two thousand cubits in each direction.
The Gemara raises a fundamental question: <b>These two thousand cubits, where are</b> they <b>written</b> in the Torah? The Gemara answers that it is <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“Remain every man in his place”</b> (Exodus 16:29); <b>these are</b> the <b>four cubits,</b> which constitute the minimum Shabbat limit, e.g., for one who ventured beyond his prescribed limit. <b>“Let no man go out of his place”</b> (Exodus 16:29); <b>these are</b> the <b>two thousand cubits</b> of the Shabbat limit for one who remains in his place. Unless otherwise specified, the measure of one’s place is two thousand cubits.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that this is the measure of one’s place? <b>Rav Ḥisda said: We derive</b> this by means of a verbal analogy between the term <b>place</b> written here: “Let no man go out of his place,” and <b>from</b> the term <b>place</b> written with regard to an unwitting murderer: “Then I will appoint you a place to where he shall flee” (Exodus 21:13). This last verse mentions both place and fleeing, <b>and</b> the term <b>place</b> is derived <b>from</b> the term <b>fleeing. And</b> the term <b>fleeing</b> is derived <b>from</b> the term <b>fleeing,</b> written in a different verse with regard to the unwitting murderer: “But if the slayer shall at any time come outside the border of the city of his refuge, whither he has fled” (Numbers 35:26). <b>And</b> the term <b>fleeing</b> is derived <b>from</b> the term <b>border,</b> which appears in the same verse. <b>And</b> the term <b>border</b> is derived <b>from</b> the term <b>border,</b> as it states there: “And the avenger of blood find him outside [<i>miḥutz</i>] the borders of the city of his refuge” (Numbers 35:27). Since this verse mentions both the term border and the term outside, the term <b>border</b> is derived <b>from</b> the term <b>outside. And</b> the term <b>outside</b> is derived <b>from</b> the term <b>outside, as it is written</b> with regard to the Levite cities, which also served as cities of refuge: <b>“And you shall measure from outside [<i>miḥutz</i>] the city on the east side two thousand cubits,</b> and on the south side two thousand cubits, and on the west side two thousand cubits, and on the north side two thousand cubits” (Numbers 35:5). From this chain of identical terms, the meaning of the term place stated in connection with Shabbat is derived from the two thousand cubits mentioned with regard to the Levite cities.
The Gemara asks: <b>But let us derive</b> instead by means of a verbal analogy between the term outside in the verse: “Outside the borders of the city of refuge,” and the term outside in the verse: <b>“From the wall of the city outward [<i>vaḥutza</i>] a thousand cubits”</b> (Numbers 35:4), that the Shabbat limit measures only a thousand cubits. The Gemara answers: <b>One derives</b> the meaning of the term <b>outside [<i>ḥutz</i>]</b> by means of a verbal analogy <b>from</b> another instance of the term <b>outside [<i>ḥutz</i>], but one does not derive</b> the meaning of the term <b>outside from</b> the term <b>outward [<i>ḥutza</i>].</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>What is</b> significant about <b>the difference</b> between the two terms? <b>Didn’t the school of Rabbi Yishmael teach</b> a verbal analogy with regard to leprosy of houses between the verse: <b>“And the priest shall return [<i>veshav</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 14:39) and the verse: <b>“And the priest shall come [<i>uva</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 14:44), from which it is derived that <b>this is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>returning,</b> i.e., it is after seven days; <b>this is</b> the same <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>coming;</b> it is after seven days. Obviously, the less pronounced difference of one letter between <i>ḥutz</i> and <i>ḥutza</i>, should not prevent the teaching of a verbal analogy.
Gemara rejects this argument: <b>This applies</b> only <b>when there are no terms</b> that are <b>identical to it however, where there are terms</b> that are <b>identical to it, we derive</b> the verbal analogy <b>from</b> terms <b>identical to it,</b> rather than from the terms that are not precisely identical.
The <i>tanna’im</i> of the mishna disagree whether the <b>two-thousand-cubit</b> limit granted to a person in every direction is measured as a <b>circle</b> or as a square tablet. The Gemara poses a question: With regard to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigenos</b> that the limit is measured as a circle, <b>no matter what</b> you say, it is difficult. <b>If he is of the</b> opinion that there is a <b>verbal analogy</b> from the verse written with regard to the Levite cities it is difficult, because <b>sides</b> is the term <b>written,</b> indicating squared boundaries. And <b>if he is not of the</b> opinion that there is a <b>verbal analogy, from where does he</b> derive that the Shabbat limit is <b>two thousand cubits?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually, he is of</b> the opinion that there is <b>a verbal analogy, but here,</b> with regard to the Levite cities, it <b>is different, as the verse says: “This shall be to them the open space of the cities”</b> (Numbers 35:5), from which it is inferred: <b>To this,</b> the open space of the city, <b>you</b> should <b>provide sides</b> and square it, <b>but you do not provide sides to those resting on Shabbat.</b> Instead, those who establish Shabbat residence are provided with a circular, two-thousand-cubit limit.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> understand the emphasis placed on the word this in the verse? The Gemara answers: As <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rav Ḥananya says: Like this</b> measure <b>shall be</b> the calculations of measures for <b>all those who rest on Shabbat,</b> i.e., square.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: One who carries</b> an object <b>four cubits in the public domain is only liable if he carries</b> it <b>four</b> cubits <b>with their diagonal.</b> The four cubits mentioned in many places is only the basic measure by which the distance beyond which it is prohibited to carry is calculated. However, in practice, a person is liable only if he carries the object the length of the diagonal of a square with four-cubit sides.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> that <b>Rava</b> once <b>tested us</b> by asking: With regard to <b>a pillar in the public domain, ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, must</b> the width <b>be</b> four handbreadths <b>with their diagonal</b> in order to be regarded a private domain, <b>or not? And we said to him: Is this not</b> that which was taught by <b>Rav Ḥananya? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rav Ḥananya says: Like this</b> measure <b>shall be</b> that of <b>all those who rest on Shabbat,</b> indicating that the diagonal is the determining measure for the <i>halakhot</i> of rest on Shabbat.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And this is</b> the meaning of that <b>which</b> the Sages <b>said: A pauper can establish an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet,</b> i.e., one who does not have the bread required to establish an <i>eiruv</i> may walk anywhere within his Shabbat limit and acquire residence. <b>We have</b> this leniency in effect <b>only</b> for <b>a pauper,</b> who does not have food for two meals. However, one who has bread may only establish residence with bread. Rabbi Yehuda says: This leniency is in effect for both a pauper and a wealthy person.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda is <b>with regard to</b> a case where the person said: My residence is in <b>my</b> current <b>location. As Rabbi Meir maintains: The primary</b> ordinance and establishment <b>of <i>eiruv</i></b> is <b>with bread.</b>

Daf 51b

Therefore, <b>it is</b> only <b>with regard to a pauper,</b> who does not have food for two meals, <b>that the Sages were lenient</b> and permitted him to establish residence merely by saying: My residence is in my current location. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a wealthy person</b> in his own house who has bread, <b>no,</b> they did not permit him to do so.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda maintains: The primary</b> ordinance <b>of <i>eiruv</i> is by foot,</b> i.e., by going and stating that he is establishing his residence in that location, and therefore it applies to <b>both a pauper and a wealthy person. However,</b> with regard a case when the person said: My residence is <b>in such-and-such place,</b> and he is not there, <b>everyone,</b> both Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, <b>agrees</b> that for <b>a pauper</b> on the road on a Shabbat eve, <b>yes, an</b> <i>eiruv</i> may be established in that manner; however, for <b>a wealthy person, no,</b> an eiruv may not be established in that manner.
And as for the mishna’s statement: <b>And this is what</b> the Sages meant when <b>they said</b> that a pauper can establish an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet, <b>who,</b> which Sage, <b>is teaching it?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Meir. And to which</b> clause of the mishna <b>is it referring?</b> It refers to the previous statement: If he is <b>not familiar</b> with a tree or any other noticeable landmark, <b>or if he is not an expert in the <i>halakha</i>,</b> and therefore is unaware that a residence can be established from a distance, and said: My residence is in my current location, he acquires two thousand cubits in each direction. <b>And</b> as for the statement in the continuation of the mishna: The Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with bread only to be lenient with the wealthy</b> person, <b>who,</b> which Sage, <b>is teaching it?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the option of establishing an <i>eiruv</i> by foot is available to the wealthy as well.
<b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> however, disagreed with Rav Naḥman and <b>said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda in the mishna is with regard to a person who said: My residence is <b>in such-and-such place,</b> in which case his residence is neither acquired by foot nor with bread. <b>As Rabbi Meir maintains: A pauper, yes,</b> he establishes residence with an <i>eiruv</i> in that manner; however, <b>a wealthy person, no,</b> he does not. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda maintains: Both a pauper and a wealthy person</b> may establish an <i>eiruv</i> in that manner. <b>However,</b> in a case where one said: My residence is <b>in my</b> present <b>location, everyone,</b> both Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, <b>agrees</b> that an <i>eiruv</i> of this kind is effective <b>both</b> for <b>a pauper and</b> for <b>a wealthy person,</b> as everyone agrees agree that <b>the primary</b> ordinance <b>of <i>eiruv</i> is by foot.</b>
And as for the mishna’s statement: <b>And this is what</b> the Sages meant when <b>they said</b> that <b>a pauper</b> can establish an <i>eiruv</i> by foot, <b>who is teaching it?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Meir. And to which</b> clause of the mishna <b>is it referring?</b> It is referring <b>to this</b> clause: <b>One who was coming along the way</b> on Shabbat eve, <b>and it grew dark</b> while <b>he</b> was traveling. According to Rabbi Yehuda, he could have established an <i>eiruv</i> even if he was in his house. And as for the statement in the continuation of the mishna: The Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with bread only</b> in order <b>to be lenient with the wealthy</b> person, <b>who is teaching it? Everyone agrees</b> with this <i>halakha</i>, and it is taught according to both opinions.
The Gemara comments: A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman,</b> who said that the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda is with regard to one who said: My residence is in my present location. It was stated in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Both a pauper and a wealthy person establish an <i>eiruv</i> with bread; however a wealthy person may not go out beyond the</b> Shabbat <b>limit and say: My residence is in my</b> present <b>location, because</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one can establish an <i>eiruv</i> by foot only</b> in the case of <b>a person who was coming along the way and it grew dark</b> while <b>he</b> was traveling. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Both a pauper and a wealthy person establish an <i>eiruv</i> by foot. And a wealthy person will go out beyond the</b> Shabbat <b>limit and say: My residence is in my</b> present <b>location. And this is the primary</b> ordinance <b>of <i>eiruv</i>. However, the Sages permitted a homeowner to send his <i>eiruv</i> in the hand of his servant,</b> or <b>in the hand of his son,</b> or <b>in the hand of his agent,</b> in order <b>to be lenient with him,</b> so that he need not exert himself and go out and establish an <i>eiruv</i> by foot. This <i>baraita</i> presents the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda as it was delineated by Rav Naḥman.
The <i>baraita</i> continues. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving the members of the household of</b> the <b>Memel</b> family <b>and members of the household of Guryon</b> family <b>in</b> the village of <b>Aroma, who were distributing dried figs and raisins to the paupers in years of famine, and the paupers of the village of Siḥin and the paupers of the village of Ḥananya would come</b> to the edge of the Shabbat <b>limit at nightfall,</b> which was also within the Shabbat limit of Aroma, and then go home. <b>The following day they would rise early and go</b> to receive their figs and raisins. Apparently, one can establish an <i>eiruv</i> by foot, if he says: My residence is in my present location.
<b>Rav Ashi said: The</b> formulation of the <b>mishna is also precise,</b> in accordance with Rav Naḥman’s explanation, <b>as it teaches: If</b> on a Shabbat eve <b>one set out to go to a city for which an <i>eiruv</i> is established</b> enabling him to go there on Shabbat, <b>and another</b> person <b>caused him to return</b> home, <b>he</b> himself <b>is permitted to go</b> to that city on Shabbat, <b>and</b> for <b>all the</b> other <b>residents of the town it is prohibited</b> to go there. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>And we discussed</b> this mishna and raised a difficulty: <b>What is different</b> about <b>him and what is different</b> about <b>them?</b> Why is he permitted to proceed to the other town while it is prohibited for the other residents to do so? <b>And Rav Huna said: We are dealing here with</b> a case <b>where he has</b> two <b>houses,</b> one in each city, <b>and</b> there is the distance of <b>two Shabbat limits,</b> four thousand cubits, <b>between them.</b>
With regard to <b>him, since he set out on his way, his</b> legal status <b>is</b> that of <b>a pauper,</b> as he did not intend to return to his first house, but to continue to his other house. Therefore, he can establish residence at the end of his Shabbat limit by verbal means alone.
<b>And</b> the legal status of <b>these</b> other inhabitants of his city, <b>is</b> that of <b>wealthy people,</b> as they are in their houses and have food. Consequently, they can only establish residence at the end of their Shabbat limit by depositing food there prior the onset of Shabbat. <b>Apparently, everything</b> stated with regard to one who says: My residence is <b>in such-and-such place;</b> to <b>a pauper, yes,</b> it applies to <b>a wealthy person, no,</b> it does not apply. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that this is the case.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi was teaching</b> the mishna to <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav before Rav.</b> He stated that this leniency applies <b>both to a pauper and to a wealthy person. Rav said to him: Conclude</b> your statement <b>also: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan was in the habit</b> of <b>coming from</b> his home in <b>Artibbena to Pumbedita</b> on Shabbat.

Daf 52a

He <b>would declare</b> on Shabbat eve: <b>My residence is in Tzinta,</b> a settlement located between the Shabbat limits of the two places. <b>Abaye said to him: What is your opinion</b> that led you to act in that manner? Is it because in a dispute between <b>Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between these two Sages is in a case where the person said: My residence is <b>in such-and-such place,</b> and you rely on Rabbi Yehuda and establish residence at a place between the two cities even though you are still at home?
<b>But didn’t Rav Naḥman</b> explain the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda differently, <b>and</b> furthermore, a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with his</b> opinion. Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan <b>said to him: I retract</b> my opinion and will no longer do so.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> The Sages <b>have said</b> that one who <b>establishes</b> residence by foot <b>has four cubits</b> at that location, and another two thousand cubits beyond. However, with regard to <b>one who deposits his <i>eiruv</i></b> in a certain place, there is a dilemma whether he <b>has four cubits</b> from the site of his <i>eiruv</i>, <b>or not.</b>
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from the mishna: The Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with bread only to be lenient with the wealthy</b> person, <b>so that he</b> need <b>not</b> exert himself and <b>go out and establish an <i>eiruv</i> with his feet. And if you say</b> that one who establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with bread <b>does not have</b> four cubits, is <b>this</b> really <b>a leniency? It is a stringency.</b> Based on the mishna, apparently, all leniencies that apply to one who establishes an <i>eiruv</i> by foot must also apply to one who establishes an <i>eiruv</i> with bread.
The Gemara rejects this argument: No proof can be cited from there, as <b>even</b> if he without the four cubits, <b>this is preferable to him, so that he</b> need <b>not exert himself and go out</b> and establish an <i>eiruv</i> by foot. Therefore, it can be said that establishing an <i>eiruv</i> with bread constitutes a leniency even if it entails the loss of four cubits.
