<b>That was also taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Eliezer of Biriyya says: Those who dwell in huts are like those who dwell in graves. And with regard to</b> one who marries <b>their daughters,</b> the verse <b>says: “Cursed be he who sleeps with any manner of beast”</b> (Deuteronomy 27:21).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this harsh statement with regard to the daughters of those who dwell in huts or travel in deserts? <b>Ulla said: They do not have bathhouses,</b> and therefore the men have to walk a significant distance in order to bathe. There is concern that while they are away their wives commit adultery, and that consequently their children are not really their own. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Because they sense when one another immerses.</b> Similarly to the men, the women must walk a significant distance in order to immerse in a ritual bath. Since the settlement is very small and everyone knows when the women go to immerse, it is possible for an unscrupulous man to use this information to engage in adulterous relations with them by following them and taking advantage of the fact that they are alone.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical difference <b>between</b> the explanations of Ulla and Rabbi Yoḥanan? The Gemara explains: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case where there is <b>a river that is adjacent to the house,</b> and it is suitable for immersion but not for bathing. Consequently, the women would not have to go far to immerse themselves, but the men would still have to walk a significant distance in order to bathe.
Having mentioned various places of residence, the Gemara cites what <b>Rav Huna said: Any city that does not have vegetables, a Torah scholar is not permitted to dwell there</b> for health reasons. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that vegetables are beneficial</b> to a person’s health? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Three</b> things <b>increase one’s waste, bend</b> his <b>stature, and remove one five-hundredth of the light of a person’s eyes; and they are</b>

Daf 56a

<b>coarse bread,</b> made from coarse flour that has not been thoroughly sifted, <b>new beer, and vegetables.</b> This indicates that vegetables are harmful to one’s well-being. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement of Rav Huna is referring <b>to garlic and leeks,</b> which are beneficial; <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to other vegetables,</b> which are harmful. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Garlic is</b> a healthy <b>vegetable; leeks</b> are <b>a half-vegetable,</b> meaning they are half as healthful. If <b>radish has been seen, an elixir of life has been seen,</b> as it is very beneficial to the body.
The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: If <b>radish has been seen, a lethal drug has been seen?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that deprecates radish, it is referring <b>to</b> its <b>leaves; there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that praises radish, it is referring <b>to the roots.</b> Alternatively, <b>here</b> it is referring <b>to the summer,</b> when radish is beneficial; <b>there,</b> it is referring <b>to the winter,</b> when it is harmful.
On the topic of the attributes of different locations, <b>Rav Yehuda</b> also <b>said that Rav said:</b> In <b>any city that has</b> many <b>ascents and descents,</b> which can be taxing to the body, <b>people and animals die at half their days,</b> meaning half of their life expectancy. The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>Can it enter your mind</b> that Rav really meant to say that they <b>die</b> prematurely? Even in such cities they are known to have a regular life expectancy. <b>Rather, say: They grow old at half their days,</b> i.e., they age prematurely due to the strain of climbing up and down the inclines. Similarly, <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: The ascents</b> and descents <b>between Beit Biri and Beit Neresh,</b> my place of residence, <b>made me grow old</b> prematurely.
With regard to the measurements of a city’s boundaries, <b>the Sages taught</b> the following <i>baraita</i>: If, in order to measure the Shabbat limit, <b>one comes to square</b> a city, i.e., to extend the city’s boundaries to include all of its protrusions within an imaginary square, <b>he squares it</b> so that the sides of the square align <b>with the four</b> directions <b>of the world. He sets the northern</b> side of the square <b>to</b> align with <b>the north of the world, and its southern</b> side <b>to</b> align with <b>the south of the world. And your sign</b> by which you can recognize the directions of the world is as follows: The constellation of <b>Ursa Major is in the north and Scorpio is in the south.</b> The directions of the city are determined by these constellations.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: If one does not know how to square</b> the city in alignment <b>with the four</b> directions <b>of the world</b> based upon the constellations, <b>he should square it based upon the seasons,</b> although this is less precise. <b>How so?</b> Where <b>the sun rises and sets on the longest day</b> of the year, the summer solstice, <b>this</b> route of the sun <b>is the face of the north.</b> The sun rises in the northeast and sets in the northwest, and thus travels from east to west across the north side of the world. Conversely, where <b>the sun rises and sets on the shortest day</b> of the year, the winter solstice, <b>this</b> route of the sun <b>is the face of the south.</b> Whereas at <b>the vernal equinox and the autumnal equinox,</b> when day and night are equal in length, <b>the sun rises in the middle of the east and sets in the middle of the west.</b>
<b>As it is stated:</b> “One generation passes away and another generation comes; but the earth abides forever. The sun also rises and the sun goes down, and hastens to its place, where it rises again. <b>It goes toward the south, and turns about to the north;</b> round and round goes the wind, and on its circuits the wind returns” (Ecclesiastes 1:4–6). The verse is understood as describing the sun’s movements, as follows: <b>“It goes toward the south” during the day; “and turns about to the north,”</b> on the other side of the earth, <b>at night. “Round and round goes the wind [<i>ruaḥ</i>];”</b> the word <i>ruaḥ</i> can also mean direction or side. Rabbi Yosei explains that <b>these are the face of the east and the face of the west; sometimes</b> the sun <b>traverses them</b> visibly, <b>and sometimes it turns about them</b> without being seen.
<b>Rav Mesharshiya said: There is no</b> validity to these <b>rules</b> established by Rabbi Yosei, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The sun has never risen,</b> even during the summer, <b>at the northeastern corner</b> of the sky <b>and set in the northwestern corner, nor has the sun</b> ever <b>risen,</b> even during the winter, <b>at the southeastern corner and set in the southwestern corner.</b> Therefore, one can establish the directions of the world according to the sun’s path only during the autumn and spring.
On the topic of the previous discussion with regard to calculating the directions of the world based upon the seasons, <b>Shmuel said: The vernal equinox occurs only at</b> the beginning of one of <b>the four quarters of a day: Either</b> precisely <b>at the beginning of the day, or</b> precisely <b>at the beginning of the night, or at midday, or at midnight.</b>
Similarly, <b>the summer solstice occurs only</b> at certain times of the day: <b>Either at</b> the conclusion of <b>one and a half</b> hours <b>or seven and a half</b> hours <b>of the day or night. And the autumnal equinox occurs only</b> at certain times: <b>Either at</b> the conclusion of <b>three hours or nine hours of the day or night. And the winter solstice occurs only</b> at certain times: <b>Either at</b> the conclusion of <b>four and a half</b> hours <b>or ten and a half</b> hours <b>of the day or night.</b>
<b>And</b> all this is based on the principle that <b>there are only ninety-one days and seven and a half hours between</b> the beginning of <b>one season and the next,</b> as he assumed that a year is exactly 365¼ days. <b>And</b> similarly, each <b>season</b> begins precisely <b>one-half</b> planetary <b>hour past the</b> beginning of the <b>previous season.</b> There are seven heavenly bodies that are each ascendant for an hour at a time in a constant rotation: Mercury, Moon, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, the Sun, and Venus. Each season begins half an hour later in this rotation than <b>the previous</b> season.
<b>And Shmuel said: There is no</b> instance when the <b>vernal equinox occurs in</b> the planetary hour of <b>Jupiter</b> and <b>it does not break the trees</b> with its strong winds; <b>and there is no</b> instance when <b>the winter solstice occurs in</b> the planetary hour of <b>Jupiter</b> and <b>it does not dry up the seeds. And this</b> applies only <b>where the new moon appeared either at</b> the hour of the <b>Moon or at</b> the hour of <b>Jupiter.</b>

Daf 56b

<b>The Sages taught: One who squares a city</b> in order to determine its Shabbat limit <b>renders it like a square tablet, and then</b> he also <b>squares the</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries and renders them like a square tablet.</b> Consequently, after squaring the city, he adds additional squares of two thousand cubits to each of its sides.
<b>And when he measures</b> the Shabbat limit, <b>he should not measure</b> the <b>two thousand cubits</b> diagonally <b>from the middle of</b> each <b>corner</b> of the city, <b>because</b> if he were to do so, <b>he would lose the corners,</b> i.e., the limit would extend only two thousand cubits on the diagonal from each of the corners. <b>Rather,</b> he measures the boundary as though <b>he brought a square tablet that is two thousand cubits by two thousand cubits, and places it at</b> each <b>corner at its diagonal.</b>
As a result, <b>it will be found</b> that <b>the city gains four hundred cubits in this</b> corner <b>and</b> another <b>four hundred cubits in the</b> opposite corner. Assuming that the city itself is round and has a diameter of two thousand cubits, as will be explained below, when the borders of the city are squared, approximately four hundred cubits are added to the city at each corner. When one then squares the Shabbat boundaries, <b>it is found</b> that the Shabbat <b>boundaries gain eight hundred cubits in this</b> corner <b>and eight hundred cubits in the</b> opposite corner. Consequently, by squaring both the city itself and its Shabbat boundaries, <b>it is found</b> that <b>the city and the</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries</b> together <b>gain 1,200</b> cubits <b>in this</b> corner <b>and 1,200</b> cubits <b>in the</b> opposite corner.
<b>Abaye said: And you find this</b> projection of the additions to the city’s borders and Shabbat boundaries to be correct <b>in</b> the case of a round <b>city that is two thousand</b> cubits <b>by two thousand</b> cubits.
The Gemara cites a similar discussion with regard to the Levite cities, the forty-eight cities given to the Levites in Eretz Yisrael instead of a tribal inheritance. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: The boundary of the cities of the Levites</b> extends <b>two thousand cubits</b> in each direction beyond the inhabited section of the city. <b>Remove from them a thousand cubits of open space</b> just beyond the inhabited area, which must be left vacant. <b>Consequently, the open space is one quarter</b> of the extended area, <b>and the rest is fields and vineyards.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters?</b> From where is it derived that the open space surrounding the cities of the Levites measured a thousand cubits? <b>Rava said: As the verse states:</b> “And the open spaces of the cities, that you shall give to the Levites, <b>shall be from the wall of the city and outward a thousand cubits round about”</b> (Numbers 35:4). <b>The Torah states: Surround the city with a thousand</b> cubits on all sides to serve as an open space. <b>Consequently, the open space is one quarter</b> of the area.
The Gemara asks: Is it <b>one quarter? It is one half.</b> One thousand cubits is exactly half of the two thousand cubits incorporated into the boundary of the cities of the Levites. <b>Rava said: Bar Adda the surveyor explained</b> the calculation <b>to me: You will find</b> this <b>in a city that is two thousand</b> cubits <b>by two thousand</b> cubits. <b>How many</b> cubits is the extended <b>boundary</b> of the city itself, without the corners? <b>Sixteen</b> million square cubits. Squares measuring two thousand by two thousand cubits are appended to each of the four sides of the city. The area of each of these squares is four million square cubits, and the total area of all the additional squares is sixteen million square cubits. <b>How many</b> cubits <b>are the corners? Sixteen</b> million square cubits, as additional squares of two thousand by two thousand cubits are appended to the corners of the outer boundaries of the cities. <b>Subtract eight</b> million square cubits <b>from the</b> area of the extended <b>boundary</b> for the open space around the city; the first thousand cubits beyond the inhabited part of the city must be left as open space, which amounts to areas measuring one thousand by two thousand cubits on each of the four sides of the city, for a total of eight million square cubits. <b>And</b> subtract another <b>four</b> million square cubits <b>from the corners,</b> as sections of the corners are parallel to the open spaces. <b>How much is</b> the sum total of the area of the open spaces? <b>Twelve</b> million square cubits.
The Gemara asks: According to this calculation, how is <b>the open space found</b> to be <b>one quarter</b> of the area? <b>It is more than one-third.</b> The entire area of the extended boundary is thirty-two million square cubits and the open space occupies twelve million square cubits, which is more than one-third of the total area of the extended boundary.
The Gemara explains: <b>Bring the four</b> million square cubits <b>of the city</b> itself and <b>add them</b> to the area of the limit, and you will arrive at the correct ratio. The Gemara asks: The opens space <b>is still one-third,</b> as the total area of the city and its extended boundary is thirty-six million square cubits, and the area of the open space is twelve million square cubits.
The Gemara answers: <b>Do you think</b> that this <i>halakha</i> <b>was stated</b> with regard <b>to a square</b> city? <b>It was</b> in fact <b>stated</b> with regard <b>to a round</b> city. The open space beyond the city is also round; however, the total extended boundary is squared, so that the total area of a round city with a diameter of two thousand cubits and its extended boundary is thirty-six million square cubits.
The Gemara explains the calculation: <b>How much larger is</b> the area of <b>a square than</b> the area of <b>the circle? One quarter. Subtract one quarter from</b> the twelve million square cubits of open space, and <b>nine</b> million square cubits <b>are left; and nine is</b> precisely <b>one quarter of thirty-six.</b>
<b>Abaye said: You will also find</b> that the open space is one quarter of the total area <b>in a city that is a thousand</b> cubits <b>by a thousand</b> cubits. <b>How many</b> cubits <b>is the</b> extended <b>boundary</b> of the city without the corners? It is <b>eight</b> million square cubits. Additional areas are appended along each side of the city and extending two thousand cubits beyond the city itself. Each of these areas is two thousand cubits by one thousand cubits, for a total area of two million square cubits. Since there are four of these zones, their total area is eight million square cubits. <b>How many</b> cubits <b>are the corners?</b> They are <b>sixteen</b> million square cubits, as squares of two thousand cubits by two thousand cubits are added to each of the four corners.

Daf 57a

<b>Subtract four</b> million square cubits <b>of the</b> extended <b>boundary</b> for the area of the open space, which is a thousand cubits by a thousand cubits on each side, <b>and</b> an additional <b>four</b> million square cubits <b>from the corners,</b> a thousand cubits by a thousand cubits in each corner, which are connected to the open space. <b>How much is</b> the sum total? It is <b>eight</b> million square cubits.
The Gemara asks: According to this calculation, the eight million square cubits of open space <b>are one-third</b> of the total area of the extended boundary, which is twenty-four million square cubits. The Gemara answers as it answered above: <b>Do you think</b> that this <i>halakha</i> <b>was stated with regard to a square</b> city? <b>It was stated with regard to a round</b> city. <b>How much larger is</b> the area of <b>a square than</b> the area of <b>a circle?</b> It is <b>one quarter</b> of the area of the circle. <b>Subtract one quarter from</b> the eight million square cubits of open space, and <b>six</b> million square cubits <b>are left; and six is</b> precisely <b>one quarter of twenty-four.</b>
<b>Ravina said: What is</b> the meaning of the statement that the open space is <b>one quarter?</b> It is <b>one quarter</b> of <b>the boundary.</b> This <i>halakha</i> was indeed stated with regard to a square city. However, there is open space only along the sides of the city but not at its corners. Accordingly, a city that is two thousand cubits by two thousand cubits has a total extended boundary of thirty-two million square cubits, of which eight million square cubits, two thousand cubits by one thousand cubits on each side, is open space. The open space is thus one quarter of the total.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> the opposite: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the statement that the open space is <b>one quarter</b> of the total extended boundary? <b>One quarter of the corners.</b> Open space is granted only in the corners, and not along the sides. Accordingly, the open space is one thousand cubits by a thousand cubits in each corner, for a total of four million square cubits. The total extended boundary in each corner is two thousand cubits by two thousand cubits, or four million square cubits per corner, which equals a grand total of sixteen million square cubits. Consequently, the open space is one quarter of the total extended boundary.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Isn’t it written</b> in the verse: “And the open spaces of the cities, that you shall give to the Levites, shall be from the wall of the city and outward one thousand cubits <b>around”</b> (Numbers 35:4)? The verse indicates that the city is provided with open space on all sides and not merely at its corners
Rav Ashi responded: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>around? Around at the corners,</b> i.e., an open space of this size is provided at each corner. <b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that the area of the corners is also called around, <b>with regard to</b> the <b>burnt-offering, as it is written: “And they shall sprinkle the blood around upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:5), <b>here, too,</b> will you say that the blood must be sprinkled <b>literally “around”</b> the altar on all sides? The blood is sprinkled only upon the corners of the altar. <b>Rather, what is</b> the meaning of <b>around? Around the corners,</b> i.e., the mitzva is to sprinkle the blood at the corners, and this is considered sprinkling blood “around upon the altar.” <b>Here too,</b> with regard to the open space of the cities of the Levites, <b>what is</b> the meaning of <b>around? Around the corners.</b>
The Gemara returns to its previous statement that the open space around a city of the Levites is one quarter of the total extended boundary when the city is round. It questions this statement based upon the mishna’s ruling that the boundaries of a city are always delineated as a square. <b>Rav Ḥavivi from Meḥoza said to Rav Ashi: But aren’t there the protrusions of the corners?</b> How can there be a thousand cubits of open space on each side; when the city is squared, the corners of the square protrude into the open space, thus reducing its area?
Rav Ashi replied: We are dealing <b>with a circular city.</b> Rav Ḥavivi responded: <b>But haven’t they squared</b> the city? Rav Ashi responded: <b>Say that we say</b> the following: <b>We view</b> the city <b>as if it were squared. Do we actually</b> add houses and <b>square it?</b> Although for the purpose of calculating the extended boundary we view the city as a square, in actuality the uninhabited sections are part of the open space.
<b>Rav Ḥanilai from Meḥoza said to Rav Ashi: Now, how much larger is</b> the area of <b>a square than</b> the area of <b>a circle? One quarter.</b> Therefore, if we calculate how much area a circular city with a diameter of two thousand cubits gains when it is squared, does it add up to <b>these eight hundred</b> cubits mentioned above? The extra area added <b>is</b> only <b>667 minus one-third</b> cubits.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: This</b> statement <b>applies only to a circle</b> enclosed <b>within a square,</b> as the area of a circle is three-quarters the area of the square around it. <b>However, with regard to the</b> additional <b>diagonal [<i>alakhsona</i>]</b> space added in the corners of the square, <b>more is required. As the Master said: Every cubit</b> in the side <b>of a square is one and two-fifths cubits in its diagonal.</b> Based on this rule, the calculation is exact.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One allocates a <i>karpef</i> to</b> every <b>city,</b> i.e., the measure of a <i>karpef</i>, which is slightly more than seventy cubits, is added to every city, and the two thousand cubits of the Shabbat limit are measured from there; <b>this is the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: They spoke of</b> the addition of <b>a <i>karpef</i> only</b> with regard to the space <b>between two</b> adjacent <b>cities.</b> How so? <b>If this</b> city <b>has seventy cubits and a remainder</b> vacant on one side, <b>and that</b> city <b>has seventy cubits and a remainder</b> vacant on the adjacent side, and the two areas of seventy-plus cubits overlap, <b>the <i>karpef</i> combines the two</b> cities <b>into one.</b>
<b>And likewise,</b> in the case of <b>three villages that are</b> arranged as <b>a triangle, if there are</b> only <b>141⅓</b> cubits separating <b>between the two outer</b> villages, the <b>middle</b> village <b>combines the three</b> villages <b>into one.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that a <i>karpef</i> is added to a city, derived? <b>Rava said: As the verse states:</b> “And the open spaces of the cities, that you shall give to the Levites, shall be <b>from the wall of the city and outward</b> a thousand cubits around. And you shall measure from outside the city on the east side two thousand cubits” (Numbers 35:4–5). <b>The Torah says: Provide</b> a certain vacant space <b>outside</b> the city, <b>and</b> only <b>afterward measure</b> the two thousand cubits.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say: They spoke</b> of the addition of a <i>karpef</i> <b>only</b> with regard to the space between two adjacent cities. <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to this issue. <b>Rav Huna said: One allocates a <i>karpef</i> to this</b> city <b>and a <i>karpef</i> to that</b> city, so that the two cities together are granted a total of slightly more than 141 cubits. <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav said:</b> One allocates only <b>one</b> common <b><i>karpef</i> to the two of them.</b>
The Gemara raises possible proofs for each opinion. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say: They spoke</b> of the addition of <b>a <i>karpef</i> only with regard to</b> the space <b>between two</b> adjacent <b>cities.</b> This appears to be <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> as it states that one <i>karpef</i> is allocated rather than two.
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in response to this difficulty: <b>What is</b> meant here by <b>a <i>karpef</i> ?</b> It means <b>the principle of a <i>karpef</i>. In actuality,</b> one allocates <b>a <i>karpef</i> to this</b> city <b>and a <i>karpef</i> to that</b> city.
The Gemara comments: <b>So, too, it is reasonable</b> to explain the mishna in the following manner: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause: If this</b> city <b>has seventy cubits and a remainder</b> vacant on one side, <b>and that</b> city <b>has seventy cubits and a remainder</b> vacant on the adjacent side, and the two areas of seventy-plus cubits overlap, <b>the <i>karpef</i> combines the two</b> cities <b>into one.</b> This indicates that an area of seventy cubits and a remainder is added to each city. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that this is the correct understanding of the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>this</b> mishna <b>is a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav,</b> that two adjacent cities are granted only one <i>karpef</i>. The Gemara answers that <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav</b> could have <b>said to you:</b>

Daf 57b

In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>this</b> clause of the mishna? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who maintains that one allocates a <i>karpef</i> to each city.
The Gemara continues to ask: <b>If it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, didn’t we</b> already <b>learn in the first clause: One allocates a <i>karpef</i> to</b> each <b>city;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir?</b> What need is there to mention Rabbi Meir’s opinion again?
The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to mention his opinion again, <b>as, if</b> we had learned his opinion only <b>from that</b> first clause, <b>I might have said</b> that one allocates <b>one</b> <i>karpef</i> <b>for one</b> city <b>and</b> also <b>one</b> <i>karpef</i> <b>for two</b> cities. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us that for two</b> cities, <b>one allocates two</b> <i>karpef</i> areas.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the mishna had <b>taught us</b> this law only <b>here,</b> with regard to two cities, one might have said that only in that case is each city granted a separate <i>karpef</i>, <b>because</b> a smaller space between the two adjacent cities would be too <b>crowded for the use</b> of both cities. <b>But there,</b> with regard to one city, <b>where</b> the area of the city itself <b>is not</b> too <b>crowded for the use of</b> its residents, one might <b>say</b> that it is <b>not</b> given any <i>karpef</i> whatsoever. Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach both clauses.
The Gemara tries again to adduce proof from the mishna, in which <b>we learned: And likewise,</b> in the case of <b>three villages that are aligned</b> in a row, <b>if there is</b> only <b>141⅓</b> cubits separating <b>between the two outer ones,</b> the <b>middle</b> village <b>combines the three</b> villages <b>into one.</b> At this point the Gemara understands that the mishna here is dealing with three villages arranged in a straight line. Therefore, it makes the following inference: <b>The reason</b> that the three villages are considered as one <b>is</b> only because <b>there is a middle</b> village, <b>but were there no middle</b> village, they would <b>not</b> be considered as one. This appears to be <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna.</b> According to Rav Huna, the two villages should be considered as one even without the middle village, due to the double <i>karpef</i>.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: Wasn’t it stated with regard to</b> that mishna that <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Idi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> It does <b>not</b> mean that the villages are <b>actually aligned</b> in a row of <b>three</b> villages in a straight line. <b>Rather,</b> even if the middle village is off to one side and the outer villages are more than two <i>karpef</i> lengths apart, <b>we see</b> their spacing and make the following assessment: <b>Any</b> case <b>where, if the middle</b> village <b>were placed between</b> the other two <b>so that they were three</b> villages <b>aligned</b> in a row, <b>there would be only</b> a distance of <b>141⅓ cubits between one and the other,</b> then the <b>middle</b> village <b>turns the three</b> villages <b>into one.</b> According to this explanation, the mishna can be understood even as a support for the opinion of Rav Huna.
With regard to this case, <b>Rava said to Abaye: How much</b> distance can <b>there be between an outer</b> village <b>and the middle one,</b> if the latter is still to combine the three villages into one? Abaye <b>said to him: Two thousand cubits.</b>
Rava replied: <b>Wasn’t it you</b> yourself <b>who said: It is reasonable</b> to rule <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, son of Rabba bar Rav Huna, who said:</b> The Shabbat limit of a bow-shaped city is measured from the imaginary bowstring stretched between the two ends of the city, even if the distance between the center of the string and the center of the bow is <b>more than two thousand cubits.</b> Why shouldn’t the three villages in this case be considered a single village also, even if they are separated by more than two thousand cubits?
Abaye rejected the comparison: <b>How can you compare? There,</b> in the case of the bow-shaped city, <b>there are houses</b> that combine the city into a single unit, whereas <b>here, there are no houses</b> linking the outer villages. Therefore, if two villages are separated by more than two thousand cubits, the measure of the Shabbat limit, they cannot be considered a single entity.
<b>And Rava said to Abaye: How much</b> distance can <b>there be between</b> one <b>outer</b> village <b>and</b> the other <b>outer</b> village? Abaye expressed surprise at this question: <b>How much</b> distance can <b>there be</b> between them? <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference to you? Any</b> case <b>where, if the middle</b> village <b>were placed between them, there would be only</b> a distance of <b>141⅓</b> cubits <b>between one and the other,</b> the middle village turns the three villages into one. Therefore, the critical detail is not the distance between the outer villages but the size of the middle village.
Rava continued his line of questioning: Is this true <b>even</b> if the distance between the two outer villages is <b>four thousand cubits?</b> Abaye <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rava asked: <b>Didn’t Rav Huna say</b> the following with regard to <b>a city shaped like a bow: If</b> the distance <b>between its two ends is less than four thousand cubits, one measures</b> the Shabbat limit <b>from the</b> imaginary <b>bowstring</b> stretched between the two ends of the bow; <b>and if not, one measures</b> the Shabbat limit <b>from the bow</b> itself? This indicates that even if there is an uninterrupted string of houses linking the two ends of the city, if the two ends are separated by more than four thousand cubits, the distance is too great for it to be considered a single city.
Abaye <b>said to him: There,</b> in the case of the bow-shaped city, <b>there is no</b> room <b>to say: Fill</b> it in, as there is nothing with which to fill in the empty space between the two ends of the city. However, <b>here,</b> in the case of the villages, <b>there is</b> room <b>to say: Fill</b> it in, as the middle village is seen as though it were projected between the two outer villages, and therefore all three combine into a single village.
<b>Rav Safra said to Rava:</b> With regard to <b>the people of</b> the city of <b>Akistefon, for whom we measure the</b> Shabbat <b>limit from the</b> far <b>end of</b> the city of <b>Ardeshir, and the people of Ardeshir, for whom we measure the</b> Shabbat <b>limit from the</b> far <b>end of Akistefon,</b> as though the two settlements were a single city; <b>isn’t there the Tigris</b> River, <b>which separates them by more than 141⅓</b> cubits? How can two cities that are separated by more than two <i>karpef</i>-lengths be considered a single entity?
Rava <b>went out</b> and <b>showed</b> Rav Safra <b>the foundations of a wall</b> of one of the cities, <b>which were submerged in the Tigris</b> River <b>at</b> a distance of <b>seventy cubits and a remainder</b> from the other city. In other words, the two cities were in fact linked through the remnants of a wall submerged in the river.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may measure</b> a Shabbat limit <b>only with a rope fifty cubits</b> long, <b>no less and no more,</b> as will be explained in the Gemara. <b>And one may measure</b> the limit <b>only at the level of one’s heart,</b> i.e., whoever comes to measure the limit must hold the rope next to his chest.
If <b>one was measuring</b> the limit <b>and he reached a canyon or a fence,</b> the height of the fence and the depth of the canyon are not counted toward the two thousand cubits; rather, <b>he spans it and</b> then <b>resumes his measurement.</b> Two people hold the two ends of the rope straight across the canyon or the fence, and the distance is measured as though the area were completely flat. If <b>one reached a hill,</b> he does not measure its height; rather, <b>he spans</b> the hill as if it were not there <b>and</b> then <b>resumes his measurement,</b>

Daf 58a

<b>provided he does not</b> thereby <b>go out beyond the</b> city’s Shabbat <b>limit,</b> as those watching the surveyor might mistakenly think the limit extends to that point.
<b>If,</b> due to the width of the canyon or hill, <b>he cannot span it, with regard to this</b> situation <b>Rabbi Dostai bar Yannai said in the name of Rabbi Meir: I heard that one may pierce hills.</b> In other words, one measures the distance as if there were a hole from one side of the hill to the other, so that in effect, he measures only the horizontal distance and ignores the differences in elevation.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that the Shabbat limit must be measured with a rope fifty cubits long, derived? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> They are derived from <b>that</b> which <b>the verse states: “The length of the courtyard shall be one hundred cubits, and the breadth fifty by fifty”</b> (Exodus 27:18). <b>The Torah states: Measure with a rope of fifty cubits,</b> i.e., the length and breadth of the courtyard must be measured “by fifty,” with a rope fifty cubits long.
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> repetitive usage of the word fifty <b>is necessary</b> to teach us something else, namely, that the area of a courtyard is equivalent to a square the size of the Tabernacle’s courtyard. To this end, the Torah states: <b>Take</b> a square of <b>fifty</b> cubits by fifty cubits, <b>and surround</b> it with the remaining <b>fifty</b> cubits in order to form a square, each side of which is just over seventy cubits long.
The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let the verse state: Fifty, fifty,</b> which would have sufficed to teach us the size and shape of a courtyard. <b>What is</b> the significance of the phrase: <b>Fifty by fifty? Conclude from this</b> that the verse comes to teach <b>two</b> things, both the matter of the square courtyard and that the length of the rope used to measure the Shabbat limit should be fifty cubits long.
We learned in the mishna: One may measure a Shabbat limit only with a rope fifty cubits long, <b>not less and not more. It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>No less, because</b> a shorter rope improperly <b>increases</b> the Shabbat limit, as the rope is likely to be stretched. <b>And no more, because</b> a longer rope <b>reduces</b> the limit, as the rope is likely to sag due to its weight.
<b>Rabbi Asi said: One may measure only with a rope of <i>afsakima</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>afsakima</i>? Rabbi Abba said:</b> It is the <b><i>nargila</i></b> plant. This name was also not widely known, and therefore the Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>nargila</i>? Rabbi Ya’akov said: A palm tree</b> that has only <b>one fibrous vine</b> wrapped around it. <b>Some say</b> a different version of the previous discussion, according to which the Gemara asked: <b>What is <i>afsakima</i>? Rabbi Abba said:</b> It is the <b><i>nargila</i></b> plant. <b>Rabbi Ya’akov</b> disagreed and <b>said:</b> It is <b>a palm tree</b> with <b>one fibrous vine.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya said: You have nothing better for measuring than iron chains,</b> as they do not stretch. <b>But what shall we do, as the Torah states:</b> “I lifted up my eyes again and looked, and behold a man <b>with a measuring rope in his hand”</b> (Zechariah 2:5), from which it is derived that measurements must be made with a rope.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it</b> also <b>written: “And in the man’s hand a measuring reed</b> of six cubits long, of one cubit and a handbreadth each” (Ezekiel 40:5), which indicates that reeds may also be used for measuring? The Gemara answers: <b>That is</b> used <b>for</b> measuring <b>gates,</b> which are too narrow to be measured with lengthy ropes.
<b>Rav Yosef taught</b> that <b>there are three</b> kinds of <b>rope,</b> each required by <i>halakha</i> for a different purpose: A rope <b>of <i>magag</i>,</b> a kind of bulrush reed; a rope <b>of <i>netzer</i>,</b> made from fibrous palm vines; <b>and</b> a rope <b>of flax.</b>
They are used for the following purposes: A rope <b>of <i>magag</i></b> is utilized <b>for</b> the burning of <b>the</b> red <b>heifer, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>They would bind</b> the heifer <b>with a rope of <i>magag</i> and place it on its woodpile,</b> where it would be burned after it was slaughtered. A rope <b>of <i>netzer</i></b> was required <b>for a <i>sota</i>,</b> a woman suspected of adultery, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: Before the <i>sota</i> is compelled to drink the bitter waters, her clothes are torn. <b>And after that</b> a priest <b>brings a <i>mitzri</i> rope,</b> i.e., a rope made of reeds [<i>netzarim</i>], <b>and binds it above her breasts,</b> so that her garments will not fall. A rope <b>of flax</b> is used <b>for measuring.</b>
It was stated in the mishna: If <b>he was measuring</b> the limit <b>and he reached</b> a canyon or a fence, he spans the area as if it were completely flat and then resumes his measurement. The Gemara comments: <b>From</b> the fact that <b>it taught</b> that <b>he resumes his measurement,</b> it may be derived <b>by inference that if he cannot span it</b> because it is too wide, <b>he goes to a place where</b> it is narrower so that <b>he can span it. And he spans it, and he</b> then <b>looks</b> for the spot at the same distance that is <b>aligned with his</b> original <b>measurement, and he resumes</b> his measurement from there.
The Gemara comments that <b>we have</b> indeed <b>learned this, as the Sages taught</b> the following <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who was measuring</b> the Shabbat limit <b>and the measurement reached a canyon, if he can span</b> the canyon <b>with a rope of fifty cubits,</b> i.e., if the canyon is less than fifty cubits wide, <b>he spans it. And if not,</b> i.e., if the valley is more than fifty cubits wide, <b>he goes to a place where</b> it is narrower so that <b>he can span it, and he spans it, and he</b> then <b>looks</b> for the spot at the same distance that aligns with his original measurement, <b>and he resumes his measurement</b> from there.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If the canyon was curved</b> so that it surrounds the city on more than one side, and it cannot be spanned on the side where he wishes to measure the limit, <b>he pierces and ascends, pierces and descends,</b> thereby measuring the canyon’s width bit by bit. If <b>he reached a wall, we do not say that he should pierce the wall</b> so that it can be precisely measured; <b>rather, he estimates</b> its width <b>and</b> then <b>leaves</b> and continues on.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: If he reached a canyon or fence, <b>he spans it and</b> then <b>resumes his measurement?</b> Why is a precise measurement required there, whereas in the case of a wall, an estimate is sufficient? The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> in the mishna, we are dealing with a place whose <b>use is convenient,</b> i.e., where the slope is relatively gentle so that the area can be crossed. Therefore, the area must actually be measured. However, <b>here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, the wall’s <b>use is not convenient.</b> Since one cannot walk through the wall, an estimate of its width is sufficient.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They taught</b> the method of piercing <b>only where a plumb line does not drop straight down,</b> i.e., where the canyon has a slope.

Daf 58b

<b>However,</b> if <b>a plumb line drops straight down,</b> i.e., if the canyon wall is very steep, <b>he measures</b> the width of the canyon <b>properly</b> at the bottom of the canyon, without taking its walls into account.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the depth of a canyon</b> that may be spanned if it is not more than fifty cubits wide? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> Up to <b>two thousand</b> cubits; but if it is deeper than that, the slope must be measured as well.
<b>Abaye raised an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: If a canyon is up to <b>one hundred</b> cubits <b>deep and</b> up to <b>fifty</b> cubits <b>wide, one may span it; and if not, one may not span it.</b> How could Rav Yosef say that the canyon may be spanned if its depth is less than two thousand cubits? The Gemara answers: <b>He stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b><i>Aḥerim</i>; as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say: Even</b> if the canyon is <b>two thousand</b> cubits <b>deep and fifty</b> cubits <b>wide, one may span it.</b>
The Gemara cites an alternate version of the previous discussion. <b>Some say</b> that <b>Rav Yosef said: Even</b> if the canyon is <b>more than two thousand</b> cubits deep, it may be spanned. The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Rav Yosef say this? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>, and</b> it is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the <i>Aḥerim</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> where the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree about the depth of a canyon that may be spanned, they refer to a case where <b>a plumb line does not drop straight down</b> and therefore there is reason to measure the slope. <b>Here,</b> however, where Rav Yosef says that the canyon may be spanned even if it is more than two thousand cubits deep, he is referring to a case where <b>a plumb line drops straight down.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And where a plumb line does not drop straight down, how much</b> must it extend from the top of the canyon in order for the wall of the canyon to be considered a slope rather than a vertical wall? <b>Avimi said: Four</b> cubits. If the bed of the canyon lies four cubits beyond the top edge of the canyon, the wall is sloped and must be included in the measurement. <b>And similarly, Rami bar Ezekiel taught,</b> based upon a <i>baraita</i>, that the maximum run is <b>four</b> cubits.
We learned in the mishna: If <b>he reached a hill,</b> he does not measure its height, but rather <b>he spans</b> the hill as if it were not there <b>and</b> then <b>resumes his measurement. Rava said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only with regard to a hill that has an incline of ten</b> handbreadths <b>within</b> a run of <b>four</b> cubits. <b>However, with regard to</b> a gentler <b>hill,</b> e.g., one <b>that has an incline of ten</b> handbreadths <b>within five</b> cubits, <b>one must measure</b> the hill <b>properly,</b> i.e., he must include the slope itself in his measurement.
The Gemara notes that <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, teaches a lenient</b> formulation of this <i>halakha</i>: <b>Rava said</b> that <b>they only taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a hill that has an incline of ten</b> handbreadths <b>within</b> a run of <b>five</b> cubits. <b>However, with regard to</b> a steeper <b>hill that has an incline of ten</b> handbreadths <b>within four</b> cubits, one need not take any precise measurements; instead, <b>he estimates</b> the length of the hill, <b>and</b> then <b>leaves</b> and continues measuring from the other side.
We learned in the mishna that one may measure a canyon or hill located within the Shabbat limit, <b>provided that one does not go out beyond the limit.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this restriction? <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> It is <b>a decree, lest</b> people <b>say: The measurement of the</b> Shabbat <b>limit comes to here.</b> Since people know that he set out to measure the Shabbat limit, if they see him measuring in a certain spot they will assume that the area is included in the Shabbat limit.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If,</b> due to the width of the canyon or hill, <b>one cannot span it,</b> he may pierce it. <b>The Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> which explains this procedure: <b>How does one</b> figuratively <b>pierce</b> a hill? Two people hold the two ends of a measuring rope. The one who is <b>lower</b> down on the hill holds the rope <b>at the level of his heart</b> while the one who is <b>higher</b> holds it <b>at the level of his feet,</b> and they proceed to measure in this fashion. <b>Abaye said:</b> Based on tradition, <b>we hold</b> that <b>one may pierce only with a rope of four cubits.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said that Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> Based on tradition, <b>we hold</b> that <b>one may not pierce</b> when measuring distances for the rite of the <b>beheaded heifer.</b> This rite is practiced when a murder victim is found, and it is not known who killed him. Judges measure the distance from the location of the corpse to the nearest town, in order to determine which town must perform the rite (Deuteronomy 21). Similarly, <b>one may not</b> pierce when measuring distances with regard to <b>cities of refuge,</b> in order to determine the boundaries within which an accidental murderer is protected from the blood redeemer (Numbers 32). <b>Because</b> these measurements <b>are from the Torah,</b> indirect methods of measurement are insufficient. The area must be measured as though it were flat.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <b>may measure</b> the Shabbat limit <b>only with an expert</b> surveyor. If it is discovered that the surveyor <b>extended</b> the limit <b>in one place and reduced it in another place,</b> so that the line marking the Shabbat limit is not straight, <b>one accepts</b> the measurement of <b>the place where he extended</b> the limit and straightens the limit accordingly. Similarly, if the surveyor <b>extended</b> the limit <b>for one and reduced</b> it <b>for another, one accepts the extended</b> measurement.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>even</b> a gentile <b>slave</b> and <b>even</b> a gentile <b>maidservant,</b> whose testimonies are generally considered unreliable, <b>are trustworthy to say: The Shabbat limit</b> extended <b>until here; as the Sages did not state the matter,</b> the laws of Shabbat limits, <b>to be stringent, but</b> rather <b>to be lenient.</b> The prohibition to walk more than two thousand cubits is rabbinic in origin and is therefore interpreted leniently.

Daf 59a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: Does this mean that in <b>a place where he extended</b> the limit, <b>yes,</b> the surveyor’s measurements are accepted, but in <b>a place where he reduced</b> the limit, <b>no,</b> his measurements are not accepted? If his extended measurement is accepted, his shortened measurement should certainly be accepted as well. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that the mishna means that the surveyor’s measurements are accepted <b>even</b> in <b>a place where he extended</b> the limit, without concern that he might have erred (<i>Tosafot</i>), and that the surveyor’s measurements are certainly accepted in places where he reduced the Shabbat limit.
We learned in the mishna: If the surveyor <b>extended</b> the limit <b>for one and reduced</b> it <b>for another,</b> one accepts the extended measurement. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need this as well? This</b> clause <b>is the same as that</b> previous clause in the mishna. The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>said:</b> If two surveyors measured the Shabbat limit and <b>one extended</b> the Shabbat limit <b>and one reduced</b> it, <b>one accepts</b> the measurements of <b>the</b> surveyor <b>who extended</b> it.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The measurements of the surveyor who extended the limit are accepted only <b>as long as he does not extend</b> the limit <b>more than</b> the difference between <b>the measure</b> of the Shabbat limit <b>of the city</b> calculated <b>as a diagonal</b> line from the corner of the city and as calculated as a straight line from the side of the city. If, however, the difference in measurements exceeds that amount, the Shabbat limit must be measured again.
We learned in the mishna: <b>As the Sages did not state the matter,</b> the laws of Shabbat limits, <b>to be stringent, but</b> rather <b>to be lenient.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t</b> the opposite <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Sages did not state the matter,</b> the laws of Shabbat limits, <b>to be lenient but</b> rather <b>to be stringent?</b>
<b>Ravina said</b> that there is no contradiction between these two statements: The very institution of Shabbat limits was enacted <b>not to be</b> more <b>lenient</b> than <b>Torah law,</b> but <b>rather to be stringent</b> beyond <b>Torah law.</b> Nonetheless, since <b>Shabbat limits are rabbinic law,</b> the Sages permitted certain leniencies with regard to how the Shabbat limits are measured.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Although this chapter as a whole deals with <i>halakhot</i> governing the joining of Shabbat boundaries, this mishna returns to the <i>halakhot</i> governing a joining of courtyards. If <b>a private city,</b> which does not have many residents, grows and <b>becomes</b> a heavily populated <b>public</b> city, <b>one may establish a joining of the courtyards for all of it,</b> as long as it does not include a public domain as defined by Torah law.
<b>And</b> if <b>a public</b> city loses residents over time and <b>becomes a private</b> city, <b>one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for all of it unless one maintains</b> an area <b>outside</b> the <i>eiruv</i> that is <b>like</b> the size of <b>the city of Ḥadasha in Judea, which has fifty residents.</b> Carrying within the <i>eiruv</i> is permitted, but it remains prohibited to carry in the area excluded from the <i>eiruv</i>. The reason for this requirement is to ensure that the laws of <i>eiruv</i> will not be forgotten. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The excluded area need not be so large; rather, it is sufficient to exclude <b>three courtyards</b> with <b>two houses</b> each.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>a private city</b> that <b>becomes a public</b> city? <b>Rav Yehuda said: For example, the Exilarch’s village [<i>de’iskarta</i>]</b> was a small village set aside for the Exilarch’s family and attendants; since it was frequented by many people, it turned into a public city.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to him: What is the reason</b> for bringing this example? <b>If you say</b> that <b>because</b> large numbers of people <b>are to be found at</b> the residence of <b>the governor [<i>harmana</i>]</b> in order to request licenses and authorizations, and <b>they remind each other</b> of the reason it is permissible to establish an <i>eiruv</i> there, and consequently they will not arrive at mistaken conclusions with regard to other places, then every city should have the same status, as <b>the entire Jewish people are also found together on Shabbat morning</b> when they come to pray. <b>Rather, Rav Naḥman said: For example, the village of Natzu’i</b> was a private city belonging to a single individual before a large influx of residents turned it into a public city.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a private city becomes public, and</b> a bona fide <b>public domain passes through it, how does one establish an <i>eiruv</i> for it? He places a side post from here,</b> one side of the public domain, <b>and side post from there,</b> the other side; <b>or,</b> he places a cross <b>beam from here,</b> one side of the public domain, <b>and</b> another cross <b>beam from there,</b> the other side. <b>He may</b> then <b>carry</b> items <b>and place</b> them <b>between</b> these symbolic partitions, as the public domain is now considered like one of the courtyards of the city. <b>And one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for half</b> the city; <b>rather,</b> one may establish <b>either</b> one <i>eiruv</i> for <b>all of it or</b> separate ones for <b>each alleyway separately</b> without including the other sections of the city.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If <b>it was</b> originally <b>a public</b> city, <b>and it</b> remains <b>a public</b> city,

Daf 59b

<b>and it has only one entrance,</b> as it is surrounded by a wall or enclosed by houses on all sides, <b>one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for all of it.</b>
The Gemara raises a question concerning this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds <b>that an <i>eiruv</i> may be established for a public domain</b> in this manner? <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: It is Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said: One who has two houses</b> opposite each other <b>on two sides of the public domain,</b> if he chooses, <b>he may</b> create a private domain for himself in the public domain. He may <b>place</b> a ten-handbreadth high <b>post from here,</b> on one side, <b>and</b> an additional <b>post from there,</b> the other side. This creates symbolic walls that provide the public domain with the legal status of a private domain. <b>Or,</b> one may place <b>a beam</b> extending <b>from here,</b> one end of the house, <b>and a beam from there,</b> the other end of the house, thereby creating symbolic partitions across the width of the street. In that way, one is permitted to <b>carry</b> objects <b>and place</b> them <b>in</b> the area <b>between</b> the symbolic partitions, as he would in a private domain. The Rabbis <b>said to him: One may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> in the public domain in that</b> way.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> quoted above: <b>And one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for half</b> the city. <b>Rav Pappa said: They said</b> this <b>only</b> in a case where one wishes to divide the city <b>according to its length.</b> Generally, a city had a public domain that ran straight across it, from the entrance on one side of the city to the entrance on its other side. The <i>baraita</i> rules that it is prohibited to establish an <i>eiruv</i> separately for the residents of each side of the public domain. <b>But</b> if one wants to divide the city <b>according to its width, he may establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for half the city. This distinction is made because in the first case the public domain that runs between the two halves is used by the residents of both halves, and therefore it joins the two into a single unit; in the second case, the residents of each half use only the half of the public domain located on their side and not the half of the public domain located on the other side.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this <i>halakha</i>? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva. As, if</b> it were <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, didn’t he say that a foot that is permitted in its</b> own <b>place prohibits</b> carrying <b>even in a place that is not its own?</b> Rabbi Akiva holds the following in the case of outer and inner courtyards, in which the residents of each courtyard established their own, independent <i>eiruv</i>: Since the residents of the inner courtyard, who are permitted to carry in their own courtyard, may not carry in the outer courtyard despite the fact that they have rights of passage there, it is prohibited even for the residents of the outer courtyard to carry there. By the same logic, since the residents of each half of the city are prohibited to carry in the public domain of the city’s other half, despite the fact that they may travel there, it should be prohibited for everyone to carry there, and the <i>eiruv</i> should not be functional.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Even if you say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, Rabbi Akiva stated</b> his opinion <b>there only in</b> a case of <b>two courtyards, one</b> farther <b>inside</b> than <b>the other, as the inner</b> courtyard <b>has no other entrance.</b> Since the residents of the inner courtyard have no choice but to pass through the outer courtyard, the residents of the outer courtyard deny the residents of the inner courtyard exclusive use of their own courtyard; therefore, they can impose restrictions upon them. <b>But here,</b> in the case of two halves of the city, <b>these may go out through this</b> part of the public domain on their side of the city, leading to one <b>entrance</b> to the city, <b>and these may go out through this</b> other part of the public domain, leading to the other <b>entrance</b> to the city. Since the residents of each half do not have to use the portion of the public domain located in the other half, they do not impose any restrictions on the residents of the other half, even if they do in fact use it.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of the previous discussion. <b>Rav Pappa said: Do not say that it is</b> only if the city is divided <b>according to its length that one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for half the city, <b>but</b> if the city is divided <b>according to its width, one may establish</b> a separate <b><i>eiruv</i></b> for each half. <b>Rather, even</b> if the city is divided <b>according to its width, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for half the city.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this <i>halakha</i>? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Even if you say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> it is possible that <b>the Rabbis stated</b> their opinion <b>there only in</b> the case of <b>two courtyards, one inside the other, as</b> the residents of <b>the inner</b> courtyard <b>can close the door</b> to the outer courtyard <b>and use</b> only their own courtyard. In doing so, they impose no restrictions on the residents of the outer courtyard. <b>But here,</b> with regard to the division of a city, <b>are they able to move the public domain from here?</b> Since the residents of each half cannot be prevented from using the public domain located in the other half, even the Rabbis would agree that the <i>eiruv</i> is ineffective.
<b>The Master said</b> in the previously cited <i>baraita</i> that an <i>eiruv</i> must <b>either</b> be established <b>for all of it or</b> for <b>each alleyway separately.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about an <i>eiruv</i> <b>for half</b> the city, <b>which is not</b> permissible? The residents of each half <b>prohibit</b> residents of the <b>other</b> from carrying, due to the fact that all the residents may use both halves. Similarly, even if they establish a separate <i>eiruv</i> for <b>each alleyway,</b> the residents should still <b>prohibit</b> residents of the <b>other</b> from carrying, as residents of one alleyway commonly enter other alleyways as well.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the residents <b>erected a partition</b> at the entrance to the alleyway as an indication that they do not want to be connected to the other alleyways. <b>And</b> it is <b>like that</b> which <b>Rav Idi bar Avin said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: One of the residents of an alleyway, who made a partition for his entrance</b> to the alleyway as a sign that he does not intend to carry from his house to the alleyway, <b>does not prohibit the</b> other <b>residents of the alleyway</b> from carrying there if he does not join in their <i>eiruv</i>. The reason for this is that this resident has demonstrated his desire to renounce his share of the alleyway.
It was taught in the <i>baraita</i>: If <b>it was</b> originally <b>a public</b> city <b>and it is</b> still <b>a public</b> city, and it has only one entrance to the public domain, one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> for the entire city. The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Zeira established an <i>eiruv</i> for Rabbi Ḥiyya’s city and did not leave any section</b> of the city <b>out</b> of the <i>eiruv</i>. <b>Abaye said to him: What is the reason that the Master acted in this</b> manner? Why didn’t you exclude a section of the city from the <i>eiruv</i>, as required in a public city?
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>The</b> city <b>Elders told me</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Asi</b> used to <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for the <b>entire</b> city without excluding any section of it, <b>and I said</b> to myself: If he would establish an <i>eiruv</i> for the whole city, I can <b>learn from this</b> that it was originally <b>a private city and</b> later <b>becomes a public one.</b> Therefore, it is permitted to establish an <i>eiruv</i> for the entire city.
Abaye <b>said to him: Those</b> same <b>Elders told me</b> that the reason was different: <b>There was a particular garbage</b> dump <b>on one side</b> of the public domain, which blocked one of the entrances, leaving only one entrance to the public domain. However, <b>now that the garbage</b> dump <b>has been cleared away, it has two entrances, and</b> it <b>is</b> therefore <b>prohibited</b> to establish an <i>eiruv</i> for the whole city without excluding a section from the <i>eiruv</i>. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: It was not on my mind,</b> i.e., I was unaware that this was the situation.
<b>Rav Ami bar Adda from Harpanya raised a dilemma before Rabba:</b> If a public domain has <b>a ladder on one side,</b> to allow people to scale the wall that blocks it, <b>and an entrance on the other side, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it considered a public domain that is open on both sides? Rabba <b>said to him</b> that <b>Rav said as follows: A ladder has the status of an entrance,</b> and therefore the public domain is considered open on both sides.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to them: Do not listen to him. Rav Adda said</b> that <b>Rav said as follows: A ladder has the status of an entrance</b> in certain cases, <b>and it has the status of a partition</b> in other cases. <b>It has the status of a partition</b> in the case that <b>we mentioned,</b> where there is a ladder at the end of a public domain. In this case, the ladder is not considered an entrance and therefore the public domain is considered closed at that end. <b>It has the status of an entrance in</b> the case of <b>a ladder between two courtyards.</b> If the residents of the courtyards <b>wish,</b> they may join the two courtyards by means of the ladder and <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>;</b> if <b>they wish,</b> the <b>two</b> courtyards may each <b>establish</b> a separate <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rav Naḥman</b> actually <b>say this? Didn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>residents of</b> the ground floor of <b>a courtyard and residents of a balcony,</b> i.e., the floor above the ground floor, <b>who forgot</b>

Daf 60a

<b>and did not establish</b> a joint <b><i>eiruv</i>, if there is a partition four</b> handbreadths wide <b>in front of</b> the entrance to the balcony, the balcony <b>does not prohibit</b> the residents of the courtyard from carrying, as each area is considered to be independent. <b>And if not,</b> the balcony <b>prohibits</b> the residents of the courtyard from carrying in the courtyard. This indicates that a ladder between two courtyards is always considered an entrance, even when that policy leads to a stringent ruling, unless the two areas are separated by a partition.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here? With</b> a case where <b>the balcony is not ten</b> handbreadths <b>high</b> from the ground. Consequently, it does not constitute a domain in its own right, and it is part of the courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>If the balcony is not ten</b> handbreadths <b>high</b> and is therefore part of the courtyard, <b>when one places a partition, what of it?</b> The balcony should nevertheless be considered part of the courtyard. The Gemara answers: We are dealing here <b>with</b> a balcony that is entirely <b>fenced off</b> except for a section <b>up to ten cubits</b> wide, which serves as an entrance. In that case, <b>since</b> the residents of the balcony <b>place a partition</b> at this entrance, <b>they</b> thereby <b>remove themselves</b> entirely <b>from</b> the courtyard.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>a wall that one lined with ladders, even</b> along a length of <b>more than ten</b> cubits, <b>it</b> still retains <b>the status of a partition.</b> The ladders do not constitute an opening that is more than ten cubits wide, which would cause the wall to be regarded as breached and would invalidate the wall as a partition.
<b>Rav Beruna raised a contradiction to Rav Yehuda in the winepress at Rav Ḥanina’s house: Did Shmuel</b> actually <b>say</b> that such a wall <b>has the status of a partition? Didn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>the residents of a balcony and the residents of a courtyard who forgot and did not establish</b> a joint <b><i>eiruv</i>, if there is a partition</b> four handbreadths wide <b>in front</b> of the entrance to the balcony, the balcony <b>does not prohibit</b> the residents of the courtyard to carry; <b>and if not, it prohibits</b> the residents of the courtyard from carrying? This indicates that a ladder is considered an entrance, as the courtyard and the balcony are considered connected.
Rav Yehuda replied in the same manner as above: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with</b> a case where <b>the balcony is not ten</b> handbreadths <b>high,</b> and that is why it is regarded as connected to the courtyard. The Gemara asks: <b>If the balcony is not ten</b> handbreadths <b>high, when he places a partition, what of it?</b> The balcony should nevertheless be considered part of the courtyard. The Gemara answers: We are dealing here <b>with</b> a balcony that is entirely <b>fenced off</b> except for a section <b>up to ten cubits</b> wide, which serves as an entrance. In that case, <b>since</b> the residents of the balcony <b>place a partition</b> at this entrance, <b>they</b> thereby <b>remove themselves</b> entirely <b>from</b> the courtyard.
The Gemara relates that <b>certain residents of</b> the city of <b>Kakunya came before Rav Yosef</b> and <b>said to him: Provide us with someone who will establish an <i>eiruv</i> for our city.</b> The city had originally been a public city and had turned into a private one, requiring that part of the city be excluded from the <i>eiruv</i>. Rav Yosef <b>said to Abaye: Go, establish an <i>eiruv</i> for them, and see</b> to it <b>that there is no outcry against it in the study hall,</b> i.e., make sure the <i>eiruv</i> is valid beyond any doubt. <b>He went</b> and <b>saw</b> that <b>certain houses opened to the river</b> and not to the city. <b>He said: Let these</b> houses serve as <b>the section excluded</b> from the <i>eiruv</i> <b>for the city.</b>
Abaye subsequently <b>retracted</b> and <b>said:</b> This cannot be done, as <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for all of it; by inference, if they wanted to establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for the entire city, <b>they would have been able to establish</b> such <b>an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> if not for the requirement to exclude a section of the city from the <i>eiruv</i>. However, these houses, which do not open to the city, could not have joined in an <i>eiruv</i> with the rest of the city in any case, and therefore they cannot serve as the excluded section. <b>Rather, I will create windows for them</b> between the courtyards of their houses and the rest of the city, <b>so that if they want to establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the rest of the city <b>by way of the windows, they can establish</b> such <b>an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> and then these houses will be fit to serve as the excluded section.
<b>He</b> subsequently <b>retracted</b> again and <b>said:</b> This <b>is not necessary, as Rabba bar Avuh established an <i>eiruv</i> for the entire</b> city of <b>Meḥoza,</b> which was a public city that had become a private one, <b>neighborhood by neighborhood, due to the</b> fact that the neighborhoods were separated by <b>ditches</b> from which <b>the cattle</b> would feed. In other words, Rabba bar Avuh established a separate <i>eiruv</i> for each neighborhood without excluding any of them, <b>as</b> he maintained that <b>each one was an excluded section for the other. And although</b> the neighborhoods <b>would not have been able to establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> together even <b>if they wanted</b> to, due to the ditches separating them, the neighborhoods were still able to serve as excluded areas for each other.
<b>He</b> subsequently <b>retracted</b> once again and <b>said:</b> The two cases <b>are not</b> really <b>comparable. There,</b> in Meḥoza, <b>if they wanted,</b> they could have <b>established</b> a single <b><i>eiruv</i> by way of the roofs;</b> but <b>these</b> houses <b>cannot establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the other houses of the city, and <b>therefore we must create windows</b> for them.
<b>He</b> subsequently <b>retracted</b> yet again and <b>said: Windows are also not necessary. As, that storehouse of straw which belonged to Mar bar Pofidata from Pumbedita was designated as the section excluded from</b> the <i>eiruv</i> arranged for the city of <b>Pumbedita,</b> which proves that it is not necessary for the excluded section to be one that could have been included in an <i>eiruv</i> with the rest of the city.
Abaye <b>said</b> to himself: <b>This is what the Master</b> meant when he <b>said to me: See</b> to it <b>that there is no outcry against it in the study hall.</b> Abaye now understood the many factors that had to be considered and how wary one must be of reaching a hasty conclusion.
The mishna stated that if a public city becomes a private city, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> for all of it <b>unless he maintains</b> an area <b>outside</b> the <i>eiruv</i> which is <b>like</b> the size of <b>the city of Ḥadasha</b> in Judea. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: There was a certain city in Judea and its name was Ḥadasha, and it had fifty residents</b> including <b>men, women, and children. And the Sages would use it to measure</b> the size of the section that must be excluded from an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>and it</b> itself was <b>the excluded section</b> of the <i>eiruv</i> of a larger city that was adjacent to it.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: As for <b>Ḥadasha, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it permissible to establish an <i>eiruv</i> for Ḥadasha itself without excluding a section of the city from the <i>eiruv</i>? The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>Ḥadasha, just as it was the excluded section of the larger</b> city, <b>the larger</b> city <b>was also the excluded section of the smaller</b> city.
<b>Rather,</b> the question pertains to a small city <b>like Ḥadasha</b> that stands by itself, not in proximity to a larger city: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does a small city require an excluded section or not? <b>Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda</b> disagreed about this issue. <b>One said: It requires an excluded section; and one said: It does not require an excluded section.</b>
It is stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The excluded area must be large enough to include at least <b>three courtyards</b> with two houses each. <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Even one house and one courtyard</b> suffice. The Gemara expresses surprise at the wording of this statement: <b>Can it enter your mind</b> that <b>one courtyard</b> even without a house is sufficient? <b>Rather,</b> correct it and <b>say</b> as follows: <b>One house in one courtyard.</b>
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Is that</b> ruling <b>of Rabbi Yitzḥak</b> based on oral <b>tradition or</b> his own <b>logic?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him: What</b> practical <b>difference</b> does Rabbi Yitzḥak’s source make <b>to us?</b> Abaye <b>said to him,</b> quoting a well-known adage: When you <b>study Talmud is it</b> merely <b>a song?;</b> Is the material you study like the lyrics of a song that you do not understand? It is proper to investigate all aspects of the statements of the Sages, regardless of the practical ramifications.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who was to the east</b> of his home when Shabbat began, <b>and he had said to his son</b> before Shabbat: <b>Establish an <i>eiruv</i> for me to the west;</b> or, if he was <b>to the west</b> of his home <b>and he had said to his son: Establish an <i>eiruv</i> for me to the east,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: <b>If there is</b> a distance of <b>two thousand cubits from his</b> current location <b>to his house, and</b> the distance <b>to his <i>eiruv</i> is greater than this, he is permitted</b> to walk <b>to his house,</b> and from there he may walk two thousand cubits in every direction, <b>but it is prohibited</b> for him <b>to</b> walk to the spot where his son had deposited <b>his <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
If the distance from one’s current location <b>to his <i>eiruv</i> is two thousand cubits,</b> and the distance <b>to his house is greater than this, he is prohibited</b> from walking to his house, <b>and he is permitted to</b> walk to the spot of <b>his <i>eiruv</i>,</b> and from there he may walk two thousand cubits in every direction. In other words, with regard to the Shabbat limit, one’s place of residence for Shabbat cannot be more than two thousand cubits from his physical location when Shabbat begins.
<b>One who places his <i>eiruv</i> in the outskirts of the city,</b> i.e., within an area of slightly more than seventy cubits surrounding the city, it is as though <b>he has not done anything.</b> The two thousand cubits of one’s Shabbat limit are measured from the edge of the outskirts of the city even if there is no <i>eiruv</i>, and one therefore gains nothing from placing an <i>eiruv</i> within this area.
If, however, <b>he placed</b> his <i>eiruv</i> <b>outside the</b> city’s <b>boundary, even</b> if he placed it only <b>one cubit</b> beyond the city,

Daf 60b

<b>what he gains</b> in distance through his <i>eiruv</i> on one side of the city <b>he loses</b> on the other side.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It</b> might <b>enter your mind</b> to say that when the mishna states that one was standing <b>to the east,</b> it means that he was standing <b>to the east of his house</b> and that he had instructed his son to establish an <i>eiruv</i> to the west of his house. Similarly, when it states that he was standing <b>to the west,</b> it means that he was positioned <b>to the west of his house</b> and that he had instructed his son to establish an <i>eiruv</i> to the east of his house. In such a case, the person’s house is located between him and his <i>eiruv</i>.
If so, the question arises: <b>Granted,</b> the mishna’s case where there is a distance of <b>two thousand cubits from his</b> current location <b>to his house, and</b> the distance <b>to his <i>eiruv</i> is greater than this, you can find, as</b> it is possible <b>that he can reach his house</b> without traveling two thousand cubits <b>and he cannot reach his <i>eiruv</i>. But where do you find</b> a case where there is a distance of <b>two thousand cubits between him and his <i>eiruv</i>, and</b> the distance <b>to his house is greater than this?</b> The person’s house is located between him and his <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Do you think</b> that <b>to the east</b> means that he was standing <b>to the east of his house, and to the west</b> means that he was standing <b>to the west of his house? No, to the east</b> means <b>to the east of his son,</b> who is depositing his <i>eiruv</i> for him, and <b>to the west means to the west of his son.</b>
<b>Rava bar Rav Sheila said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that <b>to the east</b> means <b>to the east of his house and to the west</b> means <b>to the west of his house,</b> the mishna can be understood as referring to <b>a case where his house stood</b> along <b>a diagonal</b> line in relation to the person and his <i>eiruv</i>. In that case, although he is to the west of his house and the <i>eiruv</i> is located to its east, he can still be closer to his <i>eiruv</i> than he is to his house.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One who places his <i>eiruv</i> within the outskirts</b> of the city has not accomplished anything. However, if he places it outside the city limits, it is effective. The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>Can it enter your mind</b> that the mishna is dealing with a case where one placed his <i>eiruv</i> <b>outside the</b> Shabbat <b>limit?</b> If the <i>eiruv</i> is outside the Shabbat limit as measured from his physical location at the onset of Shabbat, he cannot access it on Shabbat; it is therefore ineffective in establishing his Shabbat residence. <b>Rather,</b> correct it and <b>say</b> as follows: If one placed his <i>eiruv</i> <b>outside</b> the city’s <b>outskirts,</b> i.e., beyond the area of slightly more than seventy cubits surrounding the city, the <i>eiruv</i> is effective in establishing his Shabbat residence at that location.
We learned in the next clause of the mishna concerning one who places his <i>eiruv</i> even one cubit beyond the city’s boundary: <b>That which he gains</b> on one side of the city <b>he loses</b> on the other. The Gemara expresses surprise: Does that mean that only <b>that which he gains</b> on one side he loses on the other, <b>and no more?
