<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> Rav Huna was not attempting to offer a broad definition of an apostate, but was rather referring to the specific issue of <b>giving</b> away <b>rights or renouncing rights</b> in a domain with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>eiruvin</i>. <b>And as it was taught</b> in the following <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>An apostate Jew,</b> if he <b>observes his Shabbat in the marketplace,</b> i.e., in public, <b>he may renounce</b> his <b>rights</b> in a domain like a regular Jew, but if he <b>does not observe his Shabbat in the marketplace, he may not renounce</b> his <b>rights</b> in a domain, as he is no longer considered a Jew in this regard.
This distinction is significant <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the Sages <b>said: A Jew may receive rights and give</b> away <b>rights</b> in a domain through a mere statement of renunciation, <b>but with regard to a gentile</b> it is not so, as he may not transfer his rights to others or renounce them in a domain <b>unless he</b> actually <b>rents</b> it <b>out. How so?</b> A Jew <b>may say to</b> his fellow: <b>May my rights</b> in this domain <b>be acquired by you,</b> or <b>May my rights</b> in this domain <b>be renounced to you,</b> and his fellow thereby <b>acquires</b> those rights, <b>and it is not necessary that he take possession of it</b> through a formal mode of acquisition.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> Rav Huna’s statement that a Jew who desecrates Shabbat in public is an apostate is indeed a general statement, as he is no longer considered a Jew in any sense. In accordance with the opinion of which <i>tanna</i> did he make that statement? <b>It</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, for whom Shabbat is as severe as idolatry,</b> and therefore one who desecrates Shabbat is treated like an idol worshipper.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “Speak to the children of Israel and say to them: When any man of you brings an offering to the Lord, you shall bring your offering of the cattle, of the herd, or of the flock” (Leviticus 1:2). The <i>baraita</i> expounds: <b>“Of you,”</b> i.e., some of you, but <b>not all of you</b> may bring an offering – <b>to the exclusion of an apostate. “Of you”</b> additionally serves to emphasize that <b>among you,</b> the children of Israel, <b>I distinguish</b> between those who observe the Torah and are fit to bring an offering, and those who are not fit, <b>but not among the nations,</b> i.e., in regard to the other nations, even those who do not fulfill the precepts binding upon them may offer their sacrifices.
<b>“Of the cattle”</b> is expounded as follows: <b>To include people who are similar to animals</b> in their disdain for the proper behavior of man, i.e., that the wicked too may offer sacrifices. <b>From here</b> the Sages <b>stated: We accept</b> voluntary <b>sacrifices from Jewish transgressors, in order</b> to enable them <b>to repent, apart from the apostate, one who pours wine libations</b> as part of idol worship, <b>and one who desecrates Shabbat in public,</b> from whom we do not accept sacrifices without their complete repentance.
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself is difficult,</b> i.e., it contains an internal contradiction: <b>You</b> first <b>said: “Of you,” but not all of you, to the exclusion of an apostate; and then you taught: We accept sacrifices from Jewish transgressors.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This is not difficult,</b> as it can be explained as follows: <b>The first clause</b> refers <b>to an apostate with regard to the entire Torah,</b> whose sacrifices are not accepted, whereas <b>the middle clause</b> speaks <b>of an apostate with regard to one matter</b> alone, whose sacrifices are indeed accepted.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, <b>say</b> an explanation of <b>the last clause</b> of the mishna: <b>Apart from the apostate and one who pours wine libations</b> to idolatry, and one who desecrates Shabbat in public. <b>This apostate, what are the circumstances</b> indicating his status? <b>If</b> it refers to <b>an apostate with regard to the entire Torah, this is</b> the same as <b>the first clause.</b> And <b>if</b> it refers to <b>an apostate with regard to</b> only <b>one thing, the middle clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult,</b> for it states that we accept sacrifices from such an apostate.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> true <b>that this is</b> what <b>it is saying: Apart from the apostate with regard to pouring wine libations</b> to idolatry <b>and desecrating Shabbat in public?</b> Although they transgress only one matter, this transgression is so serious that they are considered apostates with regard to the entire Torah. <b>It is apparent</b> from here that <b>idolatry and Shabbat are equivalent,</b> which indicates that there is a <i>tanna</i> who considers public Shabbat desecration as severe a transgression as idolatry. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that it is so.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>If one of the residents of a courtyard forgot and did not participate in an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the other residents before Shabbat, and on Shabbat he renounced his rights in the courtyard to the other residents, <b>his house is prohibited</b> both <b>to him,</b> who forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>and to them,</b> the other residents, <b>to bring in</b> objects from the courtyard to his house <b>or to take</b> them <b>out</b> from his house into the courtyard. <b>But their</b> houses <b>are permitted</b> both <b>to him and to them,</b> for taking objects out into the courtyard and for bringing them in. <b>If they gave</b> away <b>their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>to him,</b> i.e., if they renounced their rights in his favor, <b>he is permitted</b> to carry from his house into the courtyard, <b>but they are prohibited</b> from doing so.
<b>If two</b> residents of the courtyard forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, and the others renounced their rights in the courtyard in their favor, <b>they prohibit one another.</b> In this scenario, the courtyard would belong to both of them, but each individual house remains the domain of its owner. It would therefore be prohibited for each of these residents to carry into the courtyard. <b>For one</b> resident <b>may give away and receive rights</b> in a domain, whereas <b>two</b> residents <b>may</b> only <b>give away rights</b> in a domain, <b>but they may not receive rights</b> in a domain. Since they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, it is unreasonable for the other residents of the courtyard to give away their rights in the domain, as the two who are prohibited because they did not participate in the <i>eiruv</i> render it prohibited for each other to carry.
The mishna poses a general question: <b>When may one give</b> away <b>rights</b> in a domain? <b>Beit Shammai say: While it is still day,</b> i.e., before the onset of Shabbat; <b>and Beit Hillel say: Even after nightfall,</b> when it is already Shabbat. The mishna cites another dispute: If <b>one gave away his rights</b> in his courtyard to the other residents of the courtyard, renouncing them after having forgotten to establish an <i>eiruv</i> with them the previous day, <b>and</b> then <b>he carried</b> something <b>out</b> from his house into the courtyard – <b>whether unwittingly,</b> forgetting that he had renounced his rights, <b>or intentionally, he</b> renders carrying <b>prohibited</b> for all the residents of the courtyard, for his action cancels his renunciation; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If he acted <b>intentionally, he</b> renders carrying <b>prohibited;</b> but if he acted <b>unwittingly, he does not</b> render carrying <b>prohibited.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara first analyzes the language of the mishna. It states: It is prohibited to bring in objects from the courtyard to his house and to take them out from his house into the courtyard. It can be inferred from this that <b>it is carrying</b> to and from <b>his house</b> that <b>is prohibited, but carrying</b> to and from <b>his</b> share of the <b>courtyard is permitted</b> to the other residents of the courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> where this ruling applies? <b>If</b> the resident who forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i> <b>renounced</b> his rights, <b>why is his house</b> rendered <b>prohibited?</b> And <b>if he did not renounce</b> his rights, <b>why is his courtyard permitted?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with</b> a special case, <b>where he renounced his rights in his courtyard</b> to the others <b>but did not renounce his rights in his house</b> to them. <b>And the Rabbis hold that one who renounces his rights in his courtyard has not renounced his rights in his house,</b> as it is common <b>for people to reside in a house without a courtyard.</b>
The Gemara proceeds in its analysis of the mishna: It states that carrying in and out of <b>their</b> houses <b>is permitted for him and for them.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>What is the reason</b> that their houses are permitted to him? The Gemara answers: <b>For he is</b> regarded <b>like a guest of theirs,</b> i.e., he is subordinate to them and may carry wherever they may do so.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If</b> the other residents <b>gave</b> away <b>their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>to him, he is permitted</b> to carry from his house into the courtyard, <b>but they are prohibited</b> from doing so. The Gemara asks: <b>But let them,</b> the ones who renounced their rights in the courtyard, <b>be</b> regarded as <b>guests of his,</b> which would enable them to carry as well. The Gemara answers: <b>One vis-à-vis five is</b> considered <b>a guest,</b> whereas <b>five</b> or more <b>vis-à-vis one are not</b> ordinarily viewed as <b>guests.</b>
The Gemara attempts to draw another inference from the wording of the mishna: Shall we not <b>learn from this,</b> from the order of events in the mishna, that <b>one may renounce</b> his rights in favor of another when he needs it, <b>and then</b> the latter <b>may renounce</b> his rights in favor of the former when he needs it? For the mishna first describes a case in which the one who forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i> renounces his rights in favor of the others, at which stage they may use the courtyard, and then afterward recounts that the other residents renounce their rights in favor of the one who forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, leaving it permitted for him and prohibited for them.
The Gemara answers: No proof can be brought from here, for <b>this is</b> what the mishna <b>is saying: If they gave away their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>to him at the outset,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for <b>him and</b> it is <b>prohibited for them.</b> In other words, this is not a continuation of the previous clause, but a separate case.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If two</b> residents of a courtyard forgot to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, and the others renounced their rights in the courtyard in their favor, <b>they</b> render <b>one another prohibited</b> from carrying. The Gemara raises a difficulty: Isn’t this <b>obvious?</b> What novel teaching is stated here? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this ruling <b>is necessary</b> in a case where the others renounced their rights in the courtyard in favor of the pair, and <b>one of them then renounced</b> his rights <b>in favor of the other. Lest you say let it</b> now <b>be permitted</b> for him to carry, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that <b>since at the time of his renunciation</b> it was <b>not permitted</b> for him to carry <b>in that courtyard,</b> he may not renounce his rights either. Therefore, his renunciation is ineffective, and they are both prohibited from carrying.
The mishna explains: <b>For one</b> resident <b>may give away</b> and receive <b>rights</b> in a domain. The Gemara poses a question: <b>Why</b> do <b>I</b> need <b>this further</b> explanation? This ruling can be deduced from the previous cases: <b>If</b> the mishna wishes to teach the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>giving</b> away rights, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> that one person may give away his rights in a domain, and <b>if</b> it wishes to teach the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>receiving</b> rights, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> it as well, so why the repetition?
The Gemara answers: <b>He needed</b> it due to the ruling in <b>the latter clause,</b> which includes the novel teaching that <b>two</b> residents <b>may give away rights</b> in a domain. The Gemara again wonders: But <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>as well,</b> that even multiple residents may give away their rights in a domain, is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara answers: This was stated <b>lest you say:</b>

Daf 70a

<b>Let us issue a decree</b> that two residents may not give away their rights in a domain, <b>lest</b> people <b>come to renounce</b> their rights <b>in favor</b> of two residents as well. People might assume that just as two may give away their rights to one, so too may one give away his rights to two. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that we do not issue such a decree.
We learned in the mishna: <b>But</b> two <b>may not receive rights</b> in a domain. The Gemara poses a question: <b>Why do I</b> need to say this? Isn’t it superfluous? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach that rights may not be acquired <b>even if</b> the other residents of the courtyard <b>say to</b> one of the two who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>: <b>Acquire</b> our rights in the courtyard <b>on condition that you transfer</b> them in turn to your friend, the other one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. The mishna teaches that he does not become their agent and cannot transfer the rights to the other person, as he himself cannot receive such rights under these circumstances.
<b>Abaye raised a dilemma before Rabba:</b> If <b>five</b> people <b>live in the same courtyard, and one of them forgot to join in an <i>eiruv</i>, when he renounces his rights</b> in the courtyard, <b>must he renounce</b> them <b>in favor of each and every one</b> of the others <b>or not?</b> Rabba <b>said to him: He must renounce</b> his rights <b>in favor of each and every one.</b>
Abaye <b>raised an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> resident of a courtyard <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce his rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of one who did establish an <i>eiruv</i>. Two</b> courtyard residents <b>who established an <i>eiruv</i> may</b> also <b>renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. And</b> similarly, <b>two</b> courtyard residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of two</b> residents <b>who did establish an <i>eiruv</i> or in favor of one</b> resident <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<b>But one</b> courtyard resident <b>who did establish an <i>eiruv</i> may not renounce his rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of one</b> resident <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, nor may two</b> residents <b>who established an <i>eiruv</i> renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of two</b> other residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, nor may two</b> residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of two</b> residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<b>In any event the first clause is teaching: One</b> resident of a courtyard <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce his rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of one who did establish an <i>eiruv</i>. What are the circumstances</b> surrounding this case? <b>If there is no other</b> resident <b>with him,</b> i.e., if there were only two people living in the courtyard, <b>with whom did he,</b> the other resident, <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i>?</b> He could not have established an <i>eiruv</i> on his own.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that there is another</b> resident <b>with him,</b> apart from the one who failed to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>and</b> yet <b>it states:</b> He may renounce his rights in the courtyard <b>in favor of one who did establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> which implies that it is enough for him to renounce his rights in favor of one of the residents. He does not have to renounce his rights in favor of all of them.
The Gemara now asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabba</b> understand this teaching? The Gemara answers: Rabba can say as follows: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> This is a special case, <b>where there was</b> another person in the courtyard with whom he established the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>but</b> that person <b>died</b> in the meantime, leaving only one who established an <i>eiruv</i>, to whom the one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce his rights.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If</b> it indeed refers to a case <b>where there was</b> another person, <b>but he died, say</b> an explanation for <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But one</b> courtyard resident <b>who did establish an <i>eiruv</i> may not renounce his rights in favor of one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. Now if</b> it refers to a case <b>where there was</b> at first another person <b>but he died, why</b> may the one courtyard resident <b>not</b> renounce his rights in the courtyard? Now there is only one other person present in the courtyard.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that there is</b> another person present, with whom the <i>eiruv</i> was established. <b>And since the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> deals with a case <b>where there is</b> another person present, <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> must also be dealing with a case <b>where there is</b> another person present.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Is this</b> necessarily <b>the designation in both</b> cases? Must the two clauses necessarily be dealing with the same case? <b>This</b> case <b>as it is, and this</b> case <b>as it is,</b> i.e., each clause deals with a unique set of circumstances, which need not accord with each other.
The Gemara adds: <b>Know</b> that this <i>baraita</i> does not only deal with one state of affairs, <b>for the last</b> part <b>of the first clause teaches: And two</b> courtyard residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of two</b> residents <b>who did establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> It can be inferred from this that <b>in favor of two</b> residents, <b>yes,</b> they may renounce their rights, but <b>in favor of one, no,</b> they may not. This clearly indicates that they must renounce their rights in the courtyard in favor of both of them.
<b>And Abaye</b> can <b>say: What</b> is the meaning of <b>in favor of two? In favor of one of the two,</b> for this is as effective as renouncing their rights in favor of both of them. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, let it teach</b> that the two courtyard residents who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce their rights in the courtyard <b>in favor of one</b> resident <b>who established an <i>eiruv</i> or in favor of one</b> resident <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> from which one would understand that there are two present, for otherwise there could be no <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara concludes: This is indeed <b>difficult</b> according to Abaye’s opinion, although it does not completely refute his opinion.
The Gemara now explains the need for each clause of the <i>baraita</i>. The <i>baraita</i> opens: <b>One</b> resident of a courtyard <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce his rights in favor of one who did establish an <i>eiruv</i>. According to Abaye,</b> this refers <b>to</b> a case <b>where there is</b> another person present, <b>and it teaches us</b> that <b>he need not renounce his rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of each and every one</b> of the others. <b>According to Rabba,</b> this refers to a case <b>where there was</b> another person in the courtyard, with whom he established the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>but</b> that person <b>died</b> in the meantime, <b>and</b> the novel teaching is that the Sages <b>did not issue a decree</b> due to the concern that <b>sometimes</b> that other person <b>is</b> still <b>present.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Two</b> courtyard residents <b>who established an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara poses a question: Isn’t this <b>obvious?</b> What new <i>halakha</i> is being taught here? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>since he did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, we should penalize him</b> by insisting that he renounce his rights in their favor and not the reverse, therefore the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that it is permitted even for the ones who established an <i>eiruv</i> to renounce their rights in his favor.
It was further taught in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> similarly, <b>two</b> courtyard residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of two</b> residents <b>who established an <i>eiruv</i>. According to Rabba,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause.</b> As the latter clause teaches that one must renounce rights to every resident in the courtyard, the first clause must refer to the case where the additional resident passed away, for otherwise, he would not be able to renounce his rights to only one of the residents of the courtyard. <b>According to Abaye,</b> it was <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>two who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> For <b>it could enter your mind to say</b> that <b>we should issue a decree</b> determining that the two residents who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> may not renounce their rights in favor of the two residents who established an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>lest</b> the two who established an <i>eiruv</i> <b>come to renounce</b> their rights <b>in favor of</b> the two who did not. The <i>baraita</i>, therefore, <b>teaches us</b> that we do not issue such a decree.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Or</b> they may renounce their rights <b>in favor of one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>Why do I</b> need this addition? The Gemara explains: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>these</b> permissive <b>rulings</b> with regard to renunciation <b>apply only</b> in a case <b>where some of</b> the residents <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> and some of them did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. But</b> in a case <b>where none of</b> the residents <b>established an <i>eiruv</i>, we should penalize them</b> by not allowing renunciation, <b>so that the</b> halakhic <b>category of <i>eiruv</i> should not be forgotten</b> by those who come after them. The <i>baraita</i>, therefore, <b>teaches us</b> that we are not concerned about this.
We further learned in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But one</b> courtyard resident <b>who did establish an <i>eiruv</i> may not renounce his rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. According to Abaye,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause,</b> for Abaye proves from here that a person may renounce his rights to one of the two courtyard residents, and need not renounce his rights to both of them. <b>According to Rabba, since</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught the first clause</b> in a certain style, <b>it also taught the latter clause</b> in that same style, but no halakhic conclusion can be garnered from here.
The <i>baraita</i> further states: <b>Nor may two</b> residents <b>who established an <i>eiruv</i> renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of two</b> other residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>this further</b> matter? Isn’t this statement superfluous? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the case <b>where one of</b> the two who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> subsequently <b>renounced</b> his rights <b>in favor of his fellow</b> resident. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>it should</b> now <b>be permitted</b> to carry, as there is only one person left who has any rights in the courtyard and failed to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, therefore it <b>teaches us</b> that <b>since at the time of his renunciation he was not permitted in that courtyard,</b> he may <b>not</b> renounce his rights in it, and therefore carrying is prohibited for both.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>Nor may two</b> residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> renounce their rights</b> in the courtyard <b>in favor of two</b> residents <b>who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara poses the question: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>this additional</b> matter? Isn’t it superfluous? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the case <b>where</b> the other courtyard residents <b>said</b> to one of the first two who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>: <b>Acquire</b> our rights in the courtyard <b>on condition that you transfer</b> them in turn to your friend, the other one who did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. They attempted to appoint one of them as an agent to transfer the collective rights to the other. The <i>baraita</i> teaches us that this method is ineffective.
<b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> With regard to <b>an heir, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> regarding whether <b>he</b> may <b>renounce rights</b> in a courtyard? If a person who had forgotten to establish an <i>eiruv</i> died on Shabbat, may his heir renounce his rights in his stead?

Daf 70b

The Gemara explains the two sides of the question: On the one hand, perhaps only in a case <b>where, if</b> the person <b>wanted to establish an <i>eiruv</i> on the previous day he could have established an <i>eiruv</i>, he can also</b> renounce his rights on Shabbat. <b>But this</b> heir, <b>since, if he wanted to establish an <i>eiruv</i> the previous day he could not have established an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> as he was not then a resident of the courtyard, therefore, today <b>he cannot renounce</b> his rights either.
<b>Or perhaps an heir is</b> like <b>his father’s foot,</b> i.e., he is considered an extension of his father and substitutes for him in all regards, which means that just as his father could have renounced his rights, so can he.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: I</b> myself <b>say</b> that an heir <b>can</b> indeed <b>renounce</b> rights in a courtyard, <b>while those</b> scholars of <b>the school of Shmuel taught: He cannot renounce</b> rights in a courtyard. Rava <b>raised an objection to</b> Rav Naḥman from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>This is the principle: Anything that is permitted for part of Shabbat is permitted for all of Shabbat, and anything that is prohibited for part of Shabbat is prohibited for all of Shabbat, apart from one who renounces his rights</b> in a courtyard, for renunciation can provide an allowance halfway through Shabbat.
The Gemara now explains each element of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Anything that is permitted for part of Shabbat is permitted for all of Shabbat. For example,</b> if <b>an <i>eiruv</i> was established</b> between two adjacent courtyards that are connected <b>via an opening</b> between them, <b>and</b> that <b>opening was closed up</b> on Shabbat, the <i>eiruv</i> is valid. Alternately, if <b>an <i>eiruv</i> was established</b> between the two courtyards that are connected <b>via a window</b> opening from one to the other, <b>and</b> that <b>window was closed up</b> on Shabbat, the <i>eiruv</i> is valid. As carrying from one courtyard to another was permitted at the beginning of Shabbat, it is permitted throughout Shabbat.
The Gemara comments: The words <b>this is the principle</b> come <b>to include</b> the case of <b>an alleyway whose</b> cross <b>beams or side posts were removed</b> on Shabbat, teaching that one may nonetheless use the alleyway, as it had been permitted at the outset of Shabbat.
The Gemara continues its explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Anything that is prohibited for part of Shabbat is prohibited for all of Shabbat. For example,</b> if there were <b>two houses on two sides of a public domain, which gentiles enclosed with a wall on Shabbat,</b> the enclosed area remains prohibited. Even though a partition of this kind is considered a proper one with regard to Shabbat domains, it is prohibited to carry objects from either house into the enclosed area, even if the owner of the first house renounces his rights in the area in favor of the owner of the second house, as they could not have established an <i>eiruv</i> between them before Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> do the words <b>this is the principle</b> come <b>to include</b> in this part of the <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include</b> the case of <b>a gentile</b> resident of the courtyard who <b>died on Shabbat</b> without having rented out his domain to a Jew for the purpose of an <i>eiruv</i>. In this case, the Jewish neighbors are prohibited from carrying in the courtyard. Because it was prohibited to establish an <i>eiruv</i> the previous day, carrying in the courtyard continues to be prohibited on Shabbat, even though the gentile is now deceased.
<b>And</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Apart from one who renounces his rights</b> in a courtyard, which teaches that a person may renounce his rights in a courtyard even on Shabbat, despite the fact that the courtyard was prohibited prior to his renunciation. The Gemara infers: <b>He</b> himself, i.e., the original owner, <b>yes,</b> he may renounce his rights even on Shabbat, but with regard to his <b>heir, no,</b> he may not renounce his rights on Shabbat, which contradicts Rav Naḥman’s opinion.
Rav Naḥman replied: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> must be understood as follows: <b>Apart from</b> anyone who falls <b>into the</b> halakhic <b>category of one who renounces his rights</b> in a domain. In other words, the <i>baraita</i> is not referring to a particular person who renounces his rights, but rather to the category of renunciation in general, which includes an heir.
Rava <b>raised a</b> further <b>objection to</b> the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a different <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a resident of a courtyard died and left his domain,</b> the use of his house, <b>to one from the marketplace,</b> i.e., a non-resident of the courtyard, the following distinction applies: If he died <b>while it was still day,</b> i.e., before Shabbat, the one from the marketplace renders carrying <b>prohibited,</b> for it is assumed that he received his portion before the onset of Shabbat and should have joined in an <i>eiruv</i> with the others. Since he failed to establish an <i>eiruv</i> with the other residents of the courtyard, he renders carrying prohibited in the entire courtyard. If, however, he died <b>after nightfall, he does not</b> render carrying <b>prohibited,</b> for so long as it was permitted to carry for part of Shabbat it remains permitted for the entirety of Shabbat.
<b>And</b> alternatively, if <b>one from the marketplace</b> who owned a residence in the courtyard but did not dwell there <b>died and left his domain to a resident of the courtyard</b> who does live there and usually joins in an <i>eiruv</i> with his neighbors, the following distinction applies: If the person from the marketplace died <b>while it was still day,</b> i.e., before Shabbat, the courtyard resident <b>does not</b> render carrying <b>prohibited,</b> as when he establishes his <i>eiruv</i> it includes his new residence as well. If, however, the person from the marketplace died <b>after nightfall</b> without having established an <i>eiruv</i>, the deceased renders carrying <b>prohibited.</b> As this residence was prohibited at the beginning of Shabbat, it can no longer be permitted on that Shabbat.
Rava’s question is based on the first case discussed in the <i>baraita</i>: According to Rav Naḥman, <b>why does</b> the heir render carrying <b>prohibited</b> in this case? <b>Let him renounce</b> his rights in the courtyard to the other residents, as Rav Naḥman maintains that an heir may renounce rights. Rav Naḥman replied: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the word <b>prohibits that</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> here? It means he renders carrying prohibited <b>until he renounces</b> his rights, i.e., although there is no way of rectifying the situation by means of an <i>eiruv</i>, it can be corrected by way of renunciation.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof challenging Rav Naḥman’s opinion, from the following <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a Jew and a convert were living in a single residency</b> comprised of several rooms, <b>and the convert died</b> childless <b>while it was still day,</b> such a convert has no heirs, and therefore the first to take possession of his property acquires it.

Daf 71a

In such a case, <b>even though a different Jew took possession of</b> the convert’s <b>property,</b> the one who acquires it renders carrying <b>prohibited.</b> If, however, he died <b>after nightfall, even though a different Jew did not take possession of</b> his property, <b>it,</b> i.e., carrying, <b>is not prohibited,</b> for carrying had already been permitted on that Shabbat.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: The <i>baraita</i> <b>itself is difficult. You</b> first <b>said:</b> If the convert died <b>while it was still day, even though a different Jew took possession of</b> his property, the latter renders carrying prohibited, which implies that <b>it is not necessary</b> to say so <b>where</b> another Jew <b>did not take possession of</b> the property, for in such a case it is certainly prohibited. But this is incorrect. <b>On the contrary,</b> in a case <b>where</b> a different person <b>did not take possession of</b> the property, <b>it is</b> certainly <b>not prohibited,</b> for in such a case the convert’s property is ownerless and there is nobody to render carrying in the courtyard prohibited.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should read as follows: <b>Even though</b> a different Jew <b>did not take possession of</b> it. The Gemara raises a difficulty: How can it be corrected in this manner? <b>But doesn’t it teach: Even though he took possession of</b> it?
The Gemara answers: <b>This is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the convert died while it was still day, then <b>even though</b> a different Jew <b>did not take possession of</b> the property <b>while it was still day but</b> only <b>after nightfall, since he had</b> the possibility <b>of taking possession</b> of it <b>while it was still day,</b> the person who acquires it renders carrying <b>prohibited.</b> If, however, the convert died <b>after nightfall, even though a different Jew did not take possession of</b> his property, <b>it does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry.
The Gemara now considers the next clause of the <i>baraita</i>, which states: If the convert died after nightfall, <b>even though a different Jew did not take possession of</b> his property, carrying is not prohibited. This implies that <b>it is not necessary</b> to say so <b>where</b> another Jew <b>did take possession of</b> the property, for in such a case it is certainly not prohibited. But, <b>on the contrary, where</b> a different person <b>takes possession of</b> the property, <b>he</b> renders carrying <b>prohibited.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said: Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should read as follows: <b>Even though</b> a different Jew <b>took possession of</b> it. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach: Even though he did not take possession of</b> it? The Gemara explains: <b>This is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the convert died after nightfall, <b>even though</b> a different Jew <b>took possession of</b> his property <b>after nightfall, since he did not have</b> the possibility <b>of taking possession</b> of it <b>while it was still day, he does not</b> render carrying <b>prohibited.</b>
After explaining the <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara proceeds to clarify the issue at hand: <b>In any event, the first clause is teaching</b> that the person who acquires the convert’s property <b>renders</b> carrying <b>prohibited;</b> but <b>why does he render</b> carrying <b>prohibited? Let him renounce</b> his rights in the domain like an heir. The implication then is that he does not have the option of renunciation, in contrast to the opinion of Rav Naḥman.
Rav Naḥman replied: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the word <b>prohibits that it teaches</b> here? It means he renders carrying prohibited <b>until he renounces</b> his rights, but renunciation is effective.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who is the <i>tanna</i> of the</b> problematic <b><i>baraitot</i></b> that imply that an heir cannot renounce rights, and from which objections were brought against Rav Naḥman? <b>It is Beit Shammai, who say</b> that <b>there is no renunciation of rights on Shabbat</b> at all, even for the owner of the property. <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>When may one give away rights</b> in a domain? <b>Beit Shammai say: While it is still day. And Beit Hillel say:</b> Even <b>after nightfall.</b>
With regard to this dispute itself, <b>Ulla said: What is the reason of Beit Hillel</b> that one may renounce rights even after nightfall? This should be considered an act of acquisition, which is prohibited on Shabbat. He explains: <b>It is comparable to one who says: Turn toward the high-quality ones.</b> If a person sets aside <i>teruma</i> from another person’s produce without the latter’s knowledge, and when the owner finds out he says: Why did you set aside this produce? Turn toward the high-quality ones, i.e., you should have gone to find better produce to use as <i>teruma</i>, then the <i>teruma</i> that was separated is considered <i>teruma</i>, provided there was indeed quality produce in that place. The reason is that the owner has demonstrated his retroactive acquiescence to the other person’s setting aside of <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, the latter is considered his agent for this purpose. The same applies to our issue. If a person intended to permit both himself and others to carry in a courtyard by means of establishing an <i>eiruv</i> but forgot to do so, by renouncing his rights after nightfall, he retroactively makes plain his desire that his domain should be mingled with that of his neighbors. What he then does on Shabbat is not a complete action, but merely a demonstration of his intentions.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This explanation is unsatisfactory, as when <b>a gentile dies on Shabbat, what</b> connection <b>is there to</b> the concept: <b>Turn toward the high-quality ones?</b> When a gentile dies on Shabbat, his Jewish neighbors may renounce their rights in the courtyard to each other and thus render carrying in the courtyard permitted, even though such renunciation would have been ineffective prior to his passing. Consequently, it cannot be said that it works retroactively.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects Ulla’s explanation and states that <b>here they disagree over the following: Beit Shammai hold</b> that <b>renunciation of a domain is</b> equivalent to <b>acquisition of a domain, and acquisition of a domain is prohibited on Shabbat. And Beit Hillel hold</b> that <b>it is merely withdrawal from a domain, and withdrawal from a domain seems well on Shabbat,</b> i.e., it is permitted. As such, there is no reason to prohibit renunciation as a form of acquisition, which is prohibited as a part of a decree against conducting commerce on Shabbat.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a homeowner was in partnership with his neighbors, with this</b> one <b>in wine and with that</b> one <b>in wine, they need not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> for due to their authentic partnership they are considered to be one household, and no further partnership is required.
If, however, he was in partnership <b>with this</b> one <b>in wine and with that</b> one <b>in oil, they must establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> As they are not partners in the same item, they are not all considered one partnership. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case, i.e., even if he partners with his neighbors in different items, <b>they need not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that one who is in partnership in wine with both his neighbors need not establish an <i>eiruv</i> applies only if their wine is <b>in one vessel. Rava said:</b> The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches:</b> If he was in partnership <b>with this one in wine and with the</b> other <b>one in oil, they must establish an <i>eiruv</i>. Granted, if you say</b> that <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna deals <b>with one vessel, and the latter clause</b> deals <b>with two vessels,</b> one of wine and one of oil, <b>it is well. But, if you say</b> that <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna speaks <b>of two vessels, and the latter clause</b> also speaks <b>of two vessels, what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if it is <b>wine and wine or wine and oil?</b> The <i>halakha</i> should be the same in both cases.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> This is no proof, and the first clause can be referring to a case where the wine was in separate vessels as well. The difference is that <b>wine and wine is suitable for mixing</b> together, and therefore can be considered a single unit even if divided into two containers. <b>Wine and oil,</b> however, <b>are not suitable for mixing.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In <b>both this</b> case, where they are partners in wine alone, <b>and that</b> case, where the partnerships are in wine and oil, <b>they need not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara poses a question: Did he say this <b>even if</b> the partnership is <b>with this one in wine and with the other one in oil?</b> But these are not suitable for mixing. <b>Rabba said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with a courtyard</b> positioned <b>between two alleyways, and Rabbi Shimon</b> follows <b>his</b> usual line of <b>reasoning.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Rabbi Shimon said: To what is this matter comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to</b> the case of <b>three courtyards that open into one another and</b> also <b>open into a public domain. If the two outer</b> courtyards each <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> with the middle one, it is permitted</b> for residents of the middle one to carry <b>with</b> the two outer ones, <b>and it is permitted</b> for residents of the two outer ones to carry <b>with</b> the middle one. <b>However, it is prohibited</b> for the residents of <b>the two outer</b> courtyards to carry <b>with each other,</b> as they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with each other. This teaches that the residents of one courtyard can establish an <i>eiruv</i> with a courtyard on each side, and need not choose between them. Here too, the residents of the courtyard can participate in an <i>eiruv</i> with both alleyways, one by means of wine and the other by means of oil.
<b>Abaye said to him: Are</b> the cases really <b>comparable? There it teaches: It is prohibited</b> for the residents of <b>the two outer</b> courtyards to carry with each other, whereas <b>here it teaches: They need not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> indicating that it is permitted for residents of all three domains to carry with each other.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is</b> the subject of the phrase <b>they need not establish an <i>eiruv</i>?</b> It refers to the <b>neighbors together with the homeowner,</b> i.e., the residents of the courtyards that open into each of the alleyways with the resident of the courtyard in the middle. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>the neighbors with each other,</b> i.e., if the residents of the two alleyways wish to be permitted to carry with each other, <b>they must establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> and place it in the middle courtyard.

Daf 71b

<b>And Rav Yosef said:</b> In fact we are dealing here with a single alleyway, and <b>Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis disagree about the</b> same point of <b>dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri and the Rabbis. As we learned</b> in a mishna: If <i>teruma</i> <b>oil was floating on the surface of wine, and one who immersed during the day, touched the oil, he disqualified only the oil alone.</b> However, he did not disqualify the wine, because it is considered separate from the oil. Only the oil is disqualified, and it does not render other items ritually impure. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says: They are both connected to each other</b> and are considered as one, so the wine is also ritually impure.
The Gemara explains: <b>The</b> opinion of the <b>Rabbis</b> in our mishna <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> in the other mishna, who maintain that wine and oil are not connected and therefore cannot be used together in an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>and</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> who holds that wine and oil are connected, and may be used together in an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Taddai says:</b> In <b>both this</b> case, of wine and wine, <b>and that</b> case, of wine and oil, <b>they must establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> The Gemara expresses wonder: Did he say this <b>even</b> if the partnership is <b>with this one in wine and</b> also <b>with the</b> other <b>one in wine?</b> Why should these partnerships not be sufficient to consider the items merged?
<b>Rabba said:</b> If they partnered in the following manner, such that <b>this one came with his</b> wine-filled <b>jug and poured</b> its contents into a barrel, <b>and the</b> other <b>one came with his jug and poured</b> his wine into that same barrel, <b>everyone agrees that it is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> even if they did not act specifically for that purpose.
<b>Where they disagree</b> is in the case <b>where they bought a barrel of wine in partnership. Rabbi Eliezer ben Taddai holds: There is no</b> principle of <b>retroactive clarification,</b> i.e., there is no halakhic assumption that the undetermined halakhic status of items can be retroactively clarified. Consequently, after the wine is consumed, it is not possible to clarify retroactively which portion of the wine belonged to each person. Therefore, they cannot each be said to own a particular part of the wine, which renders it unfit for an <i>eiruv</i>. <b>But the Rabbis hold that there is retroactive clarification,</b> and therefore they may rely on this partnership to establish an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> that this dispute should be understood differently, as <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Taddai and the Rabbis disagree about</b> whether one may <b>rely on a merging</b> of an alleyway <b>instead of an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> i.e., whether the merging of an alleyway to permit carrying in the alleyway, exempts the courtyards that open into the alleyway from having to establish an <i>eiruv</i> for the purpose of carrying from one courtyard to the other.
<b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Taddai, <b>holds</b> that one <b>may not rely</b> on it in that case, as carrying in the courtyards requires specifically an <i>eiruv</i>, and the merging of alleyways is insufficient. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>maintains</b> that one <b>may rely</b> on and use the merging of alleyways to permit carrying between the courtyards as well.
<b>Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this,</b> that this is the subject of their dispute? <b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> which will be detailed later, that one may not rely on a merging of alleyways instead of an <i>eiruv</i>. <b>And Rav Beruna said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Taddai,</b> that in both cases they must establish an <i>eiruv</i>. <b>What is the reason</b> he ruled in this manner? <b>Is it not because the rationale</b> for both rulings is <b>one</b> and the same?
<b>Abaye said to him: But if it is one reason, why do I</b> need <b>two rulings?</b> On the contrary, it would be enough to rule in one case, from which we could infer the other as well. Rav Yosef replied: There is nevertheless a reason for both rulings, as <b>this</b> comes to <b>teach us that we do not act in accordance with two stringencies</b> of one <i>tanna</i> <b>in</b> matters of <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> Had Rav ruled only in accordance with Rabbi Meir, we would have known only that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion with regard to one specific detail of the case. He therefore ruled in accordance with two Sages: Rabbi Eliezer ben Taddai with regard to a merging of alleyways with wine, and Rabbi Meir with regard to a merging of alleyways with bread. Each is stringent with regard to a different detail of the case.
Having mentioned Rabbi Meir, the Gemara now asks: <b>What</b> is the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir, and what</b> is the statement of <b>the Rabbis? As it was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with bread between courtyards</b> that open to one another, <b>but if one wanted to establish an <i>eiruv</i> with wine, one</b> may <b>not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> in that manner. <b>One</b> may <b>merge</b> the courtyards that open <b>into an alleyway with wine, and if one wanted to establish a merging</b> of alleyways <b>with bread, one</b> may <b>merge</b> the courtyards of alleyways in this manner.
Why <b>does</b> one <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> between courtyards and</b> also <b>merge</b> the courtyards that open <b>into an alleyway?</b> It is so <b>as not to cause the</b> halakhic <b>category of <i>eiruv</i> to be forgotten by the children, as</b> if a merging of alleyways alone were used, the children would later <b>say: Our fathers never established an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> Therefore, an <i>eiruv</i> is established for educational purposes; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> One may <b>either establish an <i>eiruv</i> or merge</b> alleyways.
<b>Rabbi Naḥumi and Rabba disagreed about</b> this issue. <b>One</b> of them <b>said:</b> In the case <b>of bread,</b> which may be used both for an <i>eiruv</i> and for a merging of alleyways, <b>everyone agrees that one,</b> either an <i>eiruv</i> or a merging of alleyways, <b>is enough. When they disagree</b> in the case <b>of wine,</b> which may be used only for a merging of alleyways but not for an <i>eiruv</i>, Rabbi Meir maintains that an <i>eiruv</i> is also necessary, while the Rabbis maintain that it is not required.

Daf 72a

<b>And one said:</b> In the case <b>of wine, everyone agrees that two are required,</b> both a merging of alleyways and a joining of courtyards. <b>When they disagree</b> is in a case where an <i>eiruv</i> was established <b>with bread:</b> Rabbi Meir maintains that both a merging of alleyways and a joining of courtyards are required, whereas the Rabbis say that one is sufficient.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the <i>baraita</i> itself. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One may <b>either establish an <i>eiruv</i> or a merging</b> of alleyways. <b>What,</b> does it <b>not</b> mean that one <b>either establishes an <i>eiruv</i> in the courtyard with bread or a merging in the alleyway with wine,</b> which indicates that they also disagreed in a case where a merging of alleyways was established with wine?
<b>Rav Giddel said that Rav said</b> that the Rabbis were <b>saying as follows:</b> One may <b>either establish an <i>eiruv</i> in the courtyard with bread, and</b> it would <b>be</b> rendered <b>permitted</b> to carry both <b>here,</b> in the courtyard, <b>and there,</b> in the alleyway, <b>or</b> one may <b>establish a merging</b> of alleyways <b>in the alleyway with bread, and</b> it would <b>be</b> rendered <b>permitted</b> to carry both <b>here,</b> in the courtyard, <b>and there,</b> in the alleyway.
<b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir. And Rav Huna said:</b> No clear halakhic ruling was issued in his favor, but <b>the custom is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> Therefore, if someone asks, he should be instructed to act accordingly. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is not even a custom established by the Sages. Rather, <b>the people were accustomed</b> to act <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> and we do not tell them they have acted inappropriately.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>five groups</b> of people <b>who spent Shabbat in one hall [<i>teraklin</i>]</b> that was subdivided by partitions into separate rooms, each of which had a separate entrance to a courtyard that was shared with other houses, <b>Beit Shammai say: An <i>eiruv</i></b> is required <b>for each and every group,</b> i.e., each group must contribute separately to the <i>eiruv</i> of the courtyard, as each is considered a different house. <b>And Beit Hillel say: One <i>eiruv</i></b> suffices <b>for all of them,</b> as the partitions do not render the different sections separate houses.
<b>And</b> Beit Hillel <b>concede</b> that <b>when some of them occupy</b> separate <b>rooms or upper stories, they require</b> a separate <b><i>eiruv</i> for each and every group,</b> and the fact that they are in the same building does not render them one unified group.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> applies only where they divided the hall <b>with a partition of pegs [<i>mesifas</i>]. However,</b> if they divided it <b>with</b> a sturdy <b>partition ten</b> handbreadths high, <b>all agree</b> that a separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> is required <b>for each and every group,</b> as this certainly divides the hall into separate living quarters. <b>Some say</b> a different version of the previous passage, according to which <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> as follows: <b>Even</b> where they merely divided the room <b>with a partition of pegs,</b> there is a <b>dispute</b> about whether this is considered a full-fledged partition.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>disagreed about</b> this issue. <b>One</b> of them <b>said:</b> This <b>dispute is with regard to partitions that reach the ceiling, but</b> with regard to <b>partitions that do not reach the ceiling, all agree</b> that <b>one <i>eiruv</i></b> suffices <b>for all of them,</b> as the partitions do not turn the compartments into separate houses. <b>And one said:</b> This <b>dispute is with regard to partitions that do not reach the ceiling, but</b> with regard to <b>partitions that reach the ceiling, all agree</b> that the compartments are considered separate living quarters, and <b>they require</b> a separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i> for each and every group.</b>

Daf 72b

The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda the Keen</b> [<b><i>hasabbar</i></b>], who was known by this name due to his sharp mind, <b>said: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree about partitions that reach the ceiling, as</b> all agree that <b>they require</b> a separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i> for each and every group. With regard to what did they disagree?</b> With regard to <b>partitions that do not reach the ceiling, as Beit Shammai say:</b> A separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> is required <b>for each and every group, and Beit Hillel say: One</b> contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> suffices <b>for all of them.</b>
<b>According to the one who said</b> that it was with regard to <b>partitions that reach the ceiling</b> that there was a <b>dispute,</b> this <i>baraita</i> offers a <b>conclusive refutation. And according to the one who said</b> that it was with regard to <b>partitions that do not reach the ceiling</b> that there was a <b>dispute,</b> the <i>baraita</i> offers <b>support.</b> With regard <b>to that version</b> which holds that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> applies only where they divided the hall <b>with a <i>mesifas</i>,</b> this <i>baraita</i> is <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
However, the following issue needs further clarification: With regard <b>to that version</b> which holds that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> applies <b>even</b> where the hall was divided <b>with a <i>mesifas</i>, shall we say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda the Keen’s statement <b>is a</b> conclusive <b>refutation?</b> That is to say, does it imply that all agree that in the case of a <i>mesifas</i>, one <i>eiruv</i> suffices for them all?
<b>Rav Naḥman</b> could have <b>said to you: They</b> explicitly <b>disagreed about a partition, and the same is true of a partition of pegs. And</b> the fact <b>that they disagree with regard to a partition</b> rather than a partition of pegs is <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature of</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel.</b> Even where the compartments are divided by full-fledged partitions, Beit Hillel remain of the opinion that one contribution to the <i>eiruv</i> suffices for all of them, as the partitions do not turn them into separate residences.
The Gemara asks: If they disagreed in both cases, <b>let them disagree</b> in the <i>baraita</i> <b>about a <i>mesifas</i>,</b> and thereby <b>inform you of the strength of Beit Shammai.</b> They are stringent and require a separate contribution to the <i>eiruv</i> for each and every group, even in the case of a <i>mesifas</i>. The Gemara answers: It is <b>preferable</b> for the <i>tanna</i> to teach us <b>the strength of a permissive</b> ruling. If a <i>tanna</i> can formulate a dispute in a manner that emphasizes the strength of the more lenient position, he will do so.
<b>Rav Naḥman said that Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda the Keen,</b> that all agree that where the partitions reach the ceiling, a separate contribution to the <i>eiruv</i> is required for each group, and that they disagree only about partitions that do not reach the ceiling.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: The mishna is also precise</b> according to this view, <b>as it teaches: And</b> Beit Hillel <b>concede</b> that <b>when some of them occupy</b> separate <b>rooms or upper stories, they require a</b> separate <b><i>eiruv</i> for each and every group. What</b> is the meaning of the word <b>rooms, and what</b> is the meaning of the term <b>upper stories? If you say</b> that the word <b>rooms</b> refers to <b>actual rooms and</b> the term <b>upper stories</b> refers to <b>actual upper stories,</b> i.e., they were separate from the beginning and are not subdivisions of a larger room, it is <b>obvious,</b> as this is the <i>halakha</i> governing the case of many people residing in the same courtyard. <b>Rather, doesn’t it</b> mean that they are <b>similar to rooms and similar to upper stories? And what</b> are <b>these</b> partitions? They are <b>partitions that reach the ceiling;</b> and even though they are not actual rooms or upper stories, they are considered like rooms and upper stories. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that this is the case.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case is <b>this statement,</b> that Beit Shammai require a separate contribution to the <i>eiruv</i> from each group, <b>said?</b> It is in a case <b>where</b> the groups in the hall <b>bring their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere</b> in the courtyard, i.e., to a different house. <b>But if their <i>eiruv</i> was coming to them,</b> i.e., if the other members of the courtyard brought their contributions and established the <i>eiruv</i> in that hall, <b>all agree</b> that <b>one</b> contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> suffices <b>for all of them.</b> The fact that the <i>eiruv</i> is placed in this house renders all of its residents members of a single unit.
The Gemara comments: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is</b> the ruling <b>that was taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>five</b> people <b>who</b> live in the same courtyard and <b>collected their <i>eiruv</i>, when they take their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere</b> in the courtyard, <b>one</b> contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> suffices <b>for all of them. In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this ruling? <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel.</b>
<b>And some say</b> a different version of the previous passage: <b>In what</b> case is <b>this statement,</b> that Beit Hillel require only one contribution for all the groups together, <b>said?</b> It is in a case <b>where the <i>eiruv</i> was coming to them. But if</b> the groups in the hall <b>were bringing their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere</b> in the courtyard, <b>all agree</b> that a separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i> is required for each and every one of them.</b>
If so, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is</b> the ruling <b>that was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>five</b> people <b>who</b> live in the same courtyard and <b>collected their <i>eiruv</i>, when they take their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere</b> in the courtyard, <b>one</b> contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> suffices <b>for all of them. In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this ruling? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> either <b>one</b> of them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>brothers who were eating at their father’s table and sleeping in their</b> own <b>houses</b> in the same courtyard, a separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i> is required for each and every one</b> of them. <b>Therefore, if one of them forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, he</b> must <b>renounce his rights</b> in the courtyard in order to render carrying in the courtyard permitted to the rest of the courtyard’s residents.
<b>When</b> do they state this <i>halakha</i>? They state it <b>when they take their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere</b> in the courtyard, i.e., to the house of one of the other residents. <b>But if the <i>eiruv</i> was coming to them,</b> i.e., if it was placed in their father’s house, <b>or if there are no</b> other <b>residents with</b> the brothers and their father <b>in the courtyard, they are not required to establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> as they are considered like a single individual living in a courtyard.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments on the statement in the mishna that a separate contribution to the <i>eiruv</i> must be made by each of the brothers if they sleep in their own houses: <b>Learn from it</b> that one’s <b>place of sleep determines</b> the location of his residence. The Gemara rejects this conclusion. <b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: They taught</b> this mishna <b>with regard to</b> brothers who <b>receive a portion</b> from their father. The mishna is not referring to brothers who actually eat at their father’s table, but rather to brothers whose father supplies them with food that they eat in their own homes.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who has a gatehouse, porch,</b> or <b>balcony in his friend’s courtyard does not render</b> the owner of the courtyard <b>prohibited</b> from carrying there without an <i>eiruv</i>, as these locations are not considered residences. However, if he has a <b>storeroom of straw, a cattle shed, a woodshed, or a storehouse</b> in his friend’s courtyard, <b>he renders it prohibited</b> for his friend to carry there without an <i>eiruv</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Only a place of</b> actual <b>dwelling renders</b> carrying <b>prohibited,</b> but a building that is not designated for residence does not render carrying without an <i>eiruv</i> prohibited for another resident of the courtyard.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: There was an incident with ben Nappaḥa, who had</b> houses in <b>five courtyards in Usha,</b> only one of which served as his own residence. <b>And the case came before the Sages</b> to decide whether an <i>eiruv</i> must be made for all of them, <b>and they said: Only a house of residence renders</b> carrying <b>prohibited.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise at the wording of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that the correct reading is <b>a house of residence?</b> He has a house in each of the five courtyards. <b>Rather, say: A place of residence,</b> i.e., it is prohibited to carry in the place where he actually lives, but nowhere else.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> considered one’s <b>place of residence? Rav said:</b>

Daf 73a

<b>The place</b> where he eats his <b>bread, and Shmuel said:</b> His <b>place</b> of <b>sleep.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>shepherds; fig watchmen,</b> who guard figs spread out in the field; <b>guardsmen</b> who sit in small guardhouses; <b>and produce watchmen; when they customarily sleep in the city</b> in addition to eating there, <b>they are like the residents of the city</b> with regard to their Shabbat limit, even though they were in the field when Shabbat began. However, <b>when they customarily sleep in the field,</b> even though they eat in the town, <b>they have</b> only <b>two thousand</b> cubits <b>in each direction</b> from the places where they sleep. This seems to contradict the opinion of Rav, who maintains that a person’s place of dwelling is determined by where he eats, not by where he sleeps.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of the people in the field, <b>we are witnesses,</b> i.e., it is clearly evident, <b>that if</b> people would <b>bring them bread there,</b> to the place where they sleep, <b>it would be more convenient for them.</b> Fundamentally, however, a person’s dwelling place is determined by where he eats, rather than where he sleeps.
<b>Rav Yosef said: I have not heard this <i>halakha</i></b> stated by Rav. An illness had caused Rav Yosef to forget his studies. His student, <b>Abaye, said to him: You</b> yourself <b>said it to us, and it was with regard to this that you said it to us:</b> With regard to <b>brothers who were eating at their father’s table and sleeping in their</b> own <b>houses</b> in the same courtyard, a separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i> is required for each and every one</b> of them. <b>And we said to you:</b> Can one <b>learn from</b> here that a person’s <b>place of sleep determines</b> the location of his Shabbat residence? <b>And you said to us in this regard</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: They taught</b> this mishna <b>with regard to</b> brothers <b>who receive a portion</b> from their father and are therefore considered as though they eat at his table, whereas in actual fact they eat their meals in their own homes.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who has five wives</b> who <b>receive a portion from their husband</b> while each living in her own quarters in the courtyard, <b>and five slaves</b> who <b>receive a portion from their master</b> while living in their own lodgings in the courtyard, <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira permits in</b> the case of <b>the wives,</b> i.e., they do not each have to contribute separately to the <i>eiruv</i>, as they are all considered to be residing with their husband. <b>And he prohibits in</b> the case of <b>the slaves,</b> meaning that he holds that as they live in separate houses, each is considered as residing on his own.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava permits in</b> the case of <b>the slaves,</b> as a slave necessarily follows his master, <b>and he prohibits in</b> the case of <b>the wives,</b> as each woman is significant in her own right, and is not totally dependent on her husband.
<b>Rav said: What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava? As it is written: “But Daniel was in the gate of the king”</b> (Daniel 2:49). The verse refers to Daniel’s function rather than to an actual location, indicating that wherever Daniel went, it was as though he was in the king’s gate. The same applies to any slave vis-à-vis his master.
The Gemara proceeds to clarify various aspects of this issue, starting with a summary of what has already been stated. The <i>halakha</i> is <b>obvious</b> in the case of <b>a son with his father, as we stated</b> it above the mishna. <b>A wife with her husband and a slave with his master</b> are subject to the <b>dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira and Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava.</b> With regard to <b>a student</b> who lives <b>with his master</b> in the same courtyard and receives his sustenance from him, <b>what</b> is his status with regard to <i>eiruv</i>?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this question: <b>As Rav,</b> when he was <b>in the school of Rabbi Ḥiyya, said: We do not need to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, as we are dependent upon the table of Rabbi Ḥiyya. And</b> similarly, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> himself, when he was <b>in the school of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>said: We do not need to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, as we are dependent upon the table of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Abaye raised a dilemma before Rabba:</b> With regard to <b>five</b> people <b>who</b> live in the same courtyard and <b>collected their <i>eiruv</i>, when they take their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere</b> in order to merge their courtyard with a different one, is <b>one</b> contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> sufficient <b>for all of them, or do they need</b> a separate contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i> for each and every one</b> of them? Rabba <b>said to him: One</b> contribution to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> suffices <b>for all of them.</b>
Abaye asked: <b>But</b> in the case of <b>brothers, who are comparable</b> to people <b>who collected</b> their <i>eiruv</i>, the mishna nonetheless <b>teaches: They require a</b> separate <b><i>eiruv</i> for each and every one</b> of them. Rabba responded: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where there are</b> other <b>residents,</b> in addition to the father and his sons, living <b>with them.</b> In that case, <b>since these</b> additional residents <b>render</b> carrying in the same courtyard <b>prohibited</b> unless they join in an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>those</b> brothers <b>also render it prohibited</b> for one another to carry in the other courtyard unless each of them contributes to the <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara comments: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to understand, <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches: When</b> do they state this <i>halakha</i>? <b>When they bring their <i>eiruv</i> elsewhere</b> in the courtyard. <b>But if their <i>eiruv</i> was coming to them, or if there are no</b> other <b>residents with them in the courtyard, they do not need to establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> as they are considered like a single individual living in a courtyard. <b>Learn from this</b> that the preceding ruling refers to a situation where they shared the courtyard with other residents.
The Gemara addresses a similar issue with regard to a joining of Shabbat boundaries: <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet:</b> With regard to <b>students in their master’s house who eat</b> their <b>bread in</b> their houses <b>in the field [<i>baga</i>] and</b> then <b>come and sleep in</b> their <b>master’s house, when we measure</b> their Shabbat <b>limit for them, do we measure</b> it <b>for them from</b> their <b>master’s house,</b> where they sleep, <b>or do we measure</b> it <b>for them from the field,</b> where they eat? <b>He said to him: We measure</b> it <b>from</b> their <b>master’s house.</b>
Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin asked: <b>But</b> in the case of <b>one who deposits his <i>eiruv</i>,</b> which establishes the location of his meal, <b>within two thousand cubits, and</b> then <b>goes</b> back <b>and sleeps in his house, we measure his</b> Shabbat <b>limit from his <i>eiruv</i>.</b> This implies that the determining factor is where he eats, rather than where he sleeps.
The Gemara answers: <b>In that</b> case <b>we are witnesses, and in this</b> case <b>we are witnesses,</b> i.e., in both cases the person’s intentions regarding his place of residence are clearly evident. <b>In that</b> case, where the person deposits his <i>eiruv</i>, <b>we are witnesses that if he</b> could <b>reside there,</b> at the site of his <i>eiruv</i>, <b>it would be better for him,</b> i.e., if he could spend the night there he would do so, since he wishes to continue from that place onward on the following day. <b>And in this</b> case of the students in their master’s house, <b>we are witnesses that if</b> people <b>would bring them bread in their master’s house,</b> enabling them to eat there, <b>it would be better for them.</b> Consequently, it is considered their place of residence.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised a dilemma before Rav Ḥisda:</b> With regard to <b>a father and his son,</b> or <b>a master and his student, are they considered as many</b> people <b>or as individuals?</b> The practical import of the question is as follows: If they lived together in a courtyard that was within another courtyard, are they considered as many people, who <b>require an <i>eiruv</i></b> in order to render it permitted to carry in the outer courtyard, <b>or do they not require an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> as they are treated as an individual, who does not render carrying in the outer courtyard prohibited? Is <b>their alleyway</b> rendered <b>permitted</b> for carrying <b>through a side post and</b> a cross <b>beam,</b> like one that has multiple residents, <b>or is it not</b> rendered <b>permitted</b> for carrying <b>through a side post and</b> a cross <b>beam?</b>
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: You have</b> already <b>learned this</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a father and his son</b> or <b>a master and his student, when there are no</b> other <b>residents with them, they are</b> considered <b>like individuals, and they do not need to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, and their alleyway</b> becomes <b>permitted</b> for carrying <b>through a side post and</b> a cross <b>beam</b> without a merging of alleyways.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>five courtyards open into one another and</b> also <b>open into an alleyway,</b> the following distinctions apply: If the residents of the courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> in the courtyards and did not merge the</b> courtyards that open into the <b>alleyway, they are permitted</b> to carry <b>in the courtyards and they are prohibited</b> to carry <b>in the alleyway.</b> The <i>eiruv</i> they established cannot also serve as a merging of the courtyards that open into the alleyway.

Daf 73b

<b>And if they merged</b> the courtyards of <b>the alleyway, they are permitted</b> to carry both <b>here,</b> in the alleyway, and <b>there,</b> in the courtyards.
If <b>they established an <i>eiruv</i> in the courtyards</b> and also <b>merged</b> the courtyards of <b>the alleyway, and one of the residents of the courtyard forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> in his courtyard, but did participate in the merging of the courtyards in the alleyway, <b>they are permitted</b> both <b>here and there,</b> as the merging of courtyards in the alleyway serves as an effective <i>eiruv</i> for the courtyards as well.
However, if one <b>of the residents of the alleyway</b> forgot <b>and did not</b> participate in the <b>merging</b> of courtyards that open into the alleyway, <b>they are permitted</b> to carry <b>in the courtyards and prohibited</b> from carrying <b>in the alleyway, as</b> the principle is: <b>An alleyway is to</b> its <b>courtyards as a courtyard is to</b> its <b>houses.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this mishna? The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: We require an <i>eiruv</i> and we</b> also <b>require a merging</b> of the courtyards in an alleyway, and one is not sufficient without the other.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>say</b> the <b>middle clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And if they merged</b> the courtyards <b>in the alleyway, they are permitted</b> to carry both <b>here and there. We have arrived at</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that <b>one is enough,</b> and one does not need both an <i>eiruv</i> and a merging of alleyways.
The Gemara responds: <b>That is not difficult,</b> as the mishna <b>stated</b> as follows: <b>And if they also merged</b> the courtyards in the alleyway, they are permitted to carry in the courtyards and in the alleyway.
The Gemara asks: <b>Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If <b>they established an <i>eiruv</i> in the courtyards and</b> also <b>merged</b> the courtyards <b>in the alleyway, and one of the residents of the courtyard forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> in his courtyard but did participate in the merging of the alleyway, <b>they are permitted</b> to carry both <b>here and there. What are the circumstances? If</b> the person who forgot <b>did not renounce</b> his rights to the courtyard in favor of the others, <b>why are they permitted</b> to carry? <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that he did renounce</b> those rights. But if so, <b>say the last clause</b> of the mishna: If <b>one of the members of the alleyway forgot and did not</b> participate in the <b>merging</b> of the alleyway, <b>they are permitted</b> to carry <b>in the courtyards and prohibited</b> from carrying <b>in the alleyway. But if he renounced</b> his rights, <b>why are they prohibited</b> from carrying <b>in the alleyway?</b>
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that <b>renunciation of rights is not</b> effective <b>in an alleyway,</b> that answer is insufficient. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to an alleyway: <b>As he renounced his rights in your favor;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir?</b> This indicates that Rabbi Meir accepts the principle of renunciation of rights in an alleyway.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the person who forgot to participate in the merging of alleyways <b>did not renounce</b> his rights. <b>And from the</b> fact that <b>the last clause</b> of the mishna is referring to a case <b>where he did not renounce</b> his rights, it can be inferred that <b>the first clause</b> is <b>also</b> referring to a case <b>where he did not renounce</b> his rights. This would indicate that if they carried out a merging of alleyways, it also serves as an <i>eiruv</i>, even when one of them forgot to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i> and also failed to renounce his rights in the courtyard.
