This is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, which leads to the puzzling conclusion that the <b>first and last clauses</b> of the mishna are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> while the <b>middle clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara answers: In fact, <b>it is all</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir. And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir said we require an <i>eiruv</i> and we</b> also <b>require a merging</b> of alleyways? It was only so <b>as not to cause the</b> halakhic <b>category of <i>eiruv</i> to be forgotten by the children.</b> If people would only merge courtyards, the <i>halakha</i> of establishing an <i>eiruv</i> for a courtyard would gradually be forgotten. <b>And here,</b> where only one person forgot to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>since most of</b> them <b>established an <i>eiruv</i></b> for the courtyards, the <i>halakha</i> of an <i>eiruv</i> <b>will not be forgotten.</b> Therefore, there is room to be lenient after the fact and to permit carrying in both places.
<b>Rav Yehuda said: Rav did not teach</b> the mishna as stating that the five courtyards <b>open into one another,</b> but rather that each courtyard opens into the alleyway, and each established its own <i>eiruv</i>. <b>And so too, Rav Kahana said: Rav did not teach</b> the mishna as stating that the courtyards <b>open into one another. Some say</b> that <b>Rav Kahana himself did not teach</b> the mishna as stating that the courtyards <b>open into one another.</b>
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: What is the reason he did not teach</b> the mishna as stating that the five courtyards <b>open into one another?</b> Rav Yosef replied: Because <b>he holds</b> that <b>any merging</b> of alleyways <b>that is not brought in and taken out by way of the entrances</b> that open <b>into the alleyway,</b> i.e., which is not brought from each courtyard into the alleyway and then taken from the alleyway into the courtyard where it will be deposited, <b>is not considered</b> a valid <b>merging</b> of the alleyway. If the food used for the merging of alleyways is transferred directly from one courtyard to another, it seems as though it is being used to establish an <i>eiruv</i>. It is therefore ineffective as a merging of alleyways. Here too, if the courtyards open into one another, the merging of alleyways is invalid, due to a concern that the residents of the courtyard will transfer the food directly from one courtyard to another.
<b>He raised an objection to him</b> based upon the following mishna: <b>A homeowner who was a partner of his neighbors, with this one in wine and with that one in wine, they do not need to establish an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> This indicates that it is not actually necessary to transfer the food used for the merging of alleyways from one place to another. For example, it is sufficient to have a jointly owned barrel of wine in one courtyard even if it did not pass through the alleyway. The Gemara rejects this proof and explains the mishna as follows: <b>There,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they took</b> the wine <b>out</b> into the alleyway and subsequently <b>brought it in</b> to the courtyard where it was to be kept.
<b>He raised</b> another <b>objection to him</b> from a different mishna: <b>How does one merge</b> courtyards that open <b>into alleyways?</b> The mishna continues and says that it is sufficient for one person to acquire the food used for the merging on behalf of all the other residents of the alleyway. This indicates that the food does not need to pass through all the courtyards in the alleyway. The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <b>There too,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they</b> first <b>took</b> the food <b>out</b> from each of the courtyards into the alleyway <b>and</b> from there <b>brought it into</b> the courtyard where it was to be deposited.
<b>Rabba bar Ḥanan strongly objects to this: However, if</b> that <b>is so,</b> if <b>he transferred ownership of bread in his basket to</b> another person, <b>so too, it would not be</b> considered a valid <b>merging. And if you say</b> that <b>this is</b> indeed <b>so, didn’t Rav Yehuda say that Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>members of a group who were dining</b> together on Shabbat eve, <b>and the day became sanctified for them,</b> i.e., Shabbat began while they were eating, <b>they may rely upon the bread on the table as an <i>eiruv</i></b> for the courtyard, <b>and some say, as a merging</b> of the alleyway.
<b>And Rabba said:</b> The two versions <b>do not disagree</b> with each other regarding whether the bread counts as an <i>eiruv</i> or as a merging of the alleyway. <b>Here,</b> where they can use it as an <i>eiruv</i>, it is referring to a case <b>where they were dining in a house,</b> since food deposited inside a house can serve as an <i>eiruv</i> for the courtyard. <b>There,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they were dining in a courtyard,</b> and therefore they may rely on the bread as a merging of the alleyway. This proves that even Rav agrees that it is not necessary to take the food used to merge an alleyway into the alleyway itself and then bring it back to the courtyard.
<b>Rather,</b> we must retract the previous explanation and say that <b>the reason Rav</b> did not teach the mishna as stating that the courtyards opened into one another is <b>that he holds</b> that <b>an alleyway cannot</b> be <b>rendered permitted</b> for carrying <b>through a side post and</b> a cross <b>beam unless there are houses and courtyards opening into it.</b> If, however, the courtyards open into one another, they are considered like a single courtyard, in which case they cannot be rendered permitted for carrying through a side post or a cross beam, and the merging of the alleyway is ineffective.
The Gemara now examines <b>the matter itself</b> cited in the previous discussion. <b>Rav said: An alleyway cannot</b> become <b>permitted</b> for carrying <b>through a side post and</b> a cross <b>beam,</b>

Daf 74a

<b>unless there are houses and courtyards opening into it.</b> This formulation implies that there must be at least two courtyards, each of which contains at least two houses. In the absence of these conditions, however, it is not considered an alleyway that can be permitted by means of a side post or a cross beam. <b>And Shmuel said: Even one house</b> without a courtyard <b>and one courtyard</b> with just one house is enough. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even a ruin</b> and a courtyard with a house suffice for a side post or a cross beam to render carrying in an alleyway permitted.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef:</b> Did <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that <b>even a vineyard path</b> and a courtyard with a house suffice to allow a side post or a cross beam to render carrying in the alleyway permitted? <b>He said to him: Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> his ruling <b>only</b> in the case of <b>a ruin, which is fit</b> to serve <b>as a residence. However, a vineyard path, which is not fit</b> to serve <b>as a residence,</b> is <b>not</b> sufficient.
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana said: And Rabbi Yoḥanan followed his</b> regular line of <b>reasoning</b> in this regard, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Shimon said: Roofs, enclosures, and courtyards are all</b> considered <b>one domain with regard to vessels that rested inside them</b> at the beginning of Shabbat. Therefore, it is permitted to carry vessels that were in one of these areas at the beginning of Shabbat to any of the other areas. However, they are <b>not</b> considered the same domain <b>with regard to vessels that rested inside the house</b> at the beginning of Shabbat. If the homeowners did not join the courtyard by means of an <i>eiruv</i>, it is prohibited to carry vessels from their houses to the roof, enclosure, or courtyard.
<b>And Rav said: The halakha is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. And this is</b> only in a case <b>where</b> the residents of the courtyards <b>did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for each courtyard, so that they may only carry the vessels left in the courtyards, but they may not take out vessels from their houses into their courtyards. <b>However, if they established an <i>eiruv</i></b> for each courtyard, <b>we decree</b> against carrying even vessels that were in the courtyard when Shabbat began, <b>lest they come to take out objects</b> from their <b>houses to the courtyard.</b> This would lead to the mistake of carrying those objects from one courtyard to another, which is prohibited.
<b>And Shmuel said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, <b>whether</b> the residents of the courtyards <b>established an <i>eiruv</i></b> for each courtyard <b>or whether they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for each courtyard. <b>And so too, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, whether they established an <i>eiruv</i></b> for each courtyard <b>or whether they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for each courtyard. <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that <b>we do not decree</b> against carrying vessels that began Shabbat in the courtyard <b>lest they come to take out objects from</b> their <b>houses to the courtyard. Here too,</b> with regard to an alleyway that contains a ruin, <b>we do not decree</b> against carrying in the alleyway <b>lest they come to take out objects from the courtyard to the ruin</b> by carrying it through the alleyway. Although the ruin is not included in the <i>eiruv</i>, as it has no residents, and one may not carry objects into it, Rabbi Yoḥanan is not concerned that one might come to carry in this prohibited manner.
<b>Rav Beruna sat and recited this <i>halakha</i></b> stated by Shmuel, that an alleyway containing one house and one courtyard can be rendered permitted for carrying by means of a side post or a cross beam. <b>Rabbi Elazar, a student of a Torah academy, said to him: Did Shmuel</b> really <b>say this?</b> Rav Beruna <b>said to him: Yes,</b> he did. <b>He said to him: Show me his lodging</b> and I will go and ask him myself, and <b>he showed him.</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>came before Shmuel</b> and <b>said to him:</b> Did <b>the Master</b> actually <b>say this?</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: Yes,</b> I did.
Rabbi Elazar raised the following objection: <b>Wasn’t it the Master</b> himself who <b>said</b> concerning a different issue: <b>With regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>eiruv</i>, we have only the wording of our mishna.</b> The mishna states <b>that an alleyway is to</b> its <b>courtyards like a courtyard is to</b> its <b>houses,</b> which indicates that an alleyway must have at least two courtyards in order to be considered an alleyway and be rendered permitted for carrying through a side post or cross beam. Shmuel <b>was silent</b> and did not answer him.
The Gemara asks: Did Shmuel’s silence indicate that he <b>accepted</b> Rabbi Elazar’s objection and retracted his statement, <b>or did he not accept it from him?</b> The Gemara attempts to bring a proof from the following incident. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> There was <b>a certain alleyway that Ivut bar Ihi lived in,</b> which contained only one house and one courtyard. <b>He erected a side post for it, and Shmuel permitted him</b> to carry in it.

Daf 74b

Following Shmuel’s death, <b>Rav Anan came and threw</b> the side post down, thus indicating to Ivut bar Ihi that it is prohibited to carry in the alleyway, as a side post is effective only for an alleyway that has at least two courtyards containing at least two houses each. Ivut bar Ihi <b>said</b> with resentment: <b>The alleyway in which I have been living and walking</b> based on a ruling <b>in the name of Master Shmuel, shall Rav Anan bar Rav come</b> now and <b>throw</b> its side post away <b>from</b> me? The Gemara comments: <b>Learn from</b> the fact that this side post remained intact throughout Shmuel’s lifetime that he <b>did not accept</b> Rabbi Elazar’s objection.
The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>Actually, you can say</b> that Shmuel <b>accepted</b> Rabbi Elazar’s objection and retracted his opinion, <b>and here there was</b> a synagogue <b>attendant [<i>ḥazzana</i>] who would eat bread in his</b> own <b>house</b> that was located elsewhere, <b>but</b> would <b>come and sleep in the synagogue,</b> which was open to the alleyway.
<b>And Ivut bar Ihi holds</b> that <b>the place</b> where a person eats his <b>bread determines</b> his place of residence. Therefore, he did not consider the synagogue a residence, as the attendant would eat elsewhere, and Ivut bar Ihi thought that Shmuel had permitted him to set up a side post for his alleyway even though he lived there by himself. In fact, however, this was not the case, as <b>Shmuel followed his</b> regular line of <b>reasoning, as he said: The place</b> where a person <b>sleeps determines</b> his place of residence. Since the attendant would sleep in the synagogue, it was considered a residence. Consequently, the alleyway contained two houses and courtyards, and could be made permitted for carrying by means of a side post or a cross beam.
<b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>an alleyway, one side of which</b> was occupied by <b>a gentile and one side of which</b> was occupied by <b>a Jew,</b> and the house of the Jew was connected to the houses of other Jews via windows but not via doors, and those other houses open directly into the public domain, the residents of the houses on the side of the alleyway where the Jews live <b>may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> through the windows</b> in order <b>to render</b> it <b>permitted</b> for the residents of the other houses to carry <b>through the doors</b> of the house leading <b>to the alleyway.</b>
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef:</b> Did <b>Rav say</b> this <b>even with regard to a courtyard,</b> one side of which was occupied by a gentile and the other side of which was occupied by a Jew whose house was connected through windows to the houses of other Jews? <b>He said to him: Yes, as</b> even <b>if he did not say</b> so, <b>what</b> would be the difference? It is the exact same principle.
Abaye responded: <b>I would have said</b> that <b>the rationale for</b> the opinion of <b>Rav is because he holds</b> that <b>an alleyway cannot be rendered permitted</b> for carrying within it <b>with a side post and</b> a cross <b>beam unless there are houses and courtyards opening into it.</b>
Rav Yosef said: If that were the reason, <b>why</b> would <b>I need two</b> rulings regarding the same issue? Rav already stated that an alleyway can be rendered permitted for carrying within it only if it has houses and courtyards opening into it. Abaye explained that both rulings are <b>necessary. As, if</b> Rav had taught this <i>halakha</i> only <b>from that</b> general ruling,

Daf 75a

<b>I would have said</b> that <b>the residence of a gentile is considered a residence</b> with regard to defining an area as an alleyway. Therefore, he <b>teaches us that the</b> legal <b>status of the residence of a gentile is not considered a</b> full-fledged <b>residence</b> in this regard. <b>And if</b> Rav had taught this <i>halakha</i> only <b>from</b> the ruling <b>here,</b> with regard to gentiles, <b>I would have said</b> that <b>I do not know how many houses there</b> are. Therefore, he <b>teaches us</b> that there must be at least <b>two houses</b> and two courtyards.
<b>Now that Rav</b> has <b>said</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> to <b>a courtyard,</b> this implies that <b>the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rav is that he holds: It is prohibited for an individual to establish</b> his home <b>in the place</b> where <b>a gentile</b> resides. Consequently, he is prohibited from establishing an <i>eiruv</i>, so that the difficulties of living there will force him to move.
<b>Rav Yosef said: If so, this is</b> why <b>I heard Rabbi Tavla say: A gentile, a gentile, two times</b> while teaching this subject, even though <b>I did not understand</b> then <b>what he</b> meant to <b>say.</b> Now I realize that he was speaking about both an alleyway and a courtyard.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>two courtyards, one</b> of which was <b>within the other,</b> and the outer one opened into the public domain, the following distinctions apply: If <b>the inner</b> courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i></b> for itself <b>and the outer</b> one <b>did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> carrying in <b>the inner one is permitted and</b> carrying in <b>the outer one is prohibited.</b>
If <b>the outer</b> courtyard established an <i>eiruv</i> <b>and the inner</b> one did <b>not,</b> carrying in <b>both</b> is <b>prohibited,</b> as the residents of the inner courtyard pass through the outer one, and are considered to a certain extent as residents of the courtyard who did not participate in the <i>eiruv</i>. If <b>this</b> courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> for itself, and that</b> courtyard also <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> for itself,</b> but they did not establish a joint <i>eiruv</i> with one another, <b>this one is permitted by itself, and that one is permitted by itself,</b> but they may not carry from one to the other.
<b>Rabbi Akiva prohibits</b> carrying in <b>the outer one</b> even in such a case, <b>as the</b> right of <b>entry</b> to the outer courtyard enjoyed by the residents of the inner courtyard <b>renders it prohibited. And the Rabbis</b> disagree and <b>say:</b> The right of <b>entry</b> enjoyed by the residents of the inner courtyard <b>does not render it prohibited.</b> Since the residents of the inner courtyard do not use the outer one other than to pass through it, and they are permitted to carry in their own courtyard, they do not render it prohibited to carry in the outer courtyard.
If <b>one</b> resident <b>of the outer</b> courtyard <b>forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>,</b> carrying in <b>the inner</b> courtyard <b>is permitted and</b> in <b>the outer one is prohibited.</b> If one resident <b>of the inner</b> courtyard <b>forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, they are both prohibited,</b> as the right of way enjoyed by the members of the inner courtyard through the outer courtyard renders the outer one prohibited as well.
If the residents of both courtyards <b>put their <i>eiruv</i> in one place, and one</b> person, <b>whether</b> he was <b>from the inner</b> courtyard <b>or from the outer one, forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, they are both prohibited</b> for carrying within them, as the two courtyards are treated as one. <b>And if</b> the courtyards belonged <b>to individuals,</b> i.e., if only one person lived in each courtyard, <b>they are not required to establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> as this requirement applies only to a courtyard occupied by multiple residents.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said</b> in the name of <b>Rabbi Yannai: This</b> mishna, which states that if the residents of the outer courtyard established an <i>eiruv</i> but the residents of the inner one did not, they are both prohibited from carrying, is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva, who said: Even</b> the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted in its</b> own <b>place,</b> i.e., even someone from a courtyard in which he is permitted to carry, <b>renders</b> it <b>prohibited when</b> he is <b>not in its</b> own <b>place.</b> If he enjoys the right of entry to another courtyard he is considered like a resident of that courtyard as well, and if he does not participate in the <i>eiruv</i>, no one in that courtyard may carry. <b>However, the Rabbis say: Just as</b> the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted</b> in its own place <b>does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry in another courtyard, <b>so</b> too, the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is prohibited</b> in his place <b>does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry in another courtyard. Consequently, if only the residents of the outer courtyard established an <i>eiruv</i>, the residents of the inner one do not render it prohibited to carry in the outer courtyard.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If the residents of <b>the outer</b> courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> and</b> the residents of <b>the inner</b> courtyard did <b>not, they are both prohibited. Whose</b> opinion is this? <b>If you say</b> it is that of <b>Rabbi Akiva, why</b> discuss <b>particularly</b> the case of <b>a foot that is prohibited,</b> i.e., a case where the inner courtyard did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>? According to Rabbi Akiva, <b>even a foot that is permitted also</b> renders it prohibited to carry. Therefore, even if the residents of the inner courtyard had established an <i>eiruv</i>, they would still render it prohibited to carry in the outer courtyard. <b>Rather, is it not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b> This would indicate that the Rabbis agree that one who may not carry in his own courtyard does, in fact, render it prohibited to carry in a different courtyard through which he has right of entry, contrary to Rabbi Yannai’s claim.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Actually,</b> this part of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> and <b>he teaches</b> the mishna employing the style: <b>Not</b> only <b>this</b> but <b>also that.</b> In other words, he begins by teaching the <i>halakha</i> in a relatively straightforward case and then proceeds to a more complicated example. Consequently, the mishna should be understood as follows: Not only is it prohibited to carry in both courtyards if the residents of the outer courtyard established an <i>eiruv</i> and the residents of the inner one did not, but even if the residents of both courtyards established separate <i>eiruvin</i>, it remains prohibited to carry in the outer one.
The Gemara continues: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>this</b> courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> for itself, and that</b> courtyard also <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> for itself,</b> but the two courtyards did not establish a joint <i>eiruv</i> with one another, <b>this one is permitted by itself, and that one is permitted by itself,</b> but it is prohibited to carry from one courtyard to the other. <b>The reason</b> both courtyards are permitted by themselves is that the residents of the inner courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> By inference, if they <b>did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> carrying in <b>both would be prohibited.</b>
<b>But this <i>tanna</i>, who said</b> that the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted</b> in his own place <b>does not</b> render it <b>prohibited</b> to carry, while the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is prohibited</b> in its own place <b>does</b> render it <b>prohibited</b> to carry, <b>who is this</b> <i>tanna</i>? <b>If you say</b> it is <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> there is a difficulty, as he holds that <b>even</b> the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted</b> in its own place <b>also</b> renders it prohibited to carry in a different place. <b>Rather, is it not</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> which indicates that the Rabbis agree that the foot of one who is prohibited in its own place does, in fact, render it prohibited to carry in a different place, in contrast to the statement of Rabbi Yannai? <b>And furthermore, from the fact that the latter clause</b> that follows immediately states the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> it is clear that <b>the first clause,</b> with which Rabbi Akiva disagrees, <b>is not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara responds: The <b>entire</b> mishna in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, and it is incomplete and teaches the following:</b> If <b>this</b> courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> for itself, and that</b> courtyard also <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> for itself,</b> but they did not establish a joint <i>eiruv</i> with one another, <b>this one is permitted by itself, and that one is permitted by itself,</b> but they may not carry from one to the other. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> the inner courtyard <b>constructed a</b> small <b>partition</b> at its entrance. <b>However,</b> if <b>it did not construct a partition, the outer</b> courtyard <b>is prohibited.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva, as Rabbi Akiva prohibits</b> carrying in <b>the outer</b> courtyard <b>because the</b> right of <b>entry</b> enjoyed by the members of the inner courtyard <b>renders</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry. <b>And the Rabbis say: The</b> right of <b>entry</b> enjoyed by the members of the inner courtyard <b>does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry.
<b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye raised an objection</b> based upon the final clause of the mishna: <b>And if</b> the courtyards belonged <b>to individuals,</b> i.e., if only one person lived in each courtyard, <b>they are not required to establish an <i>eiruv</i>. Doesn’t</b> this indicate that if they belong <b>to many</b> people jointly, <b>they need to establish an <i>eiruv</i>? Apparently,</b> the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted in his</b> own <b>place does not render</b> it <b>prohibited,</b> but the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is prohibited</b> in his own place does <b>render</b> it <b>prohibited.</b> This contradicts Rabbi Yannai’s understanding of Rabbi Akiva’s opinion.
<b>And Ravina raised a further objection</b> from the mishna: If <b>one</b> resident <b>of the outer</b> courtyard <b>forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, the inner</b> courtyard <b>is permitted</b> for carrying <b>and the outer one is prohibited.</b> If <b>one</b> resident <b>of the inner</b> courtyard <b>forgot and did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, both</b> courtyards <b>are prohibited,</b> as the right of way enjoyed by the members of the inner courtyard through the outer courtyard renders the outer one prohibited as well. <b>The reason is that</b> one of the residents <b>forgot</b> to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>. <b>But</b> if <b>he did not forget,</b> and each courtyard established its own valid <i>eiruv</i>, <b>both of them</b> would be <b>permitted. Apparently,</b> the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted in his</b> own <b>place does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry, but the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is prohibited</b> in his own place does <b>render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry. This cannot be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, as he holds that even the foot of one who is permitted in his own place renders it prohibited to carry elsewhere. Rather, it must be the opinion of the Rabbis, which proves that even they agree that the foot of one who is prohibited in his own place does render a different courtyard prohibited.
<b>Rather,</b> this version must be rejected, and <b>when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he cited a different version. <b>Rabbi Yannai said: There are three disputes with regard to</b> this <b>matter. The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted in his</b> own <b>place does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry elsewhere, but the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is prohibited</b> in his own place does <b>render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry. <b>Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>even</b> the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted</b> in his own place <b>renders</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry in a different place. <b>And the latter Rabbis hold</b> that <b>just as</b> the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is permitted in his</b> own <b>place does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry, <b>so</b> too, the <b>foot</b> of one <b>who is prohibited does not render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to carry. This explanation resolves all of the difficulties posed earlier.
It was stated in the mishna: If the residents of both courtyards <b>put their <i>eiruv</i> in one place, and one</b> person, <b>whether</b> he was <b>from the inner</b> courtyard or from the outer one, <b>forgot</b> and did not contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>, it is prohibited to carry in both courtyards. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>one place?</b> Is the <i>halakha</i> different if the two courtyards established their <i>eiruv</i> in one place or in different places?
Before continuing, the Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the ensuing discussion: <b>Outer; for itself; in the house of an individual; Ravina; where the inner one did not forget.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said that Rav said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case when the residents of both courtyards established their <i>eiruv</i> in <b>the outer</b> courtyard. <b>And why did they call it one</b> [<b><i>eḥad</i></b>] <b>place?</b> Because it is a place that is <b>designated</b> [<b><i>meyuḥad</i></b>] <b>for</b> the residents of <b>both</b> courtyards, as the members of the inner one also pass through the outer courtyard. Therefore, if a member of the outer courtyard forgot to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>, the inner courtyard is also prohibited. Since the <i>eiruv</i> of the inner courtyard is located in the outer courtyard, the residents of the inner courtyard cannot separate themselves from the outer one. However, if the <i>eiruv</i> was deposited in the inner courtyard and a member of the outer courtyard forgot to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>, carrying in the inner courtyard is permitted, because in that situation they can separate themselves from the outer courtyard.

Daf 75b

<b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>they placed their <i>eiruv</i> in the outer</b> courtyard, <b>and one</b> person <b>forgot</b> to contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, whether he is</b> a resident <b>of the outer</b> courtyard <b>or of the inner</b> one, <b>they are both prohibited.</b> If <b>they put their <i>eiruv</i> in the inner</b> courtyard, <b>and one</b> resident <b>of the inner</b> courtyard <b>forgot</b> to contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, they are both prohibited.</b> Similarly, if one of the residents <b>of the outer</b> courtyard <b>did not</b> contribute to the <b><i>eiruv</i>, they are both prohibited.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis</b> disagree and <b>say: In this</b> case, where the <i>eiruv</i> was deposited in the inner courtyard and the person who forgot to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i> was a resident of the outer one, the <b>inner</b> courtyard <b>is permitted and the outer one is prohibited.</b>
<b>Rabba bar Ḥanan said to Abaye: What is different according to the Rabbis, who say</b> that the <b>inner</b> courtyard <b>is permitted?</b> It is <b>because</b> the residents of the inner courtyard can <b>shut the door</b> of their courtyard to the members of the outer one <b>and use</b> the inner courtyard on their own. But if so, <b>according to Rabbi Akiva as well, let</b> the residents of the inner courtyard <b>shut the door</b> of their courtyard to the members of the outer one <b>and use</b> their courtyard on their own. Abaye <b>said to him:</b> If the <i>eiruv</i> of the outer courtyard was not placed in the inner courtyard, your argument would be valid. But the fact that <b>the <i>eiruv</i></b> is deposited in the inner courtyard <b>accustoms</b> the residents of the outer courtyard to enter it.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>according to the Rabbis as well</b> we should say that the placement of the <b><i>eiruv</i></b> in the inner courtyard <b>accustoms</b> the residents of the outer courtyard to enter it. The Gemara answers: The reasoning of the Rabbis is <b>that</b> the members of the inner courtyard can <b>say</b> to the members of the outer one: <b>We joined with you</b> in a single <i>eiruv</i> <b>to</b> our <b>benefit, and not to</b> our <b>detriment.</b> Since one of your residents forgot to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>, we no longer acquiesce to this partnership.
The Gemara asks: <b>According to Rabbi Akiva as well, let</b> the residents of the inner courtyard <b>say</b> to the residents of the outer courtyard: <b>We joined with you to</b> our <b>benefit and not to</b> our <b>detriment.</b> The Gemara answers that according to Rabbi Akiva, the case is <b>that</b> the residents of the outer courtyard <b>said</b> to the residents of the inner courtyard: <b>We renounce our rights in your favor,</b> in which case the inhabitants of the inner courtyard are permitted to carry in their own courtyard. Consequently, his ruling that the inner courtyard is also prohibited applies only before the residents of the outer courtyard renounce their rights. <b>And the Rabbis</b> hold that <b>there is no renunciation of rights from courtyard to courtyard.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Shmuel and Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who disagree about whether there is renunciation of rights from one courtyard to another, <b>disagree about the</b> same point that was the subject of a <b>disagreement between the Rabbis and Rabbi Akiva. As Shmuel said</b> that there is no renunciation of rights from one courtyard to another, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that such renunciation is valid, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you: What I said is even in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Akiva stated</b> his opinion that there is renunciation of rights from one courtyard to another <b>only here, with regard to two courtyards, one within the other, which render each other prohibited. However, there,</b> where they disagree about two adjacent courtyards, <b>do</b> the courtyards <b>render each other prohibited?</b> Consequently, even Rabbi Akiva would agree that there is no renunciation of rights from one courtyard to another.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said: What I said is even in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. The Rabbis stated</b> their opinion that there is no renunciation of rights from one courtyard to another <b>only</b> in the case <b>here, as</b> the residents of the inner courtyard <b>said to</b> the residents of the outer courtyard: <b>Until you renounce</b> your rights <b>in our favor, you render</b> it <b>prohibited</b> for <b>us</b> to carry, and therefore, we will have no connection with you and forgo both the renunciation and the prohibition. <b>But there, does</b> one courtyard <b>prohibit</b> the other? Since it does not, even the Rabbis would agree that there is renunciation from one courtyard to another.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And if</b> the courtyards belonged <b>to individuals,</b> i.e., if only one person lived in each courtyard, they are not required to establish an <i>eiruv</i>. <b>Rav Yosef said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>teaches</b> that if <b>there were three</b> people living in the two courtyards, whether two people lived in the outer courtyard and one person in the inner one, or two people lived in the inner courtyard and one person lived in the outer one, <b>they are prohibited</b> from carrying without an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rav Beivai said to</b> the Sages: <b>Do not listen to him,</b> as he is mistaken. <b>I told it to him, and I told it to him in the name of Rav Adda bar Ahava,</b> not Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, but due to his illness Rav Yosef forgot this detail. And the reason that the residents of both courtyards are prohibited from carrying if two people are living in the outer courtyard is that <b>since I call them many in the outer</b> courtyard, the Sages issued a decree prohibiting carrying, due to a case in which there are two people living in the inner courtyard. When he heard this, <b>Rav Yosef said</b> in astonishment: <b>Master of Abraham! I mistook</b> the word <b>Rabbi for</b> the word <b>many [<i>rabbim</i>].</b> He now realized that he had mistakenly understood this ruling as attributed to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi rather than a <i>halakha</i> regarding many, an error that led to his inaccurate version of the teaching.
<b>And Shmuel said: Actually, they are permitted, unless there are two</b> people living <b>in the inner</b> courtyard <b>and one in the outer one.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: And a gentile is</b> considered <b>like many,</b> i.e., if a gentile lives in the inner courtyard, the gentile’s right of way in the outer courtyard renders it prohibited to carry there. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>an</b> individual <b>Jew</b> living in the inner courtyard, that <b>he does not prohibit</b> the resident of the outer courtyard? <b>Because one who knows</b> that only one person lives there <b>knows</b> this fact, <b>and one who does not know</b> this <b>thinks</b> that <b>an <i>eiruv</i> has been established.</b> If so, in the case of <b>a gentile also, we</b> should <b>say that</b> one <b>who knows</b> that only one person lives there <b>knows,</b> and one <b>who does not know</b> this <b>thinks</b> that the Jew must have <b>rented</b> the domain from the gentile.
The Gemara answers: This is not so, as <b>a typical gentile, if he</b> had <b>rented</b> out his domain, <b>he would chatter</b> about it, and everyone would know. If he has not talked about it, everyone will assume that he did not rent out his domain.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> If there are <b>ten houses, one within the other,</b> so that the person living in the innermost house must pass through all the rest in order to reach the courtyard, <b>the innermost one</b> alone <b>contributes to the <i>eiruv</i></b> for the courtyard, <b>and it is enough.</b> The residents of the other houses are considered as living in the gatehouse and corridor of the innermost one, and therefore they do not have to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even</b> the <b>outer one</b> must contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara asks: The <b>outer</b> residence <b>is a gatehouse</b> in relation to the inner ones, so why should it have to contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>? The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring to the <b>outer</b> house <b>of</b> the <b>innermost one.</b> In other words, even the second-to-last house, the outer one only in relation to the innermost house, must contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>, as it is not viewed as a gatehouse.
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree? One Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>holds</b> that <b>the gatehouse of an individual is considered a gatehouse,</b> and therefore the ninth house, i.e., the second innermost is also a gatehouse, as it serves as a passageway for the individual living in the innermost house, <b>and one Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that the gatehouse of an individual <b>is not considered a gatehouse,</b> and therefore the ninth house must also contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>two courtyards</b> that have <b>three houses between them,</b> and a resident of <b>this</b> courtyard <b>comes through this</b> house that opens to his courtyard <b>and places his <i>eiruv</i> in that</b> middle house, <b>and</b> a resident of <b>this</b> other courtyard <b>comes through this</b> house that opens to his courtyard <b>and places his <i>eiruv</i> in that</b> middle house,

Daf 76a

<b>this</b> outer house <b>becomes a gatehouse to this</b> courtyard, <b>and that</b> outer house <b>becomes a gatehouse to that</b> courtyard, and therefore the residents of the outer houses need not contribute to the <i>eiruv</i>. <b>The middle</b> house between them <b>is the house in which the <i>eiruv</i> is placed,</b> and therefore its residents <b>need not contribute bread</b> for the <i>eiruv</i>.
The Sage <b>Raḥava tested the</b> other <b>Sages:</b> If there were <b>two courtyards and two houses between them,</b> and a resident of <b>this</b> courtyard <b>came through this</b> house that opens to his courtyard <b>and placed his <i>eiruv</i> in that</b> house farther from his courtyard, <b>and</b> a resident of <b>this</b> other courtyard <b>came through this</b> house that opens to his courtyard <b>and placed his <i>eiruv</i> in that</b> house that opens to the other courtyard, did <b>they acquire the <i>eiruv</i> or not,</b> i.e., are the two <i>eiruvin</i> valid? <b>Do you render it a house with regard to this</b> courtyard, whose <i>eiruv</i> was placed there, <b>and a gatehouse with regard to that</b> one who passed through it in order to place his <i>eiruv</i> in the other house? <b>And</b> similarly, do you render the other house <b>a gatehouse with regard to this</b> one <b>and a house with regard to that</b> one?
The Sages <b>said to</b> Raḥava: <b>Neither</b> of them <b>has acquired</b> his <b><i>eiruv</i>. Whichever way you</b> look at it, it is difficult: <b>If you consider</b> either house <b>a gatehouse,</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>one who places his <i>eiruv</i> in a gatehouse, a porch, or a balcony,</b> is that <b>it is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> And <b>if you consider</b> either one <b>a house, he would be carrying into a house for which he is not establishing an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> Since the assumption that benefits one of them harms the other, and there is no way to establish firmly the status of these houses, the residents of both courtyards fail to acquire their <i>eiruv</i>.
Raḥava asked: <b>What</b> makes this case <b>different from</b> the ruling of <b>Rava? As Rava said:</b> In the case of <b>two</b> people who <b>said to</b> one person: <b>Go and establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> of Shabbat limits <b>for</b> each of <b>us,</b> and <b>he established an <i>eiruv</i> for one</b> of them <b>while it was still day, and he established an <i>eiruv</i> for</b> the other <b>one during twilight,</b> and <b>the <i>eiruv</i> of the one for whom he established an <i>eiruv</i> while it was still day was eaten during twilight, and the <i>eiruv</i> of the one for whom he established an <i>eiruv</i> during twilight was eaten after nightfall, both of them have acquired their <i>eiruv</i>.</b> Twilight is of doubtful status as to whether it is considered day or night. If it is night, any <i>eiruv</i> established at that time is invalid, and if it is day, any <i>eiruv</i> eaten at that time is invalid. Rava nonetheless ruled leniently, despite the fact that two contradictory assumptions are involved, in keeping with the principle that in cases of doubt relating to an <i>eiruv</i>, the <i>halakha</i> is lenient. Consequently, with regard to the one whose <i>eiruv</i> was eaten during twilight, it is considered as though it was already night, and therefore his <i>eiruv</i> had already taken effect while it was still day before it was eaten. Conversely, with regard to the one whose <i>eiruv</i> was established during twilight, that period of time is viewed as day, and therefore his <i>eiruv</i> is valid as well.
The Sages respond: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> where there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>day</b> and <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>night, the matter is not noticeable,</b> as no one sees exactly when each <i>eiruv</i> was established. <b>But here,</b> where the houses are clearly distinguishable, <b>if with regard to this</b> one, who placed his <i>eiruv</i> there, it is <b>a house,</b> then <b>with regard to that</b> one, who passed through it, it should also be regarded as <b>a house.</b> And <b>if, with regard to this</b> one, who passed through it, it is <b>a gatehouse,</b> then <b>with regard to that</b> one, who placed his <i>eiruv</i> there, it should <b>also</b> be considered <b>a gatehouse.</b> Therefore, neither of them acquires his <i>eiruv</i>.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there is <b>a window</b> in a wall that separates <b>between two courtyards,</b> and the window measures <b>four by four</b> handbreadths and is <b>within ten</b> handbreadths of the ground, the inhabitants of the courtyards <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> one for each courtyard. <b>And if they desire, they</b> may <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>,</b> thereby merging the two courtyards, as they may be considered as one due to the window.
However, if the window measures <b>less than four by four</b> handbreadths, or if it is <b>above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, it is no longer considered a valid opening, and the two courtyards cannot be considered a single courtyard. Therefore, the residents <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, but they</b> may <b>not establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s determination that the size of the window must be four by four handbreadths, the Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>we learned</b> an <b>unattributed</b> mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the previously cited opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who said: Any</b> gap <b>less than four</b> handbreadths <b>is considered <i>lavud</i>,</b> i.e., two objects are considered connected if the space between them is less than four handbreadths. That would explain why the window must be four handbreadths in size, as otherwise it would be considered as though it were sealed, based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Even if you say</b> that the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> that only gaps of less than three handbreadths are included in the principle of <i>lavud</i>, <b>the Rabbis disagreed with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel only with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>lavud</i>,</b> i.e., what is considered connected. <b>But with regard to an opening, even the Rabbis agree that if there is</b> an opening of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths, it is <b>significant, and if not, it is not significant.</b>
It was taught in the mishna: If the window is <b>less than four</b> by four handbreadths, or above ten handbreadths from the ground, the residents of each courtyard must establish a separate <i>eiruv</i>. The Gemara objects: <b>This</b> is <b>obvious. Since</b> the mishna <b>stated</b> in the previous clause that if the window is <b>four by four</b> handbreadths and <b>within ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, they establish one <i>eiruv</i>, <b>from</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>itself I know</b> that if the window is <b>less than four</b> by four handbreadths <b>or above ten</b> handbreadths, they may <b>not</b> establish one <i>eiruv</i>. Why was it necessary to teach this in the mishna?
The Gemara answers: It <b>teaches us this</b> matter: <b>The reason</b> is specifically that <b>the entire</b> window is <b>above ten</b> handbreadths; <b>however,</b> if <b>part of it is within ten</b> handbreadths of the ground, <b>they establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, and if they desire, they</b> may <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara comments: According to this explanation, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> in the mishna <b>that</b> which <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If nearly <b>all of</b> the window <b>is above ten</b> handbreadths <b>and</b> only a small <b>part of it is within ten</b> handbreadths, or if nearly <b>all of it is within ten</b> handbreadths <b>and</b> only a small <b>part of it is above ten</b> handbreadths, <b>they establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, and if they desire, they</b> may <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The essential meaning of this <i>baraita</i> is clear, but the Gemara raises a question with regard to its formulation: <b>Now,</b> if nearly <b>all of it is above ten</b> handbreadths <b>and</b> only a small <b>part of it is within ten</b> handbreadths, <b>you said</b> that <b>they establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, and if they desire, they</b> may <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>,</b> i.e., the window has the status of an opening and therefore the two courtyards may establish a joint <i>eiruv</i>, then <b>is it necessary</b> to state the <i>halakha</i> governing the case where almost <b>all of it is within ten and</b> only a small <b>part of it is above ten?</b>
The Gemara answers that indeed, this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> employing the style: <b>This, and it is unnecessary to say that,</b> moving from the more difficult and novel case to the easier, more straightforward one.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A circular window must have a circumference of twenty-four handbreadths, with two and a bit of them within ten</b> handbreadths of the ground, <b>so that when he squares</b> the window, i.e., if he forms the shape of a square inside it, it measures four by four handbreadths, and <b>a bit</b> of it <b>is then within ten</b> handbreadths of the ground.
The Gemara poses a question with regard to this calculation: <b>Now, since</b> there is a general principle that <b>any</b> circle <b>with a circumference of three handbreadths is one handbreadth in diameter,</b> then according to this formula, a window with a circumference <b>of twelve</b> handbreadths, meaning that it has a diameter of four handbreadths, should be <b>sufficient</b> to create a window of four by four.

Daf 76b

<b>This</b> measurement <b>applies</b> only <b>to a circle</b> and the ratio between its circumference and diameter, <b>but with regard to a square</b> that must fit entirely within that circle, <b>we require</b> a circle with a <b>larger</b> circumference. In order for a square of four by four handbreadths to be entirely contained within a circle, the circumference of the circle must measure more than twelve handbreadths
The Gemara asks: <b>Now, how much larger is a square than a circle?</b> It is larger by <b>one quarter.</b> If so, a circle <b>with</b> a circumference of <b>sixteen</b> handbreadths at most should <b>suffice.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> statement that a square is larger than a circle by a quarter <b>applies</b> only <b>to a circle circumscribed by a square, but</b> with regard to <b>a square circumscribed by a circle, we require more,</b> and the difference between the square and the circle is greater. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>due to the projection of the corners</b> of the square, as the distance from the center of the square to its corners is greater than the distance from the center to its sides.
The Gemara further objects: <b>Since every cubit in</b> the side of <b>a square</b> is <b>a cubit and two-fifths in the diagonal,</b> a square of four by four handbreadths has a diagonal of five and three-fifths handbreadths. And since the diameter of a circle equals the diagonal of the square that it encompasses, the circle circumscribing a square of four by four handbreadths has a diameter of five and three-fifths handbreadths. If that measure is multiplied by three to arrive at the circumference of that circle, the result is that a circle with a circumference of <b>seventeen handbreadths minus a fifth is sufficient</b> to circumscribe a square of four by four handbreadths. Why, then, does Rabbi Yoḥanan say that a circular window must have a circumference of twenty-four handbreadths?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan spoke in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the judges of Caesarea, and some say in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Sages of Caesarea, who say: A circle</b> that is circumscribed <b>within a square</b> is smaller than it by <b>one quarter;</b> with regard to <b>a square</b> that is circumscribed <b>within a circle,</b> the difference between them is equal to <b>half</b> the square. According to this explanation, Rabbi Yoḥanan calculated as follows: Since a square of four by four handbreadths has a perimeter of sixteen handbreadths, the circumference of the circle that encompasses it must be fifty percent larger, or twenty-four handbreadths.
It was taught in the mishna: If a window is <b>less than four by four</b> handbreadths, or if it is above ten handbreadths from the ground, the residents of the two courtyards may not establish one joint <i>eiruv</i> but must instead establish two independent ones. <b>Rav Naḥman said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> of a window within ten handbreadths of the ground <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a window between two courtyards. But</b> with regard to <b>a window between two houses, even</b> if it is <b>above ten</b> handbreadths <b>as well, if they wish to establish an <i>eiruv</i>, they establish one <i>eiruv</i>. What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? It is that <b>a house is considered as though it</b> were <b>filled,</b> and therefore there is no difference between below and above ten handbreadths with regard to a window in a house.
<b>Rava raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A window between two courtyards, and a window between two houses, and a window between two attics, and a window between two roofs, and a window between two rooms are all one and the same to me; they all</b> must be <b>four by four</b> handbreadths and <b>within ten</b> handbreadths from the ground. This directly contradicts Rav Naḥman’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: <b>Explain</b> that this <i>halakha</i> of ten handbreadths mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> is referring only to <b>courtyards.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>Doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach: Are all one and the same to me,</b> indicating that they are all equal in this regard? Rather, <b>explain</b> that they are all equal in that the window must be the size of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths, but not that all must be within ten handbreadths of the ground.
<b>Rabbi Abba raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> With regard to <b>an aperture that opens from</b> the ceiling of <b>a house</b> occupied by one person <b>to an attic</b> occupied by another, <b>must a permanent ladder</b> be positioned in the opening <b>to render</b> carrying from one level to the other <b>permitted</b> by turning the two into a single residence? <b>Or, is a permanent ladder not necessary to render it permitted?</b>
The Gemara clarifies the two sides of the question: <b>When we say</b> that <b>a house is considered as though it</b> were <b>filled,</b> does <b>this apply</b> only to a window positioned <b>on the side, but not</b> to a window <b>in the middle?</b> In that case, the opening would not be viewed as near the full part of the house, and a permanent ladder would be required. <b>Or perhaps there is no difference,</b> and since the house is considered filled, no ladder is necessary.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: It is not necessary.</b> The Sages <b>understood from</b> this response that he meant that <b>a permanent ladder is not required, but a temporary ladder is required.</b> However, <b>it is stated</b> in this regard: <b>Rav Yosef bar Manyumi said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: Neither a permanent ladder nor a temporary ladder is required,</b> as the fact that the opening is located within the house is sufficient to render it permitted to carry from the house to the attic.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a wall between two courtyards is ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide,</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> a separate one for each courtyard, <b>but they</b> may <b>not establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<b>If there was produce on top</b> of the wall, <b>these</b> residents of one courtyard <b>may ascend from this side and eat</b> from it, <b>and those</b> residents of the other courtyard <b>may ascend from that side and eat</b> from it, <b>provided that they do not lower</b> the produce <b>down</b> from on top of the wall to one of the courtyards.
<b>If the wall was breached,</b> the following distinction applies: If the breach was <b>up to ten cubits</b> wide, <b>they establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, and if they desire, they</b> may <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>, as it is similar to an entrance,</b> like any opening less than ten cubits wide. If the breach was <b>more than this, they establish one <i>eiruv</i>, and they</b> may <b>not establish two,</b> as a breach of this size nullifies the partition and joins the two courtyards into a single domain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: If this wall <b>is not four</b> handbreadths in width, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav said:</b> In this case, <b>the air of two domains controls it.</b> Since the wall is not broad enough to be regarded a domain of its own, the top of the wall is seen as belonging to both courtyards and is then prohibited to both of them. Accordingly, <b>one may not move</b> anything <b>on</b> top of the wall, <b>even</b> as much as <b>a hair’s breadth.</b>

Daf 77a

<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: These</b> residents of one courtyard <b>may raise</b> food <b>from</b> their courtyard to the top of the wall <b>and eat</b> it there, and they may lower the food from the wall to the courtyard; <b>and those</b> residents of the other courtyard <b>may raise</b> food <b>from</b> their courtyard <b>and eat</b> it there, and they may lower the food from the wall to the courtyard. This is because the wall is considered nonexistent, and its domain is viewed as part of the two courtyards.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If there was produce on top of the wall, <b>these</b> residents of one courtyard <b>may ascend from this side and eat</b> from it, <b>and those</b> residents of the other courtyard <b>may ascend from that side and eat</b> from it. The Gemara infers from this: To <b>ascend, yes,</b> it is permitted, but to <b>raise</b> food from the courtyard to the top of the wall, <b>no,</b> it is not permitted. This presents a challenge to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion.
The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying:</b> If the top of the wall between the two courtyards <b>is four by four</b> handbreadths, then to <b>ascend, yes,</b> it is permitted. However, to <b>raise</b> food, <b>no,</b> it is prohibited, because in that case the top of the wall is considered a domain in its own right. But if <b>it is not four by four</b> handbreadths, it is an exempt domain, and therefore <b>they may raise</b> their food onto the wall <b>as well.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan followed his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> in this regard, <b>as when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to <b>a place that does not have</b> an area of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths and is situated between a public and a private domain, <b>it is permissible for</b> both <b>the people in the public domain and for the people in the private domain to</b> adjust the burden on their <b>shoulders upon it, provided they do not exchange</b> objects between them from one domain to the other domain. This demonstrates that in the case of an exempt domain, Rabbi Yoḥanan was not concerned that one might carry from one domain to another, and permitted members of both domains to use it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rav,</b> who prohibits carrying in that case even as much as a hair’s breadth, <b>not accept</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Dimi</b> in this matter? The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> this referred <b>to</b> an exempt domain situated between two <b>domains by Torah law,</b> i.e., between a public and a private domain, <b>so too,</b> Rav would agree that the members of both domains may adjust their burdens there.
However, <b>with what are we dealing here,</b> in the case of the wall? We are dealing <b>with domains by rabbinic law, and the Sages reinforced their statements</b> even <b>more than those of the Torah.</b> Due to their severity, Torah laws are generally observed. Therefore, there is no need to impose decrees and enactments in order to preserve them. The same is not true of rabbinic decrees; if people ignore the preventive measures, they might come to violate the entire enactment.
<b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> With regard to <b>a wall that is between two courtyards,</b> and <b>one side</b> facing one courtyard is <b>ten handbreadths high, and the other side is level with the ground</b> of the second courtyard, i.e., the second courtyard is built on a higher plane, so that the wall is less than ten handbreadths above its floor, in this case the Sages <b>grant</b> the use of the top of the wall on Shabbat only <b>to the</b> courtyard in which the wall is <b>level with the ground.</b>
The reason is <b>because the use of</b> the wall <b>is convenient for one</b> side, i.e., the higher courtyard, <b>but difficult for the other</b> side. The wall can be used more conveniently by the residents of the higher courtyard. <b>And</b> the principle is that in <b>any</b> case with regard to Shabbat where an action is <b>convenient for one</b> party <b>and difficult for another,</b> the Sages <b>grant it to the one for whom its use is convenient.</b>
Similarly, <b>Rav Sheizvi said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> In the case of <b>a ditch between two courtyards, one side of which is ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep, and the other side of which is level with the ground</b> of the second courtyard, i.e., is less than ten handbreadths below it, the Sages <b>grant</b> the use of the ditch <b>to the</b> courtyard in which the ditch is <b>level with the ground.</b> This is <b>because it is</b> a case in which <b>the use of</b> the ditch <b>is convenient for one</b> side, where it is close to level with the ground, <b>and difficult for the other,</b> where the ditch is ten handbreadths deep, and whenever use of an item is convenient for one party and inconvenient for another, it is granted to the one for whom it is convenient.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it was <b>necessary</b> to cite both of these cases, as it would not have been possible to learn one from the other, <b>since, had</b> Rav Naḥman <b>taught us</b> only the case <b>with regard to a wall,</b> one could have said that the <i>halakha</i> applies only in that case, <b>because people use an elevated</b> surface. Even for the residents of the lower courtyard, it is relatively easy to use this wall. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a ditch, people do not use a deep</b> surface, as it is troublesome to bend down and place an item in a ditch. In that case, one might <b>say</b> that it may <b>not</b> be used by the residents of either courtyard.
<b>And</b> likewise, <b>had he taught us</b> only the case <b>with regard to a ditch,</b> one could have said that the <i>halakha</i> applies only in that case, <b>because its use does not cause worry,</b> as anything placed in the ditch is protected. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a wall, the use of which causes worry</b> that the objects placed there are liable to fall, one might <b>say</b> that it may <b>not</b> be used by the residents of either courtyard. Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> to state both of these rulings.
With regard to a wall between two courtyards, the Gemara states: If <b>one comes to diminish</b> the height of the wall by placing a stone next to it, or by building a platform in order to permit its use or to utilize it as a passageway to another courtyard, the following distinction applies: <b>If the diminished</b> section <b>is</b> at least <b>four handbreadths</b> wide, <b>it is permitted to use the entire wall.</b> This area has the status of an entrance and the two courtyards are considered one, which renders the entire wall permitted. <b>However, if</b> the diminished section is <b>not</b> at least four handbreadths wide, <b>one</b> may <b>use only the</b> area of the wall <b>opposite</b> the <b>diminished</b> section, but no more.
The Gemara challenges this ruling: <b>Whichever way you</b> look at it, this ruling is difficult. <b>If the diminishing was effective, although</b> it extends less than four handbreadths, <b>let him use</b> the entire <b>wall;</b> and <b>if</b> the diminishing <b>was not effective, even</b> the area <b>corresponding to the diminished</b> section should <b>also not</b> be permitted for use, as this section is insignificant. <b>Ravina said:</b> Here, it refers to a case <b>where one removed a segment</b> of stone <b>from the top</b> of the wall. Since the wall is actually less than ten handbreadths high along that section, it is fit for use as is an opening in the wall.
<b>Rav Yeḥiel said:</b> If <b>one overturned a basin</b> and placed it next to a wall, such that the wall is no longer ten handbreadths high, <b>it</b> effectively <b>diminishes</b> the height of the wall.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> should this be so? Isn’t this basin <b>an item that may be moved on Shabbat,</b> i.e., something that one is permitted to handle? <b>And</b> the principle is that <b>an item that may be moved on Shabbat does not diminish</b> a wall. Since it can be removed at any moment on Shabbat, such an object cannot be viewed as a permanent part of the wall. The Gemara answers: <b>No, it is necessary;</b> this basin can be considered a permanent part of the wall in a case <b>where he attached</b> the basin <b>to the ground</b> by covering it with soil. The basin may then not be moved on Shabbat due to the prohibition of handling soil.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>And if one attached</b> the basin <b>to the ground, what of it? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an unripe</b> fig <b>that one buried in straw</b> intended for kindling, so that it would ripen, <b>or a cake that one buried in coals</b> before Shabbat, and the coals were extinguished, <b>if part of</b> either one <b>is visible, it may be moved on Shabbat.</b> This is not prohibited, although as a result one will move the straw or the coals, which are set aside.
The Gemara explains: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with</b> a case where the top of the basin <b>has a rim</b> that is fully buried in the ground, so that removing the basin will dislodge the earth under which it is buried in a manner similar to digging, which is prohibited on Shabbat.
The Gemara further challenges this explanation: <b>And if</b> the basin <b>has a rim, what of it? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who buries a turnip or a radish</b> in the ground <b>beneath a vine</b> for safekeeping, <b>when</b>

Daf 77b

<b>some of the leaves</b> of the turnip or radish <b>are showing, he need not be concerned due to diverse kinds,</b> i.e., that he violated the prohibition of planting food crops in a vineyard, as he did not intend to commit an act of planting; <b>nor due to tithes,</b> i.e., there is no concern lest the turnip or radish grew further, in which case he would be obligated to tithe it; <b>nor due to</b> the prohibition against working the land during <b>the Sabbatical Year,</b> and similarly, he need not be concerned that they grew further and that the additional growth is prohibited as produce that grew during the Sabbatical Year. <b>And</b> therefore, the turnip or radish <b>may be taken</b> from the ground <b>on Shabbat.</b> Even if most of the turnip or radish is underground, it is permitted to pull it from the ground on Shabbat. If so, in the case described in the mishna here, even if the basin buried in the ground has a rim, it should nevertheless be permitted to move it.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> Rabbi Yeḥiel’s ruling <b>is necessary</b> in a case where the basin was so firmly attached to the ground <b>that one would need a hoe [<i>mara</i>] or a spade</b> to remove it, as this action would certainly involve digging, which is prohibited on Shabbat. Therefore, since the basin cannot be removed on Shabbat, it is considered fixed in its place and effectively diminishes the height of the wall.
It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An Egyptian ladder,</b> which is small, <b>does not diminish</b> the height of a wall, whereas <b>a</b> larger, <b>Tyrian</b> ladder effectively <b>diminishes</b> its height. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of an <b>Egyptian ladder;</b> i.e., what characterizes it? <b>The</b> scholars of the <b>school of Rabbi Yannai said: Any</b> ladder <b>that does not have four rungs.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: What is the reason</b> that <b>an Egyptian ladder does not diminish</b> the height of a wall? He <b>said to him: Did you not hear</b> that which <b>Rav Aḥa bar Adda said</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is <b>because it is an object that may be moved on Shabbat,</b> i.e., it is not set-aside [<i>muktze</i>], <b>and</b> the principle is that <b>any object that may be moved on Shabbat does not diminish</b> the height of a wall, as it cannot be considered a permanent part of the wall.
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> this should apply <b>even</b> to <b>a Tyrian</b> ladder <b>as well,</b> as a large ladder is also not set-aside and may be handled on Shabbat. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of a Tyrian ladder, <b>its heaviness establishes it</b> as part of the wall. Even though one is permitted to move it, since due to its weight it is not moved easily, it effectively diminishes the height of the wall.
<b>Abaye said:</b> If <b>a wall between two courtyards</b> is <b>ten handbreadths high, and one placed a ladder four</b> handbreadths <b>wide</b> against the wall <b>on one side,</b> in one courtyard, <b>and</b> another <b>ladder four</b> handbreadths <b>wide on the other side,</b> in the other courtyard, <b>and there are less than three handbreadths between them,</b> i.e., the two ladders on the opposite sides of the wall are within three handbreadths of each other, even if they are not directly opposite each other, this <b>diminishes</b> the height of the wall. The pair of ladders is regarded as a valid passageway between the two courtyards. However, if the gap between the two ladders is <b>three</b> handbreadths or more, this <b>does not diminish</b> the height of the wall.
<b>And we only said</b> this qualification if the <b>wall was less than four</b> handbreadths wide. However, <b>if</b> the <b>wall was</b> at least <b>four</b> handbreadths wide, then <b>even</b> if one ladder was <b>greatly distanced</b> from the other, this <b>likewise</b> renders it permitted. Since it is possible to walk along the thickness of the wall, the pair of ladders constitutes a passageway between the two courtyards.
<b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: If one built a</b> wooden <b>platform</b> next to the wall <b>above</b> another <b>platform,</b> then <b>if the lower platform is four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>it diminishes</b> the height of the wall to below ten handbreadths. <b>Alternatively,</b> if <b>the lower</b> one <b>is not four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>but the upper</b> one <b>is four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>and there is</b> a gap of <b>less than three</b> handbreadths <b>between them, it diminishes</b> the height of the wall, as the two platforms are considered as one.
<b>And Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> In the case of <b>a ladder whose rungs are disconnected, if the bottom rung is four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>it diminishes</b> the height of the wall. <b>Alternatively,</b> if <b>the bottom rung is not four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>but the upper rung is four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>and there is</b> a gap of <b>less than three</b> handbreadths <b>between them, it diminishes</b> the height of the wall, because the principle of <i>lavud</i> joins the two rungs together.
<b>And Rav Naḥman said that Rabba bar Avuh said:</b>

Daf 78a

If <b>a projection four by four</b> handbreadths in area <b>extends from a wall, and one placed a ladder of any</b> width <b>against it,</b> if the rungs of the ladder are less than three handbreadths apart, <b>he has diminished</b> the height of the wall by means of this ladder and projection.
The Gemara qualifies this statement: <b>And we said</b> this <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one placed</b> the ladder directly <b>against</b> the projection, so that the ladder serves as a passage to it. <b>However, if he placed it adjacent to</b> the projection, <b>he has</b> merely <b>widened</b> the projection, while the ladder remains separate from it. Consequently, the projection does not have any connection to the ground, and a projection that is not within three handbreadths of the ground does not diminish the height of a wall.
<b>And Rav Naḥman said that Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> If <b>a wall</b> between two courtyards is <b>nineteen</b> handbreadths high, <b>it requires one projection to</b> render the use of the wall <b>permitted.</b> If there is a single projection in the middle of the wall, with a ladder of any width resting against it, it is considered a passageway between the courtyards, as the projection is within ten handbreadths of the top of the wall.
However, if <b>the wall</b> is <b>twenty</b> handbreadths high, it <b>requires two projections to</b> render the use of the wall <b>permitted,</b> one within ten handbreadths of the ground, and the other within ten handbreadths of the top of the wall. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: And this</b> applies only <b>where he positioned</b> the projections <b>not</b> directly <b>one above the other,</b> so that it is possible to use a ladder to climb from one projection to the other.
<b>Rav Huna said:</b> If <b>a pillar in the public domain</b> is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide,</b> so that it is considered a private domain, <b>and one drove a stake of any</b> size <b>into</b> the top of <b>it, he has diminished its</b> area. The usable area is now less than four handbreadths, and therefore the pillar is no longer considered a private domain.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> This applies only if the stake is at least <b>three</b> handbreadths <b>high.</b> If it is less than three handbreadths high, it is considered part of the top of the pillar, based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>. This is in contrast to <b>Abaye and Rava, who both say: Even if</b> the stake is <b>not three</b> handbreadths <b>high,</b> the pillar is no longer considered a private domain.
<b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion of Abaye and Rava? It is that the pillar <b>is no longer</b> fit to be <b>used,</b> as a surface of four by four handbreadths is suitable for use only when it is level. If it has even a small projection, it is no longer usable.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Even a stake three</b> handbreadths <b>high</b> does not diminish the area of the pillar. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is that <b>it is possible to hang an item on it. Although</b> it is no longer possible to rest objects on top of the pillar, it is still useful in some way.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> According to your opinion, if <b>he filled it entirely with stakes,</b> i.e., if he drove so many stakes into the top of the post that it was completely filled, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Did you not hear that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said?</b> He said that <b>a pit and its embankment</b> of stone around the edge <b>join</b> together to complete the measure of <b>ten</b> handbreadths. Similarly, the width of the embankment joins with the diameter of the pit to complete the measure of four by four handbreadths necessary to define the pit as a private domain.
There, too, one can raise the question: <b>But why? He cannot use</b> the embankment, as most of the area is the empty space of the pit. <b>Rather, what have you to say,</b> i.e., how can you solve this problem? The solution is <b>that he places an item,</b> e.g., a board, over the mouth of the pit, <b>and</b> then he can make <b>use</b> of it. <b>Here, too, he places an item</b> over the stakes <b>and</b> can make <b>use</b> of the pillar.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> If <b>a wall</b> is <b>ten</b> handbreadths high, <b>it requires a ladder fourteen</b> handbreadths high, so that one can place the ladder at a diagonal against the wall. The ladder then functions as a passageway and thereby renders the use of the wall <b>permitted. Rav Yosef said: Even</b> a ladder with a height of <b>thirteen</b> handbreadths <b>and a bit</b> is enough, as it is sufficient if the ladder reaches within one handbreadth of the top of the wall.
<b>Abaye said: Even</b> a ladder that is only <b>eleven</b> handbreadths <b>and a bit</b> suffices, as the ladder will still reach a height of over seven handbreadths, i.e., within three handbreadths of the top of the wall.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Even</b> if the ladder is only <b>seven</b> handbreadths <b>and a bit</b> it is sufficient, as he can stand the ladder upright against the wall. Since it will reach within three handbreadths of the top of the wall, the principle of <i>lavud</i> applies. Therefore, even a ladder placed in this manner is considered a valid passageway between the two courtyards.
Similarly, <b>Rav said: An upright ladder</b> effectively <b>diminishes</b> the height of a wall, as it creates a passageway. I received this teaching as <b>a tradition, but I do not know what the reason is,</b> as people do not generally climb ladders positioned in this manner.
<b>Shmuel said: Does Abba,</b> i.e., Rav, actually <b>not know the reason for this matter?</b> The reason here is <b>just as it is</b> in the case of <b>a platform above</b> another <b>platform.</b> Even though it is not easy to climb, since it provides steps that can be climbed, albeit with difficulty, it is considered a valid passageway.
<b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said:</b> The trunks of <b>palm trees in Babylonia</b> that were placed next to a wall between two courtyards so that people could climb on them and pass from one courtyard to another <b>do not need to be established</b> permanently and attached to the ground; rather, they serve to diminish the wall as they are. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is that <b>their heaviness establishes them</b> as connected to the ground. Although it is permitted to handle them, nevertheless, since their weight makes them difficult to move, they are considered fixed in place.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>Rav Yosef</b> said that <b>Rabbi Oshaya said: Ladders in Babylonia do not need</b> to be <b>established</b> and fixed permanently in place. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is that <b>their heaviness establishes them,</b> as the ladders in Babylonia were typically large and heavy.
The Gemara comments: With regard to <b>the one who said</b> that Babylonian <b>ladders</b> do not need to be fixed in place, <b>all the more so</b> would he agree that the trunks of <b>palm trees,</b> which are placed there from the outset for this purpose, are considered fixed, as both are extremely heavy and also designed to remain in place. On the other hand, <b>the one who said</b> that the trunks of <b>palm trees</b> need not be fixed permanently in the ground, spoke only with regard to palm trees. <b>However,</b> as for <b>ladders, no,</b> they are not considered fixed in place. A ladder, even a heavy one, is designed to be moved from place to place.
<b>Rav Yosef raised a dilemma before Rabba:</b> If there is a narrow <b>ladder</b> measuring less than two handbreadths wide <b>on one</b> side, <b>and a</b> similarly narrow <b>ladder on the other</b> side, <b>and</b> there are rungs of woven <b>straw in the middle</b> between them which would not support a person’s weight, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Are the two ladders considered a single unit, forming a ladder four handbreadths wide, which serves to diminish the height of a wall?
