Rabba <b>said to him: The sole of the foot cannot</b> climb <b>upon them.</b> A person usually places his foot in the middle of a ladder. Since the middle of this ladder is made of straw, then although it appears to be four handbreadths wide, it is not fit for use and does not diminish the height of the wall.
Rav Yosef continued to ask: And what if there were rungs of <b>straw on one</b> side <b>and</b> rungs of <b>straw on the other</b> side, <b>and a</b> narrow <b>ladder</b> less than four handbreadths wide <b>in the middle,</b> and their combined width is four handbreadths? <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case? Rabba <b>said to him: The sole of the foot can</b> climb <b>upon them,</b> and the ladder appears to be four handbreadths wide. Therefore, it serves to diminish the height of the wall.

Daf 78b

Rav Yosef further asked: If the ladder resting against the wall was less than four handbreadths wide, and <b>one dug out</b> grooves <b>in the wall</b> as extensions of the rungs of the ladder <b>to complete</b> the measure, <b>how</b> high must this hollowed-out section be to consider the ladder a valid passageway between the two courtyards? Rabba <b>said to him:</b> If it is <b>ten</b> handbreadths high and four handbreadths wide, it is considered a passageway.
Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> If there was no ladder, and <b>one dug out the entire</b> ladder <b>in the wall,</b> so that all the steps are grooves in the wall, <b>how much</b> must he hollow out? Rabba <b>said to him:</b> Those steps must reach <b>the full height of</b> the wall. Rav Yosef asked: <b>And what is the difference</b> in this case? Why must the steps reach higher in this case than in the case where the hollowed-out section was merely an extension of an existing ladder? Rabba <b>said to him: There,</b> where there is a ladder, <b>it is easy to climb</b> to the top of the wall; however, <b>here,</b> where there are only grooves in the wall, <b>it is not easy to climb.</b> If one cannot reach the top of the wall, the steps are not considered a passageway between the courtyards.
<b>Rav Yosef raised a dilemma before Rabba: If one designated a tree as a ladder, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Given that it is prohibited to climb a tree on Shabbat, if a tree stands next to a wall and it is easy to climb, is it considered with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat as an opening in the wall that can serve as a passageway between the two courtyards?
<b>Let the dilemma be raised</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who maintains that a joining of Shabbat boundaries [<i>eiruv teḥumin</i>] placed in a tree is valid; and <b>let the dilemma be raised</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Let the dilemma be raised</b> according <b>to</b> the previously stated opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>only stated there</b> that with regard to <b>anything that is</b> prohibited on Shabbat <b>due to a rabbinic decree [<i>shevut</i>],</b> the Sages <b>did not prohibit</b> it during twilight. Therefore, in Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion, it is permitted to use an <i>eiruv</i> that was deposited in a tree, as the use of a tree is prohibited on Shabbat by rabbinic decree. However, <b>this applies only</b> in that case, as the <i>eiruv</i> takes effect <b>during the twilight period.</b> Since there is doubt with regard to whether that period is considered day or night, the decree is not in force, and the <i>eiruv</i> is therefore valid. <b>However,</b> in this case, where the opening must be valid for <b>the entire day,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi would <b>not</b> rule that the decree does not apply. Since it is prohibited by rabbinic decree to climb a tree on Shabbat, a tree cannot be considered a valid passageway.
<b>Or perhaps</b> it may be argued that <b>even according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> this tree is considered an opening. They may have said that a joining of Shabbat boundaries placed in a tree is not valid only because the <i>eiruv</i> must actually be accessible during twilight, and in that case it is not, due to the rabbinic decree. However, in this case, where it is not necessary to make actual use of the tree, they would agree that a tree that serves as a ladder <b>is a</b> valid <b>entrance, but a lion crouches upon it.</b> Just as a lion crouching at an opening does not thereby nullify its status as an entrance, although in practice no one can pass through it, so too, in the case of the tree, the prohibition against climbing it does not nullify its status as a passageway.
Rav Yosef further inquired: <b>If one designated a tree worshipped as part of idolatrous rites [<i>asheira</i>],</b> from which it is forbidden to derive benefit, <b>as a ladder, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it considered a valid passageway in the wall with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat? Here, too, <b>let the dilemma be raised</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and <b>let the dilemma be raised</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Let the dilemma be raised</b> according <b>to</b> the previously stated opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yehuda only stated there</b> that <b>it is permitted to acquire,</b> i.e., make use of, <b>a house</b> for the purposes of establishing an <i>eiruv</i> even if it is among the <b>items</b> from which it is <b>prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit,</b> such as a grave. This statement applies only <b>there,</b> with regard to acquiring an <i>eiruv</i> in that location, <b>since after the <i>eiruv</i> has acquired</b> a place of residence <b>for him, it is not important to him that it is guarded.</b> He requires the grave only for the moment of the acquisition of the <i>eiruv</i>, and what happens to it afterward is of no consequence to him. However, here, since one desires the continued presence of the ladder, it is possible that even Rabbi Yehuda would agree that one may not rely on an <i>asheira</i>, as one may not climb and make use of it, since it is prohibited to derive benefit from it.
<b>Or perhaps</b> it may be argued that <b>even</b> though according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> it is prohibited to use a grave to acquire an <i>eiruv</i>, here they would agree that the <i>asheira</i> <b>is an opening, but a lion crouches upon it,</b> and this does not nullify its status as an opening.
Rabba <b>said to him: A tree is permitted</b> for use as a ladder, <b>but an <i>asheira</i> is prohibited. Rav Ḥisda strongly objects to this: On the contrary, a tree,</b> with regard to <b>which a Shabbat prohibition causes it</b> to be prohibited, <b>should be prohibited,</b> so that it will not be said that a Shabbat prohibition has been disregarded in a case involving the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat.
And the converse is also true: <b>An <i>asheira</i>,</b> with regard to <b>which something else,</b> a <i>halakha</i> unrelated to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, <b>causes it</b> to be prohibited, <b>should not be prohibited.</b> Rather, it should be considered an opening with regard to Shabbat.
Indeed, <b>it was also stated: When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Elazar said, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Anything</b> with regard to <b>which a prohibition of Shabbat causes it</b> to be prohibited <b>is prohibited;</b> and conversely, <b>anything</b> with regard to <b>which something else causes it</b> to be prohibited <b>is permitted.</b>
However, in contrast to Rav Yosef, <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak taught as follows:</b> These questions are indeed dependent on the known disputes. Whether <b>a tree</b> serving as a ladder constitutes a valid opening <b>is</b> the subject of <b>a dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and the Rabbis;</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi permits it and the Rabbis prohibit it. The debate with regard to whether or not <b>an <i>asheira</i></b> is considered an opening <b>is</b> the subject of <b>a dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who permits using items from which it is prohibited to derive benefit for the sake of an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>and the Rabbis,</b> who prohibit making an <i>eiruv</i> with such items.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a ditch between</b> two <b>courtyards</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide,</b> it is considered a full-fledged partition, and the residents of the courtyard <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> one for each courtyard, <b>but they</b> may <b>not establish one <i>eiruv</i>. Even</b> if the ditch is <b>filled</b> with <b>straw or hay,</b> it is not regarded as sealed and is therefore not nullified. However, if the ditch is <b>filled with dirt or pebbles,</b> the residents <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>, but they</b> may <b>not establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> as the ditch is nullified and considered nonexistent.
If <b>one placed a board four handbreadths wide across</b> the ditch so that he could cross it, <b>and similarly,</b> if <b>two balconies [<i>gezuztraot</i>]</b> in two different courtyards are <b>opposite one another,</b> and one placed a board four handbreadths wide between them, the residents of the courtyards or balconies <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, and if they desire, they</b> may <b>establish one,</b> as the board serves as an opening and a passageway between them. If the width of the plank is <b>less than</b> four handbreadths, the residents <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, but they</b> may <b>not establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara wonders: Does <b>hay not</b> constitute <b>a</b> proper <b>filling</b> to seal the ditch? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the following mishna: With regard to <b>a haystack ten handbreadths high</b> that stands <b>between two courtyards,</b> the residents of the two courtyards <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, but they</b> may <b>not establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b> This indicates that hay can create a valid partition.
<b>Abaye said</b> that the matter should be understood as follows: <b>With regard to a partition, everyone agrees that</b> hay <b>is a partition</b> and that it divides between the courtyards as long as it is placed there. <b>But with regard to filling</b> the ditch so that it is considered sealed, one must distinguish between two cases: <b>If one</b> explicitly <b>nullified</b> the hay and decided to leave it there, <b>it fills</b> and seals the ditch; <b>however, if he did not nullify it</b> but intends to remove the hay from the ditch, <b>it does not fill</b> it, and the ditch is not considered sealed.
It is written in the mishna: If the ditch is <b>filled with dirt</b> or pebbles, it is considered sealed. The Gemara asks: Does this apply <b>even if one did not specify</b> his intention to leave it there? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna with regard to the ritual impurity of a corpse: If there is <b>a house that one filled with hay or pebbles, and he nullified</b> the hay or pebbles and decided to leave them in the house, then the house (Rambam) <b>is nullified</b> and is no longer considered a house with partitions? Generally, a house containing a corpse is ritually impure on the inside but does not impart impurity to the surrounding area. However, in this case, the house is considered an enclosed grave that imparts ritual impurity to its surroundings.
And one can infer from the mishna: <b>If he nullified</b> the hay or pebbles, <b>yes,</b> the house is nullified and considered sealed.

Daf 79a

However, if <b>he did not nullify it, no,</b> the house retains the status of a house, although it is filled with hay. <b>Rav Huna said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> tractate <b><i>Oholot</i>? It is Rabbi Yosei,</b> and the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna does not accept his opinion.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> that mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> there is a difficulty, since <b>we heard him</b> say <b>the opposite, as it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> In a case where there is a house full of <b>hay and</b> the owner <b>does not intend to remove, it is considered as though</b> it were filled with <b>indeterminate dirt, and it is</b> therefore <b>nullified.</b> However, if the house was full of <b>dirt</b> that <b>he intends to remove, it is considered as though</b> it were filled with <b>indeterminate hay, and it is</b> therefore <b>not nullified.</b> Apparently, the decisive factor for Rabbi Yosei is not the specific material in the house, but whether or not the owner intends to remove it.
<b>Rather, Rav Asi said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> tractate <i>Eiruvin</i>? <b>It is Rabbi Yosei,</b> who does not accept the opinion of the <i>tanna</i> of tractate <i>Oholot</i>.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Are you raising a contradiction</b> between the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual <b>impurity</b> and the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat?</b> These two areas of <i>halakha</i> cannot be compared. <b>Leave</b> aside the <b>prohibition of Shabbat.</b> With regard to Shabbat, <b>a person nullifies even a pouch</b> full of money. The pouch may not be moved on Shabbat and is therefore considered fixed in place. However, hay, which may be moved even on Shabbat, is not considered to be fixed in the ditch. With regard to ritual impurity, by contrast, the nullification must be permanent.
<b>Rav Ashi said: And are you raising a contradiction</b> between the <i>halakha</i> that governs <b>a house</b> and that which governs <b>a ditch? Granted</b> in the case of <b>a ditch,</b> it typically <b>stands to be</b> permanently <b>filled.</b> As there is no doubt that one’s intention is to fill the ditch, the assumption is that anything placed inside a ditch will remain there. <b>However,</b> does <b>a house stand to be</b> permanently <b>filled?</b> Of course it does not. Presumably, the hay and dirt will be removed. Consequently, additional proof is necessary in order to conclude that the owner of the house intends to seal it permanently.
The mishna states: If <b>one placed a plank that is four</b> handbreadths <b>wide</b> across a ditch that separates two courtyards, the plank is considered an entrance. <b>Rava said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one placed</b> the plank <b>along the width</b> of the ditch. <b>But</b> if one positioned a plank <b>along its length, even</b> if the plank is of <b>minimum</b> width, it is <b>also</b> considered an entrance and reduces the ditch, <b>as he reduced</b> the opening <b>to less than four</b> handbreadths. The ditch was originally only four handbreadths wide. Therefore, if one places a plank of any width along its length, it becomes less than four handbreadths wide and no longer constitutes a partition.
The mishna continues: <b>And similarly,</b> if <b>two balconies</b> are <b>opposite each other,</b> and one placed a plank four handbreadths wide between them, the residents of the two courtyards may establish a single <i>eiruv</i>, as the plank is considered an entrance from one courtyard to the other. <b>Rava said: That which you said:</b> If the two balconies are <b>opposite each other, yes,</b> carrying between them is permitted by means of a plank; by inference, if they are <b>not opposite each other, no,</b> carrying is not permitted in this manner, <b>and</b> in a case where <b>one</b> balcony <b>is above the other as well,</b> it is prohibited, as it is not an entrance because it is too dangerous to walk from one to the other by means of the plank. <b>We said</b> the prohibition in these cases <b>only where there is</b> a disparity of at least <b>three</b> handbreadths <b>between this</b> balcony and <b>that</b> balcony. <b>However,</b> if <b>there is</b> a difference of <b>less than three</b> handbreadths <b>between this</b> balcony and <b>that</b> balcony, <b>it</b> is considered a single <b>crooked balcony.</b> Two balconies separated by a gap of less than three handbreadths are considered joined, based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a haystack that is</b> positioned <b>between two courtyards</b> and is <b>ten handbreadths high,</b> it has the status of a partition, <b>and</b> therefore the residents of the courtyards may <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, and they</b> may <b>not establish one <i>eiruv</i>. These,</b> the inhabitants of one courtyard, may <b>feed</b> their animals <b>from here,</b> from one side of the haystack, <b>and those,</b> the inhabitants of the other courtyard, may <b>feed</b> their animals <b>from there,</b> from the other side of the haystack. There is no concern that the haystack might become too small to serve as a partition. If the height of <b>the hay was reduced</b> to less <b>than ten handbreadths</b> across its entire length, its legal status is no longer that of a partition. Consequently, the residents of both courtyards <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>, and they do not establish two <i>eiruvin</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s statement that the inhabitants of the two courtyards are permitted to place their animals next to the haystack and feed them, <b>Rav Huna said: And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>provided that one does not</b> actually <b>put</b> hay <b>into his basket and feed</b> his animals. In that case, there is concern that one might inadvertently reduce the height of the partition to less than ten handbreadths, which would constitute a breach between the courtyards and invalidate both <i>eiruvin</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the actual handling of the hay is prohibited, is it <b>permitted to stand</b> one’s animal next to the haystack and let it eat? <b>Didn’t Rav Huna say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: A person may stand his animal on</b> a patch of <b>grass on Shabbat,</b> as he will certainly be careful not to pull out grass for the animal, due to the severity of the Torah prohibition involved. However, <b>a person may not stand his animal on set-aside</b> items <b>on Shabbat.</b> As the prohibition of set-aside is rabbinic in origin, he might forget and move the set-aside objects himself. The same reasoning should apply in the case of the haystack. If it is prohibited by rabbinic decree to remove hay from the stack manually, it should likewise be prohibited to position one’s animal alongside the stack.
The Gemara answers: The mishna is not referring to a case where one directly brings the animal and places it alongside the haystack. Rather, it is dealing with a situation <b>where one stands in front of</b> the animal so that it cannot go elsewhere, <b>and it goes and eats</b> from the haystack of its own accord. In that case, the rabbinic decree does not apply.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to Rav Huna’s statement itself: <b>And may one not put hay into his basket</b> and feed his animal? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a house that is</b> positioned <b>between two courtyards and</b> the residents <b>filled it with hay,</b> they <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, but</b> they <b>do not establish one <i>eiruv</i>,</b> as the hay is considered a partition that divides the house. The resident of <b>this</b> courtyard <b>puts</b> hay <b>into his basket and feeds</b> his animal, <b>and</b> the resident of <b>that</b> courtyard <b>puts</b> hay <b>into his basket and feeds</b> his animal. <b>If the hay was reduced</b> to a height less <b>than ten handbreadths,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for residents of <b>both</b> to carry in their respective courtyards.
<b>How,</b> then, <b>does</b> the resident of one of the courtyards <b>act</b> if he seeks to permit use of the other courtyard to its resident? He <b>locks his house and renounces his right</b> to carry in the courtyard in favor of the other person. Consequently, <b>it is prohibited</b> for him to carry from his house into the courtyard, <b>and it is permitted</b> for <b>the other</b> resident to do so.
<b>And you say likewise with regard to a pit [<i>gov</i>] of hay that</b> is positioned <b>between two Shabbat limits.</b> The residents of each area may feed their animals from the common hay, as there is no concern lest the animals go beyond the limit. <b>In any case,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> The resident of <b>this</b> courtyard <b>puts</b> hay <b>into his basket and feeds</b> his animal, <b>and</b> the resident of <b>that</b> courtyard <b>puts</b> hay <b>into his basket and feeds</b> his animal. This <i>halakha</i> poses a difficulty to Rav Huna’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: <b>We</b> can <b>say</b> that in the case of <b>a house, since it has walls and a ceiling, when</b> the height of the haystack <b>is reduced the matter is conspicuous.</b> The height disparity between the haystack and the ceiling is obvious. Consequently, when the haystack is reduced to less than ten handbreadths, people will stop carrying in the courtyard. <b>Here,</b> however, with regard to the hay in the pit, the difference in height <b>is not conspicuous.</b> The height of the hay in the pit could become diminished to the extent that the partition is nullified without anyone noticing.
It is stated in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> the height of <b>the hay was reduced</b> to less <b>than ten handbreadths</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> to carry in <b>both</b> courtyards. The Gemara infers from the phrasing of the <i>baraita</i>: If the hay was at least <b>ten</b> handbreadths high, it is <b>permitted</b> to carry there, even though the <b>ceiling is much higher</b> than the hay. <b>Conclude from it</b> that the legal <b>status of</b> ten-handbreadth <b>partitions that do not reach the ceiling is that of</b> standard <b>partitions,</b> which was the subject of a dispute elsewhere. Apparently, this <i>baraita</i> proves that they have the status of partitions in all respects.
<b>Abaye said: Here, we are dealing with</b> the case of a <b>house</b> that is <b>slightly less than thirteen</b> handbreadths high <b>and the hay</b> is <b>ten</b> handbreadths high. The haystack is less than three handbreadths from the ceiling, and based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>, they are considered joined as though the partitions reach the ceiling.
<b>And Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with a house ten</b> handbreadths high,

Daf 79b

<b>and</b> the <b>hay</b> in the house is <b>slightly more than seven</b> handbreadths high it is considered a full-fledged partition that reaches the ceiling, as objects separated by <b>any</b> gap of <b>less than three</b> handbreadths <b>are considered joined,</b> based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>.
The Gemara comments. <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye, that is why</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> If the height of the haystack was reduced to less <b>than ten</b> handbreadths. <b>However, according to Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, what is</b> the meaning of: Less <b>than ten?</b> Even at the outset it was never as high as ten handbreadths.
The Gemara answers: It means that it was reduced to less <b>than the law of ten</b> handbreadths. As long as the hay is slightly more than seven handbreadths high, it is regarded as ten handbreadths high, in accordance with the principle of <i>lavud</i>. Once its height is reduced to less than seven handbreadths, the <i>halakha</i> of a partition ten handbreadths high is no longer in effect.
The same <i>baraita</i> taught that if the height of the hay was reduced to less than ten handbreadths, it is <b>prohibited</b> to carry in <b>both.</b> The Gemara comments: Should we <b>learn from this</b> that <b>residents who arrive on Shabbat prohibit</b> the other residents from carrying? At the onset of Shabbat, both sets of residents were permitted to use the hay and the house, but once the hay was reduced on Shabbat it is as though new residents had been added to each of the courtyards, and it is prohibited for all of them to carry. Why not say that since at the beginning of Shabbat it was permitted to carry in the domain, they are permitted to do so for its duration?
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the hay <b>was</b> already <b>reduced on the previous day,</b> before Shabbat began. In that case, it was never permitted to carry at all.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>How,</b> then, <b>does</b> the resident of one of the courtyards <b>act</b> if he seeks to permit use of the other courtyard to its resident? He <b>locks his house and renounces his right</b> to carry in the courtyard in favor of the other person. The Gemara is surprised by this ruling: Does he require these <b>two</b> steps? One should suffice. The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Either he locks his house or he renounces his right</b> to the courtyard.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> a different explanation instead. <b>Actually, both</b> actions are required in this case, even though one of them would ordinarily suffice. The reason is: <b>Since he is accustomed to</b> using the courtyard, <b>he will come to carry.</b> Consequently, the Sages were stringent with a person in this position and obligated him to implement an additional change so that he will not forget and come to carry when it is prohibited.
It was taught in the <i>baraita</i>: If one locks his house and renounces his rights to the courtyard, <b>it is prohibited</b> for him to carry, <b>and it is permitted</b> for <b>the other</b> person to carry. The Gemara raises a difficulty: Isn’t this <b>obvious?</b> Why was it necessary to state this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary only</b> in a case <b>where the other</b> person <b>then renounced</b> his right in favor <b>of the first</b> person. <b>And</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that</b> one <b>may not renounce</b> his rights in favor of the other, <b>and then</b> have the latter <b>renounce</b> his own rights in favor of the former.
It was further taught in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And you</b> can <b>say likewise with regard to a pit of hay that</b> is situated <b>between two Shabbat limits.</b> The inhabitants of each area may feed their animals from the common hay. The Gemara raises a difficulty: Isn’t this <b>obvious?</b> The same principle that is in effect with regard to a haystack between courtyards should apply here as well. The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> only <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> that the principle of Shabbat <b>boundaries</b> is <b>by Torah law. Lest you say</b> that <b>let us issue a decree</b> and prohibit it, <b>lest</b> people <b>come to exchange</b> objects from one boundary to another, which would violate a Torah prohibition; therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that no distinction is made between the cases, and no decree of this kind is issued.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>How does one merge</b> the courtyards that open <b>into the alleyway,</b> if a person wishes to act on behalf of all the residents of the alleyway? <b>He places a barrel</b> filled with his own food <b>and says: This is for all the residents of the alleyway.</b> For this gift to be acquired by the others, someone must accept it on their behalf, <b>and</b> the <i>tanna</i> therefore teaches that <b>he</b> may <b>confer possession to them</b> even <b>by means of his adult son or daughter, and</b> likewise <b>by means of his Hebrew slave or maidservant,</b> whom he does not own, <b>and by means of his wife.</b> These people may acquire the <i>eiruv</i> on behalf of all the residents of the alleyway.
<b>However, he</b> may <b>not confer possession by means of his minor son or daughter, nor by means of his Canaanite slave or maidservant, because</b> they cannot effect acquisition, as ownership of objects that come into <b>their possession is as</b> if those objects came into <b>his possession.</b> Consequently, the master or father cannot confer possession to the slave or minor respectively on behalf of others as their acquisition is ineffective and the object remains in his own possession.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> With regard to <b>a barrel for the merging of alleyways,</b> the one acquiring it on behalf of the alleyway’s residents <b>must raise</b> it <b>a handbreadth from the ground,</b> as he must perform a valid act of acquisition on their behalf.
<b>Rava said: The elders of Pumbedita,</b> Rav Yehuda and his students, <b>stated these two matters. One</b> was <b>this</b> mentioned above with regard to lifting the barrel; and <b>the other</b> was: With regard to <b>one who recites <i>kiddush</i></b> over wine on Shabbat or a Festival, <b>if he tasted a mouthful</b> of wine, <b>he fulfilled</b> his obligation; <b>however, if</b> he did <b>not</b> taste a mouthful, <b>he did not fulfill</b> his obligation.
<b>Rav Ḥaviva said:</b> In addition to the aforementioned pair of teachings, <b>the elders of Pumbedita stated this too, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One builds a fire for a woman in childbirth on Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara comments that the Sages <b>thought</b> to infer <b>from here: For a woman in childbirth, yes,</b> one builds a fire, due to her highly precarious state; <b>for a sick person, no,</b> one does not build a fire. Likewise, <b>in the rainy season,</b> when the danger of catching cold is ever present, <b>yes,</b> one builds a fire; <b>in the summer, no,</b> one may not.
The Gemara adds that which <b>was stated: Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to one who <b>let blood and caught cold, one builds a fire for him on Shabbat, even during the season of Tammuz,</b> i.e., the summer. Clearly, Rav Yehuda’s ruling is limited neither to a woman in childbirth nor to the rainy season.
<b>Ameimar said: This too was stated by the elders of Pumbedita, as it was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to <b>which</b> tree <b>is presumed</b> to be <b>a tree designated for idolatry [<i>asheira</i>],</b> even though no one actually saw it worshipped.
<b>Rav said: It is any</b> tree <b>that</b> idolatrous <b>priests guard.</b>

Daf 80a

<b>and whose fruit they do not taste.</b> This tree is evidently consecrated to the cult.
<b>And Shmuel said: For example, if they say: These dates are for the beer of the temple of Nitzrefei, which they drink on the day of their festival,</b> then this is enough to establish the tree as an <i>asheira</i>. <b>Ameimar said: And the elders of Pumbedita said to me</b> with regard to this issue: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b>
The Gemara returns to Rav Yehuda’s ruling that the barrel used for merging the alleyway must be raised a handbreadth from the ground. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does one merge an alleyway? One brings a barrel of wine, or oil, or dates, or dried figs, or any other type of produce</b> for merging the alleyway.
<b>If</b> one contributed a barrel <b>of his own, he must confer possession</b> to all the other residents by means of another person who acquires it on their behalf. <b>And if</b> the barrel <b>is theirs, he must</b> at least <b>inform</b> them that he is merging the alleyway. <b>And</b> the one acquiring it on behalf of the others <b>raises</b> the barrel <b>a minimal amount from the ground.</b> Apparently, the barrel need not be raised a handbreadth. The Gemara answers: Here <b>too, what is</b> this <b>minimal amount of which</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>spoke?</b> This expression means <b>a handbreadth,</b> but no less.
<b>It is stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the acquisition of a <b>merging of alleyways. Rav said: It is not necessary to confer possession</b> of the food used in merging the alleyway to all the residents of the alleyway; <b>and Shmuel said: It is necessary to confer possession</b> to them. They likewise disagreed with regard to a <b>joining of</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries,</b> but the opinions are reversed. <b>Rav said: It is necessary to confer possession</b> of the food to all those who wish to be included in the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>and Shmuel said: It is not necessary to confer possession</b> to them.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> his reasoning is clear, as <b>here,</b> with regard to a merging of the alleyways, <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that he must confer possession, <b>whereas there,</b> with regard to a joining of Shabbat boundaries, <b>we did not learn</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>. <b>However, according to Rav, what is the reason</b> that he differentiates between the cases in this manner?
The Gemara answers: <b>This is</b> the subject of a dispute between <b>the <i>tanna’im</i>, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving</b> the <b>daughter-in-law of Rabbi Oshaya, who went</b> before Shabbat <b>to the bathhouse,</b> which was located beyond the Shabbat boundary, <b>and it grew dark</b> before <b>she</b> was able to return, <b>and her mother-in-law established a joining</b> of Shabbat boundaries for her so that she could return home.
<b>And the incident came before Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> for a ruling as to whether the <i>eiruv</i> is valid, <b>and he</b> ruled that it was not valid and <b>prohibited</b> her return. <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said to him: Babylonian, are you so stringent with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>? This</b> is what my <b>father said: Any</b> case <b>where you have</b> the ability <b>to be lenient with regard to an <i>eiruv</i>, be lenient.</b>
<b>And a dilemma was raised</b> before the Sages: Did the mother-in-law <b>establish the <i>eiruv</i> for</b> her daughter-in-law <b>with the mother-in-law’s</b> food, and Rabbi Ḥiyya prohibited it <b>because she did not confer possession to her,</b> i.e., she merely prepared the <i>eiruv</i> but did not confer possession of the food, and an <i>eiruv</i> of this kind is not effective? <b>Or perhaps she established the <i>eiruv</i> for her with the</b> daughter-in-law’s <b>own</b> food, but the <i>eiruv</i> was invalid <b>because</b> it was prepared <b>without her knowledge?</b>
<b>One of the Sages, named Rabbi Ya’akov, said to them: It was</b> personally <b>explained to me by Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that the mother-in-law <b>established the <i>eiruv</i> for her with the mother-in-law’s</b> food, <b>and</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya prohibited it <b>because she did not confer possession</b> of the food <b>to her.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Ya’akov, son of the daughter of Ya’akov: When you go there,</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>take a roundabout</b> route, i.e., do not travel by the shortest path, <b>and go to the Ladder of Tyre and raise</b> this <b>dilemma before Rav Ya’akov bar Idi.</b>
Rabbi Ya’akov did so and <b>raised a dilemma before him:</b> With regard to that incident, did the mother-in-law <b>establish the <i>eiruv</i> for</b> her daughter-in-law <b>from the mother-in-law’s</b> food, <b>and</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya prohibited it <b>because she did not confer possession</b> of the food <b>to her? Or perhaps she established the <i>eiruv</i> for her with</b> the daughter-in-law’s <b>own</b> food, but the <i>eiruv</i> was invalidated <b>because</b> it was prepared <b>without her knowledge?</b>
Rav Ya’akov bar Idi <b>said to him:</b> The mother-in-law <b>established the <i>eiruv</i> for her with the mother-in-law’s</b> food, and Rabbi Ḥiyya prohibited it <b>because she did not confer possession</b> of the food <b>to her.</b> Like his master and uncle, Rabbi Ḥiyya, Rav also maintains that possession of the food must be conferred upon those who wish to be included in a joining of Shabbat boundaries.
<b>Rav Naḥman said: We hold based on tradition that</b> with regard to <b>all</b> of them, <b>joining of</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries, joining of courtyards, and merging of alleyways, it is necessary to confer possession.</b> After issuing this statement, <b>Rav Naḥman raised a dilemma</b> concerning an issue that was not sufficiently clear to him: With regard to <b>a joining of cooked foods</b> [<b><i>eiruv tavshilin</i>],</b> which must be prepared in order to permit cooking for Shabbat on a Festival that occurs on a Friday, <b>is it necessary to confer possession, or is it not necessary to confer possession?</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: What is his dilemma?</b> Did <b>he not hear that which Rav Naḥman bar Rav Adda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>a joining of cooked foods, it is necessary to confer possession? Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: It is <b>obvious that he did not hear</b> that ruling, <b>as had he heard it, why would he have raised this dilemma?</b>
Rav Yosef <b>said to him: Didn’t Shmuel say,</b> with regard to a <b>joining of</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries,</b> that <b>it is not necessary to confer possession, and</b> Rav Naḥman nonetheless <b>said</b> that <b>it is necessary to confer possession?</b> Perhaps here too Rav Naḥman did not accept Shmuel’s ruling.
Abaye replied: <b>How can you compare</b> the two cases? <b>Granted, there,</b> with regard to a merging of alleyways and a joining of Shabbat boundaries, <b>Rav and Shmuel disagree, and</b> Rav Naḥman <b>teaches us</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance <b>with the stringency of</b> this <b>master and the stringency of</b> that <b>master,</b> i.e., his ruling is based on both opinions. <b>However, here,</b> with regard to a joining of cooked foods, <b>if it is so,</b> if <b>he</b> actually <b>heard</b> Shmuel’s ruling, <b>is there anyone who disputes</b> it? If one of his teachers issued an uncontested ruling, it is presumably an established <i>halakha</i>.
<b>A certain</b> gentile <b>superintendent [<i>turzina</i>] lived in Rabbi Zeira’s neighborhood.</b> The neighbors <b>said to him: Rent your domain to us</b> so that we may carry on Shabbat. However, <b>he would not rent</b> it <b>to them. They came before Rabbi Zeira and asked him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if we seek <b>to rent</b> the domain <b>from his wife</b> without her husband’s knowledge?
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to them: Reish Lakish said as follows in the name of a great man, and who is</b> this great man? It is <b>Rabbi Ḥanina.</b> He stated: <b>A man’s wife may establish an <i>eiruv</i> without his knowledge.</b> According to this principle, the superintendent’s wife could indeed rent out the domain without his knowledge.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: <b>A certain superintendent lived in the neighborhood of Rav Yehuda bar Oshaya.</b> The neighbors <b>said to him: Rent your domain to us</b> so that we may establish an <i>eiruv</i> and carry on Shabbat, but <b>he would not rent</b> it <b>to them. They came before Rav Yehuda bar Oshaya</b> and <b>said to him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if we seek <b>to rent</b> it <b>from his wife? He did not have</b> a ready answer <b>at hand. They</b> subsequently <b>came before Rav Mattana,</b> and <b>he</b> too <b>did not have</b> an answer <b>at hand. They came before Rav Yehuda,</b> who <b>said to them</b> that <b>Shmuel said as follows: A man’s wife may establish an <i>eiruv</i> without his knowledge,</b> and the same applies to renting out his property.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Women who joined</b> the courtyards <b>or merged the alleyways without the knowledge of their husbands, their <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>, and their merging</b> of alleyways <b>is not a</b> valid <b>merging.</b> How can Shmuel rule against an explicit <i>baraita</i>?
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult.</b> In <b>this</b> case, where Shmuel said that a wife may establish an <i>eiruv</i> without her husband’s knowledge, he was referring to a situation where the husband <b>would prohibit</b> his neighbors from carrying if he did not join their <i>eiruv</i>, and the <i>halakha</i> is therefore lenient, as a wife may establish an <i>eiruv</i> on his behalf. However, in <b>that</b> case, the <i>baraita</i>, which states that his wife may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> without his knowledge, is referring to a situation where <b>he would not prohibit</b> his neighbors from carrying.
The Gemara adds: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> that this is the correct interpretation, <b>as if</b> you do not say <b>this,</b> there is <b>a contradiction between</b> this ruling <b>of Shmuel and</b> another ruling <b>of Shmuel. As Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>one of the residents of an alleyway who was accustomed to join in a merging of alleyways with the</b> other <b>residents of</b> the <b>alleyway, but</b> one Shabbat <b>he did not join in a merging of alleyways</b> with them, <b>the</b> other <b>residents of the alleyway</b> may <b>enter his house and take</b> his contribution to <b>their merging of alleyways from him</b> even <b>against his will.</b>
The Gemara infers: If he was <b>accustomed</b> to join in their merging of the alleyway, <b>yes,</b> they may enter his house to collect his contribution, but if he was <b>not accustomed</b> to do so, <b>no,</b> they may not do so. Clearly, it is not possible in all cases to compel a person to participate in a merging of alleyways against his will. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that it is so.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports him.</b> The residents of an alleyway may <b>compel</b> anyone who lives in the alleyway <b>to erect a side post and a</b> cross <b>beam for the alleyway.</b> This teaching indicates that with regard to these Shabbat enactments, a person’s wishes are not taken into account; rather, others may act on his behalf even against his will.

Daf 80b

The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there, as there are no partitions.</b> That alley is breached, and it is therefore fitting to compel its residents to establish some sort of partition, if only for the sake of protection. However, if there are partitions, one is not obligated to join in a merging of alleyways.
<b>Another version</b> of this explanation: <b>From the side it is different,</b> i.e., the preparation of an <i>eiruv</i> does not involve an adjustment to the alleyway itself, but rather it is a side issue. Consequently, an individual cannot be forced to participate in its preparation (<i>Meir Netiv</i>).
<b>It is stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disputed this issue. <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said: One</b> may <b>build a side post</b> from the wood of <b>an <i>asheira</i>.</b> Although it is prohibited to benefit from the tree and it must be burned, setting up a side post is a mitzva, and mitzvot were not given for benefit, i.e., the fulfillment of a mitzva is not in itself considered a benefit. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: One</b> may <b>build a</b> cross <b>beam</b> from the wood of <b>an <i>asheira</i>.</b>
The Gemara clarifies their opinions: With regard to <b>the one who said</b> that one may build <b>a</b> cross <b>beam</b> from the wood of an <i>asheira</i>, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, <b>all the more so</b> he would permit <b>a side post</b> to be prepared from an <i>asheira</i>. <b>And the one who said</b> that one may build a <b>side post</b> from an <i>asheira</i>, Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, spoke only of a side post; <b>but</b> as for <b>a</b> cross <b>beam, no,</b> he did not permit one to build it from an <i>asheira</i>. The reason is that an <i>asheira</i> must be burned, and it is therefore as though <b>its size has</b> already <b>been crushed.</b> Consequently, a cross beam, which must be at least a handbreadth in size, may not be prepared from an <i>asheira</i>. With regard to a side post, by contrast, a minimum width suffices, which means that even wood from an <i>asheira</i> is fit, despite the fact that it is viewed as burned.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>If the food</b> in the barrel for the merging of the alleyway <b>diminished</b> and was less than the requisite measure, <b>one</b> may <b>add</b> a little of his own <b>and confer possession</b> to the others, <b>and he need not inform</b> them of his addition. However, if new residents <b>were added to</b> the residents of the alleyway, <b>he may add</b> food on behalf of those residents <b>and confer possession</b> to them, <b>and he must inform</b> the new residents of their inclusion in the merging of alleyways.
<b>What is the measure</b> of food required for a merging of the alleyways? <b>When</b> the residents of the alley <b>are numerous, food for two meals</b> is sufficient <b>for all of them; when they are few,</b> less than a certain number, <b>a dried fig-bulk for each and every one of them</b> is enough.
<b>Rabbi Yosei said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to the beginning of an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> when it is initially established. <b>However, with regard to the remnants of an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> e.g., if the <i>eiruv</i> decreased in size on Shabbat, it remains valid if even <b>any amount</b> remains.
<b>And</b> in general <b>they said</b> that it is necessary <b>to join the courtyards,</b> even though a merging of the alleyways was already in place, <b>only so that</b> the halakhic category of <i>eiruv</i> <b>will not be forgotten by the children,</b> i.e., so that the next generation should be aware that an <i>eiruv</i> can be established for a courtyard, for otherwise they would be entirely unaware of this halakhic category.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna stated: If the food in the barrel for the merging of the alleyway diminished and was less than the requisite measure, one may add to it without informing the others. The Gemara poses a question: <b>With what</b> case <b>are we dealing</b> here? <b>If you say</b> that he added <b>the same type</b> of food that had initially been used for the merging of the alleyway, <b>why specify</b> this particular case where the food <b>decreased</b> in measure? <b>Even if</b> the food <b>was</b> entirely <b>finished,</b> he should <b>likewise</b> not be obligated to inform them.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps it is referring <b>to two types</b> of food, i.e., one added a different kind of food that had not been used beforehand. If so, <b>even if it</b> only <b>decreased</b> in measure, <b>no,</b> he should <b>also</b> not be permitted to add to the merging of the alleyway without informing them. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If the food</b> of a merging of the alleyway <b>was</b> entirely <b>finished,</b> and he added <b>the same type</b> of food to it, <b>he need not inform</b> the other residents; however, if the amount he added was <b>from two types</b> of food, i.e., if the added food was different from the original, <b>he must inform</b> them. The Gemara assumes that the same <i>halakha</i> is in effect even if the food of the merging of the alleyway only decreased in measure.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case where his addition was <b>from the same kind</b> of food, <b>and if you wish, say</b> instead that it was <b>from two kinds.</b> The Gemara clarifies the previous statement: <b>If you wish, say</b> that it is referring to a case where his addition was <b>from the same kind</b> of food, and <b>what</b> is the meaning of <b>decreased?</b> It means that the food entirely <b>crumbled away,</b> so that nothing at all remained.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the mishna is referring to a case where his addition was <b>from two kinds</b> of food, for if the <i>eiruv</i> <b>was</b> entirely <b>finished,</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is different.</b> That is to say, the <i>halakha</i> of the <i>baraita</i> that he must inform the others is in effect only if the food was entirely finished, but if any of it remains there is no need to inform them of his addition, and he may confer possession of even a different kind of food.
We learned in the mishna: If other residents <b>were added to</b> the residents of the alleyway, <b>he may add</b> food for those residents <b>and confer possession</b> to them, but he must inform the new residents of their inclusion in the merging of the alleyway. <b>Rav Sheizvi said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: That is to say,</b> i.e., we can infer from the mishna, that <b>Rabbi Yehuda’s colleagues disagree with him.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that an <i>eiruv</i> may be established for a person only with his knowledge, <b>said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to a joining of</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries; however, with regard to a joining of courtyards, one</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for another person either <b>with his knowledge or without his knowledge.</b> Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion conflicts with that of the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna, who does not permit a person to be included in a joining of courtyards without his knowledge. The Gemara is surprised at this statement: <b>It is obvious</b> that <b>they disagree;</b> why did Rav Ḥisda find it necessary to teach us something so evident?
The Gemara answers: It was nonetheless necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>this</b> ruling, i.e., that he must inform them, <b>applies only to a courtyard that is</b> situated <b>between two alleyways,</b> in which case the residents of the courtyard may join in a merging of alleyways with whichever alleyway they prefer. Consequently, he must inform them with which alleyway he prepared the merging, in case they preferred to join the other alleyway. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a courtyard</b> that opens into only <b>one alleyway,</b> the merging of the alleyway only benefits them and does not harm them in any way, and you might therefore <b>say no,</b> that even the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna concedes that it is not necessary to inform them. Rav Ḥisda therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna maintains that he must inform them in all cases, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
The mishna continues: <b>What is the measure</b> of food required for a merging of the alleyways? It then specifies different amounts when the residents of the alley are numerous and when they are few. The Gemara asks: <b>How many are numerous,</b> and how many are considered few? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Eighteen people</b> are considered numerous. The Gemara registers surprise: <b>Eighteen and no more?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Say: From eighteen upward.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is</b> the significance of the number <b>eighteen</b> that <b>he cited?</b> Why this figure in particular? The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Yehuda, said: It was explained to me</b> personally <b>by my father,</b> Rav Yehuda: <b>Any</b> case where, <b>if</b> one were to <b>divide</b> the food of <b>two meals between them and it does not amount to</b> the measure of <b>a dried fig for each and every one of them, these are the very ones</b> the <i>tanna</i> called <b>numerous, and</b> in this case <b>food for two meals suffices</b> for all of them. <b>And if not, these are the very ones</b> the <i>tanna</i> termed <b>few,</b> which means food in the measure of a dried fig is required for each of them.
And Rav Yehuda <b>incidentally teaches us that</b> food for <b>two meals consists of</b> a measure equal to <b>eighteen dried figs.</b> Consequently, if there were numerous residents in the alley, then eighteen dried figs, which is food sufficient for two meals, is enough for them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One</b> may <b>join</b> courtyards <b>and merge</b> alleyways <b>with all</b> types of food, <b>except for water and salt,</b> as they are not considered foods. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehoshua says</b> that a different limitation applies: A whole <b>loaf</b> may be used for <b>an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> With regard to <b>a baked</b> product even the size <b>of a <i>se’a</i>, if it</b> consists of <b>pieces, one</b> may <b>not join</b> courtyards <b>with it.</b> However, with regard to <b>a loaf,</b> even one the size of <b>an <i>issar</i>, if it is whole, one</b> may <b>join</b> courtyards <b>with it.</b>

Daf 81a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s ruling concerning the foods which may or may not be used for an <i>eiruv</i> and to merge alleyways, the Gemara poses a question: This ruling is apparently superfluous, as we have already <b>learned</b> it <b>once</b> before in another mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> and a merging of alleyways with all</b> kinds of food, <b>except for water and salt.</b>
<b>Rabba said:</b> This addition comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> in the mishna, who <b>said</b> that <b>a loaf, yes,</b> it may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>; but <b>anything else, no,</b> other foods may not be used. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that an <i>eiruv</i> may be established <b>with all</b> kinds of food, not only bread.
<b>Abaye raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>establish a joining of courtyards with all</b> kinds of food, <b>and</b> likewise <b>one may establish a merging of alleyways with all</b> kinds of food. <b>They said</b> that <b>one</b> must <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with bread only with regard to</b> an <i>eiruv</i> of <b>a courtyard. Who did you hear that said</b> that <b>bread, yes,</b> it may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, but <b>anything else, no,</b> it may not be used? It was <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, and</b> yet the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: With all</b> kinds of food. This proves that the phrase: One may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with all kinds of food, does not necessarily exclude Rabbi Yehoshua’s opinion.
<b>Rather, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said:</b> It comes <b>to exclude</b> a different aspect of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, as</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said: A whole</b> loaf, <b>yes,</b> it is fit to be used as an <i>eiruv</i>, but <b>a broken</b> loaf, <b>no,</b> it is not suitable for this purpose. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that one may prepare an <i>eiruv</i> <b>with all</b> kinds of bread, even a broken loaf.
The Gemara analyzes Rabbi Yehoshua’s position itself: <b>And</b> with regard to a <b>broken</b> loaf of bread, <b>what is the reason</b> that it may <b>not</b> be used for an <i>eiruv</i>? <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul said</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> The reason is <b>due to</b> potential <b>enmity</b> between neighbors. To avoid a situation where one person says to the other: You contributed a mere slice of bread, while I donated an entire loaf, the Sages instituted that each person should provide a whole loaf.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> If <b>they all established</b> the <b><i>eiruv</i> with broken</b> loaves of bread, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? In this case there is no cause for enmity. Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> There is nonetheless a concern <b>lest the problem recur,</b> as one of them might give an entire loaf and proceed to complain about his neighbor who donated only a partial loaf.
A portion of dough, known as <i>ḥalla</i>, must be set aside and given to the priests. If <i>ḥalla</i> was not set aside from the dough, it must be separated from the baked bread. Moreover, if one part <i>teruma</i> fell into a hundred parts non-sacred produce, a proportionate amount must be removed from the mixture and given to a priest, after which the remainder may be eaten. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Shaul said: If one removed from</b> the loaf <b>as much as</b> must be set aside for <b>its <i>ḥalla</i>, or as much as</b> must be separated <b>from a mixture</b> of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce, <b>he</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with</b> that loaf. The reason is that in this case people would not complain that he did not give a whole loaf, as they would assume the loaf had a small part missing because <i>ḥalla</i> had been separated from it, or because <i>teruma</i> had fallen into the dough, which necessitated the separation of a certain portion. However, if more than this amount was missing, people would suspect him of eating from the <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Wasn’t it was taught</b> otherwise in a <i>baraita</i>: If a loaf was missing <b>as much as</b> must be removed <b>from a mixture</b> of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce, <b>one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> with it,</b> but if it was missing <b>as much as</b> must be removed for <b>its <i>ḥalla</i>, one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with it?</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as the two sources are not dealing with the same amounts. In <b>this</b> case, where the <i>tanna</i> permitted a loaf that was missing the amount that must be removed for <i>ḥalla</i>, he is referring <b>to a baker’s <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> which is a smaller amount and is therefore not considered a significant reduction of the loaf. However, in <b>that</b> case, where the <i>tanna</i> did not permit a loaf that was lacking the amount that must be removed for <i>ḥalla</i>, it is referring <b>to an</b> ordinary <b>homeowner’s <i>ḥalla</i>.</b> This <i>ḥalla</i> portion is larger in size, and consequently the loaf may not be used for an <i>eiruv</i> if it is missing such a large amount.
The Gemara explains that this is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The measure of <i>ḥalla</i></b> fixed by the Sages is <b>one twenty-fourth</b> of the dough. Consequently, <b>one who prepares dough for himself or dough for his son’s</b> wedding <b>feast,</b> the measure for <i>ḥalla</i> is <b>one twenty-fourth.</b> However, <b>a baker who prepares</b> dough <b>for sale in the market, and likewise a woman who prepares</b> dough <b>for sale in the market,</b> is required to separate only <b>one forty-eighth</b> of the dough, as the Sages were lenient with those who sell their wares so that they should not suffer loss.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> With regard to <b>one who connected</b> the two portions of a broken loaf <b>with a</b> wood <b>chip, one</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with it,</b> as it looks whole. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a case of this kind that <b>one</b> may <b>not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with it?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as in <b>this</b> case, where it may not be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, we are dealing with a situation <b>where the seam is conspicuous;</b> however, in <b>that</b> case, where it may be used for an <i>eiruv</i>, the reference is to a situation <b>where the seam is not conspicuous.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> even <b>with rice bread or with millet bread. Mar Ukva said:</b> This ruling <b>was explained to me by Mar Shmuel</b> himself. <b>With rice bread one</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i>, but with millet bread one</b> may <b>not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> as it is difficult to bake edible bread out of millet.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said</b> that <b>Rav said: One</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> with lentil bread.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Is that so?</b> Is such bread edible? <b>But there was that</b> lentil bread <b>in the days of Mar Shmuel, which he threw to his dog, and</b> even <b>it would not eat it.</b> Clearly, lentil bread is not fit for human consumption.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> bread which the dog refused to eat <b>was</b> a mixture of <b>various types</b> of grain. It was baked in order to discover the taste of a bread of mixed ingredients and was similar to that which the prophet Ezekiel was commanded to eat, as it is written: <b>“Take you for yourself wheat, and barley, and beans, and lentils, and millet, and spelt,</b> and put them in one vessel, and make them for yourself into bread” (Ezekiel 4:9). This bread is unfit for human consumption, as even a dog at times will not eat it. However, bread prepared from lentils alone is edible.
<b>Rav Pappa said: That</b> bread of Ezekiel’s <b>was roasted in human excrement, as it is written:</b> “And you shall eat it as barley cakes, <b>and you shall bake it with human excrement, in their sight”</b> (Ezekiel 4:12).
Having mentioned this verse, the Gemara asks a related question: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>“And you shall eat it as barley [<i>seorim</i>] cakes”? Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The verse means that he should eat it <b>in</b> small <b>measures [<i>leshiurim</i>],</b> not as a satisfying meal. <b>Rav Pappa said: Its preparation</b> must be <b>like the preparation of barley</b> bread, coarse bread with regard to which one invests little effort, <b>and not like the preparation of wheat</b> bread.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person</b> may <b>give a <i>ma’a</i></b> coin <b>to a grocer or a baker,</b> if they live in the same alleyway or courtyard, <b>so that</b> the grocer or baker <b>will confer upon him possession</b> of wine or bread <b>for</b> a merging of the alleyway or <b>an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> if other residents come to them to purchase these products for that purpose. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: His money did not confer possession on him,</b> as the transfer of money alone is not a valid mode of acquisition and cannot confer possession. One must perform a valid mode of acquisition, e.g., pulling an article into one’s possession, to transfer ownership.

Daf 81b

<b>And</b> the Rabbis <b>concede with regard to all</b> other <b>people,</b> apart from grocers and bakers, <b>that</b> if one gave them money for the food of an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>his money confers possession upon him, as one</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i> for a person only with his knowledge</b> and at his bidding. With regard to a grocer or baker, the person giving the money does not intend to appoint the grocer or the baker as his agent and the money itself does not effect an acquisition, and consequently, he did not accomplish anything. With regard to anyone else, however, there is no doubt that he must have intended to appoint him his agent, and his act is effective.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: In what case is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to a joining of</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries, but with regard to a joining of courtyards, one</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for a person either <b>with his knowledge or without his knowledge.</b> The reason is <b>because one may act for a person’s benefit in his absence, but one may not act to a person’s disadvantage in his absence.</b> As a participant in a joining of courtyards benefits from his inclusion in the <i>eiruv</i>, his consent is not required. However, with regard to a joining of Shabbat boundaries, although it enables one to go farther in one direction, he loses the option of traveling in the opposite direction. When an action is to a person’s disadvantage, or if it entails both benefits and disadvantages, one may act on that person’s behalf only if he has been explicitly appointed his agent.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara poses a question: <b>What is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion that one who gave money to a grocer or a baker has acquired possession of the food for the <i>eiruv</i>? This ruling is difficult, as <b>he did not</b> perform a transaction by <b>pulling</b> the food into his possession, and one can acquire an object only by performing a valid act of acquisition.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Abbahu said: Rabbi Eliezer established</b> this acquisition so that it should be <b>like the four times during the year</b> that the payment of money effects acquisition, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>On these four times</b> every year, on the eves of Passover, <i>Shavuot</i>, Rosh HaShana, and the Eighth Day of Assembly, one who paid for meat may <b>force the butcher to slaughter</b> an animal against his will. <b>Even</b> if his <b>ox</b> was <b>worth a thousand dinar, and the customer has</b> paid for <b>only one dinar’s</b> worth of meat, the customer may <b>force</b> the butcher <b>to slaughter</b> it, so that the buyer can receive his meat. The reason is that on these four occasions everyone buys meat, and therefore the butcher who promised to supply the customer with meat must give it to him, even if this causes the butcher a considerable loss.
<b>Therefore, if</b> the ox <b>died, it died at the buyer’s</b> expense. That is to say, he must bear the loss and is not entitled to get his dinar back. The Gemara asks: Why is this so? The customer <b>did not pull</b> the ox into his possession. As he did not perform an act of acquisition, he has not acquired any part of the ox, and his dinar should therefore be restored to him. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> We are dealing here with a case <b>where he did pull</b> the ox into his possession.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of that mishna as follows: With regard to <b>the rest of the days of the year, it is not so. Therefore, if</b> the animal <b>died, it died at the seller’s</b> expense. If, as Rav Huna claims, the mishna is referring to a case where the purchaser had already pulled the animal into his possession, <b>why</b> must the seller suffer the loss? Since the customer <b>pulled</b> it into his possession and has acquired it, the ox died in his possession.
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Yitzḥak said: Actually,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the customer <b>did not pull</b> the animal into his possession. <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with</b> a case <b>where</b> the butcher <b>conferred possession upon</b> his customer <b>by means of another</b> person, i.e., the butcher conferred possession upon the customer by instructing another person to acquire a dinar’s worth of the ox’s meat on his behalf, without having obtained his consent.
Consequently, <b>at these four times, when it is for his benefit,</b> as everyone wishes to buy meat on these days, <b>one may act for his benefit in his absence,</b> and the acquisition is valid. With regard to <b>the rest of the days of the year, when it is to his disadvantage,</b> as it obligates him in payment and he might have no interest in this purchase, <b>one may act to his disadvantage only in his presence.</b>
<b>And Rav Ila said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: At these four times, the Sages based their statement on Torah law,</b> i.e., they ruled in accordance with Torah law. <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan said: By Torah law,</b> the payment of <b>money</b> is an effective act of acquisition, which <b>acquires</b> movable property. Merchandise that is purchased with money is immediately transferred to the ownership of the buyer.
<b>And why,</b> then, <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that the mode of acquisition of <b>pulling,</b> not monetary payment, <b>acquires</b> movable goods? It is <b>a decree</b> issued by the Sages, <b>lest</b> the seller <b>say to</b> a buyer who has already paid for his merchandise: <b>Your wheat was burned in the upper story</b> of my house, and you have lost everything. According to Torah law, once the buyer pays, he owns the merchandise wherever it is located. As this state of affairs can lead to fraud, the Sages instituted that only an act of physical transfer of the item purchased can finalize the sale. On these four occasions, however, the Sages ordained that Torah law remains in effect. Rabbi Eliezer maintains that this enactment applies to an <i>eiruv</i> as well.
The mishna stated: The Rabbis <b>concede with regard to all</b> other <b>people</b> that if he gave them money for food for an <i>eiruv</i>, his money confers possession upon him. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> included among <b>all</b> other <b>people? Rav said:</b> The reference is to <b>an</b> ordinary <b>homeowner,</b> not a merchant, who was asked by someone to receive possession of food for an <i>eiruv</i> on his behalf, by means of the money that he provided.
<b>And likewise, Shmuel said:</b> The reference is to <b>an</b> ordinary <b>homeowner. As Shmuel said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a baker, but an</b> ordinary <b>homeowner</b> may <b>acquire</b> the food on behalf of another person. <b>And Shmuel</b> also <b>said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case where he gave him <b>a <i>ma’a</i>, but</b> if he gave him <b>a utensil, he acquires</b> the food for the <i>eiruv</i> by the mode of acquisition known as exchange. By handing over the utensil in exchange for the food of the <i>eiruv</i>, he acquires that food wherever it is located. However, one cannot perform the mode of acquisition of exchange with money.
<b>And Shmuel</b> further <b>said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where he said to</b> the grocer or baker: <b>Confer possession upon me; but if he said</b> to him: <b>Establish an <i>eiruv</i> on my behalf,</b> he clearly intended to <b>appoint him</b> his <b>agent</b> to establish an <i>eiruv</i> on his behalf, <b>and</b> therefore the <i>eiruv</i> <b>is acquired</b> by means of his agency.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that one may establish an <i>eiruv</i> only with a person’s knowledge, <b>said?</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies to a joining of Shabbat boundaries, but not a joining of courtyards. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> in this regard, <b>and not only that, but any place where Rabbi Yehuda taught</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion.
<b>Rav Ḥana from Baghdad said to Rav Yehuda:</b> Did <b>Shmuel state</b> this ruling <b>even with regard to an alleyway whose</b> cross <b>beam or side post was removed</b> during Shabbat? Rabbi Yehuda maintains that it is permitted to carry in this alleyway on that same Shabbat.
<b>He said to him: I spoke to you with regard to</b> the acquisition of <b><i>eiruvin</i>, and not with regard to partitions.</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of partitions are not considered part of the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>eiruvin</i>, as they touch upon several areas of <i>halakha</i>, only one of which is the issue of an <i>eiruv</i>. With regard to partitions, the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> As it is stated that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, this proves <b>by inference that there is a dispute</b> concerning this issue. <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi say: Any place where Rabbi Yehuda says when, or in what</b> case is this, <b>in the Mishna,</b> he intends <b>only to explain the</b> earlier <b>statement of the Rabbis,</b> not to disagree with them. Why, then, did Shmuel say that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, when according to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi he is merely clarifying the opinion of the Rabbis, and there is no dispute between them?
Before addressing this question, the Gemara expresses surprise over the claim itself: <b>And</b> do Rabbi Yehuda and the Sages <b>not dispute</b> this issue? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in an earlier mishna: If new residents <b>were added to</b> the original residents of the alleyway, <b>he may add</b> to the <i>eiruv</i> for those residents <b>and confer possession</b> on them, <b>and he must inform</b> the new residents of their inclusion in the merging of alleyways. Apparently, this <i>tanna</i> maintains that one must inform them even with regard to a joining of courtyards. This ruling contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, which proves that there is at least one Sage who does not accept his opinion.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to a courtyard</b> situated <b>between two alleyways,</b> in which case the residents of the courtyard may join a merging with whichever alleyway they prefer. As their participation in the merging involves a certain disadvantage, for perhaps the residents of the courtyard would not want to establish a merging of alleyways with one alleyway and lose out on a potential merging with the other, it is necessary to inform them.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>Didn’t Rav Sheizvi say</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> with regard to that same mishna: <b>That is to say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda’s colleagues disagree with him</b> over the need to inform the other residents about the <i>eiruv</i>? This statement indicates that at least some Sages hold that the matter is in dispute, and not everyone agrees with Rabbi Yehuda.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara resolves both difficulties together:

Daf 82a

<b>Are you raising a contradiction between</b> the opinion of <b>one person and</b> that of <b>another?</b> In other words, a difficulty cannot be raised from the statement of one <i>amora</i> against those of another. <b>One Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>maintains</b> that Rabbi Yehuda and the Sages <b>disagree, and one</b> other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, <b>maintains</b> that they <b>do not disagree.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi cited in the course of the previous discussion. With regard to <b>the matter itself: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said</b> that <b>any place where Rabbi Yehuda says when, or in what</b> case <b>are these, in the Mishna, he</b> intends <b>only to explain the</b> earlier <b>statement of the Rabbis,</b> not to disagree with them. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The term <b>when</b> indicates that Rabbi Yehuda comes <b>to explain,</b> but the phrase <b>in what</b> case is this, indicates that he intends <b>to disagree.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Is</b> the word <b>when</b> invariably a sign that Rabbi Yehuda merely seeks <b>to explain? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>The following</b> people <b>are disqualified</b> by the Sages from giving testimony, as they are people who commit transgressions for profit: <b>One who plays with dice [<i>kubiyya</i>]</b> for money, <b>and one who lends</b> money <b>at interest, and those who fly pigeons,</b> i.e., people who arrange competitions between pigeons while placing wagers on which bird will fly faster. The reason for their disqualification is that those who play games of chance do not fully relinquish ownership of their gambling money, as they expect to win their bet. Consequently, one who accepts money in such circumstances has effectively taken something that the giver has not wholeheartedly handed over, and he is therefore like a robber, at least by rabbinic decree. The list of those disqualified from giving testimony includes <b>merchants</b> who trade in the produce <b>of the Sabbatical Year,</b> which may be eaten but may not be sold as an object of commerce.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> is this so? <b>When he has no occupation other than this</b> one, <b>but if he has a</b> worthy <b>occupation other than this,</b> although he also earns money by these means, <b>this</b> person <b>is qualified</b> to give testimony. Rabbi Yehuda maintains that one who earns money by means of games of chance is not a criminal or a robber. Rather, the reason why these people are disqualified from giving testimony is because they are not occupied in the constructive development of the world. As they earn their money without effort, they do not care about the monetary losses of others. Consequently, if they have any other occupation, they are valid witnesses.
The Gemara resumes its difficulty: According to the above principle with regard to statements introduced with the term when, Rabbi Yehuda’s statement should be understood merely as an explanation of the previous opinion. However, <b>a <i>baraita</i> was taught about</b> the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say: Whether he has no occupation other than this</b> one, <b>or whether he has a</b> fitting <b>occupation other than this, this</b> person <b>is disqualified</b> from giving testimony. Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda is disagreeing rather than explaining, even though he introduced his statement with the term when.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> opinion in the <i>baraita</i>, with regard to those disqualified from providing testimony, is not the opinion of the Rabbis of the mishna. Rather, <b>it is</b> that <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintained that <b>Rabbi Tarfon said</b> this opinion. The Rabbis of the mishna, however, agree with Rabbi Yehuda in this regard, and his statement serves to explain their position.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to naziriteship: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said in the name of Rabbi Tarfon:</b> In a case where two people accepted a bet, with each undertaking to become a nazirite if he lost the wager, and a doubt arose as to who won, <b>neither one</b> of them <b>can possibly be a nazirite, as there is no</b> acceptance of <b>naziriteship without</b> clear and definitive <b>pronunciation.</b> A vow of naziriteship is only binding if it was expressly pronounced, i.e., if it was clear from the outset that the person intended to become a nazirite.
<b>Consequently,</b> it can be inferred that <b>since he is in doubt</b> as to <b>whether he is a nazirite or he is not a nazirite, he does not submit himself</b> to and accept his vow of naziriteship. <b>Here, too,</b> Rabbi Yehuda disqualifies those who play games of chance from delivering testimony due to the fact that they are robbers. <b>Since</b> the player <b>does not know whether he will</b> win and <b>acquire</b> the money <b>or whether he will</b> lose and <b>not acquire</b> it, <b>he does not fully transfer ownership</b> of the money with which he plays to others, which means that the one who gains from these games receives money that was not wholeheartedly given to him. He is therefore likened to a robber, at least on the rabbinic level, which disqualifies him from giving testimony.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>How does one participate in</b> the joining of Shabbat <b>boundaries?</b> One who wishes to establish a joining of Shabbat boundaries for himself and others <b>places a barrel</b> of food in the location he designates as their place of residence, <b>and says: This is for all the residents of my town, for anyone who</b> wishes to <b>go</b> on Shabbat <b>to a house of mourning or to a house of</b> a wedding <b>feast</b> situated beyond the Shabbat limit. <b>Anyone who accepted upon himself while it was still day,</b> i.e., before the onset of Shabbat, that he will rely on the <i>eiruv</i>, <b>is permitted</b> to rely upon it; but if one did so only <b>after nightfall,</b> he is <b>prohibited</b> to rely upon it, as the principle is that <b>one may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> after nightfall.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yosef said: One may establish a joining</b> of Shabbat boundaries <b>only for the purpose of a mitzva,</b> i.e., to enable the fulfillment of a religious obligation, but not for an optional activity.
