Neglect of the positive commandment of <i>sukka</i> is not punishable by the court, therefore we are not stringent in this regard. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat,</b> which is <b>a prohibition</b> punishable <b>by stoning,</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>did not state</b> his opinion. Consequently, Rabbi Yosei might agree that we must be very stringent with regard to all <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, even those that are rabbinic in origin.
<b>And if you ask: That incident, which occurred in Tzippori,</b> when they relied on suspended partitions on land for Shabbat, <b>on whose authority was it performed?</b> It was done <b>not on the authority of Rabbi Yosei, but</b> rather <b>it was performed on the authority of Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei,</b> who maintains that a suspended partition renders it permitted to carry even if it is over land and even on Shabbat.
The incident transpired in the following manner. <b>As when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said:</b> It <b>once</b> happened that the people <b>forgot and did not bring a Torah scroll</b> to the synagogue on Friday <b>while it was still day,</b> which meant they were left without a scroll from which to read on Shabbat. <b>On the following day,</b> Shabbat, <b>they spread a sheet over the pillars</b> positioned between the house where the scroll was kept and the synagogue, thereby forming a corridor with partitions suspended on each side. <b>And</b> in this manner <b>they brought the Torah scroll</b> to the synagogue <b>and read from it.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise at the wording of this account: Did they actually <b>spread</b> sheets on Shabbat? <b>Is it permitted</b> to do so <b><i>ab initio</i>? But doesn’t everyone agree that one may not erect a temporary tent on Shabbat</b> <i>ab initio</i>? Spreading sheets over pillars is considered constructing a temporary tent.
<b>Rather,</b> what happened was that <b>they found sheets spread over the pillars,</b> which they used as partitions, <b>and</b> in this manner <b>they brought the Torah scroll</b> to the synagogue <b>and read from it.</b>
<b>Rabba said: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya said the same thing.</b> Both were very lenient with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of a partition over water. The ruling of <b>Rabbi Yehuda is that which we</b> just <b>said,</b> that the wall of the courtyard permits a cistern. The ruling of <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya is as we learned: Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya says:</b> In the case of <b>a balcony that contains four cubits by four cubits,</b> which is suspended over water,

Daf 87a

<b>one may carve in it</b> a hole of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths <b>and draw</b> water through it. Even if there are no actual partitions around the hole, the section surrounding the hole is considered as though it were bent downward and formed partitions ten handbreadths high on all sides. Consequently, it is permitted to draw water through the hole.
<b>Abaye said to him: But perhaps that is not so,</b> as we can distinguish between the opinions. It is possible that <b>Rabbi Yehuda stated</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> with regard to the wall of the courtyard and the cistern, <b>as he said</b> that we rely on the halakhic principle of <b>extend and lower the partition.</b> The partition above the cistern is considered as though it descended to the bottom. <b>But</b> the principle of <b>bend</b> the partition <b>and extend</b> it downward, as suggested by Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya, <b>no,</b> he does not accept this principle.
<b>And</b> we can likewise say that <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya stated</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> in the case of the balcony, <b>with regard to the Sea of Tiberias,</b> i.e., the Sea of Galilee, <b>since it has</b> clearly defined <b>banks</b> around it, <b>and towns and enclosures surround it</b> on all sides. The Sea of Galilee is surrounded by clear boundaries on all sides and is therefore somewhat similar to a private domain in appearance. Consequently, even a minor adjustment is sufficient. <b>However, with regard to other waters, no,</b> Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya did not permit this practice.
<b>Abaye said: And according to the statement of Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya,</b> if the balcony <b>was less than three handbreadths</b> away <b>from the wall,</b> it is permitted to draw water from it in the following circumstances: <b>Its length must be four cubits, and its width</b> must be <b>eleven</b> handbreadths <b>and</b> any <b>amount.</b> By carving out a hole of slightly more than one handbreadth by four handbreadths on the side near the wall, alongside the other three handbreadths, one creates a hole of four handbreadths by four handbreadths. This hole is surrounded by partitions ten handbreadths high on each side. How so? The wall itself is one partition. The four-cubit length is viewed as bent down on both sides of the hole, forming two partitions of ten handbreadths; the remaining ten handbreadths of the width is seen as though it were bent down, which creates a partition on the fourth side of the balcony.
If the balcony <b>was upright,</b> i.e., it had upright partitions on all sides (Rabbeinu Ḥananel), <b>the height</b> of these partitions <b>must be ten handbreadths, and the width</b> of the balcony must be <b>six handbreadths and two</b> minimal <b>amounts.</b> This leaves slightly more than a handbreadth on each side of the hole of four handbreadths, on which he can stand.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> If it <b>was positioned in a corner</b> between two walls (Rabbeinu Ḥananel), <b>the height</b> of the partition <b>must be ten handbreadths, and the</b> requisite <b>width</b> of the balcony must be <b>two handbreadths and two</b> minimal <b>amounts.</b> As he is able to stand, he is provided with actual partitions.
The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya said:</b> If <b>a balcony</b> that <b>has</b> an area of <b>four cubits by four cubits</b> is suspended above water, <b>one carves in it</b> a hole of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths <b>and</b> then <b>draws</b> water through it, under <b>what circumstances</b> can a balcony with these dimensions <b>be found?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is necessary in the case of a balcony <b>that is built in the shape of a mortar,</b> where the balcony is positioned over the water on its own pillars and far removed from any wall. In that case, all of the partitions must be constructed from its floor space. And the balcony must be four cubits by four cubits in size.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a water channel that passes through a courtyard,</b> the residents <b>may not draw</b> water <b>from it on Shabbat, unless they erected for it a partition ten handbreadths high at the entrance and at the exit</b> of the courtyard. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> There is no need for a special partition, as the <b>wall that</b> runs <b>on top of it,</b> i.e., the courtyard wall, <b>is considered as a partition.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a</b> water <b>channel</b> that passed through the courtyards <b>of</b> the town of <b>Avel,</b> from <b>which</b> the residents <b>would draw</b> water <b>from it on Shabbat by the authority of the Elders,</b> relying on the courtyard wall suspended above it. <b>They said to him:</b> It is <b>due to</b> the fact that channel <b>was not of the size</b> that requires a partition, i.e., it was less than ten handbreadths deep or less than ten handbreadths wide, it was permitted to draw water from it even without a partition.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>they erected</b> a partition <b>for</b> the water channel <b>at the entrance but they did not erect</b> one <b>for it at the exit,</b> or if <b>they erected</b> a partition <b>for it at the exit but they did not erect</b> one <b>for it at the entrance, one may not draw</b> water <b>from it on Shabbat, unless they erected for it a partition ten handbreadths</b> high both <b>at the exit and at the entrance. Rabbi Yehuda says: The wall</b> that runs <b>on top of it,</b> i.e., the courtyard wall, <b>is considered as a partition.</b> Therefore, there is no need for a special partition.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving the water channel that went from Avel to Tzippori, and</b> the residents <b>would draw</b> water <b>from it on Shabbat by the authority of the Elders,</b> without any additional partition.
<b>They said to him:</b> Are you trying to bring <b>a proof from there?</b> That was either <b>due to</b> the fact that the channel <b>was not ten handbreadths deep or</b> because it was not <b>four</b> handbreadths <b>wide.</b> It lacked the requisite measure to be considered a domain in its own right. Everyone agrees that it is permitted to draw water from it even without an additional partition.
<b>It was taught in another</b> <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a water channel that passes between the windows</b> of two houses, if it is <b>less than three</b> handbreadths, <b>one may lower a bucket</b> from the window <b>and draw</b> water from it; however, if it is <b>three</b> handbreadths, <b>one may not lower a bucket and draw</b> water from it. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> If it is <b>less than four</b> handbreadths, <b>one may lower a bucket and draw</b> water from it; but if it is at least <b>four</b> handbreadths, <b>one may not lower a bucket and draw</b> water.
With regard to these measures of three and four handbreadths, the Gemara asks: <b>With what are we dealing</b> here? <b>If you say</b> this <i>halakha</i> is referring <b>to the water channel itself,</b> that it was three or four handbreadths wide, this presents a difficulty, <b>for when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A <i>karmelit</i> cannot be less than four</b> handbreadths wide. The <i>karmelit</i> is an intermediate domain established by the Sages, whose status is between a public and a private domain. Any open area that is not a public thoroughfare, e.g., a field, sea, river, alleyway, or a lane, is classified as a <i>karmelit</i>. It is prohibited to carry an article four cubits within a <i>karmelit</i>, or to transfer an object from a private domain or a public domain to a <i>karmelit</i>, or vice versa. One who draws water through a window from a water channel into a house has carried from a <i>karmelit</i> to a private domain. Consequently, if the <i>tanna’im</i> of the <i>baraita</i> dispute the width of the channel, they are in effect disagreeing about the minimal size of a <i>karmelit</i>.
The Gemara resumes its question: <b>Let us say,</b> then, that <b>the teaching that</b> Rav Dimi <b>cited,</b> that a <i>karmelit</i> cannot be less than four handbreadths wide, was actually the subject of a dispute of <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> and not a unanimous <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara rejects the previous explanation. <b>Rather,</b> the measure of three or four handbreadths is referring not to the channel itself but <b>to the banks</b> of the channel, <b>and</b> it is stated <b>with regard to</b> an act of <b>exchange.</b> The dispute here does not concern the measure of a <i>karmelit</i>, but the measure of an exempt domain. It is permitted to transfer the empty bucket from the window, which is a private domain, by way of the channel’s banks, which are exempt domains, to the water channel, which is a <i>karmelit</i>, and back again with the full bucket.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A place that does not have</b> an area of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths is an <b>exempt domain.</b> Consequently, if this place is situated between a public domain and a private domain, <b>it is permitted for</b> both <b>the people of the private domain and for the people of the public domain to</b> adjust the burdens on their <b>shoulders on it, provided</b> that <b>they do not exchange</b> objects between them via the exempt domain. How, then, can the bucket be transferred from the window to the channel, and vice versa, by means of the banks?
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> Rav Dimi is referring to <b>domains by Torah law,</b> i.e., this <i>halakha</i> involves the transfer of objects from a private domain to a public domain via an exempt domain. The Sages forbade this activity, so that people would not transfer objects directly from the private domain to the public domain.

Daf 87b

However, <b>here,</b> Rav Dimi is referring to <b>domains by rabbinic law.</b> As the transfer of objects from a private domain to a <i>karmelit</i> is prohibited only by rabbinic decree, the Sages did not prohibit this transfer when it is accomplished by way of an exempt domain.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that transferring objects from one domain to another by way of an exempt domain is prohibited <b>even in</b> the case of <b>domains</b> that apply <b>by rabbinic law. As we learned</b> in a mishna: In the case of <b>a wall that is between two courtyards,</b> if it is <b>ten handbreadths high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide,</b> the residents <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> a separate one for each courtyard, <b>but they do not establish one</b> joint <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
<b>If there was produce on top</b> of the wall, <b>these,</b> the residents of one courtyard, <b>may ascend from this</b> side <b>and eat</b> them, <b>and those,</b> the residents of the other courtyard, <b>may ascend from the other</b> side <b>and eat</b> them, provided that they do not bring the produce down from the top of the wall to the courtyards.
If <b>the wall is breached,</b> a distinction applies: If the breach is <b>up to ten cubits</b> wide, <b>they may establish two <i>eiruvin</i>, and if they wish, they may establish one <i>eiruv</i>, for it is like an entrance.</b> This breach is similar to any opening of less than ten cubits. If the breach is <b>more than this, they may establish one <i>eiruv</i>, but they may not establish two <i>eiruvin</i>.</b> A breach of this size nullifies the partition, as the two courtyards merge into a single domain.
<b>And we discussed this</b> mishna and raised a question: If this wall <b>is not four</b> handbreadths thick, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav said:</b> In that case, <b>the air of two domains controls it.</b> As the wall is not broad enough to be considered a domain of its own, its top belongs to both courtyards, and it is therefore prohibited to both of them. Accordingly, <b>one may not move</b> anything <b>on</b> top of the wall even as much as <b>a hairsbreadth.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> disagreed and <b>said: These,</b> the residents of one courtyard, <b>may carry up</b> their food <b>from</b> their courtyard to the top of the wall <b>and eat</b> it there, <b>and those,</b> the residents of the other courtyard, <b>may</b> likewise <b>carry up</b> their food <b>from</b> their courtyard <b>and eat</b> it there. The entire top of the wall has the status of an exempt domain that can be combined with either courtyard, provided that the residents of the different courtyards do not exchange food between them.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> regular line of <b>argument</b> here, <b>for when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A place that contains less than four by four</b> handbreadths is an exempt domain. Consequently, if this place is located between a public domain and a private domain, <b>it is permitted for the people of the private domain and for the people of the public domain to load</b> their burdens <b>onto their shoulders in it, as long as they do not exchange</b> objects with each other by way of the exempt domain. Apparently, Rabbi Yoḥanan prohibited exchanging articles between two domains, even if they are rabbinic domains.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> ruling concerning a wall between two courtyards, <b>Ze’eiri stated it</b> in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan. Rav Dimi transmitted a different tradition of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion. The Gemara raises a difficulty: Nonetheless, <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> concerning a water channel between two windows <b>is difficult according to Ze’eiri.</b>
The Gemara answers: Ze’eiri <b>explains</b> that the measures mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> are referring <b>to the water channel itself.</b> That is to say, the dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Sages does not concern the width of the banks of the channel but the width of the channel itself, as they dispute the basic parameters of a <i>karmelit</i>. <b>And</b> Ze’eiri maintains that the teaching of <b>Rav Dimi,</b> that a <i>karmelit</i> can be no less than four handbreadths wide, <b>is</b> in fact the subject of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And let</b> the water channel that passes through the courtyard <b>be</b> treated at least <b>like the cavities of a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> even if it is not wide enough to be considered a <i>karmelit</i> on its own. Just as the cavities in the wall of a private domain are considered a private domain even if they do not include the prescribed measure of a private domain, the water channel passing through the courtyard should likewise be considered as a cavity of the larger water channel in the street. It should therefore have the status of a <i>karmelit</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>Abaye bar Avin and Rav Ḥanina bar Avin both said: There is no</b> category of <b>cavities for a <i>karmelit</i>.</b> As a <i>karmelit</i> is only a rabbinic in origin, the <i>halakha</i> is not so stringent with regard to this domain. Consequently, a <i>karmelit</i> does not annex nearby cavities.
<b>Rav Ashi said: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that in general <b>there are holes for a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> but <b>this applies only to</b> holes that are <b>adjacent</b> to the <i>karmelit</i>, and are therefore nullified by it. <b>Here, however,</b> we are dealing with a water channel <b>that is</b> far <b>removed</b> from the <i>karmelit</i>. Therefore, it does not assume the status of the <i>karmelit</i>.
<b>Ravina said</b> a different explanation of the dispute between Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the Rabbis: The measures of three and four handbreadths refer neither to the width of the water trench nor to the width of its banks. Rather, we are dealing with a case <b>where one fashioned outlets for</b> the water channel <b>at its ends,</b> i.e., one formed gaps in the partitions to allow the water to flow.
<b>And the Rabbis follow their</b> regular line of <b>argument,</b> that the principle of <i>lavud</i> applies only to a gap less than three handbreadths wide. An opening less than three handbreadths is therefore considered completely closed, while one of four is not viewed as closed. <b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel follows his</b> regular line of <b>argument,</b> that the principle of <i>lavud</i> applies even to a gap of four handbreadths.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a balcony that</b> extends <b>over</b> a body of <b>water,</b> if a hole was opened in the floor, its residents <b>may not draw</b> water <b>from it</b> through the hole <b>on Shabbat, unless they erected for it a partition ten handbreadths high</b> around the hole. It is permitted to draw water by means of that partition, <b>whether</b> it is positioned <b>above</b> the balcony, in which case the partition is seen as descending downward, <b>or</b> whether it is placed <b>below</b> the balcony.
<b>And likewise,</b> with regard to <b>two</b> such <b>balconies, one above the other,</b> if <b>they erected</b> a partition <b>for the upper balcony but they did not erect</b> one <b>for the lower one,</b> the residents <b>are both prohibited</b> from drawing water through the upper one, <b>unless they establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> between them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna</b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya ben Akavya, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥananya ben Akavya says:</b> If <b>a balcony that contains four</b> cubits <b>by four cubits</b> is suspended above water, <b>one may carve out</b> a hole of <b>four</b> handbreadths <b>by four</b> handbreadths <b>in it and draw</b> water through it. The section of the floor surrounding the hole is considered as though it bent downward and formed a partition ten handbreadths high on all sides. Consequently, no other partition is necessary.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Yosei ben Zimra: Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya permitted</b> a balcony that is not surrounded by partitions <b>only in</b> the case of <b>the Sea of Tiberias,</b> the Sea of Galilee, <b>as it has</b> clearly defined <b>banks</b> that are visible on all sides, <b>and towns and enclosures surround it.</b> It is therefore considered part of an inhabited area. <b>But with regard to other waters,</b> such as larger seas, <b>no,</b> he did not permit them.
<b>Our Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya permitted three activities to the inhabitants of Tiberias: They may draw water</b> from the sea <b>through</b> a hole cut out of <b>a balcony on Shabbat, and they may insulate</b> produce <b>in the pods</b> of legumes, <b>and they may dry themselves</b> on Shabbat <b>with a towel [<i>aluntit</i>].</b>
The Gemara clarifies this <i>baraita</i>: <b>They may draw water through</b> a hole cut out of <b>a balcony on Shabbat</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>that we stated</b> above. <b>And they may insulate</b> produce <b>in the pods</b> of legumes; <b>what is</b> this <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>rose early</b> in the morning <b>to bring residue</b> from the field, e.g., the straw of wheat or the stalks or pods of legumes, in order to store his produce in them, the following distinction applies: <b>If</b> he rose early <b>because</b> the residue still <b>has dew on it,</b> and he wants to use this moisture for his produce, <b>this</b> instance <b>is considered</b> to be in the following category: <b>If</b> any water <b>be put.</b> Food or produce can contract ritual impurity only if it has come into contact with a liquid, either directly through the action of its owner, or without his direct intervention but with his approval. This is derived from the verse: “But if any water be put on the seed, and any part of their carcass falls on it, it shall be unclean to you” (Leviticus 11:38). Returning to our issue, if this person rose early because the residue still has dew on it, the produce he stores in it is rendered susceptible to ritual impurity, as it has come into contact with the dew with its owner’s approval.
<b>And if</b> one rose early only <b>in order not to neglect his</b> usual <b>work,</b> this <b>is not considered</b> an instance of <b>if it be put,</b> as it was not his intention to place the dew on the produce. Unintended contact with a liquid does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>And normally,</b> unless they specify otherwise,

Daf 88a

<b>the inhabitants of Tiberias</b> are considered <b>like one</b> who does so in order <b>not to neglect his</b> usual <b>work.</b> Most of them are ordinary laborers. It can be assumed that if they rose early to bring home straw or stalks in which to store their produce, they did so only to save work time.
The Gemara turns to the third activity that Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya permitted for the inhabitants of Tiberias: <b>And they may dry themselves with a towel. What is</b> this <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person</b> who washed himself in cold water on Shabbat or a Festival <b>may dry himself with a towel and place it on a window,</b> as there is no concern that he perform the prohibited labor of wringing out the towel. <b>And he may not give</b> the towel <b>to the bathhouse attendants [<i>olayerin</i>] because they are suspected with regard to that matter,</b> as they might wring out the towel before giving it to other bathers. Furthermore, one may not bring the towel home because if he does so, he might forget and wring it out. <b>Rabbi Shimon said: He may even bring</b> the towel <b>in his hand to his house,</b> as there is no concern lest he wring it.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna: They taught</b> the leniency of partitions surrounding a hole in a balcony <b>only</b> with regard <b>to drawing</b> water through the hole; <b>but to pour</b> waste water down the hole, it is <b>prohibited.</b>
<b>Rav Sheizvi raised an objection against this</b> <i>halakha</i>: <b>And what is</b> the difference <b>between this</b> case of a hole in the balcony <b>and</b> that of <b>a pit [<i>uka</i>]</b> used in a courtyard for waste water? The Sages rule in the next mishna below that one who digs a pit with a capacity of two <i>se’a</i> in a small courtyard that is less than four cubits may pour waste water into the courtyard on Shabbat, even if the pit was full before Shabbat. He need not be concerned that this will cause water to flow out of the courtyard into the public domain on Shabbat.
The Gemara answers: <b>These</b> waters, which are poured out into the courtyard, <b>are</b> likely to be <b>absorbed</b> into the ground, and it is therefore uncertain that the water will indeed leave the courtyard. <b>But these,</b> the water poured through the hole into the body of water under the balcony, <b>will not be absorbed.</b> Therefore, one knows with certainty that the water will flow out beyond the permitted boundary.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna</b> actually <b>said: You should not say that it is</b> only <b>drawing</b> water through the hole in the balcony <b>that is permitted,</b> while <b>pouring</b> waste water through it <b>is prohibited; rather, pouring</b> waste water through the hole <b>is also permitted. Rav Sheizvi said:</b> This is <b>obvious,</b> as <b>this is</b> exactly the same as the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>pit</b> discussed in the next mishna. The Gemara rejects this argument: It is necessary to specify both <i>halakhot</i>, <b>lest you say</b> there is a difference between the cases, as <b>these,</b> the water poured in the courtyard, <b>are</b> likely to be <b>absorbed</b> into the ground, <b>whereas these,</b> the water poured through the hole in the balcony, <b>will not be absorbed.</b> Rabba bar Rav Huna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that we do not distinguish between the two cases.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And likewise,</b> if there are <b>two balconies, one</b> above the other, and a partition is erected for the upper balcony but is not erected for the lower one, it is prohibited for residents of both balconies to draw water through the upper one, unless they establish a joint <i>eiruv</i> between them. <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: They taught</b> that one balcony renders it prohibited for residents of the other <b>only where</b> the one balcony <b>is near</b> the other, i.e., horizontally within four handbreadths. <b>But</b> if each balcony is <b>separated</b> by four handbreadths from the other, so that the residents of each balcony can use the other only by means of the air, the residents of <b>the upper</b> balcony <b>are permitted</b> to draw water, while the residents of the lower one are prohibited from doing so.
<b>And Rav</b> follows <b>his</b> regular line of <b>argument</b> here, <b>as Rav said: One person does not impose restrictions upon another person by way of the air.</b> Since the lower balcony is far from the higher one, it does not prohibit it, although it can make use of it by means of the vacant airspace between them, albeit with difficulty.
<b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said, and Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of <b>stealing applies to Shabbat</b> domains, <b>and a ruin must be returned to its owner.</b>
The Gemara registers surprise: <b>This</b> ruling <b>itself is difficult,</b> i.e., it is self-contradictory. <b>You</b> first <b>said</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>stealing applies to Shabbat</b> domains, which at this point is understood by the Gemara as referring to the following case: A person’s house adjoins the ruin of another, and he observes that the ruin has been left deserted by its owner. If this person uses the ruin during the week, on Shabbat he may treat it as though it were his own, by carrying objects from his own house into the ruin and vice versa. <b>From here</b> we can infer that a stolen place <b>is acquired</b> for the purpose of Shabbat domains, although it does not belong to the person for other purposes. However, you subsequently said that <b>a ruin must be returned to its owner,</b> and <b>from here</b> we can infer that a ruin <b>is not acquired</b> for the purpose of Shabbat domains by the person who used it during the week, and therefore he may not carry objects from his own house into the ruin.
The Gemara answers: We should not understand this statement as suggested above, but rather <b>this is</b> what Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Oshaya <b>are saying: The <i>halakha</i> of</b> returning <b>stolen</b> property <b>applies to Shabbat</b> domains. <b>How so?</b> This means <b>that a ruin must be returned to its owner.</b> In other words, one who uses a ruin during the week does not acquire it even for the purpose of Shabbat domains.
<b>Rabba said: And we</b> ourselves <b>raised an objection</b> against <b>our</b> own <b>teaching,</b> as we learned in the mishna. <b>And likewise,</b> if there are <b>two balconies, one above the other,</b> they prohibit one another. <b>But if you say</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> against <b>stealing applies on Shabbat,</b> which means one may not use the domain of another, and he acquires no rights to it if he does so, <b>why</b> are the two balconies <b>prohibited</b> from using it. The lower one has no right to make use of the upper one.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: We are dealing here with</b> a situation <b>where, for example,</b> the residents of the upper balcony and the residents of the lower balcony <b>jointly erected a partition</b> for the upper balcony. Consequently, the residents of the lower balcony share the right to use it with the residents of the upper one.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> in a case <b>where they erected</b> a separate partition <b>for the lower</b> balcony, the residents of the upper balcony should <b>likewise</b> be prohibited to use it. As the residents of the lower one are partners in the upper one, they should prohibit its residents from using it.
The Gemara answers: <b>Since they erected</b> a separate partition <b>for the lower</b> balcony, <b>they</b> each thereby <b>revealed their intention</b> to the residents of the upper balcony <b>that: It is not my wish to be</b> partners <b>with you.</b> Consequently, they no longer prohibit the residents of the upper balcony from using it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a courtyard that is less than four cubits</b> by four cubits in area, <b>one may not pour</b> waste <b>water into it on Shabbat, unless a pit was fashioned</b> to receive the water, and the pit <b>holds two <i>se’a</i></b> in volume <b>from its edge below.</b>
This <i>halakha</i> applies <b>whether</b> the pit was fashioned <b>outside</b> the courtyard <b>or</b> whether it was dug <b>inside</b> the courtyard itself. The <b>only</b> difference is as follows: <b>If</b> the pit was dug <b>outside</b> in the adjoining public domain, <b>it is necessary to arch over</b> it, so that the water will not flow into the public domain. If it was dug <b>inside</b> the courtyard, <b>it is not necessary to arch over</b> it.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> In the case of a drainage <b>ditch whose</b> first <b>four cubits are arched over in the public domain, one may pour</b> waste <b>water into it on Shabbat. And the Rabbis say: Even</b> if <b>a roof or a courtyard</b> is <b>a hundred cubits</b> in area, <b>one may not pour</b> water directly <b>onto the mouth of the</b> drainage <b>ditch. However, he may pour</b> it <b>upon the roof,</b> from which <b>the water spills into the drain</b> of its own accord.
<b>A courtyard and a portico,</b> a roofed but unwalled structure in front of a house, <b>combine for the four cubits</b> by virtue of which it is permitted to pour water even into a courtyard that lacks a pit. <b>And likewise,</b> with regard to <b>two upper stories [<i>deyotaot</i>], one opposite the other</b> in the same small courtyard, if the residents of <b>one</b> of them <b>fashioned a pit</b> in the courtyard, <b>and</b> the residents of <b>the other did not fashion a pit, those who fashioned a pit are permitted</b> to pour their waste water into the courtyard, whereas <b>those who did not fashion a pit are prohibited</b> to do so.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that a courtyard four by four cubits in area does not require a pit? <b>Rabba said: Because a person ordinarily uses two <i>se’a</i> of water a day,</b> and with regard to a courtyard <b>of</b> at least <b>four cubits</b> by four cubits, <b>a person wants to sprinkle</b> the water on the ground to prevent any dust from rising. Consequently, even if in practice the water does flow out of the courtyard, this effect is not necessarily his intention.

Daf 88b

But if the courtyard is <b>less than four cubits</b> by four cubits in area, <b>one</b> simply <b>pours</b> the water out, as the place is not fit for sprinkling. Therefore, <b>if one fashioned a pit, it is permitted</b> to pour out water; but if <b>not, it is prohibited</b> to do so, as one certainly intends for the water to flow outside.
<b>Rabbi Zeira</b> offered a different reason and <b>said:</b> In a courtyard of <b>four cubits</b> by four cubits, the water is likely to be <b>absorbed</b> into the ground. If it is <b>less than four cubits</b> in size, the water <b>will not be absorbed</b> but will flow out.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical <b>difference between</b> these two explanations? <b>Abaye said: There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to a <b>long and narrow</b> courtyard. As the area of this courtyard is also sixteen square cubits, it likewise absorbs the water. Rabbi Zeira would therefore rule that it does not require a pit. However, as this courtyard is not in need of sprinkling, it requires a pit according to Rabba.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>A courtyard and a portico combine for the</b> requisite <b>four cubits,</b> permitted the pouring of water into a courtyard that lacks a pit. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Zeira,</b> this <b>works out well,</b> as the total area is large enough to absorb the water. <b>However, according to Rabba it is difficult,</b> for when the courtyard is joined with the portico it is no longer in the shape of a square, and it is therefore unfit for sprinkling.
<b>Rabbi Zeira explained</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba,</b> by saying that it is referring <b>to a portico that extends along the entire courtyard,</b> so that it adds to its width alone. Consequently, the courtyard and the portico together form a square of four by four cubits, an area that is fit for sprinkling.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> that can decide this dispute. With regard to <b>a courtyard that is not four cubits by four cubits</b> in area, <b>one may not pour water into it on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara assumes that the <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that one may pour water only into a courtyard that it is four by four cubits, is precise in its wording. <b>Granted, according to Rabba,</b> this <b>works out well,</b> as he maintains that it is prohibited to pour water into a long and narrow courtyard. <b>However, according to Rabbi Zeira,</b> who maintains that the critical factor is the area of the courtyard, this is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Zeira</b> can <b>say to you:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> at the end of the mishna, who maintain that the area of the courtyard is of no importance, <b>whereas our</b> unattributed <b>mishna is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,</b> according to whom the area is the decisive factor.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what forced Rabbi Zeira to establish the mishna in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov? Rava said: The mishna was difficult for him. Why</b> did the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach</b> his ruling with respect to <b>a courtyard that is less</b> than four cubits, from which it can be inferred that if it has an area of four by four cubits it is permitted to pour water, even if it is not square in shape? <b>Let</b> the mishna <b>teach: A courtyard that is not four cubits by four cubits,</b> i.e., one that is not square shaped, even if it includes an area of sixteen square cubits.
<b>Rather, shouldn’t one conclude from this</b> argument that the unattributed section of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov?</b> The Gemara summarizes: Indeed, <b>conclude from this</b> that it is so.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with this conclusion: <b>But from</b> the fact that <b>a latter clause</b> of the mishna explicitly cites the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,</b> it can be inferred that <b>the first clause</b> does <b>not</b> represent the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov.</b>
The Gemara rejects this argument: In fact, <b>the entire</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, and</b> as for its problematic style, the mishna <b>is incomplete and it teaches the following:</b> With regard to <b>a courtyard that is less than four cubits</b> in area, <b>one may not pour</b> waste <b>water into it on Shabbat. Consequently,</b> if it is <b>four cubits</b> in area, <b>one may pour</b> water into it, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> If the first <b>four cubits of a</b> drainage <b>ditch were arched over in the public domain, one may pour</b> waste <b>water into it on Shabbat.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> If the first four cubits of a drainage <b>ditch were arched over</b> in the public domain, it is permitted to pour waste water into it on Shabbat. However, the Rabbis say: One may pour water only upon the roof, from which it will spill into the drain of its own accord.
The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna</b> was <b>not</b> taught <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya. For it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥananya says: Even</b> with regard to <b>a roof one hundred cubits</b> in area, <b>one may not pour</b> water onto it, <b>because a roof is not apt to absorb</b> the water. <b>Rather, it</b> causes it <b>to run off.</b> Consequently, pouring water onto this roof is equivalent to pouring it directly outside.
A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught: In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that a pit is required, <b>said? In the summer, but in the rainy season, one may pour and repeat, and</b> he need <b>not hold back. What is the reason? Rava said: A person is</b> equally <b>willing for the water to be absorbed on the spot,</b> i.e., as there is abundant water in the courtyard during the rainy season, it will remain muddy in any case, and he therefore does not care whether the added waste water remains in the courtyard or if it flows out.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> With regard to <b>waste</b> water poured into a drainage ditch, <b>that a person wants it to be absorbed</b> in the ditch itself, rather than flow out, <b>and</b> yet the mishna <b>teaches</b> that <b>one may not pour</b> water into the ditch.
Rava <b>said to him: There,</b> during the rainy season, there is no reason to prohibit the practice, for <b>with regard to what need we be concerned? If</b> you say he wants the water to flow out into the public domain <b>because</b> he is concerned about <b>spoiling</b> and sullying <b>his courtyard,</b> it is <b>already spoiled</b> by the rainwater. <b>And if</b> you say it should be prohibited <b>due to a decree lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>so-and-so’s gutter is flowing with water</b> on Shabbat, which might lead them to think he is watering his garden or violating some other prohibition, and they might act likewise even in the summer, this is not a relevant concern. As <b>gutters ordinarily flow</b> with water in the rainy season, people do not entertain this suspicion.
<b>Rav Naḥman said: In the rainy season,</b> with regard to <b>a pit that holds two <i>se’a</i>, we grant him</b> permission to pour <b>two <i>se’a</i></b> of water into it. If it <b>holds</b> only <b>one <i>se’a</i>, we grant him one <i>se’a</i>.</b> However, <b>in the summer,</b> if the pit has a capacity of <b>two <i>se’a</i>, we grant him two <i>se’a</i>;</b> if it holds only <b>one <i>se’a</i>, we do not grant him</b> permission to pour any water <b>at all.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>In the hot season as well,</b> if the pit <b>holds one <i>se’a</i>, let us grant him one <i>se’a</i>,</b> for if he pours only this amount of water, it will not flow out into the public domain. The Gemara answers: This is prohibited due to <b>a decree lest he come to put two <i>se’a</i> into it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, in the rainy season let us also apply the</b> same <b>preventive measure.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the rainy season, there is no reason to prohibit the practice, for if one pours more water into a pit than it can take, <b>about what need we be concerned? If</b> you say he wants the waste water to flow out into the public domain <b>because</b> he is concerned about <b>spoiling</b> his courtyard, <b>it is already spoiled</b> by the rainwater. <b>If</b> you say it should be prohibited due to <b>a decree lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>so-and-so’s gutter is flowing with water</b> on Shabbat, <b>gutters ordinarily gush</b> with water in the rainy season, as stated above.
<b>Abaye said: Therefore,</b> in accordance with this reasoning, one can pour <b>even a <i>kor</i> and even two <i>kor</i></b> of waste water into a small pit. As all gutters flow with water in the rainy season, there is no cause for any concern.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And likewise,</b> with regard to <b>two upper stories, one opposite the other</b> in the same courtyard, the residents of the one who dug a pit in the courtyard may pour water into it, while the residents of the other one who did not dig a pit in the courtyard are prohibited from doing so. <b>Rava said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even if</b> the residents of the two upper stories <b>established an <i>eiruv</i></b> together.
<b>Abaye said to him: What is the reason</b> for this ruling? <b>If you say</b> it is <b>due to the increase</b> in the amount <b>of water,</b> as two upper stories pour out more water than one, <b>wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The same</b> <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a pit, and the same</b> applies to <b>a cracked</b> earthenware <b>vessel</b> used as a receptacle for water, or a small <b>pond, or a basin: Even though they were</b> already <b>filled with water on Shabbat eve, one may pour water into them on Shabbat.</b> It is evident from here that as long as the pit is the requisite size, there is no concern about the amount of water that will flow out from it.
<b>Rather, if it was stated it was stated as follows. Rava said:</b>

Daf 89a

<b>They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to a case <b>where</b> the residents of the two upper stories <b>did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> together, <b>but if they established a</b> joint <b><i>eiruv</i>, they are</b> all <b>permitted</b> to pour water into the courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>And where they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, what is the reason</b> that the residents who did not dig a pit may <b>not</b> pour water into the courtyard? <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is <b>a decree, lest</b> people <b>come to take out vessels</b> filled with water <b>from</b> their <b>houses into</b> the courtyard, to pour into the pit. In the absence of an <i>eiruv</i>, this practice is prohibited.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the roofs of the city</b> are considered <b>one domain.</b> It is permitted to carry from one roof to another, even if the residents of the houses did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> between them. The Sages did not prohibit carrying between roofs, as it is rare to transfer an item from one roof to another. However, it is only permitted to transfer objects between roofs <b>provided that</b> one <b>roof is neither ten</b> handbreadths <b>higher nor ten</b> handbreadths <b>lower</b> than the adjacent roof. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: Each and every one</b> of the roofs is <b>a domain in and of itself.</b> It is permitted to carry from one to the other only if the residents of both houses established an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says: Roofs, courtyards, and enclosures are all one domain with regard to vessels that were inside them</b> when <b>Shabbat</b> began, and one may therefore carry from one of these areas to another. However, they are <b>not</b> one domain <b>with regard to vessels that were inside the house</b> when <b>Shabbat</b> began and were later taken into one of the above domains. A vessel that was inside the house when Shabbat began and subsequently carried to one of these areas may be carried from one roof, courtyard, or enclosure to another only if an <i>eiruv</i> had been established between the domains.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Abaye bar Avin and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Avin were sitting, and Abaye was sitting beside them, and they sat and said: Granted, the Rabbis maintain: Just as residents are divided</b> into separate domains <b>below,</b> and they may not carry from house to house without an <i>eiruv</i>, <b>so are residents divided</b> into separate domains <b>above,</b> on the rooftops, and it is prohibited to carry from one roof to another without an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>However, Rabbi Meir, what does he maintain;</b> what is the rationale for his opinion? <b>If he maintains</b> that <b>just as residents are divided</b> into separate domains <b>below, so are residents divided</b> into separate domains <b>above, why,</b> in his opinion, <b>are they</b> considered <b>one domain? And if he maintains</b> that <b>they are not divided</b> into separate domains, <b>as any</b> place <b>above ten</b> handbreadths off the ground <b>is</b> considered <b>one domain, even</b> if a <b>roof</b> is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>higher or ten</b> handbreadths <b>lower</b> than the adjacent roof, it should <b>likewise</b> be permitted to carry from one roof to the other.
<b>Abaye said to them:</b> Have <b>you not heard that which Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: Any place that you find two domains,</b> i.e., places set apart from each other by disparity in height or by boundaries, <b>and</b> yet <b>they are</b> halakhically <b>one domain, for example, a pillar ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide</b> situated <b>in a private domain,</b> it is <b>prohibited to adjust</b> a burden on one’s <b>shoulders upon it,</b> by rabbinic <b>decree, due to</b> the concern lest he come to do the same thing on <b>a mound in the public domain.</b> The legal status of a mound ten handbreadths high and four handbreadths wide located in a public domain is that of a private domain. In that case, it is prohibited by Torah law to transfer an object from the public domain to the mound. <b>Here too,</b> in the case of roofs, Rabbi Meir prohibited transferring objects between roofs with a height disparity of ten handbreadths, by rabbinic <b>decree, due to</b> the concern lest one come to transfer an object from the public domain to <b>a mound in a public domain.</b>
Abaye and Ḥanina bar Avin <b>understood</b> by inference <b>from this</b> ruling that in the opinion of Rabbi Meir, it would be prohibited to adjust one’s burden <b>even</b> on <b>a mortar and even</b> on <b>a vat</b> that were overturned in a private domain and that are large enough to constitute private domains in their own right.
<b>Abaye said to them: The Master,</b> Rabba, <b>said as follows: Rabbi Meir spoke only</b> in the case of <b>a pillar or the</b> raised <b>base of a millstone. Since a person fixes a place for them</b> they are comparable to a mound in a public domain in that they are rarely moved. However, the Sages did not issue a decree in the case of portable objects.
The Gemara raises a difficulty. There is the case of <b>a wall that is between two courtyards, which</b> is <b>fixed, and</b> nevertheless <b>Rav Yehuda said: When</b> you analyze the matter, <b>you will find</b> that <b>according to Rabbi Meir</b> all <b>roofs</b> form a single <b>domain in and of themselves,</b> and likewise all <b>courtyards</b> form a single <b>domain in and of themselves,</b> and all <b>enclosures</b> form a single <b>domain in and of themselves.</b> It is permitted to carry from one courtyard to another, although it is not permitted to carry from a courtyard to a roof.
<b>What, is it not that it is permitted to move</b> objects from one courtyard to another <b>via a</b> dividing <b>wall,</b> even though it is ten handbreadths high? This poses a difficulty to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who prohibits the transfer of an object from one place to a place ten handbreadths higher or lower.
<b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said: No,</b> that explanation is incorrect, as Rav Yehuda meant to say that according to Rabbi Meir it is permitted <b>to carry in and carry out</b> between one courtyard and another, or from one enclosure to another, <b>via</b> the <b>openings</b> between them. However, Rabbi Meir concedes that one may not transfer objects over the wall that separates the two domains, as the wall is considered a domain in and of itself.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that <b>each and every one</b> of the roofs <b>is a domain in and of itself. It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about the following issue. <b>Rav said:</b> According to the Rabbis, <b>one may move</b> objects on each roof <b>only within four cubits.</b> As, according to the Rabbis, the legal status of roofs is like that of courtyards, in that it is prohibited to carry from one roof to another, and each roof is fully open to a domain into which carrying is prohibited. Therefore, it is also prohibited to carry objects farther than four cubits on each roof. <b>And Shmuel said: It is permitted to move</b> objects throughout each <b>entire</b> roof.
The Gemara comments: <b>With regard to partitions that are conspicuous,</b> i.e., detached houses whose walls are distinct, <b>everyone agrees</b> that it is permitted to carry throughout each roof. <b>Where they disagree</b> is <b>with regard to partitions that are not conspicuous,</b> i.e., attached houses, which appear as though they share a common roof although they are owned by different people.
<b>Rav said: One may carry</b> on each roof <b>only within four cubits.</b> Rav <b>does not state</b> the principle: <b>Extend and raise the partitions</b> between the houses below, which states that the walls of the houses are considered to extend upward and create partitions between the roofs. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> It is <b>permitted to carry throughout</b> each <b>entire</b> roof, <b>as he states</b> the principle: <b>Extend and raise the partitions.</b>
The Gemara asks a question based on that which <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: And <b>the Rabbis say</b> that <b>each and every one</b> of the roofs

Daf 89b

is <b>a domain in and of itself.</b> This indicates that each roof constitutes a discrete domain, and one may carry throughout this entire domain. <b>Granted according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> this works out <b>well, but according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> it is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara answers that the Sages of the <b>school of Rav said in the name of Rav:</b> The ruling in the mishna is not a leniency permitting one to carry throughout the entire roof; rather, it is a stringency, ruling <b>that one may not move</b> an object <b>two cubits on this roof and two cubits on that roof.</b> The <i>tanna</i> rules that even the allowance to carry within four cubits is restricted to a single roof.
The Gemara raises a difficulty. <b>But didn’t Rabbi Elazar say: When we were in Babylonia we</b> would <b>say</b> that the Sages of <b>the school of Rav said in the name of Rav: One may move</b> an object <b>on</b> each roof <b>only within four cubits, and those</b> Sages of <b>the school of Shmuel taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> in accordance with their opinion: <b>They have only their</b> own <b>roof.</b>
The Gemara seeks to clarify this <i>baraita</i>. <b>What is</b> the meaning of the statement: <b>They have only their</b> own <b>roof?</b> Is it <b>not that they are permitted to move</b> an object <b>throughout</b> each <b>entire</b> roof? This <i>baraita</i> poses a difficulty to Rav. The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>And is</b> this <i>baraita</i> any <b>stronger</b> a proof <b>than our mishna, which we established</b> as a stringency, <b>that one may not move</b> an object <b>two cubits on this roof and two cubits on that roof? So too,</b> this <i>baraita</i> is teaching that one may not carry <b>two cubits on this roof and two cubits on that roof.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said,</b> after an illness had caused him to forget his knowledge: <b>I have not heard this <i>halakha</i></b> of Shmuel’s with regard to roofs. His student <b>Abaye said to him: You</b> yourself <b>said it to us, and it was about this</b> that <b>you said it to us:</b> With regard to <b>a large roof that is adjacent to a small one,</b> carrying on <b>the large</b> one <b>is permitted,</b> as its partitions are distinct where it extends beyond the small one, <b>and</b> carrying on <b>the small one is prohibited,</b> as it is breached along its entire length into the other roof, onto which it is prohibited to carry.
<b>And you said to us about it: Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: They only taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where there are residents on this</b> roof <b>and residents on that</b> roof, <b>as</b> the extended, virtual partition <b>of the small</b> roof is considered <b>a trampled partition.</b> The residents trample this virtual partition as they move from one roof to the other, and the entire length of the small roof is considered breached into the large one.
<b>However,</b> if <b>there are no residents on this</b> roof <b>and</b> none <b>on that</b> one, carrying on <b>both</b> roofs is <b>permitted.</b> Presumably, Shmuel’s reasoning is that in this case the walls of the houses below extend upward and form partitions between the roofs, in accordance with the principle: Extend and raise the partitions.
Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> I remember it now. <b>I said to you as follows: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that carrying is prohibited on the small roof, <b>only</b> with regard to a case <b>where there was an</b> actual <b>partition on</b> all sides of <b>this</b> roof <b>and an</b> actual <b>partition on</b> all sides of <b>that</b> roof, not only between the two roofs. In <b>that</b> case, carrying on <b>the large</b> roof <b>is permitted by</b> means of <b>the remnants</b> of the partition on either side of the opening, <b>and</b> carrying on the <b>small</b> roof <b>is</b> prohibited because it is <b>fully breached</b> into the larger one. <b>However, if there is no partition, neither on</b> all sides of <b>this</b> roof <b>nor on</b> all sides of <b>that</b> roof, carrying on <b>both of them is prohibited.</b>
Abaye raised a difficulty: <b>But didn’t you speak to us</b> of <b>residents?</b> Rav Yosef replied: <b>If I spoke to you</b> of <b>residents, this</b> is what <b>I said to you: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that carrying is prohibited on the small roof, <b>only</b> in a case <b>where there is an</b> actual <b>partition</b> that renders the area <b>fit for residence on</b> all sides of <b>this</b> roof, <b>and an</b> actual <b>partition</b> that renders the area fit <b>for residence on</b> all sides of <b>that</b> roof, as carrying on <b>the large</b> roof <b>is permitted by</b> means of <b>the remnants</b> of the partition on either side of the opening, <b>and</b> carrying on the <b>small</b> roof <b>is</b> prohibited because it is <b>fully breached</b> into the larger one.
<b>However,</b> if <b>there is a partition</b> that renders the area fit <b>for a residence on</b> all sides of <b>the large</b> roof, <b>but</b> there is <b>no</b> partition that renders the area fit for <b>a residence on the small</b> roof, carrying <b>even</b> on <b>the small</b> roof <b>is permitted for the residents of the large</b> roof. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Since</b> the residents of the small roof <b>did not erect a partition</b> around their roof, <b>they</b> thereby <b>removed themselves from here</b> and transferred the right to their domain to the residents of the large roof.
This is <b>in accordance with that which Rav Naḥman said:</b> If one <b>affixed a permanent ladder to his roof,</b> while the owners of the neighboring roofs did not do so, it <b>is permitted for him to</b> carry on <b>all the roofs.</b> The failure of the other owners to erect a ladder indicates that they relinquished the right to their roofs to the one who affixed the permanent ladder.
<b>Abaye said:</b> If a person <b>built an upper story atop his house,</b> by surrounding the roof with walls, <b>and erected before its</b> entrance <b>a small partition [<i>dakka</i>] four</b> cubits high that opens to other roofs, <b>it is permitted</b> for him <b>to</b> carry on <b>all the roofs.</b> His construction of the partition is indicative of his plans to utilize the other roofs, while the failure of the other owners to do so indicates that they conceded use of their roofs to him.
<b>Rava said: Sometimes the small partition</b> leads <b>to prohibition. What are the circumstances</b> of this case? It is a case <b>where</b> the partition <b>was erected</b> facing <b>toward the garden of his house</b> and the sides facing the other roofs were sealed. The reason is <b>that</b> through his actions <b>he said</b>

Daf 90a

<b>that he built</b> the upper story <b>to protect the garden [<i>tarbitza</i>],</b> not to access the roofs.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised a dilemma:</b> According to Rav, who holds that one may carry only within four cubits on each roof, if he carries an object <b>two cubits on a roof and</b> another <b>two cubits on a pillar</b> ten handbreadths high and four handbreadths wide adjacent to the roof, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rabba said:</b> With regard to <b>what</b> matter <b>is he raising a dilemma?</b> Is it with regard to <b>a <i>karmelit</i> and a private domain</b> that <b>he is raising a dilemma?</b> The roof is a <i>karmelit</i> and the pillar is a private domain; certainly carrying from one to the other is prohibited.
The Gemara explains that this was not in fact the dilemma, <b>and Rami bar Ḥama, due to his keen</b> mind, <b>did not analyze</b> the dilemma carefully and was imprecise in its formulation. <b>Rather, this is</b> the <b>dilemma he is raising:</b> If one carries an object <b>two cubits on the roof</b> of a house, <b>and</b> another <b>two cubits on</b> the slanted roof of <b>a portico,</b> a roofed structure without walls, before a house belonging to someone else, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara elaborates on Rami bar Ḥama’s dilemma: <b>Do we say</b> that <b>since neither this</b> roof <b>is fit for residence, nor is this</b> portico roof <b>fit for residence, it is</b> regarded as <b>one domain,</b> and therefore carrying between them is permitted? <b>Or perhaps since</b> carrying <b>from a roof to</b> another <b>roof is prohibited,</b> carrying <b>from a roof to a portico is likewise prohibited,</b> as the latter is also a domain in and of itself.
<b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye raised a</b> similar <b>dilemma:</b> If one carries <b>two cubits on the roof</b> of a house <b>and</b> another <b>two cubits</b> on the roof <b>of a ruin</b> belonging to someone else, one side of which was completely open to a public domain, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Rav Kahana said: Is that not</b> precisely the same dilemma raised <b>by Rami bar Ḥama</b> with regard to a portico? <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: And did I come late</b> [<b><i>me’aḥer</i></b>] merely <b>to quarrel,</b> and meddle in other people’s questions? That is not the case, as the two dilemmas are not identical. <b>A portico is not fit for residence, while a ruin is fit for residence.</b> Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> might differ in each case.
The Gemara is surprised by this explanation: <b>And now that it is fit for residence, what dilemma is he raising?</b> The situation is comparable to the case of two standard roofs. The Gemara answers: Rav Beivai was unaware of the resolution to the dilemma raised by Rami bar Ḥama, and therefore, <b>he states</b> the dilemma employing the style: <b>If you say. If you say</b> that <b>a portico is not fit for residence,</b> and therefore carrying is permitted, it can be argued that as <b>a ruin is fit for residence,</b> the legal status of its roof should be like that of a standard roof. <b>Or perhaps</b> that is not the case, as <b>now in any event there are no residents in</b> the ruin, and therefore its roof is not comparable to a standard roof. No resolution was found for these dilemmas, and they <b>stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara discusses a different question. With regard to <b>roofs that are level,</b> i.e., with a height disparity of less than ten handbreadths, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, or an isolated roof</b> that does not border other roofs, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, Rav said: It is permitted to move</b> an object <b>throughout the entire</b> roof; <b>and Shmuel said: One may move</b> an object <b>in it only within four</b> cubits.
The Gemara seeks to clarify the conflicting opinions. <b>Rav said</b> that <b>it is permitted to move</b> objects <b>throughout the entire</b> roof. This is <b>difficult,</b> as there is an apparent contradiction between one statement <b>of Rav and</b> another statement <b>of Rav.</b> With regard to level roofs, Rav said that according to the Rabbis one may carry on each roof only within four cubits. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of a roof among roofs, <b>the</b> inner <b>partitions</b> between the houses <b>are not conspicuous,</b> and therefore, are not taken into consideration. <b>Here,</b> however, <b>the</b> outer <b>partitions</b> of a single house or group of houses <b>are conspicuous,</b> meaning that they are considered to extend upward and delineate the edge of the roof.
The Gemara returns to discuss Shmuel’s ruling. <b>And Shmuel said: One may carry only within four</b> cubits. Once again, it is <b>difficult,</b> as there is an apparent contradiction between one statement <b>of Shmuel and</b> another statement <b>of Shmuel,</b> who said that in the case of level roofs, according to the Rabbis one may carry throughout each separate roof. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the area of the roof <b>is no greater than two <i>beit se’a</i>;</b> whereas <b>here,</b> the area <b>is greater than two <i>beit se’a</i>. And these partitions</b> of the house <b>were erected</b> for use <b>below</b> as partitions for the residence itself; <b>they were not erected to</b> serve as partitions for use on the roof <b>above.</b> Consequently, even if the walls are viewed as extending upward so that they constitute surrounding partitions for the roof, the legal status of the roof is <b>like</b> that of <b>an enclosure greater than two <i>beit se’a</i> that was not enclosed</b> from the outset for the purpose of <b>residence; and</b> the principle is that with regard to <b>any enclosure greater than two <i>beit se’a</i> that was not enclosed</b> from the outset <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>residence, one may move</b> an object <b>in it only within four cubits.</b>
<b>It was</b> further <b>stated</b> that these same <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to <b>a</b> large <b>ship. Rav said: It is permitted to move</b> an object <b>throughout</b> the entire ship, as it is all one domain; <b>and Shmuel said: One may move</b> an object <b>in it only within four</b> cubits. The Gemara proceeds to clarify their respective opinions. <b>Rav said: It is permitted to move</b> an object <b>throughout</b> the boat,

Daf 90b

<b>as there are partitions. And Shmuel said: One may move</b> an object <b>in it only within four cubits,</b> as <b>the partitions</b> of the ship are not considered full-fledged partitions; they <b>are erected</b> only <b>to keep water out,</b> not to render it a residence.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said to Shmuel:</b> Is <b>the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with your</b> opinion <b>or</b> is <b>the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav?</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> as his rationale is more convincing.
<b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said: And Rav concedes that if one overturned</b> the ship <b>onto its mouth,</b> and it is more than ten handbreadths high, <b>that one may move</b> an object <b>on it only within four cubits.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> purpose <b>was</b> the ship <b>overturned? If you say</b> it was overturned so <b>that</b> one may <b>reside beneath it, what is the difference</b> between it and <b>an isolated roof?</b> The legal status of the overturned ship should in every sense be that of a house, and therefore it should be permitted to carry throughout the entire ship.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be <b>that he overturned it to tar it,</b> i.e., to add a fresh coat to its underside. In that case, the boat certainly does not serve as a residence, and its sides are not considered full-fledged partitions.
<b>Rav Ashi teaches</b> Shmuel’s acceptance of Rav’s opposing view (Ritva) with regard <b>to a ship,</b> as stated above; <b>and Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, teaches it</b> with regard <b>to a portico, as it was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to <b>a portico</b> located <b>in a field.</b> A portico has a roof and either incomplete walls or no walls. Consequently, in the case of a portico located in a valley, which is a <i>karmelit</i>, it remains to be determined whether or not it is permitted to carry in it. <b>Rav said: It is permitted to move</b> an object <b>throughout the entire</b> portico, as it is a private domain. <b>And Shmuel said: One may move</b> an object <b>in it only within four</b> cubits.
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rav said: It is permitted to move</b> an object <b>throughout the entire</b> portico, as <b>we say: The edge of the roof descends</b> to the ground <b>and seals</b> the portico on all sides, rendering it a private domain. <b>And Shmuel said: One may move</b> an object <b>in it only within four</b> cubits, as <b>we do not say: The edge of the roof descends</b> to the ground <b>and seals</b> the portico.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>Rav’s</b> statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir</b> that one is permitted to carry from one roof to another if they are level, it should also be permitted <b>to carry from a roof to a courtyard.</b> Why then does Rabbi Meir rule that roofs and courtyards are separate domains and that carrying between them is prohibited? The Gemara answers: It is prohibited because Rabbi Meir issued <b>a decree, due to</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi.</b> As stated previously, Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi rules that one may not transfer objects between two halakhically equivalent but physically distinct domains ten or more handbreadths high. This is a decree lest one standing in a public domain adjust a burden on a mound ten handbreadths high and four handbreadths wide, which is a private domain, an act prohibited by Torah law.
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> according to <b>Shmuel’s</b> statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis</b> that the legal status of an isolated roof greater than two <i>beit se’a</i> is that of a <i>karmelit</i>, it should be permitted <b>to move</b> an object <b>from</b> an isolated <b>roof to an enclosure</b> within four cubits of the roof, as the legal status of the enclosure is also that of a <i>karmelit</i>. Why then do the Rabbis rule that roofs and enclosures are separate domains and carrying from one to the other is prohibited? <b>Rava bar Ulla said:</b> It is prohibited because the Rabbis issued <b>a decree lest the</b> area of the <b>roof diminish</b> to less than two <i>beit se’a</i>, in which case it would assume the status of a private domain, as it is prohibited to carry between a private domain and an enclosure.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, one should also not</b> be permitted to <b>move</b> an object <b>from one enclosure to</b> another <b>enclosure,</b> due to the concern that <b>perhaps</b> the area of one of the enclosures will <b>diminish</b> and become a private domain, <b>and he</b> will <b>come</b> to <b>move</b> an object from one to the other as before. The Gemara answers: <b>There, if</b> the enclosure <b>is diminished, the matter is conspicuous,</b> as its walls are clearly visible. <b>Here,</b> however, <b>if</b> the roof <b>is diminished, the matter is not conspicuous,</b> as the roof does not have walls.
<b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> After careful analysis, <b>you will find</b> that you can <b>say</b> that <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Meir, roofs are a domain in and of themselves,</b> and one may carry from one roof to another; and likewise <b>courtyards are</b> considered <b>a domain in and of themselves,</b> and one may likewise carry from one courtyard to another.

Daf 91a

Similarly, <b>enclosures are a domain in and of themselves,</b> and one is therefore permitted to carry from one enclosure to another. <b>According to the statement of the Rabbis, roofs and courtyards</b> constitute <b>one domain,</b> and therefore, one may carry even from a roof to a courtyard; however, <b>enclosures are one</b> discrete <b>domain. According to the statement of Rabbi Shimon, all of them,</b> roofs, courtyards, and enclosures, <b>are one domain,</b> and therefore it is permitted to carry between any of them.
The Gemara comments: A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> and a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda.</b> The Gemara elaborates. A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> that according to the Rabbis one may carry only four cubits on each roof: <b>All the roofs of a city are one domain, and it is prohibited to carry</b> objects <b>up or carry</b> them <b>down, from the roofs to the courtyard or from the courtyard to the roofs. And</b> with regard to <b>vessels that were inside a courtyard</b> when <b>Shabbat</b> began, <b>it is permitted to carry them in the courtyard</b> even if an <i>eiruv</i> was not established, and it is likewise permitted to carry them from that courtyard to other courtyards. With regard to vessels that were <b>on the roofs</b> when <b>Shabbat</b> began, <b>it is permitted to carry them on the roofs, provided that one roof is neither ten</b> handbreadths <b>higher nor ten</b> handbreadths <b>lower</b> than the other. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: Each and every one of</b> the roofs <b>is a domain in and of itself, and one may move</b> objects <b>on</b> each roof <b>only within four</b> cubits.
Likewise, a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with Rav Yehuda’s</b> interpretation of the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: When we were studying Torah with Rabbi Shimon in Tekoa, we would carry oil</b> for smearing <b>and a towel</b> for drying <b>from roof to roof, and from roof to courtyard, and from courtyard to courtyard, and from courtyard to enclosure, and from enclosure to enclosure,</b> to refrain from carrying in a prohibited place, <b>until we reached the spring in which we would bathe.</b>
And similarly, <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> There was <b>an incident during a time of danger,</b> when decrees were issued that banned religious observance, <b>and we would carry a Torah scroll from courtyard to roof, and from roof to courtyard, and from courtyard to enclosure, to read from it.</b>
The Sages <b>said to him:</b> The <i>halakha</i> cannot be determined from that incident, as an incident occurring during <b>a time of danger is no proof.</b> At a time of danger it is permitted to carry even in places where carrying is ordinarily prohibited by rabbinic law.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says: Roofs,</b> courtyards, and enclosures are <b>all</b> one domain with regard to vessels that were inside them when Shabbat began, and one may therefore carry from one of these areas to the other. However, they are not one domain with regard to vessels that were inside the house when Shabbat began.
<b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, provided that</b> the residents of each courtyard <b>did not establish a</b> separate <b><i>eiruv</i></b> for themselves, as in that case they may not move objects from their houses into the courtyard. <b>However, if they established</b> a separate <b><i>eiruv</i></b> for each courtyard, without establishing an <i>eiruv</i> between the various courtyards, <b>no,</b> that is not the <i>halakha</i>, <b>as we issue a decree lest one come to take out vessels</b> from one <b>of</b> the <b>houses to the courtyard,</b> an action that is fundamentally permitted, and subsequently proceed to carry them out to a different courtyard with which an <i>eiruv</i> had not been established, which everyone agrees is prohibited.
<b>And Shmuel said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Shimon, <b>whether they established an <i>eiruv</i> or whether they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. And similarly, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who whispered to you,</b> who told you that there is a difference <b>whether they established an <i>eiruv</i> or whether they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>?</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda strongly objects to this</b> ruling. <b>According to Shmuel and according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> people <b>will say</b> with regard to <b>two vessels</b> located <b>in the same courtyard,</b> one of which was in the courtyard when Shabbat began while the other was in the house, that moving <b>this</b> one, which was in the courtyard at the start of Shabbat, to another courtyard is <b>permitted, while</b> moving <b>that one,</b> which was in the house at the start of Shabbat, to another courtyard, is <b>prohibited.</b>
The Gemara answers: In this regard, <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard <b>reasoning, as he did not issue a decree</b> due to these concerns. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna, <b>Rabbi Shimon said: To what is this matter comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to three courtyards that are open into each other, and that are</b> also <b>open into a public domain.</b> If <b>the two outer</b> courtyards each <b>established an <i>eiruv</i> with the middle one,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for the residents of the middle one to carry <b>into</b> the two outer ones, <b>and they,</b> the residents of the two outer ones, <b>are permitted</b> to carry <b>into it, but</b> for the residents of <b>the two outer</b> courtyards it is <b>prohibited</b> to carry <b>into each other,</b> as they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> together.
<b>And</b> in that case Rabbi Shimon <b>did not issue a decree</b> prohibiting one to carry objects from the middle courtyard to one of the outer ones <b>lest one come to take out vessels from this</b> outer <b>courtyard to that</b> outer <b>courtyard,</b> despite the fact that both sets of vessels are located in the middle courtyard. <b>Here too, we do not issue a decree lest one come to take out utensils</b> from one <b>of the houses to the courtyard,</b> and carry them to a different courtyard.
<b>Rav Sheshet raised an objection.</b> We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Roofs, courtyards, and enclosures are all one domain with regard to vessels that were inside them</b> when <b>Shabbat</b> began. <b>But</b> they are <b>not</b> one domain <b>with regard to vessels that were inside the house</b> when <b>Shabbat</b> began. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that it is dealing with a case where the residents of the courtyards <b>established an <i>eiruv</i>, that is how you find vessels</b> that were taken <b>from the house in the courtyard.</b> Because those vessels were in the house at the beginning of Shabbat, they may not be moved to a different courtyard.
<b>However, if you say</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> under <b>what</b> circumstances can the case of <b>vessels from the house in the courtyard</b> be found? This poses a difficulty for Rav. Rav Sheshet <b>raised the objection, and he resolved it:</b> It refers <b>to</b> the case of <b>a hat or a shawl,</b> which one wore in the house and subsequently went out to the courtyard and placed it there. In this manner, it is possible that objects taken from the house can be found in the courtyard, even if an <i>eiruv</i> was not established.

Daf 91b

<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the residents of</b> houses that open directly into <b>a courtyard and the residents of</b> upper stories that open onto <b>a balcony</b> from which stairs lead down to that courtyard, <b>who forgot and did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> between them, <b>anything ten handbreadths high</b> in the courtyard, e.g., a mound or a pillar, is attributed <b>to the balcony</b> in terms of its use on Shabbat. The residents of the balcony may move objects between the mound or pillar and their apartments. Anything <b>lower than that</b> is attributed <b>to the courtyard. In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that it is prohibited for the residents of the courtyard to carry to the balcony and vice versa, <b>stated?</b> It is in a case <b>where</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>were many, and</b> the residents of the balcony were <b>many, and these established an <i>eiruv</i> for themselves, and those established an <i>eiruv</i> for themselves; or</b> if the courtyard and the balcony were occupied by <b>individuals who need not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for themselves.
<b>However,</b> if the residents of the courtyard and the balcony <b>were many, and they forgot and did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for their courtyard or balcony, in that case <b>roof, and courtyard, and portico, and balcony are all one domain,</b> and it is permitted to carry from one to another any vessels that were located in any one of them when Shabbat began.
