The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that carrying between them is permitted is <b>that they did not</b> each <b>establish</b> their own <b><i>eiruv</i>;</b> however, if <b>they</b> each <b>established</b> their own <b><i>eiruv</i>, no,</b> it is prohibited to carry between them. This inference supports Rav and poses a difficulty for Shmuel. The Gemara answers: <b>Whose</b> opinion is represented by <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> that of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who maintain that roofs and courtyards form a single domain, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. The Rabbis indeed issued a decree that carrying is prohibited if each group established a separate <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara comments: The language of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise, as it is not teaching</b> the cases of <b>an enclosure and an alleyway,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, but only the cases of a roof and a courtyard, in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from here</b> that this is the correct understanding.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>five courtyards that are open to each other and are</b> also <b>open to an alleyway, and</b> the residents of <b>all</b> the courtyards <b>forgot and did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, it is prohibited to carry in or carry out, from a courtyard to the alleyway or from the alleyway to a courtyard. And</b> with regard to <b>vessels that were in the courtyard</b> when <b>Shabbat</b> began, <b>it is permitted to carry them in the courtyard, but in the alleyway it is prohibited</b> to carry them.
<b>And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> doing so, <b>as Rabbi Shimon would say: Whenever</b> the courtyards <b>are</b> in the possession <b>of many</b> people, <b>and they forgot and did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> the <b>roof, and courtyard, and portico, and balcony, and enclosure, and alleyway are all one domain.</b> These areas are all classified as private domains, and therefore, it is permitted to carry from one to the other.
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that carrying between them is permitted is <b>that they did not</b> each <b>establish</b> their own <b><i>eiruv</i>;</b> however, if <b>they</b> each <b>established</b> their own <b><i>eiruv</i>, no,</b> it is prohibited to carry between them. This inference supports Rav and poses a difficulty for Shmuel. The Gemara answers: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>They did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>?</b> It means that the residents of the <b>courtyards did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> with each other; however, the</b> residents of each <b>courtyard established an <i>eiruv</i></b> with the residents of <b>the houses</b> inside it, and it is nevertheless permitted to carry between them, in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel.
The Gemara raises a difficulty. <b>But doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>state: They did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> indicating that they did not establish any <i>eiruv</i> at all, either with the residents of the other courtyard or within each courtyard? The Gemara rejects this argument. <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>They did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>?</b> It means that <b>they did not merge</b> the courtyards facing the alleyway.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Rabbi Shimon is speaking to the Rabbis in accordance with their</b> own <b>opinion,</b> not enumerating the leniencies inherent in his own ruling. His statement should therefore be understood as follows: <b>According to my own</b> opinion, <b>there is no difference</b> if <b>they established an <i>eiruv</i> and there is no difference</b> if <b>they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. However, according to your</b> opinion, <b>agree with me at least that</b> in a case <b>where they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> it is</b> all considered <b>one domain.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis said to him: No,</b> although we agree with you in the cases of a roof, courtyard, portico, and balcony, in the cases of an enclosure and an alleyway we disagree, as <b>they are two domains</b> and therefore it is prohibited to carry from one to the other.
<b>The Master said</b> above in the <i>baraita</i>: Vessels that were in a courtyard at the start of Shabbat may be carried within the courtyard, <b>but in the alleyway it is prohibited.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that this <b>supports that</b> which <b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav said, as Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In <b>an alleyway in which they did not merge</b> the courtyards facing it, <b>one may carry only within four cubits.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion. <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>But to an alleyway it is prohibited,</b> i.e., it is prohibited to carry from the courtyard to the alleyway; however, within the alleyway itself it is permitted to carry.
The Gemara raises a difficulty. If so, <b>that is</b> identical to <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>. The <i>tanna</i> would not have taught the very same thing twice. The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> apparently <b>superfluous teaching was necessary, lest you say: When the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Shimon, it is only</b> in a case <b>where they established an <i>eiruv</i>, but</b> in a case <b>where they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> the Rabbis <b>concede to</b> Rabbi Meir that it is all considered one domain and carrying is permitted. The <i>baraita</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Shimon in both cases, as they prohibit carrying in the alleyway even if the residents did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b>

Daf 92a

<b>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Shimon’s opinion that all courtyards constitute a single domain, even if each courtyard established an independent <i>eiruv</i>? <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with an unattributed mishna, and we learned:</b> With regard to <b>a wall between two courtyards, ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, they establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> one for each courtyard, <b>but they do not establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b> If <b>there was fruit atop</b> the wall, <b>these,</b> the residents of one courtyard, <b>may ascend from here and eat</b> it, <b>and those,</b> the residents of the other courtyard, <b>may ascend from there and eat</b> it, <b>provided that they do not take</b> the fruit <b>down</b> from atop the wall to the courtyards. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, all the courtyards are considered a single domain. Why may they not bring the fruit down?
The Gemara answers: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the word <b>down</b> in this context? It means <b>down to the houses;</b> however, it is indeed permitted to bring the fruit down to the courtyards. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> explicitly <b>teach</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Provided that neither will this</b> one <b>stand</b> below <b>in his place</b> in his courtyard <b>and eat, nor</b> will <b>that</b> one <b>stand in his place</b> in his courtyard <b>and eat?</b>
Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Ravina: No proof can be cited from this <i>baraita</i> of Rabbi Ḥiyya with regard to the mishna. <b>If Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>did not</b> explicitly <b>teach it</b> in this manner, <b>from where does</b> his student <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> know it? If a <i>halakha</i> is not taught by the mishna itself, it should not be distorted to have it correspond with a <i>Tosefta</i>.
<b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> dispute the following case: If there were <b>two courtyards and</b> there was <b>one ruin between them,</b> and the residents of <b>one</b> courtyard <b>established an <i>eiruv</i></b> for themselves, while the residents of <b>the other</b> courtyard <b>did not establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for themselves, <b>Rav Huna said:</b> The Sages <b>confer</b> the right to utilize the ruin <b>to</b> the residents of <b>that</b> courtyard <b>that did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>; however, to</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>that established an <i>eiruv</i>, no,</b> they do not confer the right to utilize the ruin. It is prohibited due to a decree, <b>lest people come to take out vessels</b> from one <b>of the houses to the ruin,</b> which is prohibited, as no <i>eiruv</i> was established with the ruin itself. However, this concern does not extend to the courtyard whose residents did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>. They are not permitted to move objects from their houses to the courtyard, and therefore there is no reason to issue a decree prohibiting the carrying of objects from the courtyard to the ruin.
<b>And Ḥiyya bar Rav</b> disagreed with Rav Huna and <b>said:</b> Rights to the ruin are conferred <b>to</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>that established an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> and consequently, it is <b>prohibited</b> for residents of <b>both</b> courtyards to carry objects. <b>And if you say</b> that it should be <b>permitted</b> for residents of <b>both</b> to move articles to the ruin, that is incorrect. As if that were so, <b>for what</b> reason did the Sages <b>not confer</b> the right to carry in <b>the courtyard that did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>, to the</b> residents of the <b>courtyard that established an <i>eiruv</i>?</b> If there is no cause for concern, it should always be permitted to the residents of a courtyard that established an <i>eiruv</i> to carry from their courtyard to a different courtyard whose residents did not establish an <i>eiruv</i>.
The Gemara refutes this contention: <b>There,</b> in the case of courtyards, <b>since the vessels from the houses are protected in the courtyard</b> as well, there is a concern lest people <b>come to take them out</b> from the house to the courtyard, where they could be confused with those vessels already in the courtyard, and they might come to move those objects into the other courtyard. <b>Here, in</b> the case of <b>a ruin, since the vessels from the courtyard are not protected in the ruin,</b> there is <b>no</b> concern lest people <b>come to take out</b> the vessels from the courtyard into the ruin. Therefore, it is possible that residents of both courtyards would be permitted to utilize the ruin.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of the previous discussion. <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav</b> disagreed with Rav Huna and <b>said:</b> The ruin belongs <b>even to</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>that established an <i>eiruv</i>, and</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for residents of <b>both</b> to carry in the ruin. <b>And if you say</b> they should <b>both</b> be <b>prohibited</b> to do so in accordance with the argument presented above, <b>that</b> the Sages <b>do not confer</b> the right to carry in <b>the courtyard that did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> to the</b> residents of the <b>courtyard that established an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> this proof can be refuted. <b>There, since the vessels from the houses are protected in the courtyard, the Sages did not permit</b> carrying <b>them,</b> due to the concern <b>lest</b> people <b>come to take them out</b> from the house to the courtyard and from there to the other courtyard. <b>However, in</b> the case of <b>a ruin,</b> the vessels <b>are not protected</b> in the ruin, and therefore, there is no cause for concern.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a large roof</b> was <b>adjacent to a small roof,</b> and the boundary between them was no wider than ten cubits, use of <b>the large one is permitted,</b> i.e., one may bring objects up to the roof from the house below and carry them on the roof, <b>and</b> use of <b>the small one is prohibited.</b> A similar <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a large courtyard that was breached into a small</b> one, in a manner that one entire side of the small courtyard was breached, but the breach was less than ten cubits; it is <b>permitted</b> for the residents of <b>the large</b> courtyard to carry, <b>but</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for the residents of <b>the small one</b> to do so. The rationale for this difference is <b>because</b> in that case, the legal status of the breach <b>is like</b> that of <b>the entrance of the large</b> courtyard. As the breach in the wall of the larger courtyard is surrounded on both sides by the remaining portions of that wall, and the breach is no greater than ten cubits wide, its legal status is like that of an entrance in the wall of the courtyard, and therefore it is permitted to carry in the large courtyard. With regard to the small courtyard, however, since one entire side of the small courtyard was breached, there remains no partition whatsoever on that side and carrying in that courtyard is therefore prohibited.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara poses a question: <b>Why does</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> the same <i>halakha</i> <b>twice?</b> Why is it necessary to repeat the ruling with regard to both roofs and courtyards when the cases are apparently identical?
The Gemara answers: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> with regard to the lenient ruling that the residents may carry on a roof, the repetition comes to <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a roof similar to</b> that of <b>a courtyard: Just as a courtyard, its partitions are conspicuous, so too a roof, its</b> extended <b>partitions,</b> based on the principle: Extend and raise the walls of the house, must be <b>conspicuous</b> for it to be permitted for the residents to carry on their account. In other words, the roof must not extend beyond the walls of the house.
Whereas <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> the repetition should be understood in the opposite manner, as it comes to teach the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a roof similar to</b> that of <b>a courtyard: Just as a courtyard</b> is a place <b>where multitudes tread, so too, the roof</b> is a place <b>where multitudes tread.</b> However, if it is not used by many people, even the small roof is permitted, as the principle: Extend and raise the walls of the house, is applied to the wall between the houses, despite the fact that the partition is not conspicuous.
<b>Rabba, Rabbi Zeira, and Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan were sitting, and Abaye was sitting beside them, and they sat and said: Learn from the mishna</b> that the rights of <b>the residents of the large</b> courtyard extend <b>into the small one, but</b> the rights of <b>the residents of the small</b> courtyard do <b>not</b> extend <b>into the large one.</b>
<b>How so?</b> If there are <b>vines in the large</b> courtyard, <b>it is prohibited to sow</b> crops <b>in the small one,</b> even at a distance of four cubits, due to the prohibition against planting other food crops in a vineyard. <b>And if he sowed</b> crops, <b>the seeds are prohibited.</b> As the small courtyard is considered part of the large one, the vines in the larger courtyard render the seeds in the smaller courtyard prohibited.

Daf 92b

<b>The vines,</b> however, <b>are permitted,</b> as the small courtyard does not extend into and impact upon the large one. The converse is also true: If there are <b>vines in the small</b> courtyard, <b>it is permitted to sow</b> other crops <b>in the large one</b> <i>ab initio</i>, even if they are not planted four cubits away from the vines, because the vines are not considered to be located in the larger courtyard, and therefore there is no prohibition whatsoever.
Likewise, if there were two adjacent courtyards, and <b>a wife,</b> who owned both courtyards, was standing <b>in the large</b> courtyard, <b>and</b> her husband threw her <b>a bill of divorce</b> into <b>the small</b> courtyard, <b>she is divorced.</b> Her presence in the larger courtyard extends to the smaller one, and she is therefore considered to be standing in the small courtyard. If, however, <b>the wife was in the small</b> courtyard <b>and the bill of divorce</b> was thrown into <b>the large one, she is not divorced.</b>
Likewise, with regard to communal prayer, if the <b>congregation</b> was <b>in the large</b> courtyard, <b>and the prayer leader</b> was <b>in the small one, they fulfill their obligation</b> through his prayer, as the congregation is considered to be in the small one as well. However, if <b>the congregation</b> was <b>in the small</b> courtyard, <b>and the prayer leader</b> was <b>in the large one, they do not fulfill their obligation.</b>
The same principle applies to a prayer quorum: If there were <b>nine</b> men <b>in the large</b> courtyard <b>and one</b> man <b>in the small one, they join</b> together to form the necessary quorum of ten, as the small courtyard is subsumed within the large one, and the individual is considered to be in the large courtyard. However, if there were <b>nine</b> men <b>in the small</b> courtyard <b>and one in the large one, they do not join</b> together.
Furthermore, if there was <b>excrement in the large</b> courtyard, <b>it is prohibited to recite <i>Shema</i> in the small one,</b> as the excrement is considered to be in the small courtyard as well, and it is prohibited to recite <i>Shema</i> in the presence of excrement. If, however, there was <b>excrement in the small</b> courtyard, <b>it is permitted to recite <i>Shema</i> in the large one.</b>
<b>Abaye said to them: If so, we have found a partition that</b> causes <b>prohibition.</b> According to these principles, the existence of a partition renders sowing crops prohibited; in the absence of a partition sowing the crops would have been permitted due to their distance from the vines. Ostensibly, this is a counterintuitive conclusion. <b>As, were there no partition</b> at all, it would be sufficient to <b>distance</b> oneself <b>four cubits</b> from the vine <b>and sow</b> the crop, <b>whereas now</b> that the area is divided into two courtyards by means of a partition, <b>it is prohibited</b> to sow the crop in the entire small courtyard.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Abaye: And didn’t we find a partition that</b> causes <b>prohibition? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>a large courtyard that was breached into a small</b> one, it is <b>permitted</b> for the residents of <b>the large</b> courtyard to carry, <b>but</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for the residents of <b>the small one</b> to do so. That is <b>because</b> in that case, the legal status of the breach <b>is like</b> that of <b>the entrance of the large</b> courtyard.
<b>And if he were to even its protrusions</b> by constructing partitions in the larger courtyard so that the large courtyard no longer protruded beyond the smaller one, carrying in <b>the large</b> courtyard would <b>also be prohibited,</b> as it would now be completely breached into the smaller courtyard. Apparently, in this case, construction of additional partitions causes prohibition.
Abaye <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: The two cases are not comparable, as <b>there,</b> adding partitions in order to even the protrusions is not considered establishment of partitions. On the contrary, <b>it is</b> effectively <b>the removal of partitions.</b> These partitions are designed to negate the original partitions of the courtyard.
<b>Rava said to Abaye: And didn’t we find a partition that</b> causes <b>prohibition? But wasn’t it stated:</b>

Daf 93a

If one <b>placed roofing on top of a portico that has doorposts,</b> i.e., a portico with two parallel walls that are valid for a <i>sukka</i>, as well as posts in the corners supporting the portico and protruding like doorposts, which are considered as sealing the other two sides of the portico, it is a <b>valid</b> <i>sukka</i>. However, <b>if he evened the doorposts</b> by constructing walls adjacent to the existing walls, obscuring the posts so that they do not protrude, the <i>sukka</i> is <b>invalid.</b> This teaching indicates that the creation of a partition can cause prohibition.
<b>Abaye said to him: In my opinion,</b> with regard to that case of a portico, the <i>sukka</i> is <b>valid.</b> However, even <b>according to your opinion,</b> this <b>is</b> another instance of <b>the removal of partitions.</b> Evening the doorposts does not render the <i>sukka</i> invalid through the establishment of new partitions, but because it negates the original partitions of the <i>sukka</i>.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye: And didn’t we find</b> that <b>a partition</b> causes <b>prohibition? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a house, half of which is roofed and half unroofed,</b> if there are <b>vines here,</b> under the roofed section of the house, <b>it is permitted to sow</b> crops <b>there,</b> in the open section. The reason is that it is as though the edge of the roof descends to the ground and forms a partition between the two sections of the house.
<b>And if he evened its roofing,</b> by extending the roof to cover the entire house, it would be <b>prohibited</b> to sow other crops there. It is evident that the very placement of a partition, in this case a roof, causes prohibition. Abaye <b>said to him: There</b> too <b>it is</b> an instance of <b>the removal of partitions.</b> It is prohibited to sow not due to the added roofing; rather, it is prohibited due to the negation of the imaginary partition.
<b>Rava sent</b> a different proof to <b>Abaye by means of Rav Shemaya bar Ze’eira,</b> with regard to the same issue. <b>And didn’t we find a partition</b> causes <b>prohibition? But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There is</b> an element <b>in the partitions of a vineyard</b> that causes <b>leniency</b> with regard to diverse kinds of seeds <b>and</b> an element that causes <b>stringency. How so?</b> With regard to <b>a vineyard that is planted until the</b> very <b>base of a partition, one sows</b> crops <b>from the base of</b> the other side of <b>the partition onward.</b> This is a leniency, <b>as were there no partition there,</b> he would be required to <b>distance</b> himself <b>four cubits</b> from the last vine <b>and</b> only then <b>sow</b> there. <b>And this is</b> an element in <b>partitions of a vineyard</b> that causes <b>leniency.</b>
<b>And</b> as for an element in partitions that causes <b>stringency, how so?</b> If the vineyard <b>was distanced eleven cubits from a wall, one may not bring</b> the <b>seeds</b> of other crops <b>there,</b> between the vineyard and the wall, and sow that area. This is a stringency, <b>as were there no partition,</b> it would suffice to <b>distance</b> himself <b>four cubits</b> from the last vine, <b>and sow</b> there. <b>This is</b> an element of <b>partitions in a vineyard</b> that causes <b>stringency,</b> a clear situation of a partition that causes prohibition.
Abaye <b>said to him: And according to your reasoning</b> that this presents a difficulty, <b>raise an objection against our</b> opinion <b>from a mishna,</b> rather than a less authoritative <i>baraita</i>, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a clearing in a vineyard, Beit Shammai say:</b> Its measure is <b>twenty-four cubits, and Beit Hillel say: Sixteen cubits.</b> With regard to <b>the perimeter of a vineyard, Beit Shammai say: Sixteen cubits, and Beit Hillel say: Twelve cubits.</b>
The mishna explains: <b>And what is a clearing in a vineyard?</b> It is referring to <b>a vineyard whose middle</b> section <b>was laid bare</b> of vines. If <b>there are not sixteen cubits</b> across in the clearing, <b>one may not bring</b> foreign <b>seeds</b> and sow them <b>there,</b> due to the Torah prohibition against sowing other crops in a vineyard (Deuteronomy 22:9). If <b>there were sixteen cubits</b> across in the clearing, <b>one provides</b> the vineyard with <b>its</b> requisite <b>work area,</b> i.e., four cubits along either side of the vines are left unsown to facilitate cultivation of the vines, <b>and he sows the rest</b> of the cleared area with foreign crops.
The mishna continues: <b>What is the perimeter of a vineyard?</b> It is the vacant area <b>between the vineyard and the fence</b> surrounding it. If <b>there are not twelve cubits</b> in that area, <b>one may not bring</b> foreign <b>seeds</b> and sow them <b>there.</b> If <b>there are twelve cubits</b> in that area, <b>he provides</b> the vineyard with <b>its</b> requisite <b>work area,</b> four cubits, <b>and he sows the rest.</b> However, were the vineyard not surrounded by a fence, all he would need to do is distance himself four cubits from the last vine. It is clear from this <i>halakha</i> that the partition causes prohibition.
<b>Rather,</b> the objection was not raised from there because <b>there, isn’t this the reason</b> that the partition is not considered to cause prohibition? It is <b>because the entire</b> area of <b>four cubits alongside a vineyard is</b> considered <b>the vineyard’s work area,</b> and is therefore an actual part of it. Likewise, with regard to the four cubits <b>alongside the fence</b> surrounding the vineyard, <b>since they cannot</b> easily <b>be sown</b> due to the wall, <b>he renounces ownership over</b> the area. With regard to the space <b>in between, if it is four</b> cubits, <b>it is</b> deemed <b>significant</b> in its own right, <b>and if not, it is not significant</b> and is nullified relative to the rest, and it is prohibited to sow there. A similar reasoning applies to the <i>baraita</i>. The stringency is not due to the fact that the partition causes prohibition, but because the partition impedes cultivation of the vineyard.
<b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> If there are <b>three enclosures alongside one another, and the two outer</b> ones <b>protrude,</b> i.e., they are wider than the middle one, so that there are partitions on both sides of the breach between them and the middle enclosure, <b>and the middle one does not protrude,</b> and there are no partitions between it and the outer enclosures, as it is totally breached, <b>and there is one</b> person <b>in this</b> one <b>and one</b> person <b>in that</b> one and yet another person in the third enclosure, the people in the enclosures are considered as though they are all living in one large enclosure. Consequently, the legal status of the group <b>becomes like</b> that of <b>a caravan, and one provides them</b> with <b>all</b> the space <b>that they require.</b> In other words, they may use the entire enclosure even if it is very large, just as there are no limits to the size of the enclosed area in which members of a caravan may carry.
However, if the <b>middle</b> enclosure <b>protruded, and the two outer ones did not protrude,</b> i.e., they were narrower than the middle enclosure, so that their entire width was breached into it, <b>and there is one</b> person <b>in this</b> one <b>and one</b> person <b>in that</b> one and yet another in the third, <b>one provides them only</b> an area of <b>six <i>beit se’a</i>,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of individuals in a field, who may enclose an area of only two <i>beit se’a</i> per person. As the middle enclosure is larger than the two outer ones, it determines their status, in accordance with the principle stated above, not the other way around. Consequently, the person in the middle enclosure is regarded as though he established residence in only one of the outer enclosures, constituting a group of no more than two, which does not have the legal status of a caravan.
Based on these assumptions, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If there is <b>one</b> person <b>in this</b> outer enclosure, <b>and one person in the other</b> outer enclosure, <b>and two</b> people <b>in the middle</b> enclosure, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the ruling that <b>if</b> the pair <b>exit to here,</b> one of the outer enclosures, <b>they are three</b> people in one place, <b>and if they exit to there,</b> the other outer enclosure, <b>they are three</b> people in one place, and three people are considered a caravan and provided with all the space they require, as stated above?
<b>Or perhaps,</b> as <b>one may exit to here and the other may exit to there,</b> in which case there would be no more than two people in each enclosure, they are provided with only two <i>beit se’a</i> per person.
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>one may exit to here and one may exit to there,</b> if there were <b>two</b> people <b>in this</b> outer enclosure, <b>and two</b> people <b>in that</b> outer enclosure, <b>and one</b> person <b>in the middle</b> enclosure, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is the ruling that <b>here, certainly, if he exits to here they are three, and if he exits to there they are</b> likewise <b>three,</b> and consequently they should be provided with all the space they require in any case? <b>Or perhaps,</b> in this case too there is uncertainty, as <b>say</b> that <b>he</b> might <b>exit to here, and say</b> that <b>he</b> might <b>exit to there.</b> As the direction in which he will leave his enclosure is undetermined, they should be provided with only two <i>beit se’a</i> each.
These dilemmas were essentially left unresolved, <b>but</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is</b> that <b>these dilemmas</b> are decided <b>leniently, and</b> they are provided with all the space they require in these cases.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b>

Daf 93b

<b>An embankment,</b> a height disparity between two surfaces <b>of five</b> handbreadths, <b>and</b> an additional <b>partition of five</b> handbreadths <b>do not join</b> together to form a partition of ten handbreadths, the minimum height for a partition to enclose a private domain. It is regarded as a partition of ten handbreadths <b>only if</b> the barrier <b>is</b> composed <b>entirely of the embankment or if it is</b> composed <b>entirely of a partition.</b>
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If there were <b>two courtyards, one above the other, and</b> the <b>upper one was ten handbreadths higher than the lower one, or if it had an embankment of five</b> handbreadths <b>and a partition</b> of <b>five</b> handbreadths, the two courtyards are considered separate domains <b>and they establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> one for each courtyard, <b>and they do not establish one <i>eiruv</i>.</b> If the height disparity was <b>less than</b> ten handbreadths, the two areas are considered a single domain, and <b>they establish one <i>eiruv</i> and they do not establish two <i>eiruvin</i>.</b>
<b>Rav said: Rav Ḥisda concedes</b> that an embankment and a partition combine <b>with regard to the lower</b> courtyard, <b>since it faces a wall of ten,</b> i.e., there is a full partition of ten handbreadths before its residents. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> according to this reasoning, the residents of the <b>lower</b> courtyard, from whose perspective there is a valid partition, should <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> i.e., an independent <i>eiruv</i>, <b>and do not establish one <i>eiruv</i></b> together with the upper courtyard, while the residents of <b>the upper</b> courtyard <b>establish neither one <i>eiruv</i> nor two.</b> The residents of the upper courtyard neither establish an <i>eiruv</i> on their own, as it is breached into the lower one, nor can they establish an <i>eiruv</i> together with the lower courtyard, because the latter is separated from it.
<b>Rabba bar Ulla said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the <b>upper</b> courtyard had full-fledged ten-handbreadth-high walls that <b>protruded</b> on both sides of the section of the partition that was merely five handbreadths high, a protrusion that extended <b>up to ten cubits.</b> In this case, the upper courtyard is properly enclosed by a partition ten handbreadths high, while the section that is only five handbreadths high is deemed an entrance. Consequently, even the residents of the upper courtyard can establish an <i>eiruv</i> on their own. But the two courtyards cannot be merged by a single <i>eiruv</i>, because the lower courtyard is enclosed by a partition from which there is no entrance to the upper courtyard.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i>: If the height disparity was <b>less than</b> ten handbreadths, <b>they</b> are considered a single domain, and the residents therefore <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>, but they do not establish two <i>eiruvin</i>.</b> According to the explanation suggested above, that there is a partition ten handbreadths high between the courtyards with an entrance of sorts between them, <b>if they wish, they establish one <i>eiruv</i>,</b> and <b>if they wish, they establish two <i>eiruvin</i>.</b> That is the <i>halakha</i> in a case of two courtyards with an entrance between them.
<b>Rabba, son of Rava, said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> refers to a case <b>where the lower</b> courtyard <b>was fully breached into the upper one,</b> i.e., the gap in the wall spanned the entire width of the lower courtyard. In that case, the residents of the lower courtyard establish a joint <i>eiruv</i> with the upper courtyard; however, they may not establish an <i>eiruv</i> of their own, in accordance with the mishna in which we learned that if a large courtyard is breached into a smaller one, it is permitted for the residents of the large courtyard to carry, but it is prohibited for the residents of the small one to do so.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be that the residents of the <b>lower</b> courtyard <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i></b> together with the upper one, but they <b>do not establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> i.e., the residents cannot establish an independent <i>eiruv</i> for their courtyard. However, with regard to <b>the upper one, if</b> its residents <b>wish,</b> they <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i></b> together with the lower courtyard, and <b>if</b> they <b>wish,</b> they <b>establish two <i>eiruvin</i>.</b> The residents of the upper courtyard can establish an independent <i>eiruv</i> for their courtyard, as the larger courtyard renders it prohibited for the residents of the smaller courtyard to carry, but not vice versa.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so;</b> that is the <i>halakha</i>. <b>And when</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> If the height disparity was <b>less than</b> ten handbreadths, the residents <b>establish one <i>eiruv</i>, but they do not establish two <i>eiruvin</i>,</b> this statement is not referring to both courtyards, but only <b>to the lower</b> one.
<b>Mareimar taught: An embankment of five</b> handbreadths <b>and an</b> additional <b>partition of five</b> handbreadths above it <b>combine</b> to form a partition of ten handbreadths. <b>Ravina met Rav Aḥa, son of Rava,</b> and <b>said to him:</b> Has <b>the Master taught anything with regard to</b> this <b>partition,</b> whether it is effective or not? <b>He said to him: No.</b> The Gemara concludes: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>an embankment of five</b> handbreadths <b>and a partition of five</b> handbreadths <b>combine</b> to form an effective partition of ten handbreadths.
<b>Rav Hoshaya raised a dilemma:</b> What is the ruling with regard to <b>residents who arrive on Shabbat,</b> i.e., who join the residents of a courtyard on Shabbat, e.g., if the wall between two courtyards collapsed on Shabbat so that new residents arrive in one courtyard from the other. Had these people arrived before Shabbat they would have rendered it prohibited for the residents to carry in the courtyard unless they participated with the original residents in their <i>eiruv</i>. <b>Do</b> these residents <b>render it prohibited</b> for the original residents to carry in the courtyard, even if they arrive on Shabbat itself?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma from the mishna: With regard to <b>a large courtyard that was breached into a small</b> courtyard, it is <b>permitted</b> for the residents of <b>the large</b> courtyard to carry, but it is <b>prohibited</b> for the residents of <b>the small</b> one to do so. It is permitted to carry in the large courtyard <b>because</b> the breach <b>is</b> regarded <b>like the entrance of the large</b> courtyard. Apparently, even if the breach occurred on Shabbat, it is prohibited for the residents of the small courtyard to carry. <b>Rabba said: Say</b> that the mishna is dealing with a case where <b>it was breached while it was still day,</b> i.e., on Friday. However, there is no prohibition if the breach occurred on Shabbat itself.
<b>Abaye said to him: The Master should not state: Say,</b> indicating that it is possible to explain the mishna in this manner. <b>Rather,</b> the mishna is <b>certainly</b> referring to a case where the courtyard <b>was breached while it was still day. As Master,</b> you <b>are the one who said: I raised a dilemma before Rav Huna, and I raised a dilemma before Rav Yehuda:</b> If one <b>established an <i>eiruv</i></b> to join one courtyard to another <b>via</b> a certain <b>opening, and that opening was sealed</b> on Shabbat, or if one established an <i>eiruv</i> <b>via</b> a certain <b>window, and that window was sealed</b> on Shabbat, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? May one continue to rely on this <i>eiruv</i> and carry from one courtyard to the other via other entrances? <b>And he said to me: Once</b> it <b>was permitted</b> to carry from courtyard to courtyard at the onset of <b>Shabbat, it was permitted</b> and remains so until the conclusion of Shabbat. According to this principle, if a breach that adds residents occurs on Shabbat, the breach does not render prohibited activities that were permitted when Shabbat began.
<b>It is stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed: With regard to <b>a wall between two courtyards,</b> whose residents did not establish a joint <i>eiruv</i>, <b>that collapsed</b> on Shabbat, <b>Rav said: One may carry in</b> the joint courtyard <b>only within four cubits,</b> as carrying in each courtyard is prohibited due to the other, because they did not establish an <i>eiruv</i> together. Rav does not accept the principle that an activity that was permitted at the start of Shabbat remains permitted until the conclusion of Shabbat.
<b>And Shmuel said:</b>

Daf 94a

<b>This</b> one <b>may carry to the base of the</b> former <b>partition, and that</b> one <b>may</b> likewise <b>carry to the base of the partition,</b> as he maintains that since it was permitted at the beginning of Shabbat, it remains permitted until the conclusion of Shabbat.
The Gemara comments: <b>And this</b> ruling <b>of Rav was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference;</b> i.e., it was inferred by his students from another one of his teachings. As once <b>Rav and Shmuel were sitting in a certain courtyard</b> on Shabbat, and <b>the wall between</b> the two courtyards <b>fell. Shmuel said to</b> the people around him: <b>Take a cloak</b> and <b>suspend it on</b> the remnant of the partition.
<b>Rav turned his face away,</b> displaying his displeasure with Shmuel’s opinion, as Rav maintained it was prohibited to carry a cloak in this courtyard. <b>Shmuel said to them</b> in a humorous vein: <b>If Abba,</b> Rav, <b>is particular, take his belt</b> and <b>tie it</b> to the cloak, to secure it to the partition.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Shmuel, why was it necessary</b> to suspend the cloak? He himself <b>said:</b> If a wall between two courtyards collapsed on Shabbat, <b>this</b> one <b>may carry to the base of the</b> former <b>partition, and that</b> one <b>may</b> likewise <b>carry to the base of the partition.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel</b> did not <b>do</b> so to render it permitted to carry in the courtyard. He did so <b>merely for</b> the purpose of <b>privacy,</b> as he did not want the residents of the other courtyard to see into his own courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav, if he maintains that</b> in this case carrying is <b>prohibited, he should have said</b> so <b>to him</b> explicitly. The Gemara answers: <b>It was Shmuel’s place.</b> Rav did not want to disagree with his colleague in his jurisdiction, as he accepted the opinion of the local authority.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if he accepted the jurisdiction of the local rabbinic authority, <b>why did he turn his face away?</b> The Gemara answers: He acted in this manner so <b>that</b> people would <b>not say</b> that <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, and</b> that <b>he retracted his</b> opinion with regard to this <b><i>halakha</i>.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a courtyard that was breached into the public domain,</b> and the breach was more than ten cubits wide, so that it cannot be considered an entrance, <b>one who carries</b> an object <b>from inside</b> the courtyard <b>into the private domain, or from the private domain into it, is liable,</b> as it ceases to be a private domain and is subsumed into the public domain. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis</b> disagree and <b>say:</b> One who carries <b>from inside</b> the courtyard <b>into the public domain, or from the public domain into it, is exempt, because its</b> legal status <b>is like</b> that of <b>a <i>karmelit</i>.</b> Although it ceases to be a private domain, it does not become a full-fledged public domain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Eliezer, due to</b> the fact that the courtyard <b>was breached into the public domain,</b> does <b>it become the public domain?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> as in this regard the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer:</b> In a situation where the <b>multitudes selected a path for themselves</b> in a field, or between fields, the path <b>that they selected, they selected,</b> and they retain the right to traverse this path even if the place belongs to an individual. Here too, as the partition of the courtyard was breached to the extent that the public can enter, its status is that of a public domain.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this opinion: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Rav Giddel say</b> that <b>Rav said: And this</b> applies only <b>if they had misplaced a path in that field.</b> Generally speaking, the public does not have the right to establish a path wherever it chooses. The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where a public path used to run through that field, but it fell into disuse, and no one remembers its precise course. In this case the public may once again select a path through the field.
<b>And if you say: Here too,</b> the mishna is dealing with a case <b>where</b> the public <b>misplaced a path in that courtyard.</b> They do not remember the exact position of the partition that once separated the courtyard and the public domain. The public claims that the residents of the courtyard appropriated that part of their domain. It is only this area that Rabbi Eliezer says is considered a public domain. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Ḥanina say:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis is with regard to the entire courtyard <b>to [ad] the place of</b> the fallen <b>partition,</b> not only the small section that might have been a public path.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Say</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina stated that Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis <b>disagree over [<i>al</i>] the place of</b> the <b>partition,</b> i.e., the dispute does not concern the entire courtyard, but only the former location of the partition, where a public path might once have passed.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the mishna is dealing with a case where the location of the original partition is known, and the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> the legal status of <b>the sides of a public domain. As Rabbi Eliezer maintains</b> that <b>the sides of a public domain are considered like a public domain,</b> i.e., the areas adjacent to the public domain are subsumed into the public domain. The same applies to the place of the partition that once separated the courtyard and the public domain but was breached. <b>And the Rabbis maintain</b> that <b>the sides of a public domain are not considered like a public domain.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let them disagree with regard to the sides of a public domain in general;</b> why did they disagree about this particular case? The Gemara answers: <b>Had they disagreed with regard to the sides of a public domain in general, we would have said: When do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer? This</b> dispute <b>applies only where there are stakes</b> alongside the houses, which interfere with the use of the sides of the public domain. <b>However, where there are no</b> such <b>stakes, say</b> that <b>they concede to him</b> that the sides of a public domain are considered like a public domain. By formulating the dispute with regard to a courtyard that was breached into the public domain, the mishna is <b>teaching us</b> that they disagree in all cases.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>say</b> with regard to a courtyard that was breached into the public domain, that one who carries an object <b>from inside</b> the courtyard into the private domain is liable? Apparently, he is liable if he carries an article into the private domain from anywhere in the courtyard, not only from the area adjacent to the public domain, as the entire courtyard is considered a public domain.
The Gemara answers: <b>As the Rabbis said: From inside</b> the courtyard, Rabbi Eliezer <b>also said: From inside</b> the courtyard. No conclusion can be inferred from his use of the term, as he was referring only to the section adjacent to the public domain.
The Gemara asks: <b>But,</b> if that is the case, the statement of <b>the Rabbis</b> is difficult. <b>Rabbi Eliezer said</b> that the legal status of <b>the sides of the public domain</b> is like that of a public domain, <b>and they replied to him</b> by referring to: <b>From inside</b> the entire courtyard? They appear to be addressing two different cases.
The Gemara answers: <b>This is what the Rabbis are saying to Rabbi Eliezer: Don’t you concede to us</b> with regard to a case <b>where he carried</b> an object <b>from inside</b> the courtyard <b>to the public domain, or from the public domain to</b> the courtyard, <b>that</b> he is <b>exempt, because</b> the courtyard <b>is</b> considered <b>like a <i>karmelit</i>? The sides</b> of the public domain are <b>no different,</b> and should have the status of a <i>karmelit</i> <b>as well.</b>
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> counter this argument? <b>There, the public does not tread on</b> the courtyard; <b>here,</b> the <b>public treads on</b> the edge of the courtyard adjacent to the public domain, and therefore its status is that of a public domain in every sense.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a courtyard that was breached</b> on Shabbat <b>into a public domain from two</b> of <b>its sides, and likewise</b> with regard to <b>a house that was breached from two</b> of <b>its sides, and likewise</b> with regard to <b>an alleyway whose</b> cross <b>beams or side posts were removed</b> on Shabbat, the residents of that domain <b>are permitted</b> to carry there <b>on that Shabbat, but are prohibited</b> from doing so <b>in the future.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> This cannot be the <i>halakha</i>, as <b>if they are permitted</b> to carry there <b>on that Shabbat, they are</b> likewise <b>permitted</b> to do so <b>in the future, and if they are prohibited</b> from carrying there <b>in the future, they are</b> also <b>prohibited</b> from carrying there <b>on that Shabbat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara poses a question: <b>With what</b> case <b>are we dealing? If you say</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the breach was up to <b>ten</b> cubits wide, in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> a breach <b>on</b> only <b>one side different?</b> It is due to the fact <b>that we say: It is an entrance</b> rather than a breach, and carrying is therefore permitted. If so, if it was breached <b>on two sides as well,</b> say: <b>It is an entrance,</b> and there are entrances on two sides of the courtyard. <b>Rather,</b> the mishna is certainly dealing <b>with</b> a breach that is <b>greater than ten</b> cubits. <b>If so,</b> it should be prohibited to carry <b>even</b> if the courtyard was breached <b>on</b> only <b>one side,</b> as a breach that size negates all the partitions.
<b>Rav said: Actually,</b> the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a breach that is no wider than <b>ten</b> cubits,

Daf 94b

<b>and</b> with a case <b>where</b> the courtyard <b>was breached in a corner,</b> so that it is breached on two sides. Although the opening is no more than ten cubits wide, it cannot be considered an entrance, <b>as people do not build an entrance in a corner.</b> It is therefore clear that this is a breach that negates the partition.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And likewise,</b> with regard to <b>a house that was breached</b> on Shabbat <b>from two of its sides</b> into a public domain, the residents are permitted to carry in the house on that Shabbat, but not a future Shabbat. The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> a breach <b>on one side different?</b> The difference is due to the fact <b>that we say: The edge of the roof descends and seals</b> the house, as if there were a full-fledged partition there. <b>So too,</b> when it is breached <b>on two sides, let us say: The edge of the roof descends and seals.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> Sages of the <b>school of Rav said in the name of Rav:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the house <b>was breached in a corner, and its roofing was inclined, as</b> in that case, <b>one cannot say: The edge of the roof descends and seals,</b> as the edge of an inclined roof does not appear to be the beginning of a partition.
<b>And Shmuel said:</b> The mishna is referring to a breach that is <b>even wider than ten</b> cubits. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> why did the mishna cite a case where it is breached from two sides? It should be prohibited to carry there <b>even</b> if it were breached <b>from one side.</b>
The Gemara answers: The reason that it is prohibited only if it is breached from two sides is <b>due to</b> the fact that it is <b>a house.</b> In the case of a courtyard, the same <i>halakha</i> would apply even if it were breached on only one side. However, the mishna sought to teach the <i>halakha</i> of a house as well, in which case, it is prohibited to carry only if it is breached on two sides. If it is breached on one side, the edge of the roof descends and seals, and carrying is permitted.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a house itself should pose a difficulty</b> according to this explanation. In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> a breach <b>on one side different?</b> It is due to the fact <b>that we say: The edge of the roof descends and seals</b> the house, as if there were a full-fledged partition there. <b>So too,</b> when it is breached <b>on two sides, let us say: The edge of the roof descends and seals.</b>
<b>And furthermore: Is Shmuel of</b> the opinion that there is a principle: <b>The edge of a roof descends and seals? But wasn’t it stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute with regard to a <b>portico</b> located <b>in a valley,</b> which has the status of a <i>karmelit</i>. <b>Rav said:</b> It <b>is permitted to carry in the entire</b> portico, as he maintains that the edge of the roof of the portico descends and seals, rendering it a private domain. <b>And Shmuel said: One may carry only within four cubits.</b> Apparently, Shmuel does not accept the principle: The edge of a roof descends and seals.
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is <b>not a difficulty. Where</b> Shmuel <b>is not of</b> the opinion that this principle is applied, it is <b>with regard to</b> a structure where walls on all <b>four</b> sides are formed in that manner. <b>However, with regard to</b> a structure where only <b>three</b> sides are formed in that manner and the fourth side is an actual wall, <b>he is of</b> the opinion that the principle is applied.
The Gemara comments: <b>In any case,</b> this is <b>difficult.</b> Although the contradiction between the two statements of Shmuel was resolved, the question remains: Why do we not apply the principle: The edge of a roof descends and seals, to two sides of the house?
The Gemara answers: The reason is <b>as the</b> Sages of the <b>school of Rav said in the name of Rav:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the house <b>was breached in a corner, and its roofing was inclined,</b> as in that case, one cannot say: The roof of the house descends and seals. <b>Here too,</b> Shmuel’s opinion can be explained in a similar manner: The mishna is dealing with a case <b>where</b> the house <b>was breached in a corner, and its roof is</b> at a distance <b>of</b> at least <b>four</b> handbreadths from the breach, and is uneven. In that case, the principle: The edge of a roof descends and seals, would have to be applied to four corners, and Shmuel is of the opinion that it may not be applied in that case.
The Gemara explains: <b>Shmuel did not say</b> his explanation of the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, as</b> the mishna <b>does not teach</b> that the roof was <b>slanted,</b> which is the crux of Rav’s explanation. <b>And Rav did not say</b> his explanation of the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> as <b>if so,</b> even if the roof was breached on several sides, <b>its</b> legal status would be that of <b>a portico, and Rav</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he said:</b> With regard to <b>a portico, it is permitted to carry throughout the entire</b> portico.
The Gemara proceeds to cite the dispute between Rav and Shmuel in a more comprehensive manner. <b>As it was stated</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It <b>is permitted to carry in the entire</b> portico as it is considered sealed. <b>And Shmuel said: One may carry only within four cubits.</b> As the portico does not have actual partitions it is subsumed into the field, and shares its status of a <i>karmelit</i>.
The Gemara elaborates on their respective opinions. <b>Rav said: It is permitted to carry in the entire</b> portico, as he maintains that <b>we say: The edge of the roof descends and seals</b> the portico to form a partition. As there is a roof over the portico, it is considered sealed with partitions on all four sides. <b>And Shmuel said: One may carry only within four cubits,</b> as <b>we do not say: The edge of the ceiling descends and seals.</b>
The Gemara elaborates further: If the openings on the sides of the portico are no wider than <b>ten</b> cubits, <b>everyone agrees</b> that they are considered sealed, as the status of even an unroofed breach of ten cubits or less is that of an entrance, and one is permitted to carry throughout the entire domain. <b>They disagree</b> only in a case <b>where</b> the openings are <b>more than ten</b> cubits wide.
<b>And some say:</b> On the contrary, if the openings are <b>more</b> than ten cubits wide, <b>everyone agrees</b> that they are considered breaches, and the principle: The edge of the roof descends and seals, is not applied. <b>They disagree</b> only in a case <b>where</b> the openings are no wider than <b>ten</b> cubits.
<b>And that which Rav Yehuda said:</b>

Daf 95a

<b>A</b> cross <b>beam four</b> handbreadths wide <b>renders</b> carrying <b>in a ruin</b> that is breached into a public domain <b>permitted,</b> as the edge of the cross beam is considered to descend and seal the breach. <b>And</b> that which <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: A</b> cross <b>beam four</b> handbreadths wide <b>renders</b> carrying <b>in water permitted</b> like a partition. In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion were these rulings stated?
The Gemara explains: <b>According to this version that you stated,</b> that Rav and Shmuel <b>agree with regard to</b> an opening no wider than <b>ten</b> cubits, here it is referring <b>to</b> a cross beam that is no longer than <b>ten</b> cubits, <b>and everyone,</b> both Rav and Shmuel, <b>agrees</b> with these rulings. <b>According to that</b> other <b>version that you stated,</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> an opening no wider than <b>ten</b> cubits, these rulings are <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> alone.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Abaye and Rava are disagreeing with regard to the</b> point that was the subject of a <b>dispute between Rav and Shmuel. As it was stated:</b> If one <b>placed roofing on top of a portico that has doorposts,</b> i.e., pillars that form the beginnings of partitions, <b>it is a valid <i>sukka</i>.</b> If, however, he placed the roofing atop a portico that <b>has no doorposts,</b> there is a dispute. <b>Abaye said: It is a valid <i>sukka</i>. And Rava said: It is invalid.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Abaye said: It is valid.</b> As <b>he said: The edge of a roof descends and seals.</b> Since the portico is roofed, it is considered to have partitions as well. <b>And Rava said: It is invalid,</b> as <b>he did not say: The edge of a roof descends and seals. Let us say</b> that <b>Abaye</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, and Rava</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, everyone,</b> including Abaye, <b>agrees</b> that this <i>sukka</i> is invalid. <b>Where they disagree</b> is <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav. Abaye</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> in a straightforward manner. <b>And Rava</b> claims: <b>Rav stated</b> his opinion, that the edge of the portico descends and seals, <b>only there, where those partitions</b> formed by the roof <b>were built for the portico,</b> and they are therefore viewed as sealing it. <b>However, here, where these partitions were not built for</b> the mitzva of <b><i>sukka</i>, no,</b> even Rav would agree that the partitions are not sufficiently significant to utilize for the purpose of this mitzva.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yosei says: If they are permitted</b> to carry there on that Shabbat, they are likewise permitted to do so in the future, and if they are prohibited from carrying there in the future, they are also prohibited from carrying there on that Shabbat <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Did <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> intend <b>to prohibit</b> carrying even on that Shabbat, <b>or to permit</b> carrying even in the future?
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> His intention was <b>to prohibit</b> carrying even on that Shabbat. <b>And similarly, Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> His intention was <b>to prohibit</b> carrying even on that Shabbat. <b>This</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei said: Just as they are prohibited</b> from carrying <b>in the future, so are they prohibited</b> from carrying <b>on that Shabbat.</b>
<b>It was stated: Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, while Shmuel said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>But did Shmuel</b> really <b>say this? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: In what</b> case <b>are these matters,</b> that an <i>eiruv</i> may be established for a person only with his knowledge, <b>stated?</b> It is <b>with regard to a joining of</b> Shabbat <b>boundaries, but with regard to a joining of courtyards, one may establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> for another person <b>both with his knowledge and without his knowledge, because one may act in a person’s interest</b> even when <b>not in his presence, but one may act to</b> his <b>disadvantage only in his presence.</b> One may take unilateral action on another’s behalf when it is to that other person’s benefit. However, if it is to that person’s disadvantage, or when the action entails both benefits and disadvantages, he may act on the other person’s behalf only if he was explicitly appointed as his agent. A joining of courtyards is always to a person’s benefit, and therefore it can be established even without his knowledge. However, with regard to a joining of Shabbat boundaries, any distance that a person gains in one direction he forfeits in the opposite direction. Consequently, this type of <i>eiruv</i> may be established only with his knowledge.
<b>And Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. And furthermore, anyplace where Rabbi Yehuda taught with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>eiruv</i>, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion.
<b>And Rav Ḥana of Baghdad said to Rav Yehuda:</b> Did <b>Shmuel state</b> this ruling <b>even with regard to an alleyway whose</b> cross <b>beam or side post was removed</b> during Shabbat? <b>And</b> Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: I spoke to you with regard to</b> the acquisition of <b>an <i>eiruv</i>, and not with regard to partitions.</b> The Gemara asks: How, then, could Shmuel rule that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda in this case, after explicitly stating that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his opinion in the case of fallen partitions?
<b>Rav Anan said:</b> This matter <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Shmuel</b> himself: <b>Here,</b> where Shmuel rules in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, it is in a case <b>where</b> the courtyard <b>was breached into a <i>karmelit</i>.</b> In that case the <i>halakha</i> is lenient, as there is no concern lest one transgress a Torah prohibition. <b>There,</b> where Shmuel states that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, it is in a case <b>where</b> the courtyard <b>was breached into a public domain,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is therefore stringent, due to the concern lest one transgress a Torah prohibition.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who builds an upper story atop two houses</b> on opposite sides of a public domain that passes beneath it, <b>and likewise bridges with a thoroughfare</b> beneath them that rest on walls on opposite sides of a public domain, <b>one</b> may <b>carry beneath</b> the upper story and beneath the bridge <b>on Shabbat.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that these areas are considered private domains. <b>And the Rabbis prohibit</b> carrying in these areas.
<b>And furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said: One</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> even <b>for an alleyway that is open</b> at both ends, with no need for any additional measures, <b>and the Rabbis prohibit</b> doing so.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabba said: Do not say this is Rabbi Yehuda’s reason; that he maintains</b> that <b>by Torah law two partitions</b> constitute a private domain, i.e., the areas beneath the upper story and the bridge are considered private domains, as each has two partitions, one on each side of the public domain. Rather, the reason for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion is <b>because he maintains</b> that <b>the edge of a roof descends and seals.</b> The edges of the upper story and the bridge are considered to seal the areas beneath them.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rabba from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> With regard to <b>one who has two houses on two sides of a public domain</b> and seeks to carry from one house to the other on Shabbat via the public domain, <b>he places a side post from here,</b> adjacent to one of the houses, <b>and</b> another <b>side post from there,</b> adjacent to the other house, <b>or</b> he places <b>a</b> cross <b>beam from here and</b> another cross <b>beam from there, and he may</b> subsequently <b>carry</b> objects <b>and place</b> them <b>in the middle</b> of the area, as he transformed it into a private domain. His colleagues <b>said to him: One cannot establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> to transform a <b>public domain</b> into a private domain <b>in this manner.</b> Clearly, the rationale for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion in that case is not that the edge of the roof descends and seals, as the area is not covered. Rather, he apparently holds that by Torah law, two walls suffice to form a private domain.
Rabba <b>said to him: From that</b> <i>baraita</i>, <b>yes,</b> it is indeed possible to arrive at this conclusion. But <b>from this,</b> the mishna, <b>nothing can be learned from this</b> source, as there could be a different reason for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion.
<b>Rav Ashi said: The mishna is also precise</b> in its wording, as it indicates that the rationale for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion is that the edge of a roof descends and seals. <b>As</b> the mishna <b>teaches: And furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said: One</b> may <b>establish an <i>eiruv</i></b> even <b>for an alleyway that is open</b> at both ends, <b>and the Rabbis prohibit</b> doing so.
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that the reason for Rabbi Yehuda’s leniency with regard to carrying beneath an upper story and a bridge is <b>that he maintains</b> that <b>the edge of a roof descends and seals, that is</b> why the mishna <b>states: And furthermore,</b> to introduce the ruling for an alleyway. In other words, the <i>tanna</i> of our mishna is saying that the ruling applies not only to a roofed area, but also to an unroofed alleyway, despite the fact that the reason there is that two partitions suffice to create a private domain by Torah law.
<b>However, if you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda permitted the first case as well <b>because he maintains</b> that <b>by Torah law two partitions</b> suffice to create a private domain, <b>what</b> is the need for the introduction: <b>And furthermore?</b> The rationale for the second ruling is no different from the rationale for the first. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from here</b> that this is correct.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who finds phylacteries</b> outside the city on Shabbat, where they are in danger of becoming lost or damaged, <b>brings them in</b> to his house <b>pair</b> by <b>pair</b> by donning them in the manner in which they are typically donned for the mitzva. <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> He brings them in <b>two</b> pairs by <b>two</b> pairs. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement</b> that one is permitted to carry phylacteries inside <b>said?</b> It is <b>with regard to old</b> phylacteries, which have already been used and are designated for the mitzva. <b>However, with regard to new</b> ones, as it is unclear whether they are phylacteries or merely amulets in the form of phylacteries, he is <b>exempt</b> from performing the task.
If <b>one finds</b> phylacteries <b>tied in bundles or in wrapped piles,</b> in which case he is unable to carry them in pairs, <b>he</b> sits there and <b>waits with them until dark,</b> guarding them until the conclusion of Shabbat, <b>and</b> then <b>brings them in</b> to his house.

Daf 95b

<b>And in</b> a time of <b>danger,</b> when it is dangerous to tarry outside town, <b>he covers</b> the phylacteries <b>and proceeds on his</b> way.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that there is an alternative method of transferring the phylacteries: <b>One gives them to another</b> who is less than four cubits from him, <b>and the other</b> passes them <b>to another, until</b> the phylacteries <b>reach the outermost courtyard</b> of the city. Since carrying less than four cubits in a public domain is not prohibited by Torah law, in this case, the Sages permitted carrying in that manner due to the sanctity of the phylacteries.
<b>And similarly,</b> with regard to <b>one’s son</b> who was born in a field and may not be carried on Shabbat, since that is akin to carrying a burden in the public domain: <b>One gives him to another, and the other</b> passes him <b>to another, even</b> if it requires <b>a hundred</b> people. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: A person</b> may even <b>give a barrel to another, and the other</b> may pass it <b>to another,</b> and in that way <b>even</b> take it <b>beyond the</b> Shabbat <b>limit,</b> provided that no one person carries it more than four cubits. <b>They said to him: This</b> barrel may <b>not go a greater</b> distance <b>than the feet of its owner,</b> i.e., it may not be carried any farther than its owner may walk.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that a person who finds phylacteries in a field may carry them by pairs, indicating that <b>one pair, yes,</b> it may be carried; however, <b>more</b> than one pair, <b>no,</b> they may not be carried. The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>we learned the unattributed</b> mishna <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> despite the principle that an unattributed mishna usually reflects Rabbi Meir’s opinion.
<b>As, if</b> you say that the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, didn’t</b> Rabbi Meir <b>say:</b> In order to rescue items from a fire, one is permitted to remove items from his house by wearing them, and <b>he dons all</b> the clothes <b>that he can wear, and wraps</b> himself <b>in all</b> items in <b>which he can wrap</b> himself. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>And one removes all the utensils to</b> the courtyard adjacent to the fire, <b>and dons all</b> the garments <b>that he can wear, and wraps</b> himself in <b>all</b> the items in <b>which he can wrap</b> himself in order to rescue his property.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where</b> do we know that <b>this unattributed</b> mishna with regard to Shabbat <b>is</b> a reflection of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir? As it teaches with regard to</b> that mishna: If there are many garments there, one <b>dons</b> garments, and <b>takes</b> them <b>out</b> to a safe place, <b>and removes</b> them there, <b>and returns</b> to the fire, <b>and dons</b> other garments, <b>and takes</b> them <b>out and removes</b> them. <b>And</b> he may do so <b>even all day long;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> Apparently, according to Rabbi Meir, one may don many garments at once.
In answer to the question, <b>Rava said: Even if you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> there is a distinction between the cases. <b>There,</b> if he dons the clothes in <b>the manner that he</b> typically <b>wears them, the Sages rendered</b> the legal status of wearing garments on Shabbat <b>like</b> the status of wearing garments during the <b>week</b> and permitted him to remove clothes from his house by wearing them in that manner. <b>And here,</b> too, if he dons phylacteries in <b>the manner that he</b> typically <b>dons them, the Sages rendered</b> the legal status of donning phylacteries on Shabbat <b>like</b> the status of donning phylacteries during the <b>week.</b>
Consequently, <b>there, where during the week he</b> may <b>wear as many</b> clothes <b>as he wishes, with regard to rescue</b> from a fire <b>the Sages likewise permitted him</b> to wear as many clothes as he wishes. However, <b>here,</b> in the case of phylacteries, <b>even during the week,</b> donning <b>one pair, yes,</b> one may do so, but donning <b>more</b> than one pair, <b>no,</b> he may not do so. Therefore, <b>with regard to rescue as well,</b> the Sages said: Donning <b>one pair, yes,</b> one may do so; however, donning <b>more</b> than one pair, <b>no,</b> he may not.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> He brings the phylacteries in <b>two</b> pairs <b>by two</b> pairs. The Gemara asks: <b>What does he hold?</b> What is the rationale for this <i>halakha</i>? <b>If he holds</b> that <b>Shabbat is a time for phylacteries,</b> and one is permitted or even obligated to don phylacteries on Shabbat, then the ruling should be: Donning <b>one pair, yes,</b> this is permitted; donning <b>more, no,</b> it is prohibited. It should be prohibited to wear more than one pair as there is room to don only one set of phylacteries on one’s head.
<b>And if he holds</b> that <b>Shabbat is not a time for phylacteries, and</b> it was only <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>rescue</b> was permitted only in the <b>manner</b> that one typically wears <b>clothing</b> that <b>the Sages permitted him</b> to don phylacteries, he should <b>likewise</b> be permitted to don <b>even more</b> than two pairs. He should be permitted to don as many pairs of phylacteries as possible, not only two.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually, he holds</b> that <b>Shabbat is not a time for phylacteries, and when the Sages permitted</b> one to don phylacteries <b>for the purpose of rescue,</b> it was only by donning them in the <b>manner</b> that one typically wears <b>clothing,</b> i.e., in the appropriate <b>place</b> for <b>phylacteries.</b> He may not don them anywhere else on his body, as in that case he is considered to be carrying, not wearing them.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> then <b>one pair, yes,</b> it should be permitted, but <b>more, no,</b> it should not be permitted, as the second pair is necessarily positioned out of place. <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: There is room on</b> one’s <b>head to place two phylacteries.</b> One can place two phylacteries on his head and don them both in the proper manner.
The Gemara asks: <b>It works out well</b> with regard to donning two phylacteries <b>of the head,</b> as there is room; however, with regard to the phylacteries <b>of the arm, what is there to say?</b> How can one wear two phylacteries on his arm simultaneously?
The Gemara answers that even when one dons two phylacteries on his arm, he is regarded as donning them in the typical manner, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna. As Rav Huna said: Sometimes a person comes from the field with his bundle on his head,</b> and in order not to crush the phylacteries, he <b>removes them from his head and binds them on his arm.</b> This indicates that there is room for additional phylacteries on his arm.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Say that Rav Huna said</b> that one may remove the phylacteries from his head and tie them on his arm <b>so that he will not</b> come to <b>treat</b> them <b>in a degrading manner</b> by placing a bundle on top of them. However, <b>did he say</b> that the spot on his arm is <b>fit</b> for two phylacteries? Can proof be cited from here that one may don additional phylacteries on his arm <i>ab initio</i>?
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: There is room on</b> one’s <b>head to place two phylacteries. Here, too, there is room on the arm to place two phylacteries.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>The school of Menashe taught</b> the following. The verse states: “And you shall bind them for a sign on your arm, and they shall be as frontlets between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 6:8). <b>“On your arm,” this is the biceps</b> muscle of the arm; <b>“between your eyes,” this is the crown</b> of the head. The Gemara asks: <b>Where</b> exactly on the crown of the head? <b>The school of Rabbi Yannai say:</b> Phylacteries are placed on <b>the spot where a baby’s head is soft</b> after birth.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say that</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> of the mishna <b>disagree about</b> the principle of <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak,</b> such <b>that the first <i>tanna</i> is not</b> of the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak</b> that there is room on one’s head for two phylacteries, <b>while Rabban Gamliel is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak,</b> and therefore one is permitted to bring in two pairs of phylacteries at a time.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone is</b> of the opinion of <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak, and here they disagree with regard to</b> whether or not <b>Shabbat is a time for phylacteries. The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>Shabbat is a time for phylacteries.</b> Although one may don one pair of phylacteries, he may not add to the mitzva by donning an extra pair. If he does so, it is tantamount to carrying a prohibited burden.
<b>And Rabban Gamliel holds</b> that <b>Shabbat is not a time for phylacteries.</b> Consequently, one may don more than one pair, as the day itself is not at all suitable for donning phylacteries. When he dons the second pair, he is not adding to the mitzva. With regard to rescuing them, the phylacteries have the legal status of an ornament that he is permitted to don, provided that he dons no more than two pairs.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the dispute should be understood as follows. <b>Everyone agrees that Shabbat is a time for phylacteries, and here they disagree with regard to</b> whether or not fulfillment of <b>mitzvot requires intent. The first <i>tanna</i> holds: To fulfill</b> a mitzva one <b>needs intent.</b> Therefore, if one dons phylacteries without intent to fulfill the mitzva, no mitzva is performed, and he is merely carrying a burden. However, if he has intent to fulfill the mitzva, he may don no more than one pair. If he does so, he violates the prohibition against adding to mitzvot.
<b>And Rabban Gamliel holds:</b> In order to fulfill a mitzva, <b>one does not need intent.</b> Therefore, if one dons two pairs of phylacteries he fulfills his obligation with one of them, but does not violate the prohibition against adding to mitzvot with the other. In order to do so, he would require specific intent to fulfill a second mitzva with the additional pair.

Daf 96a

<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>to fulfill</b> a mitzva <b>one does not need intent, and here they disagree with regard to</b> the condition needed <b>to violate</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not add</b> to mitzvot of the Torah. <b>As the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>one does not need intent to violate</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not add</b> to mitzvot. One who dons another pair of phylacteries transgresses the prohibition against adding to mitzvot even if he does not don them with the intention of fulfilling the mitzva. <b>And Rabban Gamliel holds</b> that in order <b>to violate</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not add</b> to mitzvot, <b>one needs intent</b> to perform a mitzva. Since in this case one’s intention is merely to move the phylacteries to a safer place, he may don a second pair.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the dispute may be explained as follows. <b>If we were to maintain</b> that <b>Shabbat is</b> a fit <b>time for</b> donning <b>phylacteries, everyone</b> would <b>agree</b> that <b>one does not need intent to violate</b> the prohibition against adding to mitzvot, <b>nor does one need intent to fulfill</b> a mitzva. In this case, one’s intention has no bearing on his action.
