<b>However, here, they disagree with regard to</b> the condition for <b>violating</b> the prohibition against adding to a mitzva <b>not in its</b> proper <b>time,</b> i.e., when a mitzva is performed not at its prescribed time. <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that if the act of a mitzva is performed not in its proper time, <b>one does not need intent;</b> that is, even if one does not intend to perform the mitzva he nonetheless violates the prohibition against adding to mitzvot by his action alone. Consequently, in this case, a person may not don more than one pair of phylacteries. <b>And Rabban Gamliel holds that to violate</b> the prohibition against adding to a mitzva <b>not in its</b> proper <b>time, one needs intent</b> to fulfill the mitzva. Without such intent one does not violate the prohibition, and therefore in this case he may don a second pair of phylacteries.
With regard to this last explanation the Gemara asks: <b>If so, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> one should <b>not even</b> don <b>one pair</b> of phylacteries. According to Rabbi Meir’s opinion, one who does so violates the prohibition against adding to mitzvot merely by donning one pair, since he is fulfilling the mitzva of phylacteries at a time when he is not commanded to do so.
<b>And furthermore,</b> according to this opinion, <b>one who sleeps in a <i>sukka</i> on the Eighth Day</b> of Assembly <b>should be flogged</b> for violating the prohibition against adding to mitzvot, as he adds to the mitzva of: “You shall dwell in booths for seven days” (Leviticus 23:42). Yet the Sages instituted that outside of Eretz Yisrael, Jews must observe <i>Sukkot</i> for eight days, even though one who sleeps in a <i>sukka</i> on the eighth night outside of Eretz Yisrael transgresses a Torah law. <b>Rather, it is clear as we originally answered,</b> i.e., you must accept one of the other explanations.
Since the topic of phylacteries was discussed, the Gemara continues to explore this issue. <b>Whom did you hear</b> who said that <b>Shabbat is</b> a fit <b>time for</b> donning <b>phylacteries?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Akiva, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the end of the section in the Torah beginning with: “Sanctify all firstborns to me” (Exodus 13:2), which deals with the mitzvot of the Paschal lamb and phylacteries: <b>“And you shall observe this ordinance in its season from year [<i>miyamim</i>] to year”</b> (Exodus 13:10), which indicates that these mitzvot apply during the <b>days</b> [<b><i>yamim</i></b>] <b>and not</b> during the <b>nights.</b> Furthermore, the letter <i>mem</i> in <b>“from year” [<i>miyamim</i>]</b> teaches: <b>But not</b> on <b>all days;</b> this <b>excludes Shabbat and Festivals,</b> on which phylacteries are not worn. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: This ordinance is stated only with regard to the Paschal</b> lamb, and it does not refer to phylacteries at all. According to Rabbi Akiva, there is no reason to refrain from donning phylacteries on Shabbat and Festivals.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that</b> which <b>we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>the Paschal</b> lamb <b>and circumcision are positive mitzvot, let us say that</b> this statement is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> The reason for this claim is <b>that if</b> you say this teaching is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, since he establishes</b> this verse as referring <b>to the Paschal</b> lamb, this would mean that in failure to bring this offering there <b>is also</b> the violation of <b>a negative</b> mitzva, <b>in accordance with</b> the principle <b>that Rabbi Avin</b> said that <b>Rabbi Elai said. As Rabbi Avin said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elai said: Any place</b> where <b>it is stated: Observe, lest, or do not,</b> this means <b>nothing other than a negative</b> mitzva, as these are negative terms. Consequently, the verse “You shall observe this ordinance,” which refers to the Paschal lamb, constitutes a negative mitzva.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Even if you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> holds that no negative mitzva applies to the Paschal lamb, it is not difficult, as an additional principle must be taken into account. Although it is true that the term <b>observe with regard to a negative</b> mitzva indicates the presence of another <b>negative</b> mitzva; that same term <b>observe</b> with regard to <b>a positive</b> mitzva has the force of <b>a positive</b> mitzva, as the Torah is warning adherents to take special care in the observance of a mitzva. The word observe in connection with the Paschal lamb is an example of this type of positive mitzva.
The Gemara returns to the issue at hand: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> really <b>hold that Shabbat is a time for</b> donning <b>phylacteries? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person should don phylacteries on <i>Shabbatot</i> and Festivals.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And it shall be for a sign for you on your arm,</b> and for a remembrance between your eyes, so that God’s law shall be in your mouth; for with a strong arm God brought you out of Egypt” (Exodus 13:9). The obligation to don phylacteries applies when Jews <b>require a sign</b> to assert their Judaism and their status as the Chosen People, i.e., during the week, <b>excluding</b> Shabbat and Festivals, <b>as they are themselves signs</b> of Israel’s status as the Chosen People and a remembrance of the exodus from Egypt. Consequently, no further sign is required on these days. This teaching proves that Rabbi Akiva maintains that Shabbat is not a fit time for donning phylacteries.
<b>Rather, it is this <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Natan, who maintains that Shabbat is a fit time for donning phylacteries, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who is awake at night, if he wishes he</b> may <b>remove</b> his phylacteries, and <b>if he wishes he</b> may continue to <b>don</b> them, and he need not worry about violating the prohibition against adding to mitzvot. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Natan. Yonatan HaKitoni says: One</b> may <b>not don phylacteries at night. From</b> the fact <b>that according to the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Natan, <b>night is</b> a fit <b>time for phylacteries,</b> it may be inferred that <b>Shabbat, too, is a time for</b> donning <b>phylacteries,</b> as Rabbi Natan evidently does not accept Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s limitation based on the phrase: From year to year.
The Gemara rejects this contention: This is not a conclusive proof, as <b>perhaps he holds</b> that although <b>night is</b> a fit <b>time for phylacteries, Shabbat is not</b> a fit <b>time for phylacteries. As we</b> have <b>heard that Rabbi Akiva said</b> that <b>night is a time for phylacteries,</b> because he does not accept the limitation of “from days to days,” and yet he maintains that <b>Shabbat is not a time for phylacteries,</b> as no sign is required on Shabbat. It is therefore possible that Rabbi Natan holds the same opinion.
<b>Rather,</b> we must say that <b>it is this <i>tanna</i></b> who maintains that Shabbat is a time for phylacteries, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Michal, daughter of Kushi,</b> King Saul, <b>would don phylacteries, and the Sages did not protest against her</b> behavior, as she was permitted to do so. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>Jonah’s wife would undertake the Festival pilgrimage and the Sages did not protest against her</b> practice. <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the Sages did not protest against</b> Michal’s donning phylacteries, <b>it is apparent that these</b> Sages <b>hold</b> that phylacteries <b>is a positive mitzva not bound by time,</b> i.e., it is a mitzva whose performance is mandated at all times, including nights and Shabbat. There is an accepted principle that women are obligated in all positive mitzvot not bound by time.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>But perhaps</b> that <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b>

Daf 96b

<b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who said:</b> It is <b>optional</b> for <b>women</b> to <b>place</b> their hands on the head of a sacrificial animal before it is slaughtered. Although only men have this obligation, women may perform that rite if they wish. Similarly, women may perform other mitzvot that they have no obligation to fulfill.
<b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that this <i>tanna</i> holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, the <i>baraita</i> states that <b>Jonah’s wife would ascend</b> to Jerusalem for <b>the Festival pilgrimage and</b> the Sages <b>did not reprimand her. Is there anyone who says</b> that the mitzva of <b>Festival</b> pilgrimage <b>is not a time-bound positive mitzva</b> and that women are obligated to fulfill it? <b>Rather, he holds</b> that she did not embark on the pilgrimage as an obligation, but that it was <b>optional; here, too,</b> with regard to phylacteries, it is <b>optional.</b> Consequently, no proof can be cited from this <i>baraita</i> as to whether or not Shabbat is a fit time for phylacteries.
<b>Rather,</b> who is the <i>tanna</i> who maintains that Shabbat is a time for phylacteries? <b>It is this <i>tanna</i></b> who taught the <i>halakha</i>, <b>as it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who finds phylacteries brings them in pair</b> by <b>pair, whether</b> the finder is <b>a man or whether</b> she is <b>a woman,</b> and <b>whether</b> the phylacteries are <b>new or whether</b> they are <b>old.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda prohibits</b> bringing in <b>new</b> phylacteries since they might merely be amulets in the form of phylacteries, <b>but</b> he <b>permits</b> bringing in <b>old</b> ones, which are certainly valid phylacteries.
Analysis of this <i>Tosefta</i> indicates that Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda <b>disagree only with regard to</b> the issue of <b>new</b> phylacteries <b>and old ones; however, with regard to a woman</b> bringing in the phylacteries, <b>they do not disagree</b> that it is permitted. <b>Learn from it</b> that this <i>tanna</i> maintains that donning phylacteries <b>is a positive mitzva not bound by time, and</b> since <b>women are obligated in every positive mitzva not bound by time,</b> a woman may don these phylacteries and walk into the town.
The Gemara attempts to refute this. <b>But perhaps</b> that <i>tanna</i> <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who said:</b> It is <b>optional</b> for <b>women</b> to <b>place</b> their hands on the head of a sacrificial animal before it is slaughtered. Here too, perhaps it is optional for women to don phylacteries. The Gemara answers: <b>This cannot enter your mind, as neither Rabbi Meir holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, nor does Rabbi Yehuda hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> as the Gemara proceeds to prove.
<b>Neither Rabbi Meir holds in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One</b> need <b>not prevent children from sounding</b> the <i>shofar</i> on Rosh HaShana. Although there is an element of prohibition in sounding the <i>shofar</i> when there is no obligation to do so, since the children will one day be obligated to sound the <i>shofar</i>, one need not prevent them from doing so and learning. It may be inferred from here that <b>one must prevent women</b> from sounding the <i>shofar</i>. <b>And an unattributed mishna</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> indicating that according to Rabbi Meir, a woman does not even have the option of performing a time-bound positive mitzva.
<b>Nor does Rabbi Yehuda hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as it was taught</b> in the <i>Sifra</i>, the halakhic <i>midrash</i> on Leviticus. The verse states: <b>“Speak to the sons of Israel…and he shall place</b> his hands on the head of the burnt-offering” (Leviticus 1:2–4). By inference, <b>the sons of Israel place</b> their hands, <b>but the daughters of Israel do not place</b> their hands. <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> It is <b>optional</b> for <b>women</b> to <b>place</b> their hands on the head of a sacrificial animal before it is slaughtered.
<b>And who is</b> the author of <b>an unattributed <i>Sifra</i>?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> This teaching proves that Rabbi Yehuda maintains that women do not have the option of placing their hands on a sacrifice. Neither Rabbi Meir nor Rabbi Yehuda accepts Rabbi Yosei’s opinion that it is optional for women to perform time-bound positive mitzvot; therefore, the <i>tanna</i> who cited their opinions that a woman may bring in phylacteries on Shabbat maintains that the mitzva of phylacteries is not time-bound and is in effect even on Shabbat, which is why even women are obligated.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> With regard to <b>one who one finds</b> fabric dyed <b>sky blue in the marketplace,</b> if he found <b>strips</b> of combed and dyed wool <b>they are unfit</b> for use as ritual fringes. The sky blue threads used in ritual fringes must be spun and dyed for the purpose of the mitzva, and these strips might have been dyed for a different purpose. However, if one found sky blue <b>threads, they are fit</b> for use in ritual fringes, as it can be assumed they were prepared for that purpose.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>strips</b> that renders them unfit? It is because Rabbi Elazar <b>said: One dyed</b> the strips <b>with the intent</b> to use them <b>for a cloak.</b> If so, with regard to <b>threads as well, let us say: One spun them with the intent</b> to use them <b>for a cloak.</b> In that case, they too would be deemed unfit. The Gemara answers: Here, it is referring to threads that are <b>twisted,</b> which are not typically used for weaving.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>twisted</b> threads <b>as well, let us say</b> that <b>one twisted them with the intent</b> of attaching them to <b>the hem of a cloak</b> as ornamentation. The Gemara answers: It is referring to twisted threads <b>that were cut</b> into short strings suitable for use as ritual fringes, <b>as people certainly do not exert</b> themselves and fashion fringes of a cloak to resemble ritual fringes.
<b>Rava said:</b> The assertion that people do not exert themselves is problematic, <b>as</b> by the same token, <b>does a person exert</b> himself <b>to fashion an amulet in the form of phylacteries?</b> Nevertheless, the Sages were concerned that an object that appears to be phylacteries might actually be a different object. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement</b> that one is permitted to carry phylacteries inside on Shabbat <b>said?</b> It is <b>with regard to old</b> phylacteries. <b>However, with regard to new</b> ones, <b>he is exempt</b> from the obligation to bring them in, as it is possible that they are not phylacteries but amulets in the form of phylacteries. Similarly, there should be concern lest people fashion items similar to objects used for a mitzva, even if exertion is involved.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to his son Ahava: Go out and teach</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>to</b> the Sages. With regard to <b>one who finds</b> fabric dyed <b>sky blue in the marketplace,</b> if he finds <b>strips, they are unfit</b> for use in ritual fringes; however, if he finds <b>threads cut</b> into short strings, <b>they are fit</b> for use in ritual fringes <b>because a person does not exert</b> himself. Apparently, that is the reason for the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rava said: And because Ahava, son of Rabbi Zeira, taught</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>has he hung</b> ornamental <b>rings on</b> that line of reasoning, i.e., does that constitute an absolute proof? The difficulty posed by Rava from the mishna is not resolved by the <i>baraita</i>, <b>as we learned: In what</b> case <b>is this statement</b> that one is permitted to carry phylacteries inside <b>said?</b> It is <b>with regard to old</b> phylacteries. <b>However, with regard to new</b> ones, <b>he is exempt.</b> Apparently, there is concern lest one exert himself to fashion an object similar to one used in a mitzva.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The sources are not contradictory, as the question of whether one <b>exerts</b> himself <b>or does not exert</b> himself <b>is</b> the subject of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> Some hold that one exerts himself as indicated by the mishna with regard to phylacteries, whereas others hold that one does not exert himself as stated with regard to sky blue dye.
<b>As it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who finds phylacteries</b> in a field <b>brings them in</b> to the town <b>pair</b> by <b>pair, whether</b> the finder is <b>a man or a woman,</b>

Daf 97a

and <b>whether</b> the phylacteries are <b>new or old;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda prohibits</b> carrying <b>new</b> phylacteries <b>but permits</b> carrying <b>old ones. Apparently,</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>a person exerts</b> himself to fashion an amulet that looks like phylacteries, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that <b>a person does not exert</b> himself for this purpose, and therefore something that has the appearance of phylacteries must be phylacteries.
<b><i>Shin</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>tzadi</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>ayin</i>, <i>tzadi</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>yod</i></b> is a <b>mnemonic</b> for the statements that follow. The Gemara adds: <b>And now that the father of Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak has taught</b> that <b>these are</b> deemed <b>old</b> phylacteries: <b>Any that have straps that</b> are permanently <b>tied</b> in the manner of phylacteries, and <b>new</b> phylacteries are those <b>that have straps that are not tied,</b> the conclusion is <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>a person does not exert</b> himself to fashion an amulet similar to phylacteries or string-like ritual fringes. They disagree with regard to new phylacteries that are not tied properly and cannot be donned in a manner typical of a weekday. The reason is that tying a permanent knot on Shabbat is prohibited by Torah law. Therefore, these phylacteries may not be donned, and Rabbi Zeira’s opinion is accepted.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion that new phylacteries may not be brought into town because they lack a permanent knot: Why must one tie the phylacteries with a knot? <b>Let him</b> simply <b>tie a bow,</b> which is not prohibited on Shabbat, and place the phylacteries on his head and arm in that manner. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: That is to say</b> that <b>a bow is invalid for phylacteries,</b> as a proper knot is required.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This is not the correct interpretation. Rather, <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms to <b>his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he said: A bow is a full-fledged knot,</b> and it is prohibited to tie it on Shabbat by Torah law.
The Gemara asks: <b>The reason</b> that it is prohibited to tie a bow is <b>that a bow is a full-fledged knot.</b> If <b>that were not so,</b> one could <b>tie</b> the phylacteries <b>with a bow. But didn’t Rav Yehuda, son of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, say in the name of Rav:</b> The form of the permanent <b>knot of phylacteries is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai; and Rav Naḥman said: And their decorative</b> side, the side of the knot where the shape of the letter appears, must face <b>outward.</b> Apparently, a bow does not suffice for phylacteries, as an actual knot is required.
The Gemara rejects this contention: It is referring to a case <b>where one tied a bow similar</b> in form <b>to a</b> permanent <b>knot,</b> without actually tying a permanent knot.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who purchases</b> a large quantity of <b>phylacteries from one who is not an expert,</b> i.e., a person who has not proven to be a reliable manufacturer of phylacteries, the purchaser <b>examines two</b> phylacteries <b>of the arm and one of the head, or two of the head and one of the arm,</b> to see if they are valid and the individual reliable. If the three phylacteries are found to be valid upon examination, the seller is considered an expert and the rest of the phylacteries are presumed valid as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>Whichever way you look at it,</b> this ruling is problematic: <b>If</b> the buyer <b>purchased</b> all of the phylacteries <b>from one person,</b> who acquired them from somebody else, <b>let him examine three</b> phylacteries <b>of the arm or three of the head,</b> in accordance with the principle that presumptive status is established after three instances.
<b>If he purchased</b> the phylacteries <b>from two</b> or <b>three people, each and every one</b> of the phylacteries <b>should require examination.</b> The presumptive status of one pair of phylacteries does not apply to the others, as they might have been produced by a different person. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> this refers to a case where the buyer <b>bought</b> the phylacteries <b>from one person, and we require</b> that the seller prove himself <b>to be an expert with regard to</b> both the phylactery <b>of the arm and</b> the phylactery <b>of the head.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rabba bar Shmuel teach</b> that <b>with</b> regard to <b>phylacteries one examines three of the arm and</b> three <b>of the head? What, is it not</b> that he examines <b>either three</b> phylacteries <b>of the arm or three of the head?</b> The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No,</b> it means that he examines <b>three</b> phylacteries in total, <b>among them</b> phylacteries <b>of the arm and among them</b> phylacteries <b>of the head,</b> as stated by Rav Ḥisda in the name of Rav.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Kahana teach</b> that <b>with</b> regard to <b>phylacteries one examines two of the arm and</b> two <b>of the head?</b> This statement certainly contradicts Rav’s opinion. The Gemara explains: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said: Presumptive status is</b> established <b>by two times.</b> Although most Sages maintain that it takes three instances to establish a presumptive status, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi rules that two cases suffice. Consequently, in the case of phylacteries, it is sufficient to examine two.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> this ruling is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>say the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i> as follows: <b>And</b> he must <b>likewise</b> examine <b>the second bundle</b> of phylacteries, <b>and likewise the third bundle. And if it is</b> in accordance with <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion, <b>is he of</b> the opinion that <b>a third</b> examination is necessary? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi does not require a third examination to establish a presumptive status, as he maintains that the examination of two bundles suffices.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>concedes with regard to bundles, as one buys</b> them <b>from two</b> or <b>three</b> different <b>people.</b> It can be assumed that the various bundles of phylacteries were not all manufactured by the same person. Consequently, the validity of one bundle does not establish a presumption with regard to another. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, even</b> the <b>fourth</b> bundle must be examined <b>as well, and even</b> the <b>fifth as well.</b> If the bundles were bought from different manufacturers, every one of them requires examination, not only the third.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so;</b> this is how one must proceed. <b>And</b> the reason <b>that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>teaches three</b> bundles rather than four or five is <b>to exclude</b> the third bundle <b>from its presumptive status.</b> By stating that the third bundle must be examined, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi indicates that in this case two examinations do not establish a presumption; rather, all of the bundles must be checked. <b>And actually, even</b> the <b>fourth and fifth</b> bundles require examination <b>as well.</b>
It was stated in the mishna that if <b>one finds</b> phylacteries <b>tied in bundles or in wrapped piles,</b> he sits there and waits with them until dark and then brings them in. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>bundles</b> in this context, <b>and what is</b> meant by <b>wrapped piles? Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The same types of objects <b>are</b> called <b>bundles, and they are</b> also called <b>wrapped piles,</b> i.e., both contain more than one pair of phylacteries. <b>Bundles</b> consist of many pairs of phylacteries arranged <b>in pairs [<i>zuvei</i>]</b> of a head phylactery with an arm phylactery, whereas <b>wrapped piles</b> indicates <b>that many</b> phylacteries <b>are wrapped together</b> in no particular arrangement.
We learned in the mishna that one sits there and <b>waits with them until dark and</b> then <b>brings them</b> in. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> must he do that? <b>Let him bring them in pair</b> by <b>pair. Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Yehuda, said:</b> This matter <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by</b> my <b>father</b> as follows: <b>Any</b> instance where there are few enough phylacteries <b>that were he to bring them in pair</b> by <b>pair he would finish before sunset, he brings them</b> in <b>pair</b> by <b>pair. But if not,</b> i.e., if there are so many pairs of phylacteries that were he to bring them in one pair at a time he would not bring them all in before sunset, <b>he waits</b> there <b>with</b> all of <b>them until dark and</b> then <b>brings them</b> in.
It was stated in the mishna that <b>in</b> a time of <b>danger one covers</b> the phylacteries <b>and proceeds on his</b> way. The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>And in</b> a time of <b>danger he carries them less than four cubits</b> at a time? The Gemara answers that <b>Rav said:</b> It is <b>not difficult.</b> In <b>this</b> mishna, which states that the finder covers the phylacteries, it is referring <b>to the danger</b> posed <b>by gentiles,</b> where the gentile authorities decreed against donning phylacteries and the finder is afraid to be seen carrying them. However, in <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that one may carry them less than four cubits at a time, it is dealing <b>with the danger</b> posed <b>by bandits [<i>listim</i>].</b> In that case he is afraid to remain there until dark, but he is not worried about taking the phylacteries with him. Consequently, he may carry them less than four cubits at a time.

Daf 97b

<b>Abaye said to him: In what</b> manner <b>did you establish our mishna</b> as dealing <b>with the danger</b> posed <b>by gentiles? Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna as follows: <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that <b>one gives them to another and the other</b> passes them <b>to another.</b> In that case, <b>all the more so</b> will <b>the matter be conspicuous,</b> and they should fear the decree issued by the gentiles.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is incomplete and is teaching the following: In what case is this statement</b> that the finder covers the phylacteries <b>said?</b> It is where the concern is <b>danger</b> posed by <b>gentiles. However,</b> where the concern is <b>danger</b> posed by <b>bandits, one carries them less than four cubits at a time.</b> In that case Rabbi Shimon disagrees, maintaining that it is preferable that many people carry the phylacteries.
It is stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: One gives them to another</b> and the other passes them to another. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle do <b>they disagree?</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that having one person carrying the phylacteries <b>less than four cubits</b> at a time <b>is preferable, as if you say</b> that the finder <b>gives them to another, and</b> the <b>other</b> passes them <b>to another, Shabbat</b> desecration <b>will be noticeable,</b> thereby demeaning Shabbat’s character as a sacred day of rest.
<b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that the solution that <b>one gives</b> the phylacteries <b>to another is preferable, as if you say</b> that the finder <b>carries them less than four cubits</b> at a time, <b>sometimes it is not in his thoughts and</b> will unwittingly <b>come to carry</b> the phylacteries <b>four cubits in the public domain.</b> That is unlikely if there are numerous people together.
It was stated in the mishna: <b>And the same</b> is true with regard to <b>one’s son.</b> The Gemara is surprised: <b>What is his son doing there</b> in the field necessitating his retrieval in this way? <b>The school of Menashe taught:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where his mother gave birth to him in a field,</b> and he must be brought to town.
<b>And what</b> may be inferred from the mishna’s ruling that the baby is passed from one person to the next, <b>even</b> if it requires <b>a hundred</b> people? This teaches <b>that although it is difficult for</b> the child to be passed from <b>hand</b> to hand, <b>even so, this</b> method of transporting him <b>is preferable</b> to his being carried by one person less than four cubits at a time.
It was stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: A person gives a barrel to another,</b> and the other may pass it to another, and in that way they may take it even beyond the Shabbat limit. The Gemara asks: <b>And is Rabbi Yehuda not of the opinion</b> of that <b>which we learned</b> in a mishna: The distance that <b>an animal and vessels</b> may be taken <b>is like</b> the distance that <b>the feet of the owners</b> may go with regard to Shabbat limits?
<b>Reish Lakish said in the name of Levi the Elder: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with</b> a case where <b>one pours</b> the water <b>from one barrel to</b> another <b>barrel</b> so that only the water, rather than the barrel itself, is taken beyond the limit. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> follows <b>his</b> usual <b>reasoning, as he said: Water has no substance,</b> i.e., it is not significant enough for its transfer beyond the Shabbat limit to be prohibited.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna that discusses a dispute on this issue: If one person adds flour for dough while another adds the water, the Rabbis say that the dough may only be taken as far as both owners are permitted to go, whereas <b>Rabbi Yehuda exempts water</b> from any limit <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>it has no substance.</b>
<b>And what,</b> then, is the meaning of the Rabbis’ statement in the mishna: <b>This</b> may <b>not go</b> farther than the feet of the owners may go, which apparently refers to the barrel? It means: <b>That which is in this</b> barrel may <b>not go farther than the feet of the owners</b> may go.
The Gemara rejects this explanation. <b>Say that you heard Rabbi Yehuda</b> express <b>his</b> opinion that water has no substance in a case <b>where it is absorbed in dough;</b> but in a case <b>where it is in its pure, unadulterated</b> state <b>did you hear him</b> say so? <b>Now,</b> if with regard to water <b>in a pot</b> of cooked food <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that it <b>is not nullified,</b> would it be <b>nullified when it is in its pure, unadulterated</b> state? That is clearly not the case, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Water and salt are nullified in dough,</b> as they are absorbed into it and are not independently discernible. However, <b>they are not nullified in a pot</b> of cooked food, <b>because</b> the water and salt are discernible in <b>its gravy.</b>
<b>Rather, Rava</b> rejected this explanation and <b>said: Here, we are dealing with a barrel</b> that belonged to a particular individual who <b>acquired residence</b> at the start of Shabbat in a specific location, <b>and water that did not</b> remain in one place, i.e., spring or river water, and that does not belong to any individual who <b>acquired residence.</b> In that case, <b>the barrel is nullified relative to the water,</b> since the barrel is designated to hold the water.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One who carries out a living person on a bed</b> from one domain to another on Shabbat <b>is exempt even for</b> carrying out <b>the bed, due to</b> the fact <b>that the bed is secondary to</b> the person. He is exempt for carrying out the living person because a living being carries itself, i.e., the person being carried lightens the load and thereby assists those bearing him.
Similarly, <b>one who carries out</b> an amount of <b>food, less than the measure</b> that determines liability for carrying out food on Shabbat, <b>in a vessel is exempt, even for</b> carrying out <b>the vessel, due to</b> the fact <b>that the vessel is secondary to</b> the food inside it. By the same reasoning, the barrel should be nullified relative to the water it contains.
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If members of <b>a caravan</b> camped in a field wish to drink, one <b>person gives a barrel to another, and the other</b> passes it <b>to another.</b> By inference: <b>In a caravan, yes,</b> it is permitted to do so due to exigent circumstances; however, in a case <b>that</b> is <b>not a caravan, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>Rather, Rav Yosef said: When we learned</b> the case <b>in the mishna as well, we learned</b> it with regard <b>to a caravan.</b> The Sages were lenient in the case of a caravan due to the lack of water.
<b>Abaye said</b> that this explanation is unnecessary: <b>In a caravan, even</b> if <b>the barrel acquired residence and the water acquired residence,</b> it is permitted to move them. If one is <b>not in a caravan,</b> if <b>the barrel acquired residence and the water did not acquire residence,</b> it is prohibited to move them.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Here, we are dealing with an ownerless barrel and ownerless water,</b> neither of which acquired residence as they do not belong to anyone. <b>And who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> about whom it says in the mishna that <b>they said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda that it may not go farther than the feet of its owners may go? <b>It is Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> who, consistent with his approach, <b>said</b> that <b>ownerless objects acquire residence</b> where they were located when Shabbat began, and it is prohibited to move them beyond their limit. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the statement: <b>This</b> may <b>not go farther than the feet of its owners</b> may go, as it has no owner? It means that the barrel and water may <b>not go farther than vessels that have owners,</b> i.e., they may not be moved beyond their limit.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who <b>was reading</b> a sacred <b>book</b> in scroll form on Shabbat <b>on</b> an elevated, wide <b>threshold, and the book rolled from his hand</b> into the public domain, <b>he</b> may <b>roll it</b> back <b>to himself,</b> since one of its ends remains in his hand.
If <b>he was reading on top the roof,</b> which is a full-fledged private domain, <b>and the book rolled from his hand, as long as</b> the edge of the book <b>did not reach</b> within <b>ten handbreadths</b> above the public domain, the book is still in its own domain, and he may <b>roll it</b> back <b>to himself.</b> However, <b>once the book has reached</b> within <b>ten handbreadths</b> above the public domain, it is prohibited to roll the book back to oneself. In that case, <b>he</b> may only <b>turn it</b> over <b>onto the</b> side with <b>writing,</b> so that the writing of the book will be facedown and not exposed and degraded.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> if the scroll <b>is removed only a needle breadth from the ground, he rolls it</b> back <b>to himself. Rabbi Shimon says: Even if</b> the scroll is <b>on the ground itself, he rolls it</b> back <b>to himself, as you have nothing</b> that was instituted <b>as a rabbinic decree</b> to enhance the character of Shabbat as a day of <b>rest</b> that <b>stands</b> as an impediment <b>before</b> the rescue of <b>sacred writings.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara questions the first clause of the mishna: <b>What are the circumstances of this threshold? If you say</b> it is referring to <b>a threshold</b> that is <b>a private domain, and</b> there is <b>a public domain before it, and</b> the mishna teaches that <b>we do not issue a decree lest</b> the entire scroll <b>fall</b> from one’s hand <b>and he come to bring it</b> from a public to a private domain,

Daf 98a

<b>who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna? <b>It is Rabbi Shimon, who said: Anything that</b> is prohibited on Shabbat and its prohibition is not by Torah law, but rather <b>is due to</b> a <b>rabbinic decree</b> issued to enhance the character of Shabbat as a day of rest <b>stands</b> as an impediment <b>before</b> the rescue of <b>sacred writings.</b> But if it is the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna as follows: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even if</b> the scroll <b>is removed only a needle breadth from the ground, he rolls it</b> back <b>to himself;</b> and <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even if</b> the scroll is <b>on the ground itself, he rolls it</b> back <b>to himself.</b>
Is it possible that the <i>tanna</i> cited in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna is Rabbi Shimon, as claimed above, while it is explicitly stated that <b>the last clause</b> represents the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> and yet its <b>middle clause</b> reflects the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda? Rav Yehuda said: Yes,</b> that is the correct, albeit unconventional, explanation. <b>The first and last clauses</b> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> while <b>the middle clause</b> of the mishna reflects the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabba said</b> that the mishna may be understood differently. <b>Here, we are dealing with a threshold that is trodden upon</b> by the public, <b>and due to</b> the potential <b>degradation of the sacred writings the Sages permitted</b> one to violate the rabbinic decree. It would be disgraceful if people were to trample over sacred writings.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to his</b> explanation: It was taught that if the scroll rolled <b>within four cubits, he rolls it</b> back <b>to himself;</b> if it rolled <b>beyond four cubits, he turns it over onto</b> its <b>writing. And if you say we are dealing with a threshold that is trodden on</b> by the public, <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> whether it remained <b>within four cubits</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if it rolled <b>beyond four cubits?</b> Since the prohibition is a rabbinic decree, not a Torah prohibition, why isn’t one permitted to move the scroll in both cases to prevent the degradation of the sacred writings?
<b>Rather, Abaye said: Here, we are dealing with a threshold</b> that is <b>a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> as the threshold is four handbreadths wide but is less than ten handbreadths high. Furthermore, on one side of the <i>karmelit</i> there is a private domain, <b>and a public domain passes before it.</b>
The reason for the different rulings is as follows: If the scroll rolled <b>within four cubits,</b> even <b>if</b> the entire scroll <b>falls</b> out of the one’s hand <b>and he brings it</b> back, <b>he cannot incur liability</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> as the prohibition against carrying from a public domain to a <i>karmelit</i> is a rabbinic decree. Consequently, <b>the Sages permitted him</b> to roll it back to himself, as there is no danger of transgressing a Torah prohibition.
However, if it rolled <b>beyond four cubits, so that if he brings it</b> back <b>he incurs liability</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> as carrying an object four cubits in the public domain is prohibited by Torah law, <b>the Sages did not permit him</b> to roll it back. In this case, if he forgot and carried the scroll instead of rolling it, he would be violating a severe prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, let us likewise issue a decree</b> in the case where the scroll remained <b>within four cubits, lest he bring</b> the scroll <b>in from the public domain to the private domain,</b> i.e., to his house. <b>And lest you say: Since a <i>karmelit</i> separates</b> the public and private domains <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> as nothing is directly carried from one domain to the other, <b>didn’t Rava say: One who carries an object from the beginning of four</b> cubits <b>to the end of four</b> cubits in the public domain, <b>and he carried it by way of</b> the airspace <b>above his head,</b> he <b>is liable, even though</b> the object remained more than ten handbreadths off the ground and passed from the beginning to the end of four cubits by way of an exempt zone? Here, too, one should be liable for carrying the scroll from the public domain to a private domain by way of a <i>karmelit</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing <b>with an extended threshold.</b> Consequently, <b>in the meantime,</b> while he is carrying the scroll along the length of the threshold, <b>he will remember</b> not to bring it into the private domain.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> it is referring <b>to a threshold that is not extended;</b> however, <b>ordinarily one peruses sacred writings and</b> then <b>puts them</b> in their place. Consequently, there is no concern that he might pass directly from the public to the private domain, as he will pause on the threshold to read the scroll. The Gemara asks: According to this explanation too, <b>let us be concerned lest he</b> pause to <b>peruse</b> the scroll <b>in the public domain, and</b> subsequently <b>carry it directly into the private domain</b> without pausing in the <i>karmelit</i>.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Ben Azzai, who said</b> that <b>walking is considered like standing.</b> Consequently, one who passes through the <i>karmelit</i> is considered to have paused and stood there. Therefore, the object was not transferred directly from the public domain to the private domain, as he paused in the <i>karmelit</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what of the concern <b>lest he throw</b> the scrolls inside, rather than carry them by hand, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Ben Azzai concedes</b> that <b>one who throws</b> an object from the public domain to a private domain by way of an exempt domain is liable?
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ahava said: That is to say</b> that <b>one does not throw sacred writings,</b> as this is demeaning to them. Consequently, there is no concern that one might throw the scrolls rather than carry them by hand.
It was stated in the mishna: If <b>one was reading on top of the roof,</b> which is a full-fledged private domain, and the scroll rolled from his hand, as long as the edge of the scroll did not reach ten handbreadths above the public domain, he may roll it back to himself. However, once the scroll reached within ten handbreadths above the public domain, it is prohibited to roll it back. In that case, he should turn it over, so that the writing of the scroll will be facedown and not be exposed and degraded. The Gemara asks: <b>And is it permitted</b> to do so? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that with regard to <b>writers of scrolls, phylacteries, and <i>mezuzot</i></b> who interrupt their work, the Sages <b>did not permit them to turn the sheet</b> of parchment <b>facedown</b> lest it become soiled? <b>Rather, one spreads a cloth over it</b> in a respectful manner.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to scribes, <b>it is possible</b> to cover the parchment respectfully; <b>here,</b> it <b>is not possible</b> to do so. <b>And if he does not turn</b> the scroll <b>over, it will be more degrading to the sacred writings.</b> Consequently, although this is not an ideal solution, it is preferable to turn it over rather than leave the scroll exposed.
The mishna states: Once the scroll has reached within ten handbreadths above the public domain, it is prohibited to roll it back to oneself, and <b>one turns it over onto the writing.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why is this prohibited? Since the scroll <b>did not</b> come to <b>rest</b> in the public domain, rolling it back to oneself should not be prohibited. <b>Rava said:</b> This teaching is referring <b>to an inclined wall.</b> Although the scroll did not reach the ground, it came to rest within the confines of the public domain.
<b>Abaye said to him: In what</b> manner <b>did you establish</b> that <b>the mishna</b> is referring <b>to</b> the case of <b>an inclined wall? Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna as follows: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> if the scroll <b>is removed only a needle breadth from the ground, he rolls it</b> back <b>to himself. But didn’t</b> the scroll come to <b>rest</b> in the public domain? It shouldn’t matter whether or not the scroll is in contact with the ground.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is incomplete and is teaching the following: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>in</b> the case of <b>an inclined wall. However,</b>

Daf 98b

<b>with regard to a wall that is not inclined,</b> the following distinction applies: If the end of the scroll is <b>three</b> handbreadths <b>above</b> the ground, <b>he</b> may <b>roll it</b> back <b>to himself;</b> but if it is <b>below three</b> handbreadths from the ground, it is considered as though the scroll is on the ground, and <b>he must</b> therefore <b>turn it</b> facedown <b>onto the writing.</b>
It was stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> if the scroll <b>is removed only</b> a needle breadth <b>from the ground,</b> one rolls it back to himself. The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yehuda maintains <b>that</b> in order for an object to be deemed at rest, <b>we require</b> that it <b>rest atop something.</b> Consequently, a scroll that is not actually touching the ground is not considered resting and may be rolled back.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> consider <b>that</b> which <b>Rava said</b> with regard to an object located <b>within three</b> handbreadths of the ground. Rava said that according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Akiva and claim that something in the air is not considered to be at rest, nevertheless, for one to incur liability <b>it is necessary</b> for the object to <b>rest</b> on a surface. <b>Let us say</b> that <b>he stated his <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> only one of <b>the <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> but not in accordance with all of them. This is an unacceptable conclusion.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects the previous explanation in favor of the following one: The mishna <b>is all</b> in accordance with <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and it is incomplete and is teaching</b> the following: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement</b> that once the end of the scroll is within ten handbreadths of the ground it may not be rolled back <b>said?</b> It was said in the case of <b>an inclined wall. But with regard to a wall that is not inclined, even</b> if the end of the scroll is <b>less than three handbreadths</b> from the ground, <b>one</b> may <b>roll it</b> back <b>to himself, as Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> if the scroll <b>is removed only a needle breadth from the ground, he rolls it</b> back <b>to himself.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this ruling? The reasoning is that for an object to be considered at rest, <b>we require</b> that it <b>rest atop some</b> surface. Consequently, if the scroll is not actually touching the ground, it is not considered at rest, even if it is less than three handbreadths from the ground.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a ledge in front of a window,</b> that is ten handbreadths high and four handbreadths wide, <b>one</b> may <b>place</b> objects <b>upon it or remove</b> them <b>from it on Shabbat</b> via the window.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies: <b>This ledge, to where does it protrude? If you say</b> that the ledge <b>protrudes into a public domain,</b> one should be prohibited to place an object on it, as <b>we should be concerned lest</b> the object <b>fall and he</b> will forget and <b>come to bring it in</b> from the public domain to a private domain. <b>Rather,</b> it must be <b>that</b> the ledge <b>protrudes into a private domain;</b> but if so, it is <b>obvious</b> that it is permitted to place objects on it and to remove them.
<b>Abaye said: Actually,</b> the mishna is dealing with a case <b>where it protrudes into a public domain, and what</b> is the meaning of <b>that</b> which <b>it teaches: One</b> may <b>place</b> objects <b>upon it?</b> This refers to <b>fragile utensils,</b> which would break instantly if they fell. Consequently, there is no concern that one might then bring them in from the public domain to the private domain.
The Gemara comments: <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a ledge in front of a window that protrudes into a public domain, one</b> may <b>place on it bowls, cups, small cups [<i>kitoniyot</i>], and saucers.</b> All of these utensils are made of fragile glass or earthenware, which supports Abaye’s opinion.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And one</b> may <b>use</b> this ledge along the <b>entire</b> length of <b>the wall,</b> if the ledge spans its length, whether in close proximity to the window or removed from it, <b>until the lower ten</b> handbreadths of the wall, but not if the ledge is lower than that. <b>And if there is one</b> other <b>ledge below it</b> but still ten handbreadths above the ground, <b>one</b> may <b>use</b> the lower ledge along the entire length of the wall; <b>but with regard to the upper</b> ledge, <b>one</b> may <b>use it only opposite his window.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> upper <b>ledge, what are its circumstances? If it is not four</b> handbreadths deep, although <b>it is an exempt domain</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, which means it does not pose a problem in itself, <b>one should</b> nonetheless <b>not</b> be permitted to <b>use</b> it <b>even opposite his window,</b> as anything placed on this narrow ledge is likely to fall. Consequently, it is as though he has thrown the object directly to the ground. <b>And if it is four</b> handbreadths deep, <b>let him use</b> the ledge along the <b>entire</b> length of the ledge along <b>the wall.</b>
<b>Abaye said:</b> We are dealing with a case where <b>the lower</b> ledge <b>is four</b> handbreadths deep <b>and the upper</b> ledge <b>is not four</b> handbreadths deep, but the <b>windowsill</b> on the inside <b>completes it to</b> form a surface <b>four</b> handbreadths deep. Accordingly, <b>one</b> may <b>use</b> the part of the upper ledge <b>opposite the window, as it is</b> considered <b>an extension of the window,</b> but the parts <b>to this side or to that side</b> of the window are <b>prohibited,</b> as they are less than four handbreadths deep.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person</b> may <b>stand in a private domain and move</b> objects that are <b>in a public domain,</b> as there is no concern that he might mistakenly bring them into the private domain. Similarly, one may stand <b>in a public domain and move</b> objects <b>in a private domain, provided that he does not carry</b> them <b>beyond four cubits</b> in the public domain, which is prohibited on Shabbat.
However, <b>a person</b> may <b>not stand in a private domain and urinate into a public domain,</b> nor may one stand <b>in a public domain and urinate into a private domain. And likewise, one</b> may <b>not spit</b> in such a manner that the spittle passes from a private domain to a public domain or vice versa.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even once</b> a person’s <b>spittle is gathered in his mouth, he</b> may <b>not walk four cubits</b> in the public domain <b>until he spits</b> it out, for he would be carrying the accumulated spittle in his mouth, which is akin to carrying any other object.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Shelamiya would teach</b> this mishna <b>to Ḥiyya bar Rav before Rav</b> as follows: <b>A person</b> may <b>not stand in a private domain and move</b> objects that are <b>in a public domain.</b> Rav <b>said to him:</b> Have <b>you abandoned</b> the majority opinion of <b>the Rabbis and followed</b> the solitary dissenting opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who is stringent in this regard?

Daf 99a

The Gemara explains: Rav Ḥinnana <b>maintains that from</b> the fact that <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna, was taught in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> it can be inferred that <b>the first clause</b> was <b>likewise</b> taught in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir. But</b> in fact <b>that is not so: The latter clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, while the first clause</b> is in accordance with that of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
We learned in the mishna: One may move objects in a public domain when he is standing in a private domain, <b>provided that he does not carry</b> them <b>beyond</b> four cubits in the public domain. The Gemara infers: This teaching indicates that if <b>he carried</b> them beyond four cubits, <b>he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>this</b> ruling <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, as Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>one who carries an object</b> in a public domain <b>from the beginning of four</b> cubits <b>to the end of</b> those <b>four</b> cubits, even if he <b>carried it above his head,</b> i.e., he lifted the object above his head so that it passed through an exempt place, <b>he is</b> nonetheless <b>liable</b> for carrying four cubits in a public domain. Here, too, although he is standing in an elevated private domain and carries the object at that elevated height, he is still liable.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Is</b> the mishna <b>teaching</b> that <b>if he carried</b> the object beyond four cubits <b>he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering? Perhaps</b> the mishna means: <b>If he carried</b> the object beyond four cubits, he is <b>exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, <b>but it is</b> nevertheless <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic decree to do so.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of the previous discussion: The Gemara’s initial inference was actually that if <b>he carried</b> the object beyond four cubits he is <b>exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, <b>but it is prohibited</b> by rabbinic decree to do so. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let us say</b> that this <b>is a conclusive refutation of Rava’s</b> opinion, <b>as Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>one who carries</b> an object in a public domain <b>from the beginning of four</b> cubits <b>to the end of</b> those <b>four</b> cubits, even if he <b>carried it above his head, he is liable.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Is</b> the mishna <b>teaching</b> that <b>if he took</b> it beyond four cubits he is <b>exempt, but it is prohibited</b> to do so? <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>tanna</i> means that <b>if he carried</b> it beyond four cubits, he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
The mishna states: <b>A person</b> may <b>not stand in a private domain</b> and urinate or spit into the public domain. <b>Rav Yosef said: One who urinated or spat</b> in this manner is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> for an act of carrying to be considered a prohibited Shabbat labor that entails liability, <b>we require</b> that the <b>lifting and placing</b> of the object be performed <b>from atop an area four</b> by four handbreadths, the minimal size of significance with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of carrying on Shabbat. <b>And</b> that is <b>not</b> the case here, as one’s mouth, which produces the spittle, is not four by four handbreadths in size.
The Gemara answers: One’s <b>intent renders it an area</b> of significance, i.e., as one certainly considers his mouth a significant area, it is regarded as four by four handbreadths in size. <b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that the size of an area is not the sole criterion, but that a person’s thoughts can also establish a place as significant, there is a difficulty with <b>that</b> which <b>Rava said:</b> If <b>a person threw</b> an object <b>and it landed in the mouth of a dog or in the mouth of a furnace,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering. But don’t we require</b> that the object be <b>placed on an area of four</b> by four handbreadths? <b>And</b> that is <b>not</b> the case here.
<b>Rather,</b> the person’s <b>intent</b> to throw the object into the dog’s mouth <b>renders it an area</b> of significance. <b>Here too, his intent renders</b> his own mouth <b>a</b> significant <b>area.</b>
<b>Rava raised a dilemma:</b> If <b>one</b> is standing <b>in a private domain, and the opening of his</b> male <b>member is in the public domain,</b> and he urinates, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? How should this case be regarded? Do <b>we follow</b> the domain where the urine is <b>uprooted</b> from the body, i.e., the bladder, which is in the private domain? <b>Or</b> do <b>we follow the</b> point of the urine’s actual <b>emission</b> from the body, and since the urine leaves his body through the opening of his member in the public domain, no prohibition has been violated? Since this dilemma was not resolved, the Gemara concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
The mishna states: <b>And likewise, one</b> may <b>not spit</b> from one domain to another. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Once a person’s spittle is gathered in his mouth, he may not walk four cubits in the public domain until he removes it. The Gemara asks: Does this teaching mean that it is prohibited to do so <b>even if he has not turned</b> the spittle <b>over</b> in his mouth, i.e., after he has dredged up the saliva but before he has rolled it around in his mouth in preparation to spit it out?
<b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna the <i>halakha</i> of one who <b>was eating a dried fig</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>with unwashed hands?</b> By Torah law, only food that has come into contact with a liquid is susceptible to ritual impurity, and no liquid had ever fallen on this fig. The significance of the fact that his hands are unwashed is that by rabbinic law, unwashed hands have second degree ritual impurity status and therefore invalidate <i>teruma</i>. If this person <b>inserted his hand into his mouth to remove a pebble, Rabbi Meir deems</b> the dried fig <b>impure,</b> as it had been rendered liable to contract impurity by the spittle in the person’s mouth, and it subsequently became impure when it was touched by his unwashed hand. <b>And Rabbi Yosei deems</b> the fig <b>ritually pure,</b> as he maintains that spittle which is still in one’s mouth is not considered liquid that renders food liable to contract impurity; the spittle does so only after it has left the mouth.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that there is a distinction between the cases: If <b>he turned</b> the spittle <b>over</b> in his mouth, it is like spittle that has been detached from its place, and therefore its legal status is that of a liquid, which means the fig is <b>impure.</b> However, if <b>he</b> had <b>not</b> yet <b>turned</b> the spittle <b>over</b> in his mouth, the fig is <b>pure.</b> This indicates that according to Rabbi Yehuda, spittle that has not yet been turned over in one’s mouth is not considered detached.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The</b> attribution of the <b>opinions is reversed,</b> as the opinion attributed to Rabbi Yehuda is actually that of a different <i>tanna</i>, while Rabbi Yehuda himself maintains that the fig is ritually impure in either case.
<b>Reish Lakish said: Actually, do not reverse</b> the opinions, <b>and</b> the apparent contradiction can be reconciled in accordance with the original version of the text: <b>With what we are dealing here</b> in the mishna? We are dealing <b>with his phlegm</b> that is expelled through coughing.
The Gemara raises a difficulty against this resolution. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If <b>one’s phlegm was detached,</b> he may not walk four cubits in the public domain with it in his mouth? <b>What, is it not</b> the case that this <i>halakha</i> refers to <b>spittle that was detached?</b> The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>No,</b> this ruling applies only to <b>one’s phlegm that was detached.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If <b>one’s phlegm was detached, and likewise,</b> if <b>his spittle was detached, he</b> may <b>not walk four cubits</b> in the public domain <b>before he spits</b> it out, even if he has not yet turned it over. <b>Rather, it is clear as we originally answered,</b> that the opinions in the mishna with regard to spittle and ritual impurity must be reversed.
Having mentioned phlegm, the Gemara cites a related teaching: <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> One who expelled <b>phlegm in front of his master</b> has acted in a disrespectful manner and is <b>liable for</b> the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven, <b>as it is stated: “All they who hate Me love death”</b> (Proverbs 8:36). <b>Do not read it</b> as: <b>“They who hate [<i>mesanai</i>] Me”; rather,</b> read it as: <b>“Those who make themselves hateful [<i>masniai</i>] to Me,”</b> i.e., those who make themselves hateful by such a discharge.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this ruling: <b>But doesn’t he</b> do so <b>involuntarily,</b> as no one coughs and emits phlegm by choice; why should this be considered a transgression? The Gemara answers: <b>We are speaking</b> here of someone who had <b>phlegm</b> in his mouth <b>and spat</b> it out, i.e., one who had the opportunity to leave his master’s presence and spit outside.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person</b> may <b>stand in a private domain</b> and extend his head <b>and drink in a public domain,</b> and he may stand <b>in a public domain and drink in a private domain, only if he brings his head and most of his</b> body <b>into the domain</b> in <b>which he drinks. And the same</b> applies <b>in a winepress,</b> as will be explained in the Gemara.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara registers surprise at the mishna: It would seem that <b>the first clause,</b> i.e., the previous mishna, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who maintain that a person located in one domain is permitted to move objects in another domain, <b>whereas the latter clause,</b> i.e., this mishna, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who maintains that it is prohibited for a person in one domain to move objects in a different domain.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This mishna is referring <b>to objects that one needs, and</b> the ruling is accepted by <b>all.</b> In this case, even the Rabbis concede that it is prohibited to move objects in another domain, lest one absent-mindedly draw the objects to him and thereby violate a Torah prohibition.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If one of the domains is a <b><i>karmelit</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Abaye said: This</b> case <b>is</b> equal <b>to that</b> case, i.e., in this situation a <i>karmelit</i> is governed by the same <i>halakha</i> that applies to a domain defined by Torah law. Just as the Sages prohibited one in the private domain from drinking from the public domain and vice versa, so too, they prohibited one in a <i>karmelit</i> from drinking in the same manner. <b>Rava said:</b> How can you say so? The prohibition against carrying to or from a <i>karmelit</i> is <b>itself</b> a rabbinic <b>decree. And will we</b> then <b>proceed to issue a decree to</b> prevent violation of another <b>decree?</b>
<b>Abaye said</b> in explanation of his opinion: <b>From where do I say that</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it is taught</b> in the mishna:

Daf 99b

<b>And the same</b> applies <b>in a winepress.</b> This winepress cannot be a private domain, as the first clause of the mishna already dealt with a private domain. The winepress must therefore be a <i>karmelit</i>, which proves that it is prohibited to drink from a <i>karmelit</i> while standing in a public domain.
<b>And Rava said:</b> This proof is not conclusive, as the words: The same applies in a winepress, do not refer to Shabbat but <b>to the matter of</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>tithes,</b> as explained below. <b>And similarly, Rav Sheshet said</b> that the statement that <b>the same</b> applies <b>in a winepress</b> refers <b>to the matter of tithes.</b>
The Gemara clarifies this statement. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>drink</b> grape juice directly <b>on the winepress</b> <i>ab initio</i> without tithing, <b>whether</b> the juice was diluted <b>with hot</b> water, even though he will then be unable to return the leftover wine to the press, as it would ruin all the wine in the press, <b>or whether</b> the juice was diluted <b>with cold</b> water, in which case he could return the leftover wine without ruining the rest, <b>and he is exempt.</b> Drinking that way is considered incidental drinking, and anything that is not a fixed meal is exempt from tithing. This is the <b>statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Eliezer bar Tzadok deems</b> one <b>obligated</b> to tithe in both cases.
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> There is a distinction between these two cases. When the juice is diluted <b>with hot</b> water, since one cannot return what is left of the juice to the press, <b>he is obligated</b> to tithe it, as this drinking is like fixed drinking for which one is obligated to tithe. However, when the juice is diluted <b>with cold</b> water, <b>he is exempt</b> from tithing it, <b>because he</b> can <b>return the leftover</b> juice to the press. Therefore, it is considered incidental drinking, which is exempt from tithing. The teaching of the mishna: The same applies to a winepress, is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, as it teaches that that the leniency to drink without separating tithes applies only if the drinker’s head and most of his body are in the winepress.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person</b> standing in a public domain on Shabbat may <b>catch</b> water in a vessel <b>from a gutter</b> running along the side of a roof, if it is <b>less than ten handbreadths</b> off the ground, which is part of the public domain. <b>And from a pipe</b> that protrudes from the roof, <b>one</b> may <b>drink in any manner,</b> i.e., not only by catching the water in a vessel, but even by pressing his mouth directly against the spout.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A careful reading of the mishna indicates that to <b>catch, yes,</b> one may catch the water from a distance, <b>but</b> to <b>press</b> his hand or mouth to the gutter, <b>no,</b> that is prohibited. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this distinction? <b>Rav Naḥman said: Here, we are dealing with a gutter within three</b> handbreadths <b>of the roof,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the principle that <b>anything within three</b> handbreadths <b>of a roof is considered like the roof</b> itself, based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>, according to which two solid surfaces are considered joined if there is a gap of less than three handbreadths between them. Since the roof of the house is a private domain, one would be carrying from a private domain to a public domain, which is prohibited.
<b>That</b> ruling, that there is a distinction between catching water falling from a gutter and pressing one’s hand or mouth to it, <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person</b> may <b>stand in a private domain and raise his hand above ten handbreadths,</b> until it is <b>within three</b> handbreadths <b>of the roof, and catch</b> any water falling from his neighbor’s roof in a vessel, <b>provided that he does not press</b> his hand or mouth to the roof.
<b>It was</b> likewise <b>taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person</b> may <b>not stand in a private domain and raise his hand above ten handbreadths, to within three</b> handbreadths <b>of the roof, and press</b> his hand to the gutter, <b>but he</b> may <b>catch</b> water falling from the gutter <b>and drink.</b>
It was stated in the mishna: <b>But from a pipe one</b> may <b>drink in any manner,</b> as it protrudes more than three handbreadths from the roof. A Sage <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>If the pipe</b> itself <b>is four by four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>it is prohibited</b> to stand in the public domain and press one’s hand or mouth to the water, <b>because he is like</b> one who <b>carries from one domain to</b> another <b>domain,</b> as the pipe is considered a domain in its own right.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a cistern in a public domain, with an embankment ten handbreadths high,</b> i.e., the embankment constitutes a private domain by itself, if there is <b>a window above</b> the cistern, i.e., the window of an adjacent house is situated above the cistern, <b>one</b> may <b>draw</b> water <b>from</b> the cistern <b>on Shabbat</b> through the window, as it is permitted to carry from one private domain to another.
Similarly, with regard to <b>a garbage dump in a public domain</b> that is <b>ten handbreadths high,</b> which means it has the status of a private domain, if there is <b>a window above</b> the pile of refuse that abuts the garbage dump, <b>one</b> may <b>throw water</b> from the window <b>onto</b> the dump <b>on Shabbat,</b> as it is permitted to carry from one private domain to another.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>With what are we dealing</b> here? <b>If you say</b> we are dealing <b>with</b> a cistern that is <b>adjacent</b> to the wall of the house, i.e. the cistern and wall are separated by less than four handbreadths, <b>why do I</b> need the cistern’s <b>embankment</b> to be <b>ten</b> handbreadths high? Presumably the cistern is ten handbreadths deep, which makes it a private domain, and as it is too close to the house for the public domain to pass between them, one should be permitted to draw water from the cistern through the window, regardless of the height of the embankment.
<b>Rav Huna said: With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case where the cistern or garbage dump is <b>four</b> handbreadths <b>removed from the wall</b> of the house, i.e., a public domain separates the house from the cistern or heap. It is prohibited to carry from one private domain to another by way of a public domain. However, if the cistern’s embankment is ten handbreadths high, the one drawing the water transfers it by way of an area that is more than ten handbreadths above the public domain, which is an exempt domain.
<b>And the reason</b> that drawing the water is permitted is <b>that there is an embankment of ten</b> handbreadths; but <b>if there is no embankment of ten</b> handbreadths, it is prohibited, as this would involve <b>moving</b> objects <b>from one private domain to another by way of the public domain.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The above explanation is unnecessary. <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that we are dealing <b>with</b> a cistern that is <b>adjacent</b> to the wall of the house, the mishna comes to <b>teach us that a cistern and its embankment combine to</b> complete the <b>ten</b> handbreadths required for a private domain, and it is not necessary that the embankment itself reach a height of ten handbreadths.
The mishna states: With regard to <b>a garbage dump in a public domain</b> that is ten handbreadths high, if there is a window above the heap, one may throw water from the window onto the heap on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>Aren’t we concerned that the</b> entire <b>garbage dump</b> or part of it <b>might be removed,</b> turning the area into a public domain, and people will continue to throw water onto it on Shabbat?
<b>But didn’t Ravin bar Rav Adda</b> say that <b>Rav Yitzḥak said: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving a certain alleyway, one of whose sides terminated in the sea,</b> which closed it off on one side, <b>and the other side</b> of which <b>terminated in a garbage dump. And the incident came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi for his ruling as to whether the alleyway has the status of an alleyway closed on both sides, <b>and he did not say</b> anything <b>about it, either prohibition or permission.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>did not say about it</b> that carrying in the alleyway is <b>permitted, as we are concerned lest the garbage dump be removed</b> from its present spot, leaving one side of the alleyway open, <b>and</b> we are likewise concerned that perhaps <b>the sea will throw up sediment</b> and recede. These sedimentary deposits will intervene between the end of the alleyway and the sea, thereby depriving the alleyway of one its partitions.
Similarly, <b>he did not say about it</b> that carrying in the alleyway was <b>prohibited, as</b> its <b>partitions,</b> the sea and the garbage dump, indeed <b>exist,</b> and it was certainly permitted at that time to carry in the alleyway. Apparently, there is indeed a concern that a garbage dump might be removed; why, then, does the same concern not apply to the case in the mishna?
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult.</b> In <b>this</b> case, with regard to the alleyway between the garbage dump and the sea, we are concerned, as we are dealing <b>with a private</b> garbage dump, whose owner might change his mind and remove it; whereas in <b>that</b> case, i.e., the case in the mishna, it is referring <b>to a public</b> heap, which will certainly remain fixed in place.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a tree that was hanging over the ground,</b> i.e., its branches hung down on all sides like a tent so that it threw a shadow on the ground, <b>if</b> the tips of <b>its branches are no higher than three handbreadths from the ground, one</b> may <b>carry under it.</b> This applies even if the tree is planted in a public domain, as the branches form partitions which turn the enclosed area into a private domain.
If <b>its roots</b> were <b>three handbreadths higher than the ground, one</b> may <b>not sit on them,</b> as it is prohibited to use a tree on Shabbat. Any part of a tree that is three handbreadths above the ground has the status of a tree with regard to this prohibition.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: One</b> may <b>not move</b> objects in the area <b>under</b> the tree if it is <b>more than two <i>beit se’a</i>. What is the reason</b> for this prohibition?

Daf 100a

This was prohibited <b>because it is a dwelling that serves</b> only <b>the air,</b> i.e., it is used only by someone guarding the fields or the like. It is not used as permanent living quarters, despite its partitions. <b>And</b> the rule with respect to <b>any dwelling that serves</b> only <b>the air</b> is that <b>it is not permitted to carry in it</b> if its area is <b>more than two <i>beit se’a</i>.</b> As it is not a proper place of residence, the Sages treated it as an enclosure.
The mishna states: If <b>the roots</b> of the tree are three handbreadths <b>above the ground,</b> one may not sit on them on Shabbat. <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to <b>the roots of a tree that</b> rise up and then bend and <b>come</b> down <b>from above, from</b> a height of <b>three</b> handbreadths <b>to within three</b> handbreadths of the ground. <b>Rabba said: It is permitted to use them,</b> and <b>Rav Sheshet said: It is prohibited to use them.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the rationale of each opinion. <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>it is permitted to use them,</b> as <b>anything less than three</b> handbreadths <b>from the ground is</b> considered as <b>the ground. Rav Sheshet said: It is prohibited to use them; since they come from a prohibited source, they are prohibited.</b> The section of the tree from which they grow is prohibited. Therefore, these roots should likewise be prohibited.
The Gemara proceeds to qualify the dispute: With regard to ascending and descending roots <b>that resemble</b> a rocky <b>crag, those that rise upward are</b> certainly <b>prohibited</b> according to all opinions; those that <b>fall downward are permitted</b> according to everyone. It is the roots that branch out <b>to the sides</b> that are the subject of the <b>dispute between Rabba and Rav Sheshet.</b> Rav Sheshet prohibits using them, while Rabba is lenient.
<b>And likewise,</b> Rabba and Rav Sheshet disagree about <b>a tree that grows in a ditch</b> that has elevated roots, some of which are concealed by the banks of the ditch. The <i>amora’im</i> dispute whether the roots concealed by the banks are considered part of the ground. <b>And likewise,</b> in the case of a tree that grows <b>in a corner</b> between two walls, they disagree as to whether the section between the walls is considered part of the ground.
The Gemara relates that <b>Abaye had a certain palm tree</b> that grew in his house and <b>that projected through an opening in the roof. He came before Rav Yosef</b> to ask him about it, <b>and he permitted him</b> to use the first three handbreadths of the palm tree above the roof, as the tree’s lower part is treated as though it were in the ground.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Taḥlifa said</b> to Abaye: <b>He who permitted</b> it <b>to you, permitted it to you</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabba,</b> who maintains that a section of a tree concealed from view in at least two directions is considered as though it were underground. Consequently, the first three handbreadths above that section may be used on Shabbat, as they have the status of the ground.
The Gemara expresses surprise: This is <b>obvious.</b> What novel element is Rav Aḥa bar Taḥlifa teaching us? The Gemara answers: It is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that in this case it should be permitted <b>even according to Rav Sheshet,</b> as <b>the house is considered full,</b> i.e., it is as though it were filled with earth, <b>and</b> this would mean it is permitted <b>to use</b> the section <b>less than three</b> handbreadths <b>from the roof.</b> Rav Aḥa bar Taḥlifa therefore <b>teaches us</b> that Rav Sheshet is stringent even in this case.
The Gemara attempts to adduce proof from the mishna, in which <b>we learned:</b> If <b>the roots</b> of the tree are <b>three handbreadths above the ground, one</b> may <b>not sit on them. What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If</b> the situation is <b>that</b> the roots <b>do not bend over again,</b> this is <b>obvious,</b> as anything higher than three handbreadths is part of the tree. <b>Rather, doesn’t</b> it mean that one may not sit on them <b>even though they bend back</b> downward to within three handbreadths of the ground? The mishna apparently indicates that if parts of the roots are more than three handbreadths above the ground, it is prohibited to use them along the rest of their entire length, as maintained by Rav Sheshet, contrary to Rabba.
