The Gemara answers: <b>Straw is different, as one does not negate it;</b> rather, he intends to remove it once the water has been absorbed. He is therefore permitted to scatter the straw in the courtyard, just as it is permitted to put it in any other place. However, it is prohibited to scatter objects that one intends to leave in place, such as salt, as this appears as though he is adding to the ground and building.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: This salt, what are the circumstances? If one negates it</b> vis-à-vis the ramp so that it becomes part of the ramp, <b>he</b> effectively <b>adds to the structure</b> of the Temple, <b>and it states</b> with regard to the Temple: <b>“All this do I give you in writing as God has made me wise by His hand upon me,</b> even all the works of this pattern” (I Chronicles 28:19). This verse indicates that all the details of the Temple structure were determined through prophecy and may not be changed in any way, even on a weekday.
<b>And if he does not negate</b> the salt vis-à-vis the ramp, <b>it</b> would <b>constitute an interposition</b> between the feet of the priests and the altar. This would mean that they would not be walking on the ramp during their service, and consequently they would not be performing the service as required by the Torah.
The Gemara answers: In fact, he does not negate the salt. However, he scatters it <b>when the limbs</b> of the sacrifice <b>are brought up the ramp,</b> a procedure <b>that is not</b> considered part of the <b>Temple service</b> subject to disqualification due to interposition, as it is merely preparation for the burning of the limbs.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is this <b>not</b> a service? <b>But isn’t it written: “And the priest shall offer it whole and make it smoke upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:13), <b>and the Master said</b> in explanation: <b>This</b> is referring to <b>bringing the limbs to</b> the top of <b>the ramp.</b> Evidently, this too is a service written in the Torah. <b>Rather, say</b> that he scatters the salt <b>when the wood is brought</b> up the ramp <b>to the arrangement</b> of wood on the altar, a procedure <b>that is not a service.</b>
<b>Rava taught:</b> In <b>a courtyard that was damaged</b> on Shabbat <b>by rainwater, one</b> may <b>bring straw and scatter it about</b> to make it easier to walk across. <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava: But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>When one scatters</b> the straw, <b>he</b> must <b>not scatter</b> it either <b>with a</b> small <b>basket or with a large basket, but</b> only <b>with the bottom of a</b> broken <b>basket,</b> i.e., he must scatter the straw in a manner different from that of an ordinary weekday. Rava, however, indicates that he may scatter the straw in the usual fashion.
<b>Rava then appointed an <i>amora</i> before him</b> to publicize his teaching, <b>and taught: The statement I issued before you was a mistake of mine. However,</b> in fact <b>they said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer as follows: And when one scatters</b> the straw, <b>he</b> must <b>not scatter</b> it either <b>with a</b> small <b>basket or with a large basket, but</b> only <b>with the bottom of a</b> broken <b>basket.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>draw water from the Cistern of the Exiles</b> by means of a wheel. The Gemara relates: <b>Ulla happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Rav Menashe</b> when <b>a certain man came and knocked at the door.</b> Ulla <b>said: Who is that? May his body be desecrated, as he desecrates Shabbat</b> by producing a sound.
<b>Rabba said to him:</b> The Sages <b>prohibited only a</b> pleasant <b>musical sound</b> on Shabbat, not the rasping sound of knocking on a door. <b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rabba from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>draw up</b> wine from a barrel <b>with a siphon [<i>diyofei</i>], and one</b> may <b>drip</b> water from a vessel that releases water in drops [<b><i>miarak</i></b>], <b>for an ill</b> person <b>on Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>For an ill</b> person, <b>yes,</b> this is permitted, but <b>for a healthy</b> person, <b>no,</b> one may not do so, <b>what are the circumstances?</b> Is it <b>not</b> the case <b>that he is dozing off and they wish to waken him,</b> and as they do not want to alarm him due to his illness, they do it by means of the sound of water poured from a vessel? <b>And</b> one can <b>learn from here</b> that <b>it is prohibited to produce a sound</b> on Shabbat, even one that is unpleasant, as the Sages permitted this only for an ill person.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>No,</b> it is referring to an ill person <b>who is awake and whom they want to have fall asleep,</b> and to this end they let water fall in drops, producing <b>a sound that is heard as melodious.</b>
Abaye <b>raised</b> another <b>objection to</b> Rabba from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who is guarding his produce from birds or his gourds from beasts</b> may <b>guard</b> them, <b>in</b> the <b>manner</b> that <b>he</b> typically does so, <b>on Shabbat,</b> as his guarding does not entail a prohibited labor, <b>provided that he neither claps, nor slaps</b> his hands against his body, <b>nor dances</b> and produces noise with his feet, <b>in the manner that is performed on weekdays</b> to chase away birds and animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that these activities are prohibited? Is it <b>not because he is producing a sound</b> on Shabbat, <b>and any production of a sound is prohibited? Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> This is not the reason. Rather, it is <b>a decree</b> issued by the Sages, <b>lest</b> while acting in his usual weekday fashion <b>he</b> mistakenly <b>picks up a pebble</b> to throw at the birds, thereby handling an object that is set-aside.
The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Women who play with nuts</b> by rolling them on the ground until they collide with each other, it is <b>prohibited</b> for them to do so; <b>what is the reason</b> for this prohibition? Is it <b>not because</b> knocking nuts together <b>produces a sound, and any production of a sound is prohibited?</b>
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>No,</b> it is prohibited because <b>perhaps they will come to level the holes.</b> As small holes in the ground will interfere with their game, they might level them out and seal them up on Shabbat, which is prohibited as building.
<b>For if you do not say</b> that <b>this</b> is the reason, there is a difficulty with <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda said: Women who play with apples,</b> this is <b>prohibited,</b> as <b>what production of a sound is involved there?</b> Apples do not produce a sound when they collide with each other. <b>Rather,</b> the reason is that <b>they will perhaps come to level holes,</b> and the same reasoning applies to nuts.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>draw water from the Cistern of the Exiles and from the Great Cistern by</b> means of <b>the wheel on Shabbat.</b> From this it can be inferred: <b>In the Temple, yes,</b> it is permitted to do so; but outside the Temple <b>in</b> the rest of <b>the country, no,</b> it is prohibited to draw water from cisterns. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not because he is producing a sound, and</b> that <b>is prohibited</b> on Shabbat?
The Gemara again rejects this contention: <b>No,</b> it is <b>a decree</b> issued by the Sages, <b>lest he draw</b> water <b>for his garden and for his ruin.</b> As the wheel draws up large quantities of water, once he starts to use it, he might draw water for his garden as well and thereby transgress the prohibition against watering on Shabbat, a subcategory of a prohibited labor.
The Gemara relates that <b>Ameimar permitted</b> people <b>to draw</b> water on Shabbat <b>by</b> means of <b>a wheel in Meḥoza,</b> as <b>he said: What is the reason the Sages decreed</b> that this is prohibited? They did so <b>lest one draw</b> water <b>for his garden and for his ruin.</b> However, <b>here</b> in Meḥoza <b>there are neither gardens nor ruins.</b> Meḥoza was entirely built up and lacked gardens or empty areas for sowing, and consequently, there was no concern that people might transgress.
However, <b>once he saw that</b>

Daf 104b

<b>they were soaking flax</b> in the water, <b>he prohibited them</b> from drawing water by means of a wheel, so that they should not draw water for prohibited purposes.
We learned in the mishna that water may be drawn on a Festival <b>from the Heker Well.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the Heker Well? Shmuel said:</b> It is <b>a cistern with regard to which they advanced</b> [<b><i>hikru</i></b>] <b>arguments and permitted</b> drawing water from <b>it</b> on a Festival, by proving that the Torah permits doing so.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They did not permit all Heker wells, but only this one. And if you say</b> it was named because it is a cistern <b>with regard to which they put forward arguments</b> and permitted it, <b>what is</b> the meaning of Heker wells in the plural, and what does <b>only this one</b> mean? If it was named because of a particular announcement, how could other wells, about which no announcement was issued, bear the same name?
<b>Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The term Heker well denotes <b>a well of living water, as it is stated: “As a well keeps its water fresh</b> [<b><i>hakir</i></b>], so she keeps fresh her wickedness” (Jeremiah 6:7), i.e., it is a well of spring water.
Returning to <b>the matter itself,</b> the Gemara cites the above <i>baraita</i> in full: <b>They did not permit all Heker wells, but only this one. And when the exiles ascended</b> from Babylonia, <b>they encamped by it, and the prophets among them,</b> Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi, <b>permitted</b> it <b>to them. And it was not</b> really <b>the prophets among them</b> who permitted them to draw water from this well on a Festival, <b>but</b> rather, it was <b>a customary practice</b> that was handed down <b>to them from their forefathers,</b> a practice the prophets permitted them to continue.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> of one of the eight species of reptile or rodent listed in Leviticus 11:29–30, one of the primary sources of ritual impurity <b>that is found in the Temple, a priest</b> should <b>carry it out</b> on Shabbat <b>in his girdle,</b> which was one of the priestly garments. Although the girdle will be defiled by the carcass of the creeping animal, this is the best way to proceed, <b>so as not to delay</b> the removal of <b>the impurity</b> from the Temple. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The creeping animal carcass should be removed <b>with wooden prongs, so as not to increase the impurity,</b> as a wooden prong is not susceptible to impurity.
It is obvious that on a weekday the creeping animal carcass is removed from wherever it is found in the Temple, but <b>from where does one remove it</b> on Shabbat? <b>From the Sanctuary, from the Entrance Hall, and from</b> the area in the courtyard <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar,</b> the most sanctified precincts of the Temple. However, it need not be removed from the rest of the courtyard. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: Any place where one is liable to</b> be punished with <b><i>karet</i></b> if he <b>intentionally</b> enters there in a state of ritual impurity, <b>and</b> is liable to bring a <b>sin-offering</b> if he does so <b>unwittingly, from there one</b> must <b>remove it.</b> This includes the entire area of the Temple courtyard. <b>And</b> as for <b>the rest of the places</b> in the Temple, <b>one covers</b> the creeping animal carcass <b>with a bowl [<i>pesakhter</i>]</b> and leaves it there until the conclusion of Shabbat.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that this is the principle: <b>Wherever the Sages permitted</b> something <b>to you, they granted you</b> only <b>from your own, as they permitted to you only</b> activities that are prohibited <b>due to rabbinic decree,</b> not labors prohibited by Torah law.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Tavi bar Kisna said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>one who brings into the Temple</b> an object that was <b>defiled by a creeping animal</b> carcass, <b>he is liable,</b> but if he brings in the carcass of <b>a creeping animal itself, he is exempt. What is the reason</b> for this distinction? <b>The verse said: “Both male and female shall you put out,</b> without the camp shall you put them; that they defile not their camp, in the midst whereof I dwell” (Numbers 5:3). This verse teaches that the obligation to send out of the camp applies only to <b>one who has</b> the option of <b>purification in a ritual bath,</b> i.e., the male and female mentioned by the Torah; this <b>excludes</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal, which has no purification.</b> Consequently, one who brings the carcass of a creeping animal into the Temple is exempt, as he did not transgress the Torah’s commandment to send away the impure.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that a <i>baraita</i> <b>supports him: “Both male and female shall you put out”;</b> this <b>excludes an earthenware vessel.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not because</b> an earthenware vessel <b>does not have purification in a ritual bath,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rav Tavi bar Kisna?
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>No,</b> the reason is that only <b>something that can become a primary source of ritual impurity,</b> i.e., a human being or a metal utensil, must be sent out of the camp. This <b>excludes an earthenware vessel, which cannot become a primary source of ritual impurity.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this issue, whether or not there is liability for bringing a creeping animal carcass into the Temple, is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as we learned in the mishna: With regard to <b>a creeping animal</b> carcass <b>that is found in the Temple, a priest</b> should <b>carry it out</b> on Shabbat <b>in his girdle, so as not to delay</b> the removal of <b>the impurity.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka. Rabbi Yehuda says: He</b> should <b>remove it with wooden prongs, so as not to increase the impurity.</b>
<b>What, isn’t it</b> the case <b>that this</b> is the matter with regard to which the two <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree: The one who said</b> we should <b>not delay</b> the removal of the impurity <b>maintains</b> that <b>one who brings a creeping animal</b> carcass <b>into the Temple is liable,</b> and therefore every effort must be made to remove it immediately. <b>And the one who said</b> we should <b>not increase impurity maintains</b> that <b>one who brings a creeping animal</b> carcass <b>into the Temple is exempt.</b> As no special command is in effect, the correct procedure is to prevent any additional impurity.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No, everyone agrees</b> that one who brings a creeping animal carcass itself into the Temple <b>is liable, and here, this</b> is the matter with regard to which <b>they disagree: The</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, <b>holds: Delaying</b> removal of the <b>impurity</b> is the consideration that <b>takes precedence.</b> Consequently, it is permitted even to defile the priestly garments to prevent any delay in the removal of the impurity from the holy place. <b>Whereas the</b> other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds: Increasing impurity</b> is the consideration that <b>takes precedence,</b> and therefore the impurity should be removed only by means of wooden prongs.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests that this issue is the subject of a dispute between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>, as we learned</b> in that same mishna: <b>From where does one remove</b> the creeping animal carcass? Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva disagree whether it is removed only from the Sanctuary, the Entrance Hall, and the area of the courtyard between the Entrance Hall and the altar, or from the entire area of the courtyard as well.
<b>Isn’t it</b> the case <b>that</b> the two <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree about the following: The one who said</b> we do <b>not</b> remove it <b>from the</b> Temple <b>courtyard maintains</b> that <b>one who brings a creeping animal</b> carcass <b>into the Temple is exempt,</b> and there is therefore no obligation to remove it from the courtyard on Shabbat. <b>And the one who said that</b> it must be removed <b>from the entire courtyard maintains</b> that one who brings a creeping animal carcass into the Temple <b>is liable.</b>

Daf 105a

<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Both</b> of them, Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva, <b>derived their opinions from the same verse: “And the priests went into the inner part of the House of God, to cleanse it, and they brought out all the impurity that they found in the Temple of God into the courtyard of the House of God. And the Levites took it, to carry it out to the brook of Kidron”</b> (II Chronicles 29:16).
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon Ben Nannas, <b>maintains: As there was a change</b> from the priests who removed the ritual impurity from the inner part of the Temple to <b>the Levites,</b> who took over <b>in the courtyard,</b> this indicates that <b>there is no</b> obligation to remove <b>impurity in the courtyard,</b> and consequently the priests are not required to do so.
<b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>maintains: Up to where it is impossible</b> for the task to be performed <b>by the Levites,</b> as it is prohibited for Levites to enter the Sanctuary, <b>the priests took it out.</b> However, <b>now</b> in the courtyard, <b>where it is possible</b> for the ritual impurity to be removed <b>by the Levites, the priests no longer render themselves ritually impure,</b> as they are prohibited from maintaining contact with ritual impurity for any longer than necessary. That is to say, the Levites removed it from any place where they were permitted to enter.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is permitted for <b>everyone</b> to <b>enter the Sanctuary to build, to repair, or to remove impurity</b> from inside. However, wherever possible, <b>the mitzva is</b> for these tasks to be performed <b>by priests. If no priests are available, Levites enter; if no Levites are available, Israelites enter. In both</b> cases, if <b>they are</b> ritually <b>pure, yes,</b> they may enter, but if <b>they are impure, no,</b> they may not enter the holy place.
<b>Rav Huna said: Rav Kahana,</b> who was a priest, <b>supports priests</b> by emphasizing their special sanctity. <b>As Rav Kahana taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Since it is stated</b> with regard to a priest who has a physical blemish, <b>“Only he shall not go in unto the veil,</b> nor come near to the altar, because he has a blemish, that he profane not My holy places; for I am the Lord who sanctifies them” (Leviticus 21:23), I <b>might</b> have thought that <b>priests with blemishes</b> may <b>not enter</b> the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar to manufacture beaten plates</b> of gold for the Holy of Holies.
Therefore, <b>the verse teaches “only”</b> as an expression of exclusion, which means that there is <b>a distinction</b> here: Although the <b>mitzva</b> should be performed with <b>unblemished</b> priests <i>ab initio</i>, <b>if no unblemished</b> priests <b>are available, blemished ones</b> may <b>enter.</b> Likewise, it is the duty of ritually <b>pure</b> priests; <b>if no pure</b> priests <b>are available, impure ones</b> may <b>enter. In both</b> cases, if they are <b>priests, yes,</b> they may enter, but if they are <b>Israelites, no,</b> they may not enter the holy place. According to Rav Kahana, ritually impure priests take precedence over ritually pure Israelites.
<b>A dilemma was raised</b> before the Sages: If one priest is ritually <b>impure and</b> another <b>has a blemish, which of them</b> should <b>enter</b> to perform repairs? <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b>impure one</b> should <b>enter, as he is permitted</b> to participate <b>in communal service.</b> If the entire community is ritually impure, even impure priests may perform the service, whereas blemished priests may not serve under any circumstances. <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The <b>one with the blemish</b> should <b>enter, as he is permitted to eat consecrated foods,</b> which indicates that he retains the sanctity of the priesthood despite his blemish. The Gemara leaves this question unresolved.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Wherever the Sages permitted an action to you, they granted you only from your own. The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>Rabbi Shimon, on the basis of what</b> mishna did he formulate this principle? The Gemara answers: He taught this principle <b>on the basis</b> of the mishna <b>there, as we learned:</b> With regard to <b>one</b> for <b>whom it grew dark</b> while he was <b>outside the</b> Shabbat <b>limit, even</b> if he was only <b>one cubit</b> outside the limit <b>he</b> may <b>not enter</b> the town. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even</b> if he was <b>fifteen cubits</b> outside the limit, <b>he</b> may <b>enter</b> the town, <b>because</b> when <b>the surveyors</b> mark the Shabbat limit, they <b>do not measure precisely.</b> Rather they position the boundary mark within the two-thousand-cubit limit, <b>because of those who err.</b>
With regard to <b>that which the first <i>tanna</i> said,</b> i.e., that <b>he</b> may <b>not enter, Rabbi Shimon said to</b> the <i>tanna</i>: <b>He</b> may <b>enter.</b> His reason, as stated, is that the limit does in fact extend that far, as any area the Sages granted to a person was actually permitted to him by Torah law.
Rabbi Shimon further said: <b>As they permitted to you only</b> activities prohibited <b>due to rabbinic decree,</b> but not actions prohibited by Torah law. The Gemara asks: <b>On the basis of what</b> teaching did he formulate this principle? The Gemara answers: He taught it <b>on the basis</b> of the mishna <b>there, where the first <i>tanna</i> said</b> with regard to a harp string in the Temple that broke on Shabbat, that <b>one</b> may <b>tie it</b> with a knot, <b>and Rabbi Shimon said: He</b> may <b>form</b> only <b>a bow.</b>
The reason why only <b>forming a bow</b> is permitted, is <b>that it cannot lead to liability for a sin-offering,</b> as forming a bow cannot constitute a violation of the category of the prohibited labor of tying. Consequently, <b>the Sages permitted it.</b> However, with regard to <b>tying</b> a knot, <b>which can lead to liability for a sin-offering</b> when performed outside the Temple, <b>the Sages did not permit it,</b> as Rabbi Shimon maintains that the Sages permitted only activities whose prohibition involves a rabbinic decree.
